After two stories about the 19-year-old<U+0089><U+06EA>s personal life appeared in tabloid and conservative media, voices from both ends of the political spectrum called for giving the young Obama her privacy. <U+0089><db><cf>Malia Obama should be allowed the same privacy as her school aged peers,<U+0089><U+06DD> Ivanka Trump tweeted on Friday. <U+0089><db><cf>She is a young adult and private citizen, and should be OFF limits.<U+0089><U+06DD> Chelsea Clinton, a persistent advocate for privacy when it comes to kids living in the White House, chimed in shortly afterward. <U+0089><db><cf>Malia Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s private life, as a young woman, a college student, a private citizen, should not be your clickbait,<U+0089><U+06DD> she wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>Be better.<U+0089><U+06DD> Since President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s family moved into the White House, Clinton has also been moved to call out media outlets that focus attention on Barron Trump ,<e5><ca>who is 11 years old. Leaked video published by the conservative site The Daily Caller and other outlets appeared to show Malia Obama smoking. Another video, published by TMZ along with still photos, showed her kissing someone during a tailgate party for the annual Harvard-Yale football game. Tabloids claim to have identified the young man as a student at Harvard, where Obama has just begun her freshman year after taking time off following high school. She has expressed interest in pursuing a career in the film industry. Noticing that Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s name was trending due to the gossip headlines,<e5><ca>people on social media reacted with pointed jokes about the media<U+0089><U+06EA>s choices and sober criticisms <U+0089><U+06E5> but mainly jokes.
Title.x: Ivanka Trump And Chelsea Clinton Come To Malia Obama's Defense Against The Tabloids
Title.y: Ivanka Trump And Chelsea Clinton Come To Malia Obama's Defense Against The Tabloids

text: Joe Biden is a man looking for his moment. Behind those famous aviators, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s surveying the landscape to see if 2020 might just be his year to fulfill his presidential dreams. Biden has already run for president twice. Although he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t run in 2016, he thinks he could have won that race. When Hillary Clinton lost, she was heavily criticized for not having a populist economic message that could have reached the working-class white voters who swung over to Donald Trump. Those voters are the speciality of the former vice president, who was born in the Rust Belt city of Scranton, Pennsylvania. When he represented Delaware in the U.S. Senate, Biden was known for taking Amtrak to and from Washington, just like the regular people. Biden is now wondering if 2020 may be his time. <U+0089><db><cf> I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not closing the door . I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve been around too long and I<U+0089><U+06EA>m a great respecter of fate, but who knows what the situation is going to be a year and a half from now,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said Tuesday. According to Politico, Biden has also privately been telling people that as of now, he doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t see anyone besides himself who could stop Trump from winning a second term. But 2020 may not be Biden<U+0089><U+06EA>s year. While he is better than many other Democrats at offering up economic populism, there are other rising movements for which he isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t well positioned to be the face of the party. Clinton lost. And with her defeat went many people<U+0089><U+06EA>s hope that the nation would finally have its first female president. Afterward, women <U+0089><U+06E5> some of whom had supported Clinton and some who did not <U+0089><U+06E5> launched a resistance movement to push back on Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s policies and get more politically engaged. Record numbers of women are now running for office. The movement has extended beyond politics. Men in entertainment, media, business and other areas are finally being held accountable for sexist behavior. From former Fox News host Bill O<U+0089><U+06EA>Reilly to producer Harvey Weinstein to comedian Louis C.K., men are losing their jobs after years of having sexually harassed or assaulted women with impunity. Biden is the wrong guy to bear the standard of any party purporting to speak for the victims of unaccountable power. In many ways, Anita Hill launched the movement against sexual harassment in 1991. Then a 35-year-old law professor, she publicly accused Supreme Court nominee Clarence Thomas of having sexually harassed her when she worked for him. She faced a Senate Judiciary Committee composed entirely of white men. Although the Senate went on to confirm Thomas anyway, women around the country were captivated by her testimony. For the first time on national television, a woman was describing what so many of them faced every day in their jobs. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve seen movements come and go. And some are quite powerful. I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve not seen something like this. And I<U+0089><U+06EA>m hoping that<e5><ca>[it will] bring lasting change,<U+0089><U+06DD> Hill told CNN last week on the progress that has been made since her testimony. Hill has previously said she doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe her allegations against Thomas received the consideration they deserved. There were other women who were ready to support her allegations, but they were never allowed to testify before the Judiciary Committee. The man who could have changed that was Biden, who served as chair of the committee in 1991. In the years since,<e5><ca>he has publicly presented himself as Hill<U+0089><U+06EA>s ally , but she made clear in an interview with HuffPost in 2014 that she believes the senator let her down. <U+0089><db><cf>There were three women who were ready and waiting and subpoenaed to be giving testimony about similar behavior that they had experienced or witnessed. He failed to call them ,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Hill said. <U+0089><db><cf>There also were experts who could have given real information as opposed to the misinformation that the Senate was giving ... and helped the public understand sexual harassment. He failed to call them.<U+0089><U+06DD> Biden told The New York Times two days before Hill was set to testify that he began by assuming that Thomas was innocent <U+0089><U+06E5> and, as it follows, by assuming that Hill was lying. <U+0089><db><cf>I must start off with a presumption of giving the person accused the benefit of the doubt ,<U+0089><U+06DD> Biden said. <U+0089><db><cf>I must seek the truth and I must ask straightforward and tough questions, and in my heart I know if that woman is telling the truth it will be almost unfair to her. On the other hand, if I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t ask legitimate questions, then I am doing a great injustice to someone who might be totally innocent. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a horrible dilemma because you have two lives at stake here.<U+0089><U+06DD> Since that time, Biden has built a long record of championing women<U+0089><U+06EA>s rights. As vice president, he sought to address the scourge of sexual assault on college campuses and fought to make the matter a priority in the Obama administration. But part of his record remains the way he treated Hill. And for that, he has never fully apologized. Instead, on Monday, he said he felt bad that Hill felt she had been mistreated <U+0089><U+06E5> but he still insisted he was her champion. <U+0089><db><cf>I feel really badly that she didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t feel like the process worked, but I tell you what, I said something at the time that proved to be right,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Biden said. <U+0089><db><cf>I said this is going to be the start of a fundamental change of what constitutes harassment in the workplace and people are going to begin to change.<U+0089><U+06DD> Biden was correct. But it was in large part because of the way Hill was treated and the way he handled the hearing that people started talking. Women saw Hill go up against the white men on the Senate Judiciary Committee <U+0089><U+06E5> who were either unsympathetic to what she had gone through or simply didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t come to her assistance <U+0089><U+06E5> and decided that they needed to change the face of Congress. In response, a record number of women ran for Congress in 1992. And two new female senators finally took seats on the Judiciary Committee <U+0089><U+06E5> but not without a misstep by Biden . After then-Rep. Barbara Boxer (D-Calif.) won her party<U+0089><U+06EA>s Senate primary, the chairman hand-delivered to her a dozen red roses with the note, <U+0089><db><cf> Welcome to the Senate Judiciary Committee .<U+0089><U+06DD> News reports at the time described the moment in highly gendered language <U+0089><U+06E5> that Biden had tried to <U+0089><db><cf>woo<U+0089><U+06DD> Boxer but was <U+0089><db><cf>scorned<U+0089><U+06DD> and that Biden had gone <U+0089><db><cf> courting <U+0089><U+06DD> while the new female senators played <U+0089><db><cf>hard to get.<U+0089><U+06DD> Boxer ultimately chose not to join the committee. Biden also continues to maintain <U+0089><U+06E5> as he did in his remarks Monday <U+0089><U+06E5> that he wanted the other women to testify on behalf of Hill. He claimed that they didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to do so and that they would have undercut Hill<U+0089><U+06EA>s testimony. That is not, however, the version of events that Hill and her legal team remember , as HuffPost has reported. They believe that Biden, like the other senators at the time, simply wanted to finish up Thomas<U+0089><U+06EA> confirmation hearing and move on <U+0089><U+06E5> even if it meant Hill would get the short end of the stick. Today, part of Biden<U+0089><U+06EA>s schtick is that he<U+0089><U+06EA>s Uncle Joe. He<U+0089><U+06EA>s the jovial guy who can go into a bar and connect with anyone there. During the Obama administration, his ability to glad-hand and connect with people in an entertaining way was on full display every two years when he greeted the new senators and their families as they were sworn in. He<U+0089><U+06EA>d schmooze and make jokes with little kids and elderly relatives alike. His behavior also had more patronizing undercurrents.<e5><ca>A big part of his act was remarking on the attractiveness of women, young and old. He would comment on how pretty young women were and warn their fathers to keep the guys away. Many people found this behavior charming.<e5><ca>He wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t stiff like some politicians. He grabbed people<U+0089><U+06EA>s hands, put his arm around them and even kissed people on the cheek. But it<U+0089><U+06EA>s clear some people were uncomfortable. The teenage daughter of Sen. Chris Coons (D-Del.), for example, visibly cringed and pulled away when Biden whispered in her ear and kissed her on the head. In 2015, when Biden put his arms on the wife of Defense Secretary Ash Carter at Carter<U+0089><U+06EA>s swearing-in ceremony, people noticed how uncomfortable the moment looked. There are plenty of other examples. New York Magazine even had a slideshow of them called <U+0089><db><cf> 9 Times Joe Biden Creepily Whispered in Women<U+0089><U+06EA>s Ears .<U+0089><U+06DD> In 2015, conservative columnist Byron York wrote about Biden<U+0089><U+06EA>s handsy ways,<e5><ca>questioning whether his gestures were appropriate . <U+0089><db><cf>Do the incidents add up to anything? Assume that all of Biden<U+0089><U+06EA>s gestures were entirely innocent, just Joe being Joe,<U+0089><U+06DD> York wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>Still, in today<U+0089><U+06EA>s society, sexual harassment complaints have been lodged for less. Biden<U+0089><U+06EA>s behavior gives critics plenty of ammunition and puts supporters in a difficult position. Why is that kind of stuff OK when the vice president does it and cringe-making when it<U+0089><U+06EA>s the overly-friendly guy in the office?<U+0089><U+06DD> Biden has clearly been a champion for women<U+0089><U+06EA>s rights in his policies. Even advocates who criticized his conduct during the Hill testimony say he is today one of their strongest allies . He has evolved <U+0089><U+06E5> but so have his party and the country. And the newly energized women under the Democratic tent may not want a relic from the pre-woke era to be their standard-bearer.
Title.x: Joe Biden 2020 Is A Terrible Idea In A Post-Weinstein America
Title.y: Joe Biden 2020 Is A Terrible Idea In A Post-Weinstein America

text: President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s interview with The New York Times generated plenty of headline-making comments .<e5><ca>But his remarks on health insurance, the biggest topic of the week, suggested he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know how it works or how much it costs. He said: <U+0089><db><cf>So pre-existing conditions are a tough deal. Because you are basically saying from the moment the insurance, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re 21 years old, you start working and you<U+0089><U+06EA>re paying $12 a year for insurance, and by the time you<U+0089><U+06EA>re 70, you get a nice plan.<U+0089><U+06DD> The notion of paying $12 a year for health insurance is even less than the $ 15 per month number Trump floated in an interview with the Economist earlier this year. <U+0089><db><cf>Insurance is, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re 20 years old, you just graduated from college, and you start paying $15 a month for the rest of your life and by the time you<U+0089><U+06EA>re 70, and you really need it, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re still paying the same amount and that<U+0089><U+06EA>s really insurance,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said in the May interview. The average premium for a single person who gets health benefits from an employer last year was $536 a month , with employees paying an average of 18 percent of the cost while employers pick up the rest, according to data from the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and the Health Research and Education Trust. Prices are different in the market for people who don<U+0089><U+06EA>t get health benefits from an employer or a government program <U+0089><U+06E5> including those who purchase policies directly, through a broker or a health insurance exchange. For consumers in this health insurance market, the average monthly unsubsidized premium a mid-level <U+0089><db><cf>Silver<U+0089><U+06DD> plan ranges from<e5><ca>$364.91 for a 30-year-old to<e5><ca>$872.01 for a 60-year-old, according to data compiled by HealthPocket. All of those numbers, of course, are significantly higher than either figure suggested by the president. This prompted a number of observers to wonder if Trump was confusing health insurance with the life insurance ads that air in heavy rotation on cable news. This article has been updated with additional data on average health insurance costs. Jeffrey Young contributed reporting.
Title.x: Trump Doesn't Seem To Know What Health Insurance Is, How It Works Or What It Costs
Title.y: Trump Doesn't Seem To Know What Health Insurance Is, How It Works Or What It Costs

text: Donald Trump loves fast food . The 45th president has no problem wolfing down a Quarter Pounder or digging his way through a bucket of KFC. <U+0089><U+06DD> Great stuff ,<U+0089><U+06DD> he once called the cheap, greasy fare. Six months into Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s presidency, the fast-food industry has plenty of reason to love him back. The oil and gas sector, coal producers and for-profit colleges are all clear winners in the Trump team<U+0089><U+06EA>s mission to deconstruct the administrative state . But so far, fast food, retail and other lower-wage industries have benefited as much as anyone from the administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s great regulatory rollback. Lobbyists for restaurants, hotels and other franchised businesses spent the last several years fighting the Obama administration on one regulation after another. But the new White House occupant has heard their grievances, making industry-friendly changes to employment laws and how they<U+0089><U+06EA>re enforced. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s included abandoning Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s overtime reforms, shying away from a minimum wage raise, and limiting who<U+0089><U+06EA>s considered an <U+0089><db><cf>employer<U+0089><U+06DD> under the law <U+0089><U+06E5> all of which have a disproportionate effect on lower-wage, labor-intensive fields like fast food. All told, the new administration has given McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s and its friends plenty to cheer about. <U+0089><db><cf>The early signs are that it can be more like night and day in terms of approach,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Matt Haller, senior vice president at the International Franchise Association, an industry group representing franchisers, including McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s. <U+0089><db><cf>We just want regulations that are fair and reasonable and very clear.<U+0089><U+06DD> The previous White House viewed regulation as a means to lift up workers at the bottom of the economic ladder, particularly folks doing low-paid service work like fast food and hospitality. Hence their push for a higher mandated wage floor, expanded overtime protections and aggressive enforcement of wage and hour laws. Like Obama, Trump speaks often of forgotten workers whose pay has stagnated, but so far his prescription for improving their lot mainly involves unfettering their employers. That shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t come as a surprise for a president who made his fortune in hotels and went on to nominate a burger chain executive to be the country<U+0089><U+06EA>s top workplace watchdog. (Andrew Puzder, the former CEO of Hardee<U+0089><U+06EA>s and Carl<U+0089><U+06EA>s Jr., ended up withdrawing his controversial nomination.) Still, the degree to which the administration is taking the reins off employers has distressed past officials who took a more aggressive tack. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s the combination of these policies that<U+0089><U+06EA>s deeply troubling,<U+0089><U+06DD> said David Weil, who led the Labor Department<U+0089><U+06EA>s Wage and Hour Division under Obama. <U+0089><db><cf>I see very little evidence that they are doing anything to address the needs of working people who have been left behind for a long time.<U+0089><U+06DD> While he was in office, Weil tried to steer the agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigations toward the industries where he saw the most vulnerable workers <U+0089><U+06E5> fast food, sit-down restaurants, hotels and motels, janitorial companies and so forth. A Labor Department spokesman said the agency under Trump still carries out what it calls <U+0089><db><cf>targeted enforcement<U+0089><U+06DD> programs. But pressed on whether they were targeting the same low-wage fields as before, the spokesman declined to say. Some of the changes under Trump have little practical impact, but speak volumes about the administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s peculiar form of populism. Employers in food and hospitality were apoplectic over the Obama administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s view on <U+0089><db><cf>joint employment<U+0089><U+06DD> : the idea that more than one entity might be responsible when a worker gets injured or shorted on pay. The Obama administration put companies on notice that they, too, could be responsible for abuses against workers who are technically employed by temp firms and contractors. Fast-food brands like McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s recoiled at the idea they might be as liable for workplace violations as the franchisees who operate McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s restaurants. After Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s second pick for labor secretary, Alexander Acosta, assumed office in April, one of the first steps the agency took was to rescind the guidance on joint employment issued under Obama. Speaking to a retail lobby last month, Vice President Mike Pence proudly noted the change , drawing applause. In another early move, the Labor Department brought back what are known as <U+0089><db><cf>opinion letters.<U+0089><U+06DD> When employers are sued for allegedly not paying overtime or the minimum wage, they can ask the Labor Department to pen one of these letters in their defense, to be used in court. Weil likens them to a <U+0089><db><cf>get-out-of-jail-free card<U+0089><U+06DD> for employers, and the Obama administration did not issue them. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Labor Department, however, has trumpeted their return . Trump also rescinded an executive order from Obama that would have made it harder for firms to secure federal contracts if they have a documented history of wage theft. Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s order was the result of a campaign by fast-food workers who had been shorted on their pay while working on federal properties. (Two other orders from Obama <U+0089><U+06E5> one raising the minimum wage for federal contractors and another mandating sick leave for them<e5><U+0289><U+06E5> have so far survived this administration.) Other changes on the employment front are far more significant. The Obama administration tried to reform the nation<U+0089><U+06EA>s overtime rules and guarantee more workers time and a half pay when they work more than 40 hours in a week. The share of salaried employees who are protected by overtime law has dropped off a cliff since the 1970s. The changes the Obama administration made would have extended overtime rights to 4 million additional workers, according to the previous White House. After business groups sued to stop Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s plan, the Trump White House declined to defend it . The new administration seems to share the view of business groups that Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s proposal covered too many workers and was too costly for employers. If Trump takes his own crack at overtime reform, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s likely he<U+0089><U+06EA>ll make far fewer workers eligible for time and a half pay. Many of the people Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s reforms aimed to help work in food and retail jobs, earning relatively low salaries while clocking long days. A group of Chipotle workers recently sued the burrito chain for backpay, arguing Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s overtime changes should still apply even though the rule is now in legal limbo. The case hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t yet been decided. As with the overtime expansion, this White House has abandoned the push for a higher minimum wage made by Obama. The idea of hiking the minimum wage tends to poll well across party lines; although he flip-flopped on the issue as a candidate, Trump once said he would like to raise it to <U+0089><db><cf>at least $10.<U+0089><U+06DD> But so far as president, he seems intent to leave such matters to the market. The federal minimum wage, which prevails in any state without a higher one, is currently $7.25 per hour and hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t been raised in eight years. Beyond the major policy shifts, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s effect on low-wage work will be felt in less obvious ways. He recently made two nominations to the five-member National Labor Relations Board, which interprets collective bargaining law and referees disputes between employers and unions. His conservative choices <U+0089><U+06E5> one is a management-side attorney, the other a former GOP staffer who served on the House labor committee <U+0089><U+06E5> would end the current liberal majority and push the board to the right. (One of them has already been confirmed.) If history is any indication, the Republican board would likely reverse some union-friendly rulings and draw tighter boundaries around who<U+0089><U+06EA>s eligible to unionize. Celine McNicholas, a labor policy expert at the left-leaning Economic Policy Institute, said the board is one way Trump could chip away at what she considered modest gains made for lower-income workers during the Obama years. <U+0089><db><cf>These potential setbacks are going to prove to be incredibly damaging, particularly for folks who are low-wage workers,<U+0089><U+06DD> McNicholas said. <U+0089><db><cf>They are certainly losers under the Trump administration.<U+0089><U+06DD> One potential beneficiary of the new board is McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s. The fast-food giant recently went to trial before an administrative law judge at the labor board to determine whether it counts as a joint employer alongside its franchisees; McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s could be held jointly responsible for violating workers<U+0089><U+06EA> rights. In general, a conservative labor board would be more likely to side with employers in such contentious cases. The board<U+0089><U+06EA>s general counsel, Richard Griffin, who functions as a quasi-prosecutor, brought the case against McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s on behalf of workers who claimed they<U+0089><U+06EA>d been illegally retaliated against for their activism in the Fight for $15 protests. A former union lawyer, Griffin assumed the post in 2013 and has been a thorn in the side of not just McDonald<U+0089><U+06EA>s but also Walmart and other employers he<U+0089><U+06EA>s taken to trial. His aggressive tenure has so infuriated business groups that some Republicans have demanded that he step down. But at this point, that would no longer be necessary. Griffin<U+0089><U+06EA>s four-year term expires in November. It will be up to Trump to choose his replacement.
Title.x: Donald Trump Is The Fast-Food President
Title.y: Donald Trump Is The Fast-Food President

text: It<U+0089><U+06EA>s safe to say Robin Roberts isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t too upset about Omarosa Manigault Newman<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure from the White House. Roberts,<e5><ca>co-host of ABC<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>Good Morning America,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>had two sassy parting words for Newman, the controversial reality TV star who just left her position in President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s White House: <U+0089><db><cf>Bye, Felicia.<U+0089><U+06DD> Newman appeared on <U+0089><db><cf>Good Morning America<U+0089><U+06DD> Thursday to deny reports that White House Chief of Staff John Kelly fired her from her job as director of communications for the Public Liaison Office. Newman said during the interview that she had <U+0089><db><cf>seen things<U+0089><U+06DD> during her time in the White House that made her <U+0089><db><cf>uncomfortable<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>deeply<U+0089><U+06DD> affected her. She said she hoped to tell her <U+0089><db><cf>profound story<U+0089><U+06DD> when the time was right. Roberts squeezed in a dig at Newman before moving on to the next headline, suggesting the <U+0089><db><cf>Apprentice<U+0089><U+06DD> star would try to capitalize on her short-lived and controversial White House experience. <U+0089><db><cf>She said she has a story to tell,<U+0089><U+06DD> Roberts said. <U+0089><db><cf>And I<U+0089><U+06EA>m sure she<U+0089><U+06EA>ll be selling that story. ... Bye, Felicia.<U+0089><U+06DD> Newman fired back hours later, reportedly telling <U+0089><db><cf>Inside Edition<U+0089><U+06DD> via text message that Roberts comments were <U+0089><db><cf>petty<U+0089><U+06DD> and part of <U+0089><db><cf>a black woman civil war.<U+0089><U+06DD> In the meantime, Twitter lit up with love for Roberts<U+0089><U+06EA> diss. This article has been updated with Newman<U+0089><U+06EA>s response.
Title.x: Robin Roberts Literally Says 'Bye Felicia' To Omarosa Manigault Newman
Title.y: Robin Roberts Literally Says 'Bye Felicia' To Omarosa Manigault Newman

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> Texas Republicans, long accustomed to bashing the federal government, are already changing their tune now that Hurricane Harvey has devastated parts of their state. An emergency aid package hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t surfaced yet, but Congress almost certainly will have to approve a spending bill to help those affected by the hurricane-force winds and widespread flooding in southeastern Texas. The question is whether that money will be offset by cuts to other government programs, whether extraneous spending will be attached to the package, and whether, under any circumstances, Texas Republicans will have a problem voting for it. Money to help those in need from a lawmaker<U+0089><U+06EA>s homestate isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t a particularly tough vote. At this point, no Texas Republican has declared any sort of condition for their support of an emergency aid package. But when it was New York and New Jersey hit hard by Hurricane Sandy in 2012, all but one Texas Republican in Congress <U+0089><U+06E5> Rep. John Culberson <U+0089><U+06E5> voted against a $50.5 billion package to help people in those states. That was no surprise. The Texas delegation tends to speak with one voice , and there<U+0089><U+06EA>s little political repercussions for its members to vote against government largesse for another state. Many Republicans at the time said they took issue with unrelated spending that was attached to the Sandy bill, though most of the funding was directed at helping the storm<U+0089><U+06EA>s victims. And even some of the most derided provisions <U+0089><U+06E5> like $2 million to repair Smithsonian roofs in Washington <U+0089><U+06E5> were, in fact, related to that storm (it brought heavy wind and rain to that nation<U+0089><U+06EA>s capital, as well.) Overall, according to an analysis of the legislation compiled by CQ, the Sandy aid bill included $16 billion for community development programs, $11.5 billion for FEMA<U+0089><U+06EA>s disaster relief fund, $10.9 billion for transportation system repairs, $5.4 billion for Army Corps of Engineers projects, $800 million for social service programs, and $826 million for repairs to national parks and facilities. But Texas Republicans latched onto the notion that the Sandy relief package was full of wasteful spending. When the Senate was voting on the bill in early 2013, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) railed against the <U+0089><db><cf>unrelated spending, including projects such as Smithsonian repairs, upgrades to National Oceanic and Atmospheric airplanes, and more funding for Head Start.<U+0089><U+06DD> Again, the Smithsonian repairs <U+0089><U+06E5> representing .004 percent of the money appropriated <U+0089><U+06E5> were related to Sandy, and the upgrades and repairs to NOAA aircraft were to help with future hurricane forecasting. The money for Head Start, meanwhile, was available only to those facilities damaged by Sandy. On Monday, when Cruz was asked about voting against Sandy aid in 2013 but now openly seeking help for his state, he said there would be time for <U+0089><db><cf>political sniping<U+0089><U+06DD> later. <U+0089><db><cf>The problem with that particular bill,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz said of the Sandy package on MSNBC, <U+0089><db><cf>is it became a $50 billion bill that was filled with unrelated pork. Two-thirds of that bill had nothing to do with Sandy, and what I said then and still believe now is that it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not right for politicians to exploit a disaster and people hurting to pay for their own political wishlist.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz seems to be referring to the fact that only $17 billion of the package was for immediate relief and recovery needs, while other spending was for longer-term projects. Notwithstanding Cruz<U+0089><U+06EA>s call for a moratorium on <U+0089><db><cf>political sniping,<U+0089><U+06DD> s ome New York and New Jersey Republicans couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t help but take a few shots at the Texas delegation on Monday, even as they affirmed that they would support those people in need. Rep. Peter King, whose district encompasses parts of Long Island, tweeted that he wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t <U+0089><db><cf>abandon Texas the way Ted Cruz did New York;<U+0089><U+06DD> New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie called the Texas lawmakers <U+0089><db><cf> hypocrites ; <U+0089><U+06DD> and Rep. Frank LoBiondo of the Garden State tweeted that d espite the stance of his Texas colleagues on the Sandy relief package, he would support emergency money for their constituents. Overall, 23 of the 24 Texas Republicans then in the House voted against the Sandy package. And joining Cruz in opposing it was the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s other senator, John Cornyn (who<U+0089><U+06EA>s now that chamber<U+0089><U+06EA>s majority whip). HuffPost reached out Monday morning to the offices of the 20 Texas Republicans still in the House, as well as staff members for Cruz and Cornyn, with questions that included whether they thought emergency aid for their state ought to be offset with spending cuts elsewhere and whether they could commit to backing the storm-related funding even if it is not offset and the bill contains some extraneous spending provisions. As of late Monday afternoon, only House Rules Chairman Pete Sessions<U+0089><U+06EA> staff responded and <U+0089><U+06E5> no shocker here <U+0089><U+06E5> the lawmaker has no reservations about supporting aid for Texas. With President Donald Trump already touting his administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to Hurricane Harvey, members of his team also find themselves facing a course reversal from their previous political principles. Vice President Mike Pence, for instance, as a House member from Indiana led the conservative call to offset emergency spending in 2005 when Hurricane Katrina hammered Louisiana and Mississippi. Pence said Monday he expected Congress to make resources available for Texas, with no mention of strings attached. Office of Management and Budget director Mick Mulvaney <U+0089><U+06E5> who as a House member from South Carolina pushed for offsets to the Sandy bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s spending and voted against the package <U+0089><U+06E5> now will be in charge of putting together the administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s emergency request for Texas. Hardly anyone expects Mulvaney to insist that those emergency dollars be paid for with cuts elsewhere. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s possible that the package just gets attached to an upcoming bill to keep the government operating past Sept. 30. In that case, a number of Republicans <U+0089><U+06E5> including House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.), who opposed the Sandy bill <U+0089><U+06E5> could be spared from the political hypocrisy of supporting aid now. After all, they could explain their <U+0089><db><cf>yes<U+0089><U+06DD> vote by simply focusing on the need to keep the government open. And they<U+0089><U+06EA>ll be able to decide if supporting aid for the next natural disaster fits with their political agenda without worry that someone might throw this vote back in their face. CORRECTION : A previous version of this story incorrectly stated that the money to repair roof damage to Smithsonian museums included in the Hurricane Sandy aid bill represented .00004 percent of the legislation<U+0089><U+06EA>s total. The correct figure is .004 percent.
Title.x: Hurricane Harvey And The Potential Hypocrisy Of Texas Republicans
Title.y: Hurricane Harvey And The Potential Hypocrisy Of Texas Republicans

text: Either Apollo 11 astronaut Buzz Aldrin had a bad meal or he was as confused as we were about President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments on space and security Friday in the Oval Office. The astronaut was at Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s side as the president announced a new executive order reestablishing the National Space Council <U+0089><db><d3> 24 years after it was last active<e5><U+0289><db><d3> to direct space policy in his administration. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s remarks began with the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s usual boasting: <U+0089><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to lead again like we never led before .<U+0089><U+06DD> But he then appeared to claim all of space for the U.S., calling it the <U+0089><db><cf>next great American frontier.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also referred to space <U+0089><db><cf>providing the security that we need to protect the American people.<U+0089><U+06DD> And he sent Aldrin<U+0089><U+06EA>s eyebrows shooting up when he added, inexplicably, <U+0089><db><cf>At some point in the future, we<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to look back and say, <U+0089><db><f7>How did we do it without space?<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>We know what this is, space. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s all it has to say: space,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said as he prepared to sign his executive order. He then turned to Aldrin and asked, <U+0089><db><cf>There<U+0089><U+06EA>s a lot of room out there, right?<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>To infinity, and beyond,<U+0089><U+06DD> Aldrin quipped as others laughed. But Trump apparently didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t get the reference to Buzz Lightyear<U+0089><U+06EA>s catchphrase in <U+0089><db><cf>Toy Story.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This is infinity here. It could be infinity,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump answered in a rambling response. <U+0089><db><cf>We don<U+0089><U+06EA>t really don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know. But it could be. It has to be something <U+0089><db><d3> but it could be infinity, right?<U+0089><U+06DD> Besides Aldrin, three other astronauts also joined the president in the Oval Office for the ceremony. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence, however, only introduced the men <U+0089><db><d3> Aldrin, former astronaut David Wolf and current astronaut Benjamin Alvin Drew<U+0089><db><d3> and failed to mention the lone female astronaut on the scene, Sandy Magnus, The Washington Post reported. Magnus is currently the executive director of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. Pence will head the new space council, despite trying in vain in 2005 to shut down NASA<U+0089><U+06EA>s space exploration plans. The council will also include members of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Cabinet and representatives from NASA. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s still awaiting a new head of NASA, whom Trump hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t yet named. The executive order also creates a <U+0089><db><cf>users<U+0089><U+06EA> advisory group<U+0089><U+06DD> to <U+0089><db><cf>ensure that the interests of industries and other non-Federal entities involved in space activities, including in particular commercial entities, are adequately represented<U+0089><U+06DD> in the council. Aldrin hailed the move to reestablish the space council on his Twitter account, linking to the vice president<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments, not Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s.
Title.x: Buzz Aldrin Looked As Baffled As We Felt During Trump's Space Talk
Title.y: Buzz Aldrin Looked As Baffled As We Felt During Trump's Space Talk

text: Roy Moore , the Republican candidate for U.S. Senate from Alabama ,<e5><ca>fired off a tweet on Tuesday evening bragging about his <U+0089><db><cf>Alabama values.<U+0089><U+06DD> His critics had plenty to say about those values given that Moore has been accused of sexual misconduct by multiple women, including some who say their encounters took place when they were teenagers .
Title.x: Roy Moore's Boast About His 'Alabama Values' Did Not Go Well
Title.y: Roy Moore's Boast About His 'Alabama Values' Did Not Go Well

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> Federally insured property in Florida is in the crosshairs of potentially catastrophic Hurricane Irma <U+0089><U+06E5> including President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach. The property has a flood insurance policy through the National Flood Insurance Program , a Federal Emergency Management Agency spokesperson told HuffPost. The program provides affordable insurance in flood-prone zones where private insurers have traditionally refused to insure properties because they<U+0089><U+06EA>re so vulnerable. The Mar-a-Lago club<U+0089><U+06EA>s policy, which is insured to the Trump Organization and Donald J. Trump Revocable Trust, is not subsidized and is classified at a full-risk rate for the applicable flood zone, the FEMA spokesperson said. A property covered at the <U+0089><db><cf>full-risk<U+0089><U+06DD> rate means that its owner is paying a rate that reflects the full risk of flooding up to a certain coverage amount . Older properties can be <U+0089><db><cf>subsidized,<U+0089><U+06DD> meaning their rates do not necessarily reflect the full risk for those properties. The 1968-era National Flood Insurance Program, or NFIP, offers a mix of rates. The insurance program<U+0089><U+06EA>s authorization was set to expire at the end of this month, but Trump signed legislation on Friday that temporarily extends it . NFIP as a whole has been criticized for not charging enough to cover the expected costs of liabilities . It also consistently does not bring in enough money to pay out the properties it insures, and owes around $25 billion to the U.S. Treasury. Based on policies that went into effect on Aug.<e5><ca>31, 2016, the program is projected to have a one-year shortfall of $1.4 billion, according to a Congressional Budget Office report published this month. Some critics say the program benefits affluent people who live on beachfront property , essentially allowing them to live in places that are at a high risk of being damaged. <U+0089><db><cf>If [NFIP] was a regular insurance company, they would have been in receivership,<U+0089><U+06DD> Burl Daniel, an insurance expert witness from Texas, told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>But it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a political football because of the people who live on the coast.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>The program was already in trouble<U+0089><U+06DD> before Hurricanes Harvey and Irma began approaching the U.S., said Karen O<U+0089><U+06EA>Neill, an associate professor at Rutgers University who studies how policies about land and water affect government power. <U+0089><db><cf>It became super in trouble after Katrina, and Sandy was another blow,<U+0089><U+06DD> O<U+0089><U+06EA>Neill said. Mar-a-Lago, Trump International Golf Club in Palm Beach and Trump National Golf Club in Jupiter are all closed in advance of Irma, a Trump Organization spokesperson said. (She did not respond to the question about insurance.) Irma, one of the largest storms ever recorded , is expected to hit Florida this weekend. Mar-a-Lago has weathered hurricanes before. According to a n Associated Press investigation , Trump claimed that he received a $17 million insurance payout for the estate in 2005 due to damage from a series of storms, but said he pocketed some of the money instead of using it to rebuild. Trump once boasted in a deposition that he had a <U+0089><db><cf> very good insurance policy , <U+0089><U+06DD> apparently in reference to private insurance. ( The FEMA spokesperson declined to comment on whether Mar-a-Lago was also insured by NFIP at the time, as that is <U+0089><db><cf>not publicly available information.<U+0089><U+06DD>) Mar-a-Lago, which Trump bought for $10 million in 1985 , could see its main buildings damaged by an 8-foot storm surge, according to the AP. Thirty years from now, the property could be under at least a foot of water for most of the year, according to a risk analysis prepared for the Guardian . A group of Democratic lawmakers introduced a bill in June that specifically aimed to block Trump properties from receiving any federal subsidy for flood insurance coverage. The name of the bill <U+0089><U+06E5> the Prohibiting Aid for Recipients Ignoring Science , or Paris, Act <U+0089><U+06E5> riffs off the Paris climate accord , an agreement from which Trump withdrew that same month. As FEMA noted,<e5><ca>the NFIP policy for Mar-a-Lago isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t explicitly subsidized. (HuffPost did not ask the agency about policy details for other Trump-owned properties in Florida.) But Democrats say the Paris Act, which is not expected to pass anytime soon, is about the larger principle. <U+0089><db><cf>It would be outrageous for somebody who is denying the reality of climate, who is undercutting our ability to minimize the effects, to then turn around and be a recipient of federal largess,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.), who introduced the House bill. <U+0089><db><cf>We need to stop building in places where nature shows repeatedly that they<U+0089><U+06EA>re not wanted,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added. <U+0089><db><cf>We need to stop making it worse, and we need to put in place programs to try and minimize damage.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Mar-A-Lago Has A Flood Insurance Policy Through The Federal Government
Title.y: Mar-A-Lago Has A Flood Insurance Policy Through The Federal Government

text: A Florida congresswoman described President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s phone call to the widow of a soldier killed during an ambush in Niger as <U+0089><db><cf>insensitive<U+0089><U+06DD> after the president reportedly said the man <U+0089><db><cf>must<U+0089><U+06EA>ve known what he signed up for.<U+0089><U+06DD> Rep. Frederica Wilson (D-Fla.) was in a car with Myeshia Johnson, the pregnant widow of Army Sgt. La David Johnson, when Trump called her Tuesday and spoke for about five minutes, according to South Florida<U+0089><U+06EA>s NBC affiliate. Wilson said she heard the conversation on speakerphone. <U+0089><db><cf>Sarcastically he said: <U+0089><db><f7>But you know he must have known what he signed up for,<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Wilson recounted to NBC6. <U+0089><db><cf>How could you say that to a grieving widow? I couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe... and he said it more than once. I said this man has no feelings for anyone. This is a young woman with child who is grieved to her soul.<U+0089><U+06DD> Wilson, speaking to CNN, said her community was angry about the comments and described Johnson as a local hero. <U+0089><db><cf>We don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have many heroes in our young men in Miami-Dade County, but he was a hero for us,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>the congresswoman told host Don Lemon. When asked what her immediate reaction was, she said: <U+0089><db><cf>I asked them to give me the phone, because I wanted to speak with him. And I was going to curse him out. That was my reaction... I was livid.<U+0089><U+06DD> The White House declined to comment on the account in statements given to The Washington Post and an ABC affiliate. <U+0089><db><cf>The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s conversations with the families of American heroes who have made the ultimate sacrifice are private,<U+0089><U+06DD> an unnamed official said in the statement. Four Green Berets were killed in an ambush in Niger earlier this month, and two others were wounded. Following a question about why he hadn<U+0089><U+06EA>t spoken about their deaths publicly or called troops<U+0089><U+06EA> families, Trump said Monday that he had written personal letters and that he planned to call later. He then used the opportunity to falsely assert that his predecessors <U+0089><db><cf> didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t make calls <U+0089><U+06DD> themselves. Former President Barack Obama frequently called the families of soldiers killed in action and visited those wounded during his administration. President George W. Bush visited troops at the Walter Reed medical center 16 times before he left office. White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders confirmed on Twitter late Tuesday that Trump had called all four families of those killed, saying he offered <U+0089><db><cf>condolences on behalf of the country.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump returned to the subject Tuesday, using the death of Chief of Staff John Kelly<U+0089><U+06EA>s son in 2010 to illustrate Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s record on calling bereaved families, saying his predecessor did not call in that instance. Obama invited Kelly and his wife, Karen, to a breakfast in 2011 for Gold Star families who have lost children in combat. They were seated at a table with first lady Michelle Obama . Wilson on Tuesday described Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s call as <U+0089><db><cf> insensitive <U+0089><U+06DD> in an interview to a local ABC affiliate. She was with Myeshia Johnson and her two children, ages 2 and 6, as she watched the casket carrying her husband arrive at Miami International Airport. <U+0089><db><cf>He should have not have said that,<U+0089><U+06DD> Wilson told ABC 10, before repeating, <U+0089><db><cf>He shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have said it.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Trump Told Army Widow Her Husband Knew 'What He Signed Up For,' Congresswoman Says
Title.y: Trump Told Army Widow Her Husband Knew 'What He Signed Up For,' Congresswoman Says

text: Former Department of Justice officials and voting advocates are seriously alarmed over a DOJ letter sent to states last week that they say could signal a forthcoming effort to kick people off voter rolls. This comes as national attention focuses on several states blocking a request for voter information from President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s commission to investigate voting fraud, which does occur, but is not a widespread problem . The DOJ sent the letter to 44 states last Wednesday, the same day the Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity sent a letter controversially requesting personal voter information . The DOJ letter requests that election officials respond by detailing their compliance with a section of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 (NVRA), which covers 44 states and was enacted to help people register to vote, but also specifies when voters may be kicked off the rolls. Several experts said it<U+0089><U+06EA>s difficult not to see the DOJ letter in connection with the commission<U+0089><U+06EA>s letter as part of a multipronged effort to restrict voting rights. Former Justice Department officials say that while there<U+0089><U+06EA>s nothing notable about seeking information about compliance with the NVRA, it is unusual for the department to send out such a broad inquiry to so many states seeking information. Such a wide probe could signal the department is broadly fishing for cases of non-compliance to bring suits aimed at purging the voter rolls. <U+0089><db><cf>These two letters, sent on the same day, are highly suspect, and seem to confirm that the Trump administration is laying the groundwork to suppress the right to vote,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Vanita Gupta, the CEO of the Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights and former head of DOJ<U+0089><U+06EA>s civil rights division under President Barack Obama. <U+0089><db><cf>It is not normal for the Department of Justice to ask for voting data from all states covered by the National Voter Registration Act. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s likely that this is instead the beginning of an effort to force unwarranted voter purges.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>If this went to any individual states, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t think anybody would<U+0089><U+06EA>ve blinked twice,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Justin Levitt, a professor at Loyola Law School who served as deputy assistant attorney general in the civil rights division in the Obama administration. The letter asked for public information that was uncontroversial, he added, but what made the letter <U+0089><db><cf>really weird<U+0089><U+06DD> was that it was sent out to so many states. <U+0089><db><cf>The Department of Justice does investigations all the time, but those are usually based on individualized predicates to believe that there<U+0089><U+06EA>s a problem in a given area, in a given jurisdiction. And I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not aware of a similar letter being sent to blanket jurisdictions across the country,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. The NVRA requires states to <U+0089><db><cf>conduct a general program that makes a reasonable effort to remove the names of ineligible voters from the official lists.<U+0089><U+06DD> If a state wants to act to remove a voter from its rolls, it must first send a broad, nondiscriminatory solicitation seeking a confirmation of address to those registered. If a person fails to respond, they can only be removed from the rolls if they don<U+0089><U+06EA>t vote in the next two consecutive federal elections. In the past, voting rights groups have used the legislation as a powerful tool to try to prevent states from kicking eligible voters off their rolls. The Supreme Court will consider a case next term dealing with whether a voter removal process used in Ohio is violating the NVRA. The DOJ letter asks the states covered by the NVRA to provide information on the processes they use to remove people from the voting lists and the people authorized to implement them. It also asks for data from recent years on the number of voters removed from the voting rolls and the reasons they were removed. <U+0089><db><cf>When you see DOJ send a bunch of letters like this requesting information about compliance with the law, that<U+0089><U+06EA>s usually a sign that they<U+0089><U+06EA>re kicking an enforcement campaign into gear,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sam Bagenstos, who served as the principal deputy assistant attorney general for civil rights from 2009 until 2011. <U+0089><db><cf>It looks like what they<U+0089><U+06EA>re doing is they<U+0089><U+06EA>re laying the groundwork to file lawsuits against states that, in their view, aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t kicking enough people off of the rolls.<U+0089><U+06DD> Devin O<U+0089><U+06EA>Malley, a Justice Department spokesman, said the department<U+0089><U+06EA>s review of list maintenance procedures hadn<U+0089><U+06EA>t been done in many years. <U+0089><db><cf>The Department of Justice is committed to free and fair elections for all Americans. Congress enacted the NVRA<U+0089><U+06EA>s list-maintenance provisions specifically to advance that goal. The Department had not conducted a review of state and local list-maintenance activities under the NVRA for many years,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>The Department looks forward to working with state and local election officials to facilitate appropriate list-maintenance activities toward our common goal of free and fair elections for all voters.<U+0089><U+06DD> A DOJ official also said the department had not coordinated with the separate election integrity commission. But Bagenstos said he was skeptical the two efforts weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t related and were part of a multifaceted approach by the Trump administration to make voting more difficult. <U+0089><db><cf>What an amazing coincidence that these letters went out on the same day. This administration is, without even knowing it, doing parallel efforts to try to trim the voting roll. I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t buy it,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. He added that the voter fraud commission led by Vice President Mike Pence and Kansas Secretary of State Kris Kobach was trying to create a nationwide database of voter registration that would paint a picture of potential voter fraud that could then be used to justify more restrictive voting laws. David Becker, the executive director of the Center for Election Innovation and a former DOJ lawyer, agrees. <U+0089><db><cf>In the quarter-century since passage of the NVRA, of which I spent seven years as a DOJ lawyer enforcing the NVRA, among other laws, I do not know of the DOJ conducting any other broad-based fishing expedition into list maintenance compliance, whether during Democratic or Republican administrations,<U+0089><U+06DD> he wrote in a Thursday op-ed . Becker also noted it was strange the DOJ letter only focused on voter list maintenance procedures and did not want to examine compliance with parts of the law aimed at making it easier to vote. Allegra Chapman, director of voting and elections at nonprofit group Common Cause, said she found it striking the DOJ was uninterested in the aspect of the law that provided voter registration opportunities at public assistance agencies. <U+0089><db><cf>To me, that indicates this agency just has zero interest in ensuring the rights of poor Americans too and ensuring that, you know, people across the income divide are equally being given the registration services that they<U+0089><U+06EA>re entitled to under federal law,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said in an interview. While Bagenstos said he was alarmed by both the Kobach and DOJ requests, he believed the department could be a much more potent tool in curbing access to the ballot box. <U+0089><db><cf>On Kris Kobach<U+0089><U+06EA>s work on this commission, they<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to get a lot of pushback, they<U+0089><U+06EA>ve already gotten some pushback from states. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s all been sort of ham-handed,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>They don<U+0089><U+06EA>t really have staff, so that<U+0089><U+06EA>s all really amateurish and it might not go anywhere. But the folks at DOJ know what they<U+0089><U+06EA>re doing and I really worry that at the end of the day there<U+0089><U+06EA>s gonna be a lot of noise about this Kobach-Pence commission and people will miss the enforcement efforts of DOJ.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>DOJ, at the end of the day, is more likely to be successful as a tool in this process than is this commission, so that<U+0089><U+06EA>s why I worry more about them,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. Read the DOJ letter below:
Title.x: This DOJ Letter May Be More Alarming Than Trump Commission's Request For Voter Data
Title.y: This DOJ Letter May Be More Alarming Than Trump Commission's Request For Voter Data

text: Steve Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s eyes lit up. Several months before he left his job as a senior White House adviser last August, Bannon was talking to President Trump about the brewing political storm over the Justice Department investigation into his campaign<U+0089><U+06EA>s alleged ties to the Kremlin. Suddenly, Trump had an inspiration.<e5><ca>He looked straight at Bannon,<e5><ca>jabbed at him with his finger and uttered the phrase that would become the slogan of the White House pushback against the Russia probe: <U+0089><db><cf>Witch hunt!<U+0089><U+06DD> Brilliant,<e5><ca>thought Bannon, as he later related the exchange to colleagues. Ever since, it is a phrase Trump has returned to time and again <U+0089><db><d3> and repackaged with typical Trumpian hyperbole. <U+0089><db><cf>This is the single greatest witch hunt of a politician in American history!<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump tweeted last May after ex-FBI director Robert Mueller was appointed as Justice Department special counsel to oversee the probe. But now, as Trump prepares to end his first year in office, the witch hunt narrative may have outlived its usefulness. Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation has expanded and gained serious traction: The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s former campaign manager, Paul Manafort, and Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s chief deputy, Rick Gates, have been indicted. His former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, has pleaded guilty and is now a cooperating witness. So too is a former foreign policy adviser, George Papadopoulos, who has admitted lying to the FBI about repeated contacts with alleged Russian cutouts who had offered the Trump campaign <U+0089><db><cf>dirt<U+0089><U+06DD> on Hillary Clinton in the form of <U+0089><db><cf>thousands of emails.<U+0089><U+06DD> As described by sources familiar with various aspects of the investigation, the Mueller probe is fast approaching a critical crossroads.<e5><ca>The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyers, Ty Cobb and John Dowd, are pressing Mueller to wind down the investigation and exonerate their client, which they have assured the president will happen by early next year. But the sources familiar with the probe say that such a rapid conclusion is <U+0089><db><d3> as one put it <U+0089><db><d3> <U+0089><db><cf>fanciful.<U+0089><U+06DD> Mueller and his team, they say, are pursuing new leads, interrogating new witnesses and collecting a mountain of new evidence, including subpoenaed bank records and thousands of emails from the campaign and the Trump transition. In just the last few weeks, his prosecutors have begun questioning Republican National Committee staffers about the party digital operation that worked with the Trump campaign to target voters in key swing states. They are seeking to determine if the joint effort was related to the activities of Russian trolls and bots aimed at influencing the American electorate, according to two of the sources. In what is potentially another ominous sign for the White House, the lawyer for Jared Kushner, the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s son in law and senior adviser who was in charge of the campaign<U+0089><U+06EA>s digital operation, recently began searching for a crisis public relations firm to handle press inquiries <U+0089><db><d3> a step frequently taken by people who believe they may be facing criminal charges.<e5><ca>(Kushner has denied all wrongdoing, and his lawyer, Abbe Lowell, has said he is cooperating with the Mueller investigation.) Even if the new lines of inquiry don<U+0089><U+06EA>t result in additional indictments <U+0089><db><d3> something unknowable at this point <U+0089><db><d3> the new material all but guarantees the Mueller investigation will stretch on for months, if not years, likely provoking Trump to revisit his decision not to fire the special counsel. And if the president does take that step, many lawmakers and legal veterans say, it will cause a political explosion unlike any the capital has seen in decades. <U+0089><db><cf>It will be cataclysmic,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Richard Ben-Veniste, a former Watergate prosecutor who lived through the so-called Saturday night massacre when President Richard Nixon fired special prosecutor Archibald Cox. <U+0089><db><cf>It will create a constitutional crisis.<U+0089><U+06DD> In the meantime, the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s allies are mounting a ferocious attack on Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team <U+0089><db><d3> pointing to tens of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions to Hillary Clinton and other Democrats by the special counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s prosecutors, and to text messages disparaging Trump by FBI agent Peter Strzok, whom Mueller has since moved off the investigation.<e5><ca>They are also gunning for top FBI officials,<e5><ca>especially deputy director Andrew McCabe, who they believe began a counterintelligence investigation of the Trump campaign<U+0089><U+06EA>s links to the Russians last year based in part on the controversial dossier prepared by a former British spy and funded as <U+0089><db><cf>opposition research<U+0089><U+06DD> by the Clinton campaign. <U+0089><db><cf>Everything points to the fact that there was an orchestrated plan to try to prevent Donald Trump from being the next president of the United States,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, a member of the House Judiciary Committee,<e5><ca>in a recent television interview in which he vowed to subpoena senior FBI agents about the origins of the probe.  But for Democrats, the attacks on Mueller and the FBI are a distraction tactic meant to obscure how much has already been uncovered about the Trump team<U+0089><U+06EA>s contacts with the Russians. Back in January, when the issue first starting getting political traction, the president and his top aides denied that he and his campaign had any connections to Moscow. <U+0089><db><cf>I have nothing to do with Russia,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump tweeted at the time. Since then, Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team and congressional investigators have detailed numerous contacts, meetings and email exchanges between Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign and Russian-connected operatives and officials that were unknown to the public when voters went to the polls in November 2016. Jeff Sessions, the Trump campaign<U+0089><U+06EA>s chief national security adviser, met with the Russian ambassador at a hotel reception and later in his Senate office. Papadopoulos met with a Russia-connected professor and a woman introduced as <U+0089><db><cf>Putin<U+0089><U+06EA>s niece<U+0089><U+06DD> in an effort to set up a summit between Trump and the Russian president. And most famously, Donald Trump Jr., Kushner and Manafort all met in Trump Tower with a delegation of Russians who they believed had derogatory information on Hillary Clinton <U+0089><db><d3> including <U+0089><db><cf>official documents<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><d3> that came straight from the highest levels of the Kremlin. <U+0089><db><cf>Just from what<U+0089><U+06EA>s been made public, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s pretty clear the Trump campaign and family were willing and eager to work with the Russians,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Rep. Eric Swalwell, D-Calif., a member of the House Intelligence Committee. <U+0089><db><cf>They showed almost no restraint in engaging with the Russians to see what they had to offer on their opponent. It was a <U+0089><db><f7>whatever it takes<U+0089><U+06EA> mentality.<U+0089><U+06DD> Whether all this adds up to <U+0089><db><cf>collusion<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><d3> the sensational charge of active collaboration between the Trump campaign and Moscow that was first laid out in the controversial dossier commissioned by the Clinton campaign <U+0089><db><d3> is far from clear. But for Swalwell and quite a few others, it is already clear that the Russian probe has been far more than a witch hunt. Best of 2017 Yahoo News Features School shooting survivors united by a chain of grief <U+0089><db><d3> and hard lessons passed on >>> Hate in America: Where it comes from and why it<U+0089><U+06EA>s back>>> 64 hours in October: How one weekend blew up the rules of American politics >>> Opioids in Middletown >>> Weed & The American Family >>> Exclusive: Assad is confronted with photos of his torture victims This post was originally published on Yahoo News.
Title.x: Mueller Probe Outgrows Its Witch Hunt Phase
Title.y: Mueller Probe Outgrows Its Witch Hunt Phase

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) said Friday that he doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t support the latest Obamacare repeal bill, all but ensuring Republicans<U+0089><U+06EA> last-ditch effort to gut the Affordable Care Act is dead in the water. <U+0089><db><cf>I cannot in good conscience vote for the Graham-Cassidy proposal,<U+0089><U+06DD> McCain said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>I believe we could do better working together, Republicans and Democrats, and have not yet really tried,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>Nor could I support it without knowing how much it will cost, how it will affect insurance premiums, and how many people will be helped or hurt by it. Without a full [Congressional Budget Office] score, which won<U+0089><U+06EA>t be available by the end of the month, we won<U+0089><U+06EA>t have reliable answers to any of those questions.<U+0089><U+06DD> Since the entire Democratic caucus opposes the bill, dubbed Cassidy-Graham, Republican leaders can afford to lose only two GOP senators on it. McCain<U+0089><U+06EA>s decision means the bill doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t appear to have the votes to pass.<e5><ca>Sen. Rand Paul (R-Ky.) has said he<U+0089><U+06EA>s opposed to it , and Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine) has said she<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>leaning against<U+0089><U+06DD> it . Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R-Alaska), who voted against the last repeal bill, has also raised concerns with this one. In a lengthy statement, McCain underscored that the process has been terrible and suggested he won<U+0089><U+06EA>t support any repeal bill that wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t vetted through the usual rigorous, bipartisan debate. Republican leaders have been rushing to try to pass the bill<e5><U+0289><U+06E5> any repeal bill, really <U+0089><U+06E5> because their ability to pass something with 51 votes (including Vice President Mike Pence<U+0089><U+06EA>s tiebreaker) instead of 60 expires at the end of the month. <U+0089><db><cf>I would consider supporting legislation similar to that offered by my friends Senators Graham and Cassidy were it the product of extensive hearings, debate and amendment. But that has not been the case,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>Instead, the specter of September 30 th budget reconciliation deadline has hung over this entire process.<U+0089><U+06DD> He also nudged leadership to let the senators working on a bipartisan solution to health care continue their work.<e5><ca>Sens. Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) and Patty Murray (D-Wash.) have been holding hearings and trying to come up with a health care bill both parties can get behind, but GOP leaders effectively shut down their work to clear the path for the Cassidy-Graham bill. <U+0089><db><cf>Senators Alexander and Murray have been negotiating in good faith to fix some of the problems with Obamacare,<U+0089><U+06DD> said McCain. <U+0089><db><cf>But I fear that the prospect of one last attempt at a strictly Republican bill has left the impression that their efforts cannot succeed. I hope they will resume their work should this last attempt at a partisan solution fail.<U+0089><U+06DD> Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.)<e5><ca>hailed McCain<U+0089><U+06EA>s decision to move on from his party<U+0089><U+06EA>s months-long repeal effort. <U+0089><db><cf>John McCain shows the same courage in Congress that he showed when he was a naval aviator,<U+0089><U+06DD> Schumer said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>I have assured Senator McCain that as soon as repeal is off the table, we Democrats are intent on resuming the bipartisan process.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Arizona senator<U+0089><U+06EA>s announcement isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t a total surprise. He helped bring down the GOP<U+0089><U+06EA>s last repeal bill in a dramatic, late-night vote. But this time, his close friend Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) is leading the charge on the legislation, and it was unclear if McCain was prepared to vote against his pal. McCain acknowledged that made his decision more difficult. <U+0089><db><cf>I take no pleasure in announcing my opposition. Far from it,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>The bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s authors are my dear friends, and I think the world of them. I know they are acting consistently with their beliefs and sense of what is best for the country. So am I.<U+0089><U+06DD> Graham tweeted later that there<U+0089><U+06EA>s no hard feelings. One of the first people to praise McCain for his decision was late-night show host Jimmy Kimmel. He<U+0089><U+06EA>s been tearing into the bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s other author, Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.), all week for going back on his word about advocating a repeal bill that ensures pre-existing condition protections and lower costs. The Cassidy-Graham bill does neither. <U+0089><db><cf>Thank you, @SenJohnMcCain for being a hero again and again and now AGAIN,<U+0089><U+06DD> tweeted Kimmel. CORRECTION: Republican leaders can afford to lose the votes of only two GOP senators, not three, on the current Obamacare repeal bill.
Title.x: John McCain: 'I Cannot In Good Conscience Vote' For The GOP Obamacare Repeal Bill
Title.y: John McCain: 'I Cannot In Good Conscience Vote' For The GOP Obamacare Repeal Bill

text: Donald Trump Jr. managed to spread some fake news Thursday on Twitter. The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s son used the platform to criticize supporters of net neutrality after the Federal Communications Commission repealed the Title II protections that kept the internet a public utility. Unfortunately, Trump Jr. doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t seem to have all the facts in order. <U+0089><db><cf>I would pay good money to see all those people complaining about Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s FCC chairman voting to repeal #NetNeutality actually explain it in detail,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump Jr. wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>d also bet most hadn<U+0089><U+06EA>t heard of it before this week. #outrage.<U+0089><U+06DD> In fact,<e5><ca>President Donald Trump designated Ajit Pai the FCC chairman in January. Former President Barack Obama appointed Pai to a five-year term on the commission in 2012, but Democrats fought against his term<U+0089><U+06EA>s renewal last year. The commission voted to repeal the net neutrality protections in a 3-2 vote, with Pai voting in the majority. Net neutrality rules were initially put in place to ensure that internet service providers, ISPs, treated all information and content across the web equally. Repealing the Title II protections would allow internet service providers, such as Verizon or Comcast, to decide what content would be blocked or offered at slower speeds in favor of the company<U+0089><U+06EA>s own content. Critics of Pai<U+0089><U+06EA>s repeal effort fear that ISPs will discriminate against internet traffic and charge companies such as Netflix or Amazon exorbitant fees to give consumers efficient access to those services. (HuffPost<U+0089><U+06EA>s parent company, Oath, is owned by Verizon. HuffPost is also represented by the Writers Guild of America, East, which supports net neutrality and opposed its repeal). Millions of Americans had protested Pai<U+0089><U+06EA>s plan to repeal net neutrality regulations. Citizens have protested to keep the rules in place , in addition to calling offices of public officials to protect the internet.<e5><ca>Congress could nullify the FCC decision with a Congressional Review Act resolution,<e5><ca>and Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.) said Thursday that he would introduced one, but it<U+0089><U+06EA>s considered a long shot. More than 20 U.S. senators attempted to delay Thursday<U+0089><U+06EA>s vote after suspecting that the FCC was flooded with fraudulent comments , especially those in favor of the repeal. New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman opened an investigation, which showed that up to 2 million comments were submitted under false names. Schneiderman announced that he would sue to prevent the rollbacks on Thursday. In a YouTube video , Schneiderman criticized the FCC<U+0089><U+06EA>s lack of assistance in his office<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation and called the vote a travesty. <U+0089><db><cf>Today<U+0089><U+06EA>s vote also follows a public comment process that was deeply corrupted, including 2 million comments that stole the identities of real people,<U+0089><U+06DD> Schneiderman said in his video. <U+0089><db><cf>This is a crime under New York law <U+0089><U+06E5> and the FCC<U+0089><U+06EA>s decision to go ahead with the vote makes a mockery of government integrity and rewards the very perpetrators who scammed the system to advance their own agenda.<U+0089><U+06DD> Language in this story and its headline has been amended to clarify that while former President Barack Obama appointed Ajit Pai to the FCC, it was President Donald Trump who designated Pai the agency chairman.
Title.x: Trump Jr. Doesn't Seem To Know His Dad Designated The FCC Chairman
Title.y: Trump Jr. Doesn't Seem To Know His Dad Designated The FCC Chairman

text: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie got into a spat with a baseball fan at a game in Milwaukee on Sunday, his latest public relations snafu to cap a month of snafus. In a video posted to Twitter, Christie is seen leaning over a fan who heckled him, angrily calling the man a <U+0089><db><cf>big shot<U+0089><U+06DD> before storming away with a bowl of nachos. The governor was at the stadium to watch the game between the Chicago Cubs and the Milwaukee Brewers. Christie<U+0089><U+06EA>s son works for the Brewers. A local news reporter for the station WISN12, Ben Hutchison, said he was a relative of the man Christie confronted, Brad Joseph. Joseph told the outlet he yelled the governor<U+0089><U+06EA>s name <U+0089><db><cf> and told him that he sucked ,<U+0089><U+06DD> which sparked the encounter. <U+0089><db><cf>I called him a hypocrite because I thought it needed to be said. He turned around back towards me and got in my face for what seemed like a long time, but was probably only about 30 seconds or a minute. (He) was yelling at me. First he told me, <U+0089><db><f7>Why don<U+0089><U+06EA>t you have another beer?<U+0089><U+06EA> which I thought was a decent come back, and I thought that was kind of funny. Then he started calling me a tough guy.<U+0089><U+06DD> It<U+0089><U+06EA>s the second ballpark blunder for Christie this month. He was roundly booed by fans at a New York Mets game after catching a foul ball and giving it to a kid nearby, just weeks after he was lambasted in the media for closing some public beaches in New Jersey over the July 4 holiday weekend, and then vacationing on one himself .
Title.x: Chris Christie Has Another Bad Day At The Ballpark After Yelling At Cubs Fan
Title.y: Chris Christie Has Another Bad Day At The Ballpark After Yelling At Cubs Fan

text: President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s latest sycophantic cabinet meeting is receiving widespread ridicule online. After House Republicans passed the final version of the GOP tax bill on Wednesday, Trump asked Vice President Mike Pence <U+0089><db><cf>to say a few words.<U+0089><U+06DD> Pence didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t hold back in lavishing praise on POTUS, applauding him for unleashing American energy and spurring a record-setting optimism. Many Twitter users mocked Pence<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>ass kissing<U+0089><U+06DD> while others said it left them <U+0089><db><cf>ashamed<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>disgusted<U+0089><U+06DD>:
Title.x: Tweeters Ridicule Mike Pence's Fawning Praise Of Donald Trump At Cabinet Meeting
Title.y: Tweeters Ridicule Mike Pence's Fawning Praise Of Donald Trump At Cabinet Meeting

text: HuffPost asked Paul Nehlen three times by email this week if he considers himself a white nationalist. Twice Nehlen dodged the question. The third time he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t respond. The Wisconsin Republican is running to replace House Speaker Paul Ryan, who might not be seeking re-election. Nehlen campaigned in Alabama recently for Roy Moore, the Senate nominee accused of sexual misconduct, who suffered a historic defeat Tuesday. Nehlen claims to have raised <U+0089><db><cf>six figures<U+0089><U+06DD> for the Moore campaign. Nehlen was a speaker Monday at Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign rally in Midland City, Alabama. He took the stage wearing the red <U+0089><db><cf>Make America great again<U+0089><U+06DD> cap and warned the crowd that <U+0089><db><cf>we<U+0089><U+06EA>re engaged in a spiritual battle.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore was the only one, he said, who could <U+0089><db><cf>drain that swamp<U+0089><U+06DD> up in D.C. Only two days earlier, on Dec. 9, Nehlen was a guest on an anti-Semitic white power podcast called <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation,<U+0089><U+06DD> talking to hosts <U+0089><db><cf> Jazzhands McFeels<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>Marcus Halberstram<U+0089><U+06DD> for about an hour. (<U+0089><db><cf>Fash<U+0089><U+06DD> is shorthand among the so-called alt-right, a loose association of white nationalists, for <U+0089><db><cf>fascist.<U+0089><U+06DD>) It was Nehlen<U+0089><U+06EA>s second appearance on the show, and his fluency with white nationalist jargon was evident as he made thinly veiled anti-Semitic remarks and proudly recounted having told a Jewish magazine editor to <U+0089><db><cf>eat a bullet.<U+0089><U+06DD> On Dec. 8, Nehlen used Gab, a micro-blogging platform used primarily by white nationalists, to repost a drawing another user had made for him. The drawing showed a puny Ryan, seen as the anti-Trump, next to a buff <U+0089><db><cf>Chad<U+0089><U+06DD> Nehlen. (Chad is an alt-right term for a fit alpha-male womanizer.) In the accompanying text, Nehlen is described as having <U+0089><db><cf>redpilled on globalism, RR and JQ.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Redpilled,<U+0089><U+06DD> a reference to the Matrix movie trilogy, is used to describe an awakening to white supremacist teachings. <U+0089><db><cf>RR<U+0089><U+06DD> stands for <U+0089><db><cf>race realism,<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>JQ<U+0089><U+06DD> stands for the <U+0089><db><cf> Jewish question ,<U+0089><U+06DD> the anti-Semitic conspiracy theory that Jews have undue influence over the media, banking and politics that must somehow be addressed. Earlier this month, Nehlen tweeted <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s okay to be white,<U+0089><U+06DD> a meme that originated on the message board 4chan, a haven for neo-Nazi trolls, and was spread enthusiastically by white nationalists. <U+0089><db><cf>In fact it<U+0089><U+06EA>s pretty awesome,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added in a follow-up tweet.
