On at least two occasions this month, Nehlen has retweeted racist memes shared by Mark Collett, a British Nazi sympathizer. On the night of Aug. 11, when neo-Nazis and other assorted racists marched with tiki torches through Charlottesville, Virginia, Nehlen retweeted an image of the march posted by white nationalist Jason Kessler: <U+0089><db><cf>Incredible moment for white people who<U+0089><U+06EA>ve had it up to here & aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t going to take it anymore. Tomorrow we #UnitetheRight #Charlottesville.<U+0089><U+06DD> After Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s defeat in Alabama, Nehlen shared another piece of fan art Wednesday that was created for him on Gab. It showed Roman centurions with <U+0089><db><cf>Pepe the Frog<U+0089><U+06DD> heads. (Pepe the Frog is the mascot of the white nationalists.) <U+0089><db><cf>I call on all ready and able #GabFam to run for #House and #Senate and to vote for fellow #GabFam like @pnehlen in 2018,<U+0089><U+06DD> read the text. HuffPost emailed Nehlen on Wednesday detailing some of these <U+0089><db><d3> and other <U+0089><db><d3> flirtations he<U+0089><U+06EA>s made with being an avowed white nationalist.<e5><ca>Asked if he considers himself either a white nationalist or a member of the alt-right, Nehlen largely dodged the question, sending the following statement: I<U+0089><U+06EA>m a successful businessman and have had something like 20,000 employees around the globe of every color, race, and creed; not to mention patented inventions so attempts to paint me as anything but a successful businessman reflect on the media<U+0089><U+06EA>s identity politics not my Christian faith. Besides <U+0089><U+06E5> it<U+0089><U+06EA>s true that it<U+0089><U+06EA>s okay to be white <U+0089><U+06E5> it<U+0089><U+06EA>s pretty awesome in fact. Asked in a follow-up email to clarify whether or not he<U+0089><U+06EA>s a white nationalist with a simple yes or no, Nehlen responded: Given that the media is still determined to libel all conservatives as bigots, it seems some clarity on the definition of American Nationalism <U+0089><U+06E5> the idea that the United States should put the economic and security interests of American citizens ahead of the economic and security interests of illegal aliens and non-citizens <U+0089><U+06E5><e5><ca>is in order. In a third email Thursday, HuffPost noted that this was a definition of nationalism, but that it didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t answer the question as to whether Nehlen considers himself a white nationalist or a member of the alt-right. He didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t respond. Nehlen<U+0089><U+06EA>s association with the Moore campaign, which received funding from the Republican National Committee and was endorsed by President Donald Trump , shows that a faction of the GOP appears to be at ease with white nationalists in its ranks. At the Moore campaign rally Monday he attended,<e5><ca>Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s wife defended her husband from accusations of anti-Semitism by saying that one of his attorneys is a Jew. (An investigation by The Forward failed to find this Jewish lawyer.) It also shows that Steve Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s effort to publicly distance himself from the alt-right is a ruse.<e5><ca>Bannon, the Breitbart News executive chairman and a former White House chief strategist, had championed Moore and is backing Nehlen. Nehlen told HuffPost that Bannon is a <U+0089><db><cf>friend.<U+0089><U+06DD> On the <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation<U+0089><U+06DD> podcast, Nehlen said Bannon considers him a <U+0089><db><cf>kamikaze<U+0089><U+06DD> against the GOP establishment. Bannon did not respond to a request for comment on Nehlen<U+0089><U+06EA>s white nationalist sentiments.<e5><ca>Neither did the Moore campaign.<e5><ca>Nor did the National Republican Congressional Committee. Nehlen has been comfortable expressing bigoted comments in public for a while now, as documented by the Angry White Men blog run by Twitter user @EyesOnTheRight. Earlier this month, during a Twitter spat with Richard Lawler, an editor at tech news site Engadget who is black, Nehlen tweeted, <U+0089><db><cf>Run along Tyrone.<U+0089><U+06DD> As @EyesOnTheRight wrote, <U+0089><db><cf>There are two ways to interpret that comment, both of which suggest Nehlen was making a racist remark. On the one hand, Nehlen used a stereotypically black name to refer to an African-American man whose name he clearly knew. On the other, <U+0089><db><f7>Tyrone<U+0089><U+06EA> is a reference to a racist joke popular on the alt-right.<U+0089><U+06DD> That <U+0089><db><cf>joke<U+0089><U+06DD> features a deeply racist cartoon rendering of a black man, which we won<U+0089><U+06EA>t republish here. On the <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation<U+0089><U+06DD> podcast last weekend,<e5><ca>Nehlen recounted another Twitter spat he<U+0089><U+06EA>d had, this one with John Podhoretz, the conservative editor of Commentary magazine. After an argument over gun control, Nehlen had tweeted to Podhoretz, who is Jewish,<e5><ca>that he should <U+0089><db><cf>self-deport<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>eat a bullet.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>So Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s catamite @pnehlen has, in the past 12 hours, suggested I commit suicide and called on me, born and raised in the U.S. but Jewish, to <U+0089><db><f7>self-deport,<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Podhoretz tweeted. <U+0089><db><cf>Catamite<U+0089><U+06DD> is an obscure word referring to a young boy kept by a pederast. <U+0089><db><cf>What race even has that word? <U+0089><U+06DD> Nehlen asked on <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Well, there<U+0089><U+06EA>s one .<U+0089><U+06DD> The hosts laughed. McFeels called it a <U+0089><db><cf>very biblical term,<U+0089><U+06DD> emphasizing again Podheretz<U+0089><U+06EA>s religious heritage. <U+0089><db><cf>If people watch you stand in the face of the people like [the] John Podhoretzes of the world, the people who want to throw their parentheses at you <U+0089><db><d3> I have no time for that,<U+0089><U+06DD> Nehlen said. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not afraid of those guys.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Parentheses<U+0089><U+06DD> is a reference to the anti-Semitic <U+0089><db><cf> echo <U+0089><U+06DD> gimmick, in which the names of Jews or Jewish institutions are placed in triple parentheses. Nehlen was suspended from Twitter for 12 hours for telling Podhoretz to <U+0089><db><cf>eat a bullet.<U+0089><U+06DD> He told the <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation<U+0089><U+06DD> hosts that he <U+0089><db><cf>got shoah<U+0089><U+06EA>d for 12 hours.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Shoah<U+0089><U+06DD> is a Hebrew word for <U+0089><db><cf>calamity,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>used most commonly to refer to the Holocaust. For white nationalists, though, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s used as a slur, reserved for small inconveniences <U+0089><db><d3> like getting suspended by Twitter <U+0089><db><d3> as a way of diminishing the horror of the Holocaust. Nehlen also bragged that his fans had listened to his first appearance on <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation<U+0089><U+06DD> and that the<e5><U+0289><db><cf>the redpills are being shot at people like with bump fire stocks.<U+0089><U+06DD> (Translation: He<U+0089><U+06EA>s converting a lot of his supporters into white nationalists.) At another point,<e5><ca>Nehlen and the hosts talked gushingly about a recent stunt by the white nationalist group Identity Evropa , whose members joined the violent <U+0089><db><cf>Unite the Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally in Charlottesville this summer. In March, Identity Evropa hung a giant banner from a highway overpass in Georgia that read <U+0089><db><cf>America first. End immigration now.<U+0089><U+06DD> The group tweeted out a photo, which Nehlen retweeted. The <U+0089><db><cf>Fash the Nation<U+0089><U+06DD> hosts were deeply flattered that Nehlen was a guest on their show. McFeels <U+0089><db><d3> who, it should be noted, has appeared on the radio show of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard, and has called for the creation of a <U+0089><db><cf>white ethno-state<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><d3> lashed out at Paul Ryan for taking money from Jewish <U+0089><db><cf>paymasters<U+0089><U+06DD> and promised to <U+0089><db><cf>make sure<U+0089><U+06DD> Nehlen wins his congressional race in Wisconsin. Nehlen replied that he was <U+0089><db><cf>honored<U+0089><U+06DD> to be on the show. <U+0089><db><cf>You guys do great, great work,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said.
Title.x: A Republican Running To Replace Paul Ryan Comes With White Nationalist Street Cred
Title.y: A Republican Running To Replace Paul Ryan Comes With White Nationalist Street Cred

text: Roy Moore , the Republican candidate from Alabama vying for the U.S. Senate, once slammed the United States for promoting <U+0089><db><cf>a lot of bad things,<U+0089><U+06DD> and praised Russian President Vladimir Putin . In an interview over the summer that<U+0089><U+06EA>s getting renewed attention this week, The Guardian quoted President Ronald Reagan as once calling the Soviet Union <U+0089><db><cf>the focus of evil in the modern world.<U+0089><U+06DD> Reagan made the comment during his <U+0089><db><cf> evil empire <U+0089><U+06DD> speech in 1983. <U+0089><db><cf> You could say that very well about America, couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t you ?<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore said. <U+0089><db><cf>We promote a lot of bad things.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore then cited same-sex marriage as an example. When questioned about the fact that Putin held similar views, Moore gave an unconventional answer for an American politician. <U+0089><db><cf>Well, then maybe Putin is right,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Moore said. <U+0089><db><cf>Maybe he<U+0089><U+06EA>s more akin to me than I know.<U+0089><U+06DD> See the full interview above. ( h/t The Reagan Battalion )

text: Amid the violence and chaos taking place in Charlottesville, Virginia, this weekend,<e5><ca>one Twitter thread has gone viral for nailing exactly what<U+0089><U+06EA>s going on. User @JuliusGoat began a poignant Twitter thread that explained why the white supremacists protesting have absolutely no reason to be protesting and rioting: They have not experienced any kind of oppression, unlike marginalized groups in the U.S. The thread has been retweeted thousands of times and has been quoted by many high-profile Twitter users, including Gabby Sidibe , Cheryl Strayed , Paul F. Tompkins and J.K. Rowling . A similar sentiment was posted on Facebook by The Love Life Of An Asian Guy who asked <U+0089><db><cf>WHAT THE FUCK ARE THESE WHITE PEOPLE FIGHTING FOR?<U+0089><U+06DD> You can read the whole thread here .

text: In an astonishing defense of dropping <U+0089><db><cf>death taxes<U+0089><U+06DD> for individual estates worth more than $5.5 million, GOP Iowa Sen. Chuck Grassley implied that people not currently affected by that tax are <U+0089><db><cf>spending every darn penny ... on booze or women.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I think not having the estate tax recognizes the people that are investing <U+0089><db><d3> as opposed to those that are just spending every darn penny they have, whether it<U+0089><U+06EA>s on booze or women or movies,<U+0089><U+06DD> Grassley told the Des Moines Register in an interview published Saturday. Grassley, who serves on the Finance Committee, made the remark when asked about the Senate tax reform measure which would double the exemption for estates to $11 million for an individual and $22 million for a couple. Heirs would inherit the estates tax-free. Grassley<U+0089><U+06EA>s comment triggered a wave of criticism on social media.<e5><ca>Many complained that the working class is, in fact, spending <U+0089><db><cf>every darn penny<U+0089><U+06DD> on raising their kids, caring for elderly parents, health care and putting food on the table. One Twitter user complained that the GOP was turning America into a version of <U+0089><db><cf>The Hunger Games.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Grassley interview was part of the Des Moines Register<U+0089><U+06EA>s examination of how the tax reform measure radically reducing estate taxes will affect Iowans. Grassley has long argued that estate taxes, which currently must be paid on individual estates worth more than $5.5 million ($11 million for a married couple), hurt farms and small businesses in the state. Now, the Iowa senator apparently sees the tax change as a way to reward those who have accumulated millions of dollars by <U+0089><db><cf>investing.<U+0089><U+06DD> The newspaper found that the estate tax break will affect only <U+0089><db><cf>dozens<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>among 1.4 million Iowa taxpayers, according to IRS data ,<e5><ca>because almost all estates fall under the current exemption cap. The newspaper noted that the number of Iowans owing estate taxes was just 32 of 1.4 million taxpayers in 2012 <U+0089><db><d3> or .002 percent of the total. Sixty-one people <U+0089><db><d3> .004 percent of all Iowa taxpayers<e5><U+0289><db><d3> filed estate taxes in 2015. Only a fraction of those were farmers or small business owners,<e5><ca>the newspaper reported. Currently, only .2 percent of Americans pay estate tax and will benefit from the changes.<e5><ca>The House measure would eliminate the tax on all estates of any size by 2024. The Senate and House measures will have to be reconciled. Rep. David Young (R-Iowa) and Rep. Steve King (R-Iowa) both applauded the changes in the estate tax and emphasized how the changes would help farms and small businesses. Young insisted in a newsletter Friday that it is a<e5><U+0289><db><cf>myth<U+0089><U+06DD> that <U+0089><db><cf>repealing the estate tax is a massive giveaway to the wealthiest Americans.<U+0089><U+06DD> Grassley said earlier this year that the federal estate tax <U+0089><db><cf>may force family members to liquidate to pay the death tax.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: GOP Senator Implies Those Who Aren't Millionaires Waste Money On 'Booze, Women'
Title.y: GOP Senator Implies Those Who Aren't Millionaires Waste Money On 'Booze, Women'

text: As Donald Trump gleefully skewers men like Matt Lauer and Sen. Al Franken on Twitter over allegations of sexual harassment, the president himself is facing accusations of being a <U+0089><db><cf>creeper.<U+0089><U+06DD> On Wednesday night, the Daily Beast reported that Trump once bragged there<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf> nothing in the world like first-rate pussy <U+0089><U+06DD> while leering at a young woman at his golf club at Mar-a-Lago. Michael Corcoran, a reporter for the now-defunct Maximum Golf magazine, said he heard the remark while he shadowed Trump in 2000 for a feature story. According to Corcoran and his then-editor, Joe Bargmann, the quote was altered in the article by the magazine<U+0089><U+06EA>s editor-in-chief, who swapped the word <U+0089><db><cf>pussy<U+0089><U+06DD> for the rather more innocuous <U+0089><db><cf>talent.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I was asked to change the last word of the story from <U+0089><db><f7>pussy.<U+0089><U+06EA> When I refused, my top editor changed the quote,<U+0089><U+06DD> Bargmann said. As the Daily Beast noted, the word <U+0089><db><cf>pussy<U+0089><U+06DD> is not uncommon in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s parlance. Fox News commentator Tucker Carlson said Trump once told him he gets <U+0089><db><cf> more pussy than you do <U+0089><U+06DD> after Carlson made a jibe on air about his hair. In the now-infamous <U+0089><db><cf>Access Hollywood<U+0089><U+06DD> tape , Trump is heard boasting about being able to grab women <U+0089><db><cf>by the pussy.<U+0089><U+06DD> Using smutty language, however, isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t the worst of the allegations leveled against the president. Trump has been accused by at least 16 women of sexual harassment and assault . Among them, Jill Harth said Trump sexually assaulted her in his daughter Ivanka<U+0089><U+06EA>s bedroom in 1993; Jessica Leeds said Trump <U+0089><db><cf>grabbed her breasts and tried to put his hand up her skirt<U+0089><U+06DD> on an airplane in the 1970s; and Rachel Crooks, then a 22-year-old receptionist in Trump Tower, said Trump kissed her <U+0089><db><cf>directly on the mouth<U+0089><U+06DD> at their first meeting in 2005. The White House has said that all 16 women are lying . As sexual harassment and assault allegations against powerful men in Hollywood, the media and elsewhere continue to dominate the news cycle, Trump has not minced words in condemning the behavior of men like Franken (D-Minn.) and former President Bill Clinton . Wednesday he called out NBC anchor Matt Lauer after he was fired over sexual misconduct allegations. While those accused certainly deserve scrutiny, Trump has been nothing if not entirely dismissive of similar allegations leveled against him <U+0089><U+06E5> and those he considers friends. He<U+0089><U+06EA>s recently tried to deny that the voice on the <U+0089><db><cf>Access Hollywood<U+0089><U+06DD> tape was his , despite once publicly acknowledging its authenticity. And he spoke up in defense of Roy Moore, the Republican Senate nominee in Alabama who has been accused of sexual misconduct, including with minors. <U+0089><db><cf> He says it didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t happen ,<U+0089><U+06DD> the president told reporters of Moore earlier this month. <U+0089><db><cf>You have to listen to him also.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Trump Reportedly Once Bragged About 'First-Rate P***y'
Title.y: Trump Reportedly Once Bragged About 'First-Rate P***y'

text: A former Fox News anchorwoman who accused Bill O<U+0089><U+06EA>Reilly of sexually harassing her in 2011 is now claiming that Donald Trump kissed her on the lips in an elevator. Juliet Huddy said Thursday morning on the <U+0089><db><cf>Mornin!!! With Bill Schulz<U+0089><U+06DD> podcast (which has a paywall) that it happened around 2005 or 2006 when Trump was hosting <U+0089><db><cf>The Apprentice<U+0089><U+06DD> on NBC. <U+0089><db><cf>He took me to lunch in Trump Tower,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>He said goodbye to me in an elevator while his security guy was there. <U+0089><db><cf>He went to say goodbye and he, rather than kiss me on the cheek, he leaned in on the lips.<U+0089><U+06DD> Huddy, whom Trump knew because she co-hosted <U+0089><db><cf>Fox & Friends<U+0089><U+06DD> on the weekends, said she assumed Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s lip kiss was just confusion: <U+0089><db><cf>Oh, we went the wrong way,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. She also said she wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t offended. <U+0089><db><cf>I thought, <U+0089><db><f7>This is interesting.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> It should be noted that this was her expression on the show when she said that: Huddy said she was surprised he went for her lips but <U+0089><db><cf>didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t feel threatened.<U+0089><U+06DD> In fact, she brought a friend back to Trump Tower so that the future president could give them a tour of <U+0089><db><cf>The Apprentice<U+0089><U+06DD> set. Huddy believes Trump was single at the time, and, after checking the math, host Bill Schulz said it was possible he wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t engaged to Melania Trump at the time of the kiss. She says Trump referenced the kiss when he was Huddy<U+0089><U+06EA>s guest on her syndicated series, <U+0089><db><cf>The Morning Show With Mike and Juliet.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>He came up on stage and he turned around to the audience <U+0089><U+06E5> and, you know, there were 50 people there <U+0089><U+06E5> and he said, <U+0089><db><f7>I tried to hit on her, but she blew me off,<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Huddy remembered. Huddy emphasized that at the time she wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t offended that he kissed her but that she has a different perspective now. <U+0089><db><cf>Now that I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve matured, I would<U+0089><U+06EA>ve said, <U+0089><db><f7>Nope.<U+0089><U+06EA> At that time, I was making excuses.<U+0089><U+06DD> HuffPost reached out to the White House for comment, but it did not immediately respond. Huddy commented further on Twitter on Friday evening after the New York Post picked up the story.
Title.x: Ex-Fox News Anchor Juliet Huddy Says Trump Kissed Her On Lips After A Lunch
Title.y: Ex-Fox News Anchor Juliet Huddy Says Trump Kissed Her On Lips After A Lunch

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> Fifty-eight House Democrats voted to advance the impeachment of President Donald Trump on Wednesday, in direct defiance of the pleas of House Democratic leaders earlier in the day. A vote to table the impeachment resolution was agreed to 368-58, with four Democrats voting just <U+0089><db><cf>present<U+0089><U+06DD> and 126 other Democrats voting with Republicans to kill the resolution. It may seem like this was an overwhelming confirmation of Trump <U+0089><U+06E5> and it was, in the sense that no Republican voted to advance impeachment and more than two-thirds of Democrats joined their GOP colleagues <U+0089><U+06E5> but 58 Democratic votes is still a significant statement on impeachment.  House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Minority Whip Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) issued a joint statement just before the vote urging their Democratic colleagues to reject the impeachment resolution. They presented the vote as a distraction from efforts to kill the Republican tax bill, which is swiftly making its way through Congress, and they cited the special counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation of Trump, as well as inquiries from congressional committees, to plead with Democrats to hold off. <U+0089><db><cf>Now is not the time,<U+0089><U+06DD> Pelosi and Hoyer wrote. But the most progressive wing of the Democratic caucus, bolstered by a large number of Congressional Black Caucus members <U+0089><U+06E5> including the No. 3 Democrat, Assistant Democratic Leader Jim Clyburn (S.C.) <U+0089><U+06E5> ignored Pelosi and Hoyer and voted for impeachment. The resolution was introduced by CBC member Al Green (D-Texas), who was talked out of forcing an impeachment vote earlier in the year. Green, wearing an American flag tie, said his resolution wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t about Democrats or Republicans; it was about democracy, about <U+0089><db><cf>the fate of our republic.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>May everyone vote their conscience knowing that history will judge us all,<U+0089><U+06DD> Green said. Rather than attacking Trump over issues like Russia, Green<U+0089><U+06EA>s impeachment resolution hits Trump for race-baiting, bigotry, anti-Semitism, and a number of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments, including his statements after the protests in Charlottesville, Virginia; comments against the governor of Puerto Rico; and even Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s crusade against NFL protests. By not bringing Russia into the matter, the resolution may just be a proxy for the general anger toward Trump in the Democratic base, and Green may have had an easier time arguing to his colleagues that his resolution should proceed. Despite Pelosi and Hoyer<U+0089><U+06EA>s concerns that the impeachment resolution would simply become a cudgel to divide Democrats, the vote will likely help some Democratic members, particularly those in far-left districts. But the vote might not be without consequences. Unabashed liberal Rep. Jared Polis (D-Colo.) and more moderate Rep. Tim Walz (D-Minn.),<e5><ca>who are both running for governor of their respective states, also voted to advance the impeachment process. Still, Green argued that civility from Democrats had prevented them from confronting Trump for too long. <U+0089><db><cf>In doing this, hatred disguised as acceptable political correctness has festered in our body politic and polluted our discourse to our detriment. It divides and damages the social fabric of our country in ways that obstruction of justice cannot. It causes unparalleled destruction to our society in the long- and short-term that will not easily heal,<U+0089><U+06DD> Green wrote in a letter to his colleagues .
Title.x: House Votes Down Trump Impeachment Resolution
Title.y: House Votes Down Trump Impeachment Resolution

text: U.S. Army soldiers assigned to protect Vice President Mike Pence have been removed from their detail after an incident in Colombia, NBC reported . Sources told NBC that the men were caught on camera bringing women back to their hotel last week without registering them. It is unclear where Pence was at the time. Security video reportedly showed the soldiers bringing the women into a restricted area. <U+0089><db><cf>We are aware of the incident and it is currently under investigation,<U+0089><U+06DD> a spokesperson for the Department of Defense told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>We can confirm that the individuals in question have been re-assigned back to the Army.<U+0089><U+06DD> Pence was in Colombia last week as a part of a tour of Latin America , which included a meeting Aug. 13 with Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos. The U.S. vice president also visited Chile, Argentina and Panama. In 2012, 11 Secret Service agents were placed on leave after allegedly employing prostitutes while in Colombia for a visit by President Barack Obama . Officials don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have any evidence that the women with the soldiers last week were prostitutes. The report didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t indicate how many soldiers were involved and where the hotel was located.
Title.x: Soldiers Reassigned After Bringing Women To Hotel During Pence Detail
Title.y: Soldiers Reassigned After Bringing Women To Hotel During Pence Detail

text: Over the past two weeks, conservative media has been warning of a new menace loose in the corridors of Washington, a <U+0089><db><cf> rogue <U+0089><U+06DD> agent <U+0089><db><cf> burrowing <U+0089><U+06DD> into the federal bureaucracy to mount a <U+0089><db><cf> coup <U+0089><U+06DD> that could shatter the rule of law and shred the Constitution in a deranged bid for unaccountable power. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s the type of conspiracy theory popular in Facebook groups and Reddit forums that cater to fringe paranoia. But in this case, these ominous concerns are coming from Republican senators. They<U+0089><U+06EA>re the latest salvo in a quixotic, yearslong battle the GOP has waged against the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB), an agency Congress created in 2010 to streamline federal oversight of abusive banking practices. And the main target of this impassioned vitriol is a 34-year-old bureaucrat named Leandra English. English, according to interviews with several former colleagues, is, well <U+0089><U+06E5> she<U+0089><U+06EA>s boring. Not dull. Plenty of people commended her energy and intellect. But someone who specializes in work that doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t demand a spotlight.<e5><ca>After earning a master<U+0089><U+06EA>s degree from the London School of Economics, she<U+0089><U+06EA>s built a career as a Washington functionary, changing federal agencies every few years as new opportunities arose, distinguishing herself by working long hours and, as multiple people said, <U+0089><db><cf>keeping the trains running on time.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>At the bureau, she was known as somebody with no ego,<U+0089><U+06DD> notes Patricia McCoy, former CFPB assistant director for mortgage markets. <U+0089><db><cf>Her talent in cutting through red tape was widely recognized.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>She worked later than probably anybody I know,<U+0089><U+06DD> says Chris Vaeth, who spent five years at the CFPB, ultimately leading its Office of Community Affairs. English declined to comment for this story. The bulk of that work took place at the CFPB, where English started in 2010 and returned after separate stints at the Office of Management and Budget and the Office of Personnel Management. She worked on the transition team that put the nascent agency on its feet. As deputy director for external affairs, she was charged with such radical activities as outreach to community banks and the establishment of a consumer complaint system. She<U+0089><U+06EA>s been deputy chief operations officer and deputy chief of staff. Prior to the election last year, she applied for a job as the bureau<U+0089><U+06EA>s chief of staff, which she started in January. And she<U+0089><U+06EA>s effective. The consumer complaint system works. Even bank lobbyists pressing for lighter regulation acknowledge some grudging admiration. <U+0089><db><cf>I like Leandra,<U+0089><U+06DD> Consumer Bankers Association CEO Richard Hunt told American Banker. <U+0089><db><cf>I think she was a terrific chief of staff.<U+0089><U+06DD> Then, on Nov. 24, English took a career risk that landed her name in the papers. When CFPB Director Richard Cordray resigned to run for office in Ohio, he named English deputy director.<e5><ca>English accepted the nod, knowing it was a politically controversial appointment <U+0089><U+06E5> a deliberate attempt to prevent President Donald Trump from installing a loyalist hostile to the agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s mission without at least going through the Senate confirmation process. Under the Dodd-Frank Act, the 2010 law that established the agency, the deputy director becomes acting director whenever the director himself is <U+0089><db><cf>absent or unavailable.<U+0089><U+06DD> English was, she believed, now in charge of the agency she had helped found. But the president was apparently unhappy with this reasoning. Over Thanksgiving weekend, he named his budget director, Mick Mulvaney , acting head of the CFPB. English sued , and the question of who is actually running the agency is now making its way through federal court. Mulvaney is ideologically hostile to the bureau. He once called it a <U+0089><db><cf>sick, sad<U+0089><U+06DD> joke . At a news conference last Monday, he declared that it had been <U+0089><db><cf>trampling on capitalism.<U+0089><U+06DD> This is rather feverish rhetoric to describe an agency that essentially guards against petty theft. Over the past six years, the CFPB has returned roughly $12 billion in ill-gotten gains from financial institutions to over 29 million consumers. For individual families, that can mean substantive relief <U+0089><U+06E5> hundreds, and in some cases, thousands of dollars over bogus charges or deceptive contracts. But it<U+0089><U+06EA>s hardly a threat to American capitalism, which has grown from a $16 trillion annual enterprise the day the CFPB opened its doors to an over $17 trillion operation today. The agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s most recent major enforcement action was a $100 million fine imposed against Wells Fargo for secretly creating millions of bank accounts for customers who had never asked for them. In Mulvaney<U+0089><U+06EA>s installation, CFPB<U+0089><U+06EA>s leadership saw an effort from the Trump administration to dismantle an organization they had constructed from scratch. English and her supporters are perfectly aware they may well lose their case. An early court ruling has already come down in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s favor, and the CFPB<U+0089><U+06EA>s own general counsel has issued a memo siding with Mulvaney, who says he would keep English as deputy director if he ultimately prevails . If Trump were simply better organized, he could sidestep the entire affair by just naming a full-time director and getting him or her confirmed by the Senate. But it<U+0089><U+06EA>s hard to build things in Washington that genuinely work, and very easy to destroy them. To English and her allies, even a long-shot bid to postpone or mitigate the damage is better than a full surrender. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s the not-so-secret reason Republicans expend so much venom on the CFPB. Though plenty of the CFPB<U+0089><U+06EA>s enemies in the GOP have accepted robust campaign contributions from the financial sector, the agency poses a much more serious threat to conservative ideology than it does to any donor<U+0089><U+06EA>s bottom line. The financial industry has been booking handsome profits throughout the CFPB<U+0089><U+06EA>s existence <U+0089><U+06E5> the $12 billion it has had to give back didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t put an end to big bonuses, or force any legitimate businesses to close up shop. The CFPB instead serves as a constant institutional reminder that government can <U+0089><U+06E5> if it relies on the right people <U+0089><U+06E5> actually get things done. And so the Republican attacks on English don<U+0089><U+06EA>t accuse her of waste or incompetence or any of the other stock conservative objections to bureaucracy. They have instead portrayed her as a dangerous mastermind. <U+0089><db><cf>This rogue employee is trying to ... run the agency as an unaccountable fourth branch of government,<U+0089><U+06DD> wrote nine GOP senators, including Ben Sasse (R-Neb.) and Ted Cruz (R-Texas) in a letter to Mulvaney. Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.), meanwhile, penned a lengthy conspiratorial inquiry to Kathleen McGettigan, acting director of the Office of Personnel Management, accusing English of <U+0089><db><cf>burrowing<U+0089><U+06DD> into the CFPB for political purposes. Johnson wanted to know whether English had <U+0089><db><cf>abused<U+0089><U+06DD> the hiring process by securing the chief of staff job in January. The criticism has outraged English<U+0089><U+06EA>s former colleagues. <U+0089><db><cf>As somebody who saw her work and values her highly, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m just really offended at the attempt to portray her as some kind of venal, spotlight-grabbing carpetbagger,<U+0089><U+06DD> says Holly Petraeus, a former assistant director at the CFPB who retired this year. <U+0089><db><cf>She<U+0089><U+06EA>s not that at all.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>The things they<U+0089><U+06EA>re saying are so ridiculous. They just say the absolute opposite of what is true,<U+0089><U+06DD> says Elizabeth Vale, who served as director of external affairs for the CFPB. <U+0089><db><cf>She could have gone and made a lot of money somewhere. She is a true, dedicated public servant who wants to make a real difference in this world ... if you asked me to put the people I admire most as public servants on that list, she would be in the top five.<U+0089><U+06DD> Vale, who also worked with former senior adviser Valerie Jarrett in the Obama White House, now teaches at the University of Pennsylvania. That is the ultimate tragedy of the CFPB. Eventually, English will lose, one way or another. Trump or Vice President Mike Pence or someone else will get around to naming a full-time director and for a few months or maybe even a couple of years, devoted public servants will try to hang on. But capable people like English will only stick around for so long in a place where the top brass is determined to prevent them from actually accomplishing anything. They<U+0089><U+06EA>ll accept other job offers, finding a different quiet,<e5><ca>thankless way to contribute to society. The CFPB will decay into just another dysfunctional Washington paper-mill and banks will become steadily more shameless in their reliance on predatory practices. Not because it is inevitable, but because a handful of people in power will decide it should be so.
Title.x: Meet Leandra English, The GOP's Latest Boogeyman
Title.y: Meet Leandra English, The GOP's Latest Boogeyman

text: A retired Alabama police officer said she and her colleagues were told decades ago to <U+0089><db><cf>make sure<U+0089><U+06DD> Roy Moore <U+0089><db><cf>didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t hang around<U+0089><U+06DD> high school cheerleaders, and confirmed previous reports that the Republican Senate candidate was banned at the time from a local mall for predatory behavior toward teenage girls. <U+0089><db><cf>The rumor mill was that he liked young girls, and ... we were advised that he was being suspended from the mall because he would hang around the young girls that worked in the stores and ... really got into a place of where they say he was harassing,<U+0089><U+06DD> former Gadsden police officer Faye Gary told MSNBC on Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>We were also told to watch him at the ball games, and make sure that ... he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t hang around the cheerleaders,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. Gary did not clarify who issued the warnings, saying they <U+0089><db><cf>were just rumors<U+0089><U+06DD> that circulated both at the local police department and courthouse. She also said that while working on juvenile cases as an officer, she never received a formal complaint about Moore. <U+0089><db><cf>Every day we were looking for a complaint to come in,<U+0089><U+06DD> but none did, she said. The 70-year-old former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court has been accused of sexual misconduct by nearly 10 women, with several incidents allegedly occurring when the women were teenagers and he was in his early 30s. <U+0089><db><cf>I didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t realize it until some time later that when they said he liked young girls <U+0089><db><d3> I just thought he liked young ladies, you know, younger than him, maybe in their 20s,<U+0089><U+06DD> Gary said. <U+0089><db><cf>I had no idea, or we had no idea that we were talking about 14-year-olds. But we never got a complaint on it.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore targeting young girls <U+0089><db><cf>was a known fact,<U+0089><U+06DD> Gary told the New York Times last week . <U+0089><db><cf>It was treated like a joke. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s just the way it was.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore, known nationally for his anti-gay and anti-Muslim views, has steadfastly denied the allegations, casting them as a conspiracy against him. While many national Republican leaders have called on Moore to exit the race <U+0089><U+06E5> saying the allegations against him ring true <U+0089><U+06E5> Alabama GOP officials are sticking by him. And his campaign has held several events this week to defend him and discredit the women who have made the sexual assault and harassment accusations. <U+0089><db><cf>Allegations are words. They are not facts,<U+0089><U+06DD> Stan Cooke, an Alabama pastor, said at an event Tuesday afternoon. <U+0089><db><cf>Allegations are words. They are not indictments and they are not charges.<U+0089><U+06DD> After remaining mum on Moore after the allegations surfaced earlier this month , President Donald Trump on Tuesday all but endorsed him . He told reporters in Washington that he would rather have Moore in the Senate than <U+0089><db><cf>a liberal person in there,<U+0089><U+06DD> referring to Democratic nominee Doug Jones. When asked whether <U+0089><db><cf>an accused child molester is better than a Democrat,<U+0089><U+06DD> the president repeatedly said that Moore <U+0089><db><cf>denies it.<U+0089><U+06DD> He would not say whether he believes the women. <U+0089><db><cf>He says it didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t happen, and you know, you have to listen to him also,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Trump said. Moore and Jones face off in a Dec. 12 special election for the seat Republican Jeff Sessions gave up to serve as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s attorney general. Recent polls have shown a close race. In remaining defiant, Moore, criticizing Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), tweeted last week to<e5><U+0289><db><cf>bring it on<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><U+0289><db><d3> an unfortunate choice of words, because, as many pointed out , <U+0089><db><cf>Bring It On<U+0089><U+06DD> is the title of a popular movie about high school cheerleaders.
Title.x: Police Were Told To Keep Roy Moore Away From High School Cheerleaders, Retired Officer Says
Title.y: Police Were Told To Keep Roy Moore Away From High School Cheerleaders, Retired Officer Says

text: A new national Pew Research Center poll released Thursday shows that President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s approval rating is declining among demographic groups that previously gave him relatively high numbers, particularly among evangelicals. According to Pew, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s approval rating among white evangelical Protestants dropped 17 percentage points from February to December, down from 78 percent to 61 percent. Eighty-one percent of white evangelical voters backed Trump in the 2016 presidential election, NPR reported . Though the decline was not as steep, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s approval rating also dropped among adults 50 and older (from 47 percent to 38 percent) as well as among whites (49 percent to 41 percent). As Axios noted, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s approval rating had either remained the same or dropped among every demographic group Pew polled. The survey was conducted Nov. 29 to Dec. 4 among 1,503 participants nationwide, a period during which Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s former national security adviser, Michael Flynn, pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI. According to a new HuffPost/YouGov poll taken in the wake of Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s plea, half of Americans thought the ties between Russia and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s team were a legitimate issue. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s approval rating has been hitting record lows throughout his first term in office, and Pew<U+0089><U+06EA>s latest survey is no exception. It found that 32 percent of respondents approved of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s job performance while 63 percent disapproved.
Title.x: Poll Shows Trump's Support Dropping Among White Evangelicals
Title.y: Poll Shows Trump's Support Dropping Among White Evangelicals

text: Former Vice President Al Gore says he<U+0089><U+06EA>s given up hope that President Donald Trump will act on key climate issues. Gore recounted to<e5><U+0289><db><cf>Late Show<U+0089><U+06DD> host Stephen Colbert his optimism after his meeting with Trump to discuss climate change and the landmark Paris Accord . Trump had promised supporters during the campaign that he would pull out of the agreement, arguing it was a <U+0089><db><cf>bad deal.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I went to Trump Tower after the election,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Gore, who was on Colbert<U+0089><U+06EA>s show to promote his new movie, <U+0089><db><cf> An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power .<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I thought that there was a chance he would come to his senses. But I was wrong.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump announced the United States<U+0089><U+06EA> withdrawal from the agreement last month, a decision met with wide criticism from business leaders , fellow politicians and longtime U.S. allies . More than 350 mayors in cities across the U.S. have since pledged to honor the Paris climate agreement. Gore added he worried that Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s decision to exit the agreement would be <U+0089><db><cf>disastrous,<U+0089><U+06DD> but he was excited by the response of political leaders in the U.S. <U+0089><db><cf>A lot of our most important governors and mayors and business leaders said, <U+0089><db><f7>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re still in the Paris Agreement, and we<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to meet the commitments of the country regardless of what Donald Trump tweets.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Watch the whole clip in the video above. This article has been updated with an updated figure for the number of mayors who have signed on to the Climate Mayors initiative.
Title.x: Al Gore: 'I Was Wrong' About Donald Trump
Title.y: Al Gore: 'I Was Wrong' About Donald Trump

text: On Oct. 25, 2009, Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump pledged their undying devotion to each other in front of 500 of their family members and friends. Now,<e5><ca>eight years later, to celebrate the anniversary of their blessed union, it appears that our country<U+0089><U+06EA>s foremost power couple will enjoy a tight 21 minutes of sweet, presumably missionary-style love-making with 2004 pop sensation James Blunt crooning in their ear.<e5><ca>We can surmise this thanks to Spotify. Because, reader, on Sunday,<e5><ca>Oct. 15, Ivanka Trump made this playlist : The 21-minute-long collection of songs is as horny as it is depressing.<e5><ca>The playlist evokes motionless, antiseptic coitus.<e5><ca>It evokes two Tide pens in a plastic sale tub. It evokes Lysol wipes. It evokes the smooth, genderless slopes of a couple of undressed dolls. This is sex music only in the sense that two pages pressed together in a new Williams Sonoma catalog is sex. How can we be so sure this is about sex, you wonder? For starters, consider that this is the first public playlist Ivanka has made since her 2015 banger, <U+0089><db><cf> Holiday Party ,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>and that it is also the only one she has ever made with such a cryptic title. (The rest bear names like<e5><U+0289><db><cf>Walk to Work<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>Weekend Morning.<U+0089><U+06DD>) Should you google the playlist<U+0089><U+06EA>s title, <U+0089><db><cf>991122,<U+0089><U+06DD> the vast majority of your results would relate to the corresponding HTML color code, a deep red, which prompts the images you see below: Pair all this with the knowledge that the list was made just 10 days before the couple<U+0089><U+06EA>s anniversary, and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s hard to see this as anything but their 21-minute sex playlist. Still, admittedly, it is not definitive proof. There are, however, some things we can know for certain. The Spotify account, for instance,<e5><ca>definitely belongs to Ivanka.<e5><ca>Back in 2014,<e5><ca>Ivanka Trump shared her <U+0089><db><cf>Weekend Morning<U+0089><U+06DD> playlist on her website, IvankaTrump.com . The embedded list <U+0089><db><d3> which contains such aggressively uninteresting hits as <U+0089><db><cf>Send Me On My Way<U+0089><U+06DD> by Rusted Root and <U+0089><db><cf>Uptown Funk<U+0089><U+06DD> by Mark Ronson <U+0089><db><d3> was created by the same Ivanka Trump who created the apparent 21-minute sex playlist in question. We also know that the couple (or at least the Ivanka half of it) has a history of getting sentimental over songs<U+0089><db><d3>especially those that hold some sort of significance to their relationship. In 2013, while talking about giving birth to her first child, Arabella, Ivanka told Fit Pregnancy magazine that she and Jared <U+0089><db><cf>made a playlist for the delivery of all the songs from our relationship. Arabella was actually born while my wedding song, <U+0089><db><f7>This Year<U+0089><U+06EA>s Love<U+0089><U+06EA> by David Gray, was playing. It was a coincidence, but it was cool!<U+0089><U+06DD> Though we can<U+0089><U+06EA>t know for sure how these specific songs might be important to Jared and Ivanka<U+0089><U+06EA>s pure,<e5><ca>carefully scheduled love, we can take some educated guesses.<e5><ca>In John Legend<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>All of Me,<U+0089><U+06DD> for instance, Legend sings, <U+0089><db><cf>Even when I lose I<U+0089><U+06EA>m winning.<U+0089><U+06DD> Jared and Ivanka are both notorious workaholics, with Ivanka even telling New York in 2009, <U+0089><db><cf>Jared and I are very similar in that we<U+0089><U+06EA>re very ambitious.<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>In the song <U+0089><db><cf>Ordinary People,<U+0089><U+06DD> the line <U+0089><db><cf>I know I misbehaved and you made your mistakes<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>might be an allusion to Ivanka<U+0089><U+06EA>s initial hesitancy in converting to Judaism. A true shonda. Then, in Bruno Mars<U+0089><U+06EA> <U+0089><db><cf>When I Was Your Man,<U+0089><U+06DD> we hear <U+0089><db><cf>Oh, I know I<U+0089><U+06EA>m probably much too late/To try and apologize for my mistakes,<U+0089><U+06DD> a clear reference to Jared<U+0089><U+06EA>s failure in brokering Middle East peace. <U+0089><db><cf>You<U+0089><U+06EA>re Beautiful<U+0089><U+06DD> is of course a reference to the fact that they are sexually attracted to one another, while <U+0089><db><cf>When We Were Young<U+0089><U+06DD> alludes to the fact that they are both, in fact, <U+0089><db><cf>young.<U+0089><U+06DD> So, is this Ivanka and Jared<U+0089><U+06EA>s 21-minute sex playlist?<e5><ca>The verdict here is a lusty yes.<e5><ca>And if you, too, want to make love for 21 minutes like Jared and Ivanka, just grab a partner, put on this playlist, and be born to millionaire parents who thrust vitally important jobs onto you for which you are grossly unqualified.<e5><ca>Enjoy!
Title.x: Is This Jared And Ivanka's 21-Minute Sex Playlist?
Title.y: Is This Jared And Ivanka's 21-Minute Sex Playlist?

text: Hillary Clinton called out the vulgar depictions of her during the 2016 presidential campaign and noticed they didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t receive the same backlash that comedian Kathy Griffin faced for posing with a fake bloody severed head of President Donald Trump earlier this year. During the latest episode of Clinton<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign-related podcast<e5><U+0289><db><cf>With Her,<U+0089><U+06DD> the former Democratic nominee discussed the research that found a negative correlation between a women<U+0089><U+06EA>s professional success and her likability. She then compared Griffin<U+0089><U+06EA>s gruesome photo to the anti-Clinton merchandise unofficial vendors were selling at the Republican National Convention. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve always just sucked it up,<U+0089><U+06DD> Clinton said about the gender bias she<U+0089><U+06EA>s experienced as a successful woman working in government. <U+0089><db><cf>I sucked it up in <U+0089><U+06EA>08 when some really unpleasant things happened to me<e5><ca>...<e5><ca>And I sucked it up in the 2016 campaign when I was called names and things were said and done to me.<U+0089><U+06DD> She added,<e5><U+0289><db><cf>We recently had this big kerfuffle <U+0089><U+06E5> this condemnation of Kathy Griffin <U+0089><U+06E5> for the picture she had of herself holding a head of Trump like a play on Perseus holding the head of Medusa,<U+0089><U+06DD> Clinton said. <U+0089><db><cf>They were selling T-shirts and mugs at the Republican [National] Convention with Trump holding my head. Nobody said a word. Not a word!<U+0089><U+06DD> It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not clear if such severed head merchandise existed, but HuffPost reporters saw lots of other offensive anti-Clinton merchandise on display at the convention, including a violent image of her falling off a motorcycle and another of Trump punching her out. In May, Griffin issued a formal apology, which she later rescinded , saying the Trump head photo shoot went <U+0089><db><cf>way too far.<U+0089><U+06DD> The incident led to lost gigs for Griffin and reports that she was questioned by the Secret Service. The anti-Clinton merchandise created during the 2016 campaign was disgustingly sexist, featuring profane slogans calling her a <U+0089><db><cf>bitch,<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>tramp<U+0089><U+06DD> and even more crass terms. In Clinton<U+0089><U+06EA>s new election memoir, What Happened, released on Tuesday, she references the merchandise to illustrate what she called the <U+0089><db><cf>flood of hatred<U+0089><U+06DD> from Trump supporters. <U+0089><db><cf>I had left the State Department one of the most admired public servants in America,<U+0089><U+06DD> Clinton writes in the book. <U+0089><db><cf>Now people seemed to think I was evil. Not just <U+0089><db><f7>not my cup of tea<U+0089><U+06EA> but evil. It was flabbergasting and frightening.<U+0089><U+06DD> Click here to listen to the podcast episode in its entirety.
Title.x: Hillary Clinton: 'Nobody Said A Word' When It Was My Fake Severed Head
Title.y: Hillary Clinton: 'Nobody Said A Word' When It Was My Fake Severed Head

text: Suspicious ties between President Donald Trump and the Russian government just keep appearing. In 2015, a Russian-born real estate broker working for the Trump Organization, Felix Sater, reportedly wrote a series of emails to Michael Cohen, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyer, attempting to broker a deal for a Trump Tower in Moscow. Those emails, obtained by The New York Times on Monday, appear to indicate Sater<U+0089><U+06EA>s willingness to use a Moscow deal as a way to bolster a Trump presidency. <U+0089><db><cf>Our boy can become president of the USA and we can engineer it,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sater wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>I will get all of Putins [sic] team to buy in on this, I will manage this process.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I will get Putin on this program and we will get Donald elected,<U+0089><U+06DD> another email said, referring to Russian President Vladimir Putin. The deal in Moscow, spearheaded in 2015 while Trump was already running for president, was originally reported by The Washington Post on Sunday. In an additional story published Monday afternoon, the Post reported that Cohen reached out to a top aide to Putin for help on the deal, at Sater<U+0089><U+06EA>s recommendation. <U+0089><db><cf>As this project is too important, I am hereby requesting your assistance,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cohen wrote in an email to Dmitry Peskov, Putin<U+0089><U+06EA>s press secretary. <U+0089><db><cf>I respectfully request someone, preferably you, contact me so that I might discuss the specifics as well as arranging meetings with the appropriate individuals. I thank you in advance for your assistance and look forward to hearing from you soon.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sater reportedly suggested Trump visit Moscow, baiting him by claiming President Vladimir Putin could say <U+0089><db><cf>great things<U+0089><U+06DD> about Trump. Trump never ended up traveling to Moscow to pursue the deal, and Cohen says he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t either. <U+0089><db><cf>I ultimately determined that the proposal was not feasible and never agreed to make a trip to Russia,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cohen told The New York Times in a statement. Side-by-side Justice Department and congressional investigations are currently underway to determine whether Trump campaign aides colluded with Moscow to influence the 2016 election. The investigations are looking into a number of possible contacts, including a meeting Donald Trump Jr. organized in June 2016. That meeting was with a woman Trump Jr. and others had been told was a Russian government attorney who could provide documents that would <U+0089><db><cf>incriminate<U+0089><U+06DD> Hillary Clinton. This article has been updated with details about Michael Cohen reaching out to a Putin aide.
Title.x: Trump Associate Tried To Broker Moscow Deal So That 'Our Boy Can Become President'
Title.y: Trump Associate Tried To Broker Moscow Deal So That 'Our Boy Can Become President'

text: The White House <U+0089><U+06E5> the storied, 55,000-square-foot mansion that<U+0089><U+06EA>s housed America<U+0089><U+06EA>s first families for centuries <U+0089><U+06E5> is apparently not up to snuff for President Donald Trump . <U+0089><db><cf>That White House is a real dump,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump reportedly told members of his Trump National Golf Course in Bedminster, New Jersey, before teeing off recently. The remark was included in a lengthy Golf Magazine feature published Tuesday exploring Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s complicated relationship with the sport. The article also appears in the Aug. 7 issue of Sports Illustrated. But late Wednesday, after widespread criticism for his reported comment, Trump denied calling the White House <U+0089><db><cf>a dump,<U+0089><U+06DD> labeling the claim as <U+0089><db><cf>totally untrue.<U+0089><U+06DD> It<U+0089><U+06EA>s no secret that Trump enjoys spending time away from the White House at his own resorts. He<U+0089><U+06EA>s taken four trips to the Bedminster club since his inauguration, the feature noted. Another site tracking Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s leisure reports he has vacationed on 11 weekends out of the 28 in his presidency, costing taxpayers around $29 million . Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s predecessor, Barack Obama , commented that the White House <U+0089><db><d3> which was rebuilt in the early 1800s and has undergone regular renovations since, the most notable under the Truman administration <U+0089><db><d3><e5><ca>does show its age. But that<U+0089><U+06EA>s kind of the point, the former president wrote in his 2006 book, The Audacity of Hope. Here<U+0089><U+06EA>s how Obama described the first time he walked into the building as a freshman senator. The inside of the White House doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have the luminous quality that you might expect from TV or film; it seems well kept but worn, a big old house that one imagines might be a bit drafty on cold winter nights. Still, as I stood in the foyer and let my eyes wander down the corridors, it was impossible to forget the history that had been made there<U+0089><db><d3>John and Bobby Kennedy huddling over the Cuban missile crisis; FDR making last-minute changes to a radio address; Lincoln alone, pacing the halls and shouldering the weight of a nation. In a May interview with Time magazine, Trump praised the White House for its <U+0089><db><cf>beautiful kitchen,<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>amazing<U+0089><U+06DD> phone system and <U+0089><db><cf>incredible<U+0089><U+06DD> historical furniture. He patted himself on the back for appreciating it more than others might. <U+0089><db><cf>You have to be a certain type of person,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said as he led a tour of the house. <U+0089><db><cf>People have no idea the beauty of the White House. The real beauty of the White House.<U+0089><U+06DD> So what does Trump really think of his taxpayer-provided residence? He probably doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t filter himself when chatting with members of his New Jersey club, which <U+0089><db><cf>morphed into a kind of permanent campaign rally site<U+0089><U+06DD> during the election, the Golf Magazine feature<U+0089><U+06EA>s author Alan Shipnuck wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>Trump is often at his most unguarded among the people who pay for their proximity to him,<U+0089><U+06DD> the writer observed. This article has been updated to include Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweet late Wednesday denying the <U+0089><db><cf>dump<U+0089><U+06DD> comment.
Title.x: Trump Reportedly Calls White House 'A Real Dump'
Title.y: Trump Reportedly Calls White House 'A Real Dump'

text: President Donald Trump may be vacationing at his Mar-a-Lago estate, but he has dedicated part of his holiday weekend to berating top FBI officials. Trump on Saturday took aim at FBI deputy director Andrew McCabe, the second highest ranking official at the bureau who has received many political jabs from the Republican Party in recent years. McCabe faced more than 16 hours of questioning this week from several House committees about his role in the FBI<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigations into Russia<U+0089><U+06EA>s election meddling and Hillary Clinton<U+0089><U+06EA>s private email server, according to CNN. <U+0089><db><cf>How can [McCabe], the man in charge, along with leakin<U+0089><U+06EA> James Comey, of the Phony Hillary Clinton investigation (including her 33,000 illegally deleted emails) be given $700,000 for wife<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign by Clinton Puppets during investigation,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>the president tweeted Saturday. Trump also pointed out that McCabe may be retiring soon, as The Washington Post reported Saturday. Early Sunday morning,<e5><ca>he referenced a Fox News segment that reported that McCabe allegedly used <U+0089><db><cf>his FBI Official Email Account to promote<e5><ca>[Hillary Clinton<U+0089><U+06EA>s] campaign.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets were an apparent attempt to undermine McCabe<U+0089><U+06EA>s credibility in the wake of reports that FBI agent Peter Strzok had sent texts considered politically biased against Trump. Strzok had mentioned <U+0089><db><cf>Andy,<U+0089><U+06DD> which could be a reference to McCabe, in an August 2016 text message to FBI attorney Lisa Page. Some Republicans believe the text messages show a conspiracy to take down Trump , possibly involving McCabe, according to the Post. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets also rehashed an alleged controversy surrounding 2016 campaign donations made by Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, an ally of Hillary and Bill Clinton, to McCabe<U+0089><U+06EA>s wife, who was running for (and eventually lost) a seat in Virginia<U+0089><U+06EA>s Senate. Many Republicans found the donations suspicious and used it to draw ties between the Clintons and McCabe, who oversaw the FBI<U+0089><U+06EA>s Clinton email probe. They then called for McCabe<U+0089><U+06EA>s firing. McCabe had alerted a department ethics official when the donations were made, according to the Washington Post. Later Saturday, Trump shifted his attention to reports that FBI general counsel James Baker was being reassigned. According to the Post, which first reported the news, Baker<U+0089><U+06EA>s reassignment was FBI director Christopher A. Wray<U+0089><U+06EA>s attempt to assemble a new team of senior advisers while fending off GOP claims of political bias within the FBI. The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets echo the chorus of Republicans on Capitol Hill who have ramped up their criticism of the Department of Justice<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into ties between Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign and Russia. Democrats have denounced the Republican attacks on the FBI and Justice Department, claiming they are attempts from the right to interfere with Special Counsel Robert Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe. This story has been updated with Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Sunday morning tweet.
Title.x: Donald Trump Lashes Out Against Top FBI Officials Over Holiday Weekend
Title.y: Donald Trump Lashes Out Against Top FBI Officials Over Holiday Weekend

text: Anthony Scaramucci, the new White House communications director, used vulgar language while talking to a New Yorker reporter this week about White House chief of staff Reince Priebus and chief strategist Steve Bannon. The conversation with The New Yorker came after Ryan Lizza, a reporter for the publication, tweeted that he had learned from a source that President Donald Trump and Scaramucci would be dining with former Fox News executive Bill Shine and Fox News host Sean Hannity. Scaramucci asked Lizza who had leaked the information and then threatened to fire the entire White House communications office. <U+0089><db><cf>They<U+0089><U+06EA>ll all be fired by me,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said Wednesday, according to a New Yorker report published Thursday. <U+0089><db><cf>I fired one guy the other day. I have three to four people I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll fire tomorrow. I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll get to the person who leaked that to you. Reince Priebus<U+0089><db><d3>if you want to leak something<U+0089><db><d3>he<U+0089><U+06EA>ll be asked to resign very shortly.<U+0089><U+06DD> He also called Priebus a <U+0089><db><cf>paranoid schizophrenic, a paranoiac.<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci previously said he and Priebus are like brothers who <U+0089><db><cf> rough each other up once in a while .<U+0089><U+06DD> He also suggested during an interview with CNN on Thursday morning that Priebus was behind White House leaks . While talking with Lizza, Scaramucci also attacked Bannon and accused him of acting in his own self-interest. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not Steve Bannon, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not trying to suck my own cock,<U+0089><U+06DD> he told The New Yorker. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not trying to build my own brand off the fucking strength of the President. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m here to serve the country.<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci later addressed the interview on Twitter: And later, implied Lizza had breached his trust. The communications director reportedly received approval from Trump to attack Priebus publicly, and the White House has said the president is content with competition among top aides. Both Bannon and Priebus moved to block Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s appointment as communications director. This article has been updated with tweets from Scaramucci. CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article referred to Bill Shine as a Fox News host. He is a former executive of Fox News.
Title.x: Anthony Scaramucci Goes On Crass, Unhinged Rant Against Top White House Aides
Title.y: Anthony Scaramucci Goes On Crass, Unhinged Rant Against Top White House Aides

text: Contradicting U.S. intelligence agencies, President Donald Trump on Saturday said he believes Russian President Vladimir Putin<U+0089><U+06EA>s claim that the Kremlin did not attempt to interfere in the 2016 election. Trump spoke with the Russian leader this week in Vietnam during a joint summit with other Asia-Pacific countries. When a reporter asked if the subject of Russian election interference came up, Trump replied, <U+0089><db><cf>He said he absolutely did not meddle in our election. He did not do what they are saying he did. ... Every time he sees me, he says, <U+0089><db><f7>I didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t do that,<U+0089><U+06EA> and I really believe that when he tells me that, he means it. But he says, <U+0089><db><f7>I didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t do that.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also took multiple shots at his 2016 rival Hillary Clinton and lamented that Putin is<e5><U+0289><db><cf>very insulted<U+0089><U+06DD> by the accusations of election meddling. The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments fly in the face of a report from U.S. intelligence agencies earlier this year that concluded that Putin had ordered hacking against the Democratic National Committee as well as the deliberate spread of misinformation and inflammatory rhetoric about Clinton to help Trump get elected.<e5><ca>The effort is the subject of multiple federal investigations into whether the Trump campaign coordinated with Russia at all, which the president has strongly denied. Trump told reporters on Saturday that he was skeptical of the intelligence findings and spoke dismissively of several former top Obama officials with long careers in public service. <U+0089><db><cf>You hear it<U+0089><U+06EA>s 17 agencies [who agreed on the hacking]. Well, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s three,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>And one is [then-CIA Director John] Brennan. And one is, whatever. I mean, give me a break. They<U+0089><U+06EA>re political hacks. So you look at it, and then you have Brennan, you have [then-Director of National Intelligence James] Clapper and you have [then-FBI Director James] Comey. Comey<U+0089><U+06EA>s proven now to be a liar and he<U+0089><U+06EA>s proven to be a leaker. So you look at that.<U+0089><U+06DD> In a statement to CNN on Saturday, CIA Director Mike Pompeo <U+0089><db><d3> a Trump appointee <U+0089><U+06E5> stood by the agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s findings . <U+0089><db><cf>The Director stands by and has always stood by the January 2017 Intelligence Community Assessment entitled: Assessing Russian Activities and Intentions in Recent U.S. Elections,<U+0089><U+06DD> the agency said. <U+0089><db><cf>The intelligence assessment with regard to Russian election meddling has not changed.<U+0089><U+06DD> It<U+0089><U+06EA>s also worth noting that the number of intelligence agencies involved is four, not three : the CIA, the National Security Agency, the FBI and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. As The New York Times pointed out in July, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not problematic that the remaining agencies didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t report similar findings because <U+0089><db><cf>not all 17 were involved in the assessment of Russian interference.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump has largely refused to blame Putin for the hacking and even told reporters in July that he believes <U+0089><db><cf>other countries<U+0089><U+06DD> besides Russia were involved.<e5><ca>Early last month he missed a key deadline to implement new sanctions on Russia in response to the hacking, sanctions that were set forth in a bipartisan bill that he<U+0089><U+06EA>d signed into law in August.<e5><ca>Weeks later, Foreign Policy reported that the State Department had shuttered the office that deals with sanctions policy. Meanwhile, evidence is mounting that some in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign had ties to the Kremlin. Last month, former campaign manager Paul Manafort , along with his business associate Rick Gates , was indicted by a grand jury in connection with the investigation. At the same time, it was revealed that a former Trump adviser, George Papadopoulos , had pleaded guilty in early October to lying to FBI agents about his efforts to receive <U+0089><db><cf>dirt<U+0089><U+06DD> on Clinton. The story has been updated with additional comment from President Trump and CIA Director Mike Pompeo.
Title.x: Trump Sides With Putin Over U.S. Intelligence On Election Meddling
Title.y: Trump Sides With Putin Over U.S. Intelligence On Election Meddling

text: President Donald Trump said Friday that he had met with the president of the Virgin Islands to discuss hurricane relief efforts. Trump is the president of the U.S. Virgin Islands. Trump made the slip-up while addressing the Values Voter Summit in Washington, D.C., becoming the first sitting president to appear at the anti-LGBTQ event. He was likely referring to meetings and calls he had with U.S. Virgin Islands Gov. Kenneth Mapp. Trump on Friday addressed the U.S. government<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria. The storms left millions of Americans in ravaged areas, and some had no power or water for weeks. Puerto Rico received some of the worst damage from Maria, and local officials have repeatedly called for more help from the federal government. (Citizens of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are American citizens.) The president has been criticized for his response to the devastation in Puerto Rico. Much of the island has been without power in the weeks since Maria wreaked havoc there. Trump tweeted Thursday:<e5><U+0289><db><cf>We cannot keep FEMA, the Military & the First Responders... in P.R. forever!<U+0089><U+06DD> He seemed to walk back that comment Friday. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not even a question of a choice, we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t even want a choice. We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to be there as Americans,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said.
Title.x: Trump Says He Met With The President Of The Virgin Islands, Which Is... Trump
Title.y: Trump Says He Met With The President Of The Virgin Islands, Which Is... Trump

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s former national security adviser pleaded guilty Friday morning to lying to the FBI about his contacts with the Russian government, an extraordinary development in special counsel Robert Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Michael Flynn was charged with one count of making a false statement to FBI agents and appeared in federal court in D.C. In a criminal information filing from Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team, the government alleges that Flynn <U+0089><db><cf>willfully and knowingly made materially false, fictitious, and fraudulent statements<U+0089><U+06DD> in an interview with FBI agents on Jan. 24. It alleges he falsely told the FBI that he did not ask the Russian ambassador to refrain from retaliating to sanctions the Obama administration imposed on Russia in late December. Flynn also allegedly lied about asking the Russian ambassador on Dec. 22 to delay or defeat a pending United Nations Security Council resolution. Considering all of the additional charges Flynn could have faced in connection with his overseas dealings, the fact that he is facing only one charge is an indication that Flynn is offering significant cooperation and information that could further Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation. The Associated Press and Washington Post reported Friday that Flynn admitted in his plea that he spoke to the Russians at the direction of Trump transition team officials . In response to Friday morning<U+0089><U+06EA>s charge, Trump lawyer John Dowd told Wall Street Journal reporter Rebecca Ballhaus : <U+0089><db><cf>I have no reaction. I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know enough. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not worried about it.<U+0089><U+06DD> White House lawyer Ty Cobb said the plea implicates only Flynn. <U+0089><db><cf>The false statements involved mirror the false statements to White House officials which resulted in his resignation in February of this year,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cobb said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>Nothing about the guilty plea or the charge implicates anyone other than Mr. Flynn. The conclusion of this phase of the Special Counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s work demonstrates again that the Special Counsel is moving with all deliberate speed and clears the way for a prompt and reasonable conclusion.<U+0089><U+06DD> The New York Times reported in late November that Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyer, Robert Kelner, was no longer sharing information with Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s legal team , further raising the possibility that Flynn was cooperating with Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe. Kelner later met with the investigators , according to ABC News. Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s indictment follows Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team charging Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s former campaign chairman Paul Manafort and his former aide Rick Gates with 12 counts, including allegations of conspiracy against the U.S. and money laundering. Manafort and Gates pleaded not guilty to the charges and are scheduled to face a federal trial in May. In October, the investigators also reached a plea agreement with former Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos , who lied to the FBI about being offered <U+0089><db><cf>dirt<U+0089><U+06DD> on Hillary Clinton during the 2016 election.<e5><ca>Papadopoulos also reportedly suggested a meeting between then-candidate Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin last year. But those indictments involved only Trump campaign officials. Flynn is the first former administration official to be charged, making it more difficult for the White House to distance the president from Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe. After Trump fired then-FBI Director James Comey amid his investigation into the campaign, Comey testified that Trump had requested that he end the FBI<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into Flynn . Flynn, who stepped down as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s national security adviser in February after lying to administration officials about the extent of his communications with Russian officials, had long faced scrutiny from the multiple investigations into Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign . Of particular interest was Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s history of suspicious business dealings and financial ties to Russia, as well as his concealing that he worked as a foreign lobbyist for the Turkish government while advising Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign. In the fall of 2016,<e5><ca>a businessman with close ties to Turkey<U+0089><U+06EA>s autocratic President Recep Tayyip Erdogan paid Flynn more than $500,000 to conduct research aimed at discrediting the exiled cleric Fethullah G<cc>_len.<e5><ca>Flynn failed to disclose the work until March ,<e5><ca>after he had already stepped down as national security adviser. Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team has reportedly investigated Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s lobbying firm and its dealings with Turkey. Flynn also hid multiple contacts with Russia during Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s transition, including discussing sanctions with then-Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak. He also attended a meeting with Kislyak to discuss creating a backchannel with Putin . Also in attendance was Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s adviser and son-in-law Jared Kushner, who is now a senior White House adviser and also reportedly a subject of Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe. White House officials have repeatedly denied any collusion between Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s team and Russia, often by downplaying suspected officials<U+0089><U+06EA><e5><ca>involvement in the campaign or the administration. In March, then-press secretary Sean Spicer diminished Flynn as just <U+0089><db><cf>a volunteer.<U+0089><U+06DD> Alana Horowitz Satlin contributed reporting. This story has been updated with Flynn<U+0089><U+06EA>s guilty plea and responses to his charges.
Title.x: Former Trump Adviser Michael Flynn Pleads Guilty In Special Counsel's Russia Investigation
Title.y: Former Trump Adviser Michael Flynn Pleads Guilty In Special Counsel's Russia Investigation

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> When Donald Trump was elected president last year, a sweeping rewrite of the tax code was one of his top priorities. Throughout the campaign, Trump said he wanted a <U+0089><db><cf>middle-class tax cut,<U+0089><U+06DD> one that wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t benefit wealthy people like him and would spur huge levels of economic growth while not adding to the national debt. <U+0089><db><cf>For the hedge fund guys, they<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to be paying up,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump promised in September 2015 . As president, Trump has continued to insist the tax code overhaul won<U+0089><U+06EA>t be good for himself or other millionaires. <U+0089><db><cf>This is going to cost me a fortune, this thing <U+0089><U+06E5> believe me,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said this week . But the big winners in the GOP bill that the Senate passed early Saturday morning are corporations and the wealthy. Trump himself <U+0089><U+06E5> a self-proclaimed billionaire <U+0089><U+06E5> stands to gain millions through the elimination of certain taxes (though we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know exactly how much because Trump won<U+0089><U+06EA>t release his tax returns). Far from being a middle-class tax cut, the measure is a massive corporate giveaway, a bill that recycles decades of Republican ideology on trickle-down economics and trusts that executives will hand over their new gains to average-income workers. <U+0089><db><cf>If my friends here want to give a tax cut to the middle class,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) asked on the Senate floor Thursday, <U+0089><db><cf>why don<U+0089><U+06EA>t we give a tax cut to the middle class?<U+0089><U+06DD> His argument had no effect. After months of negotiations, the Senate passed the proposal, 51-49, with just one Republican <U+0089><U+06E5> Bob Corker of Tennessee <U+0089><U+06E5> joining all Democrats in opposition. Corker took issue with how much debt the bill would produce, and after the Senate parliamentarian struck down Corker<U+0089><U+06EA>s debt-control proposal , GOP leaders invited the retiring Republican to just vote no rather than finding him an accommodation. With the bill finally through the Senate <U+0089><U+06E5> the House passed its tax bill two weeks earlier <U+0089><U+06E5> the two chambers still have to work out their legislative differences in a conference committee before the tax rewrite becomes law. There<U+0089><U+06EA>s a slim chance the House could adopt the Senate bill and send it to the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s desk, but it<U+0089><U+06EA>s more likely that negotiators will merge the two versions. Both chambers need to pass the same measure for the bill to become law. For most Americans, the legislation is still indeed <U+0089><U+06E5> at least in the short term <U+0089><U+06E5> a tax cut. Those cuts are due in large part to Republicans approving $1.5 trillion in added debt over the next 10 years. But of that pie, the wealthy disproportionately benefit, and some households could wind up with higher tax bills. The richest 20 percent of households reap 90 percent of the benefit of the tax cuts over that time period, according to the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center . Still, in the short term, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s difficult to say exactly whose taxes go up and whose go down. Tax burdens depend on what deductions individual filers claim, and this bill is a complicated tax code rewrite <U+0089><U+06E5> one that analysts say will have limited impact on the economy, will cost the nation more than a trillion dollars over the next 10 years, and will do much more for rich investors than it will the middle class. Despite all that, despite poll after poll showing the measure is unpopular , most Republicans were ecstatic to pass the bill. While the bill took months to draft, the final package came together over a frenetic last few days .
