Republicans didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t even have finished legislative text until Friday night, hours before the vote, and Democrats slammed their GOP colleagues for rushing through a bill that was cobbled together with handwritten changes and crossed-out pages at the last minute. Those procedural concerns did nothing to slow the bill, however, with Republicans falling in line to vote down a Democratic motion to adjourn Friday night. Senators then began a so-called vote-a-rama,<e5><ca>in which amendments get up-or-down approval one after the other until lawmakers are exhausted enough to stop. Eventually, in the early hours of Saturday morning, senators moved to a final vote on the reconciliation bill, and it passed. To get the bill over the 50-vote threshold for reconciliation legislation, GOP leaders cut deals this week on how much certain businesses could deduct off the top of their tax bills, as well as on what would be included in an upcoming government funding measure. Sen. Susan Collins (R-Maine), for example, demanded that year-end spending legislation include funding for Obamacare subsidies that the Trump administration has targeted. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) said he got assurances on a contentious immigration program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, though Trump administration officials said Flake only got assurances on being part of the conversation. Overall, the legislation would cut the corporate tax rate from 35 to 20 percent, which has been the GOP<U+0089><U+06EA>s priority all along. Republicans say this dramatic reduction will unleash the economy and raise wages by making big businesses more internationally competitive <U+0089><U+06E5> claims that are dubious according to corporate executives themselves, who say they will throw the money at shareholders instead of workers. In addition to reducing corporate and individual tax rates across the board, the bill would simplify the tax code by getting rid of most deductions, which businesses and individuals use to reduce the amount of their income subject to taxation. Because Congress over the years has added write-offs in order to encourage and subsidize certain endeavors <U+0089><U+06E5> such as homeownership and higher education <U+0089><U+06E5> the mass elimination of these tax preferences could have wide-ranging effects that are incidental to the overall Republican goal of encouraging business investment. Axing deductions for state and local taxes, for instance, while increasing the value of a fixed <U+0089><db><cf>standard deduction,<U+0089><U+06DD> would result in far fewer households finding it worthwhile to deduct the amount they spend on mortgage interest. A study commissioned by the National Association of Realtors earlier this year said the proposal would reduce home values by 10 percent (which could be a good thing for people who don<U+0089><U+06EA>t already own homes). Republicans have long championed homeownership but have been undeterred by a lobbying blitz from the real estate industry. While fewer deductions makes for a simpler tax code, the bill would also create a complicated new deduction for certain businesses that aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t taxed as corporations. Determining which firms have the kind of <U+0089><db><cf>qualified business income<U+0089><U+06DD> eligible for the deduction will require many pages of new IRS regulation, though the bill explicitly excludes high-income service providers like accountants, lawyers and investment managers. In the day before the final vote, Republicans increased the value of the deduction to win over Sens. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) and Steve Daines (R-Mont.), both of whom had previously withheld support because they felt the legislation disproportionately benefited firms that pay the corporate tax. And in a catchall <U+0089><db><cf> manager<U+0089><U+06EA>s amendment <U+0089><U+06DD> adopted just before the bill passed, Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) added a provision to allow publicly traded partnerships to claim the new deduction. Victor Fleischer, a tax professor at the University of San Diego School of law, said t hat the Cornyn amendment would specifically benefit oil and gas companies. <U+0089><db><cf>We should all re-read <U+0089><db><f7>Why Nations Fail<U+0089><U+06EA> after this tax bill passes,<U+0089><U+06DD> Fleischer said on Twitter . Another provision in the manager<U+0089><U+06EA>s amendment, inserted by Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.), would have exempted schools that don<U+0089><U+06EA>t take federal funds, such as the conservative Hillsdale College in Michigan, from a new tax on college and university endowments. The tax seems designed less to raise money than to poke educated liberals in the eye. Several Republicans joined Democrats in defeating the amendment. Toomey<U+0089><U+06EA>s office did not respond to a request for comment. To keep the cost of the bill beneath $1.5 trillion <U+0089><U+06E5> an arbitrary level Republicans set for themselves in a budget process earlier this year <U+0089><U+06E5> almost all of the tax cuts for individuals expire at the end of 2025. Republicans say that expiration won<U+0089><U+06EA>t happen, noting that even President Barack Obama made nearly all of the Bush tax cuts permanent when they were up for reauthorization. But for all the GOP bluster about this bill being a tax cut for the middle class, and for all the rhetoric about the false necessity of making tax cuts permanent, the bill would keep the corporate tax rates the same while putting the individual rates up for expiration. Because of those temporary cuts, the Joint Committee on Taxation, which scores tax legislation for Congress, found that most households earning less than $75,000 annually would pay higher taxes 10 years from now. Just before debate began Friday night, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) said on the Senate floor that this day would be remembered as one of the <U+0089><db><cf>great robberies in U.S. history.<U+0089><U+06DD> CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story incorrectly reported that Toomey<U+0089><U+06EA>s Hillsdale carveout had been adopted. This story has also been updated to clarify which industry Fleischer says would benefit from Cornyn<U+0089><U+06EA>s amendment.
Title.x: Senate Passes Massive Tax Cuts For The Rich In Middle Of The Night
Title.y: Senate Passes Massive Tax Cuts For The Rich In Middle Of The Night

text: President Donald Trump was reluctant to send more troops to Afghanistan after years of saying the war was <U+0089><db><cf>wasting our money.<U+0089><U+06DD> So national security adviser H.R. McMaster used a 1972 photo of Afghan women in miniskirts to show the president that the country had once adopted Western values and to convince him to escalate the war, according to The Washington Post . McMaster reportedly showed Trump a black-and-white snapshot of bare-legged women in Kabul to illustrate that the region might be able to embrace Western ideals again.<e5><ca>Miniskirts were replaced by full-body burqas in the mid-1990s, when the Taliban took over Afghanistan, banned Western clothing and rolled back women<U+0089><U+06EA>s rights. The Taliban now controls only parts of the country, but many Afghan women still choose to wear traditional burqas because it makes them feel safer from violence and judgment in a society where gender-based violence is rampant. Trump has called the war in Afghanistan a <U+0089><db><cf>disaster<U+0089><U+06DD> and spent his entire presidential campaign criticizing the United States<U+0089><U+06EA><e5><ca>continued involvement in it. His former top adviser, Steve Bannon, also opposed sending more troops to the region and suggested relying on private military contractors instead. But after some urging from McMaster and other top generals, Trump ultimately changed his mind and decided to escalate troop levels by roughly 4,000 . <U+0089><db><cf>My original instinct was to pull out, and, historically, I like following my instincts,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said Monday in a televised address. <U+0089><db><cf>But all of my life I heard that decisions are much different when you sit behind the desk in the Oval Office.<U+0089><U+06DD> The miniskirt photo reportedly was not the only reason Trump decided to escalate the war, but the anecdote failed to surprise anyone familiar with Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s long history of objectifying women .
Title.x: H.R. McMaster Showed Trump Photo Of Afghan Women In Miniskirts To Escalate War
Title.y: H.R. McMaster Showed Trump Photo Of Afghan Women In Miniskirts To Escalate War

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><db><d3> It was Saturday night, and the Corner Pub in Brentwood, Tennessee, was bustling. Sports fans and families dug into a menu of chili cheese fries and hot chicken chunks. Servers offered Guinness and Caramel Apple bushwackers. Some people were wearing Halloween costumes. Then, sometime before 7:45 p.m., several dozen men and women dressed in black filed into the restaurant and took over a long table. In an adjoining room of the restaurant, Annelise Werme, a business owner from Murfreesboro,<e5><ca>30 miles away, noticed the group<U+0089><U+06EA>s attire. The hair on her neck stood up. <U+0089><db><cf>Our mayor and police chief advised we needed to prepare as if for a hurricane, hoping for the best but preparing for the worst,<U+0089><U+06DD> she told HuffPost in a Facebook message. <U+0089><db><cf>All of us who own businesses in our historic downtown closed, boarded up.<U+0089><U+06DD> Near the large group, a 30-year-old white woman and a 37-year-old black man were sitting at a table. Several men from the large group started talking to them, another restaurant patron told HuffPost in a phone interview. (He declined to be named, citing safety and privacy concerns.) <U+0089><db><cf>They were talking about what was good on the menu,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>the patron recalled, noting that a guy in the group <U+0089><db><cf>wanted anything that was fried.<U+0089><U+06DD> Then, his wife added, <U+0089><db><cf>some words were exchanged. I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know what was said, but the black man ... he was visibly upset.<U+0089><U+06DD> One member of the black-clad group asked the 30-year-old woman to <U+0089><db><cf>guess,<U+0089><U+06DD> the woman said later , possibly about who they were. <U+0089><db><cf>White lives matter,<U+0089><U+06DD> she responded. <U+0089><db><cf>That<U+0089><U+06EA>s right,<U+0089><U+06DD> another member said, then he allegedly urged her to join their table and leave her male friend. <U+0089><db><cf>They immediately started taunting her for being with a black man,<U+0089><U+06DD> Werme said. <U+0089><db><cf>Understandably, she was extremely upset.<U+0089><U+06DD> The argument escalated even after the woman went outside. The big group got up to leave. <U+0089><db><cf>They didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t place an order or anything, they were looking for a place to cause some trouble,<U+0089><U+06DD> the first patron said, noting that one person with the group quickly took out a professional camera complete with a shotgun mic. <U+0089><db><cf>We thought it was all over at that point,<U+0089><U+06DD> his wife said. But about a minute later, they noticed a fight starting outside. Jerry Grim, manager of the Corner Pub,<e5><ca>told HuffPost that his business called the police right away. <U+0089><db><cf>I didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know who they were. They were just a group of men in black puffy jackets. They had no tags, no markers, nothing on them. It could have been anybody.<U+0089><U+06DD> In fact, white supremacists, including neo-Nazis and Klan members, had rallied earlier Saturday in Shelbyville, about an hour away. But they skipped a planned rally in Murfreesboro after being delayed by security in Shelbyville and hearing that nearly 1,000 counter-protesters awaited them . They tried to gather in a nearby park <U+0089><db><d3> managing to form a human swastika <U+0089><db><d3> but ran when they heard that antifascists might show up,<e5><ca>and they had to bail on a planned tiki-torch march. Now a contingent of the white supremacist group had made its way to the restaurant. <U+0089><db><cf>One of our guys was getting his jacket, and words were exchanged,<U+0089><U+06DD> Matthew Heimbach, a prominent neo-Nazi, told Mic reporter Jack Smith IV. He blamed <U+0089><db><cf>the black gentleman<U+0089><U+06DD> for starting the confrontation. But video from the incident shows a large group of white men brawling and a woman, with blood dripping down her face, pushed against the window of the sports bar. Inside, some people started to record the fight on their phones, and the environment grew tense as bystanders argued about whether to intervene. <U+0089><db><cf>Do you want me to go out there and get beat up? Would that be better?<U+0089><U+06DD> A man asked. <U+0089><db><cf>Oh, my God ... she<U+0089><U+06EA>s bleeding,<U+0089><U+06DD> a man said. <U+0089><db><cf>We were afraid someone was going to be thrown through the window,<U+0089><U+06DD> the unnamed patron<U+0089><U+06EA>s wife told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>It was terrifying.... We didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know if anyone had weapons [or] how far this was going to escalate.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Do you speak up? Do you step in and get involved?<U+0089><U+06DD> her husband said. <U+0089><db><cf>It was kind of difficult to judge what was best to do, because it was a quickly escalating situation. My thought was not to go and make it worse.<U+0089><U+06DD> By the time police arrived, everyone had dispersed. The 30-year-old woman later came back to make a report. Authorities are looking for the man accused of punching her, described as a white man in his 30s wearing a black jacket and black jeans, according to an Oct. 29 statement from the Metropolitan Nashville Police Department that includes the woman<U+0089><U+06EA>s account of the incident. (The names of the victims have not been publicly released.) Heimbach said , <U+0089><db><cf>The confrontation wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t any of us.<U+0089><U+06DD> The woman who made the report said she is still shaken. <U+0089><db><cf>We as Americans need to open our eyes and come together to stop this injustice and hate,<U+0089><U+06DD> the victim told Fox 17 in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>I was terrified, and still am.<U+0089><U+06DD> Luke O<U+0089><U+06EA>Brien contributed reporting.
Title.x: A Black Man And A White Woman Sat Down At A Pub. Then The White Supremacists Showed Up.
Title.y: A Black Man And A White Woman Sat Down At A Pub. Then The White Supremacists Showed Up.

text: Barack Obama will always be a baby whisperer. Jolene Jackinsky was in at the Anchorage International Airport when she thought she spotted a man who bore a striking resemblance to the former president, The Associated Press reports . The mother was walking toward the man in a waiting area for private planes, and soon, Jackinsky knew she had the real deal. <U+0089><db><cf>As I got closer, I thought: Oh my God, it is Obama,<U+0089><U+06DD> Jackinsky told the AP. And, as if from a dream, Obama came up to her and asked about her adorable 6-month-old daughter, Giselle. <U+0089><db><cf>Who is this pretty girl?<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama reportedly said. We wish we all could be so lucky during our travels. Obviously, like any good mother, Jackinsky snapped photos of Obama and her daughter. Giselle, with her wide eyes, reacted no different than the rest of us if we were graced with such a chance encounter. In fact, she may have been more composed than any of us would have been. The former president certainly has a special relationship with children. During his presidency, he was photographed dozens of times with kids who were in total awe of him. And now we can be constantly reminded of that fact. Former White House photographer Pete Souza was thankfully there to capture what are arguably Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s most adorable baby moments . And now he posts them to Instagram in really sweet throwbacks. Lucky, lucky babes. Giselle<U+0089><U+06EA>s encounter with Obama was quick, but it could have been a much sweeter deal. Apparently when her father approached, Obama joked that he was going to steal his baby. Maybe now that Malia and Sasha are about to leave the nest, the former president has some baby fever.
Title.x: A Mom Spotted Barack Obama In An Airport And Her Baby Was Too Excited
Title.y: A Mom Spotted Barack Obama In An Airport And Her Baby Was Too Excited

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><db><d3> A journalist who revealed the racist, anti-Semitic internet troll behind the CNN beat-down video that President Donald Trump shared says he<U+0089><U+06EA>s facing a barrage of death threats. And he warns that the president is fueling a violent, anti-media conversation online. Jared Yates Sexton , a New York Times contributor and assistant professor of creative writing at Georgia Southern University, shared with HuffPost several threatening messages directed at him since he unmasked the troll Sunday. In one, a Reddit user warns of a looming <U+0089><db><cf>journocaust<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><d3> presumably a holocaust for journalists. In another, a Twitter user says there<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>a civil war coming<U+0089><U+06DD> and that memes <U+0089><db><d3> specifically, the antisemitic one by the creator of the video that Trump shared <U+0089><db><d3> are <U+0089><db><cf>the least<U+0089><U+06DD> of Sexton<U+0089><U+06EA>s problems. <U+0089><db><cf>There<U+0089><U+06EA>s a fever pitch to this dialogue that is dangerous to everybody,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sexton told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>And it<U+0089><U+06EA>s the people who are mentally ill, who are unhinged, who are unwell <U+0089><db><d3> they pick up on this stuff. And they are really, really moved to act by it.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>If we keep this up, there<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to be more consequences,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added. <U+0089><db><cf>That<U+0089><U+06EA>s just a fact.<U+0089><U+06DD> The GIF surfaced last week under the Reddit thread <U+0089><db><cf> Trump takes down fake news <U+0089><U+06DD> and appears to have been created by user <U+0089><db><cf>HanAssholeSolo.<U+0089><U+06DD> It is from a 2007 wrestling clip of then-reality TV star Trump tackling and punching WWE owner Vince McMahon . Superimposed over McMahon<U+0089><U+06EA>s head in the GIF, however, is the logo of CNN, a news outlet Trump repeatedly attacks and refers to as <U+0089><db><cf>fake news.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump posted a slightly edited version of the clip to Twitter on Sunday morning, which the official @POTUS account retweeted. The video has been widely viewed as the latest example of Trump endorsing violence against the media, which he has called <U+0089><db><cf> the enemy of the American people .<U+0089><U+06DD> Following Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweet, Sexton revealed in a series of posts to Twitter that HanAssholeSolo has an ugly history of online racism and anti-Semitism. Having written about the rampant homophobia, misogyny and racism at Trump rallies along the campaign trail,<e5><ca>Sexton is no stranger to online harassment. But after he exposed the type of person Trump had elevated,<e5><ca>Sexton said neo-Nazis and nihilists <U+0089><db><cf>came out of the woodwork.<U+0089><U+06DD> This violent internet culture is nothing new.<e5><ca>What has changed, Sexton told HuffPost, is many in this world feel empowered by and have found a hero of sorts in Trump. And many have embraced the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s clear hatred of the press, with calls for bloodshed and civil war. <U+0089><db><cf>I think a lot of these people have a shared idea that this would be a time where they would basically be able to kill liberals,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sexton said. <U+0089><db><cf>With a little bit of research what I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve found is there are large online havens where they talk about widespread murder of journalists. They fantasize about killing them in the streets, like a revolution. They have terms for it, like <U+0089><db><f7>day of the rope.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Sexton has tweeted extensively in the wake of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s controversial post. He warned about the possibility of Trump getting someone killed . He noted that a little over a month ago, Greg Gianforte, the millionaire Republican running for Montana<U+0089><U+06EA>s open congressional seat, was charged with misdemeanor assault after attacking a reporter <U+0089><db><d3> and went on to win the election the very next day. And he said the president is <U+0089><db><cf> giving power and voice to antisemitic people and emboldening them and their dangerous conspiracies.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sexton said he<U+0089><U+06EA>s been subjected to an <U+0089><db><cf>overwhelming<U+0089><U+06DD> amount of harassment. On Monday, he posted a series of tweets about what journalists are up against in 2017. <U+0089><db><cf>This environment is the creation of the man in the White House. There are valid criticisms of the media, many on point, this isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t that,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added on Twitter. <U+0089><db><cf>When you start calling a group of people enemies of the country, this is what happens. When you call them scum, this happens.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be a country where these violent instincts are cultivated and encouraged,<U+0089><U+06DD> he continued. <U+0089><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re at a real tipping point right now.<e5><ca>But make no mistake, there<U+0089><U+06EA>s something growing in this country, and it is very, very ugly.<U+0089><U+06DD> While Sexton<U+0089><U+06EA>s inbox and Twitter account were being flooded with threats, HanAssholeSolo was basking in their newfound internet glory. <U+0089><db><cf> Holy shit!! ,<U+0089><U+06DD> the user wrote on Reddit following Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s endorsement. <U+0089><db><cf>I wake up and have my morning coffee and who retweets my shitpost but the MAGA EMPORER himself!!!<e5><ca>I am honored!!<U+0089><U+06DD> Many other Trump-supporting Reddit users extended congratulations , with one admirer calling HanAssholeSolo a <U+0089><db><cf>legend.<U+0089><U+06DD> By sharing the meme, Trump has<e5><U+0289><db><cf>given more power to an obvious racist, anti-Semite and misogynist,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sexton told HuffPost; he has sent a clear message that such behavior is acceptable. In a response, CNN said it<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>a sad day when the president of the United States encourages violence against reporters.<U+0089><U+06DD> It called the tweet <U+0089><db><cf>juvenile behavior far below the dignity of his office.<U+0089><U+06DD> CNN commentator Ana Navarro went a step further, warning Trump <U+0089><db><cf> is going to get somebody killed in the media . Maybe that will stop him.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Washington Post also looked into the Reddit user<U+0089><U+06EA>s disturbing history, noting a post in which he or she claimed to carry <U+0089><db><cf>punch blades<U+0089><U+06DD> while traveling in Paris, in case <U+0089><db><cf>any of those Islamic fucks tried shit with me would get an immediate punch to the neck with 2 inches of titanium embedded in their throat.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Anti-Defamation League <U+0089><U+06EA>s Center on Extremism, which tracks extremism and hate online and offline, analyzed the Reddit account and found<e5><U+0289><db><cf>an 18-month record of vile comments and memes against Muslims, African-Americans, Jews and others.<U+0089><U+06DD> Although not much is known about the person, ADL said some posts indicate the user is<e5><U+0289><db><cf>a parent and a veteran in his 40s living in Tennessee.<U+0089><U+06DD> The organization compiled a number of the user<U+0089><U+06EA>s disturbing posts. <U+0089><db><cf>In an online culture where sharing of memes and comments is the ultimate validation, this obvious purveyor of hate has been elevated by what can be considered the ultimate share,<U+0089><U+06DD> the group wrote. Sexton said he<U+0089><U+06EA>s becoming increasingly concerned about the long-term effects of such hateful discourse. <U+0089><db><cf>It might be a couple of generations before we actually understand how much damage has been wrought here and what the long-term consequences are,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>Some of it is violent and some of it is social and personal. We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to find out in the long run what this has done and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s probably going to be significant.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Journalist Who Exposed The Racist Creator Of Trumps CNN Tweet Gets Death Threats
Title.y: Journalist Who Exposed The Racist Creator Of Trumps CNN Tweet Gets Death Threats

text: Donald Trump promised a <U+0089><db><cf>major speech<U+0089><U+06DD> attacking campaign rival Hillary Clinton last June, just hours after his son, Donald Trump Jr., set up a meeting with a Russian lawyer he was told had compromising information on the Democratic candidate. In a speech on June 7, 2016, first flagged by Washington Post reporter Philip Bump, then-candidate Trump promised vaguely to discuss <U+0089><db><cf>all the things that have taken place with the Clintons.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I am going to give a major speech on probably Monday of next week, and we<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to be discussing all of the things that have taken place with the Clintons,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said at the time. <U+0089><db><cf>I think you<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to find it very informative and very, very interesting. I wonder if the press will want to attend. Who knows?<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s promise of big Clinton news came four days after his eldest son was contacted by publicist Rob Goldstone about information obtained by the Russian government that would be damaging to Clinton, according to emails Trump Jr. released Tuesday. Trump Jr.<U+0089><U+06EA>s emails show that Goldstone offered a meeting with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya, who Goldstone said had information on Clinton that was <U+0089><db><cf>part of Russia and its government<U+0089><U+06EA>s support for Mr. Trump.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump Jr. replied simply: <U+0089><db><cf>If it<U+0089><U+06EA>s what you say I love it.<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>A meeting between the two was set up for several days later, confirming the timing via email around 5 p.m. on June 7. Hours later, his father began the speech. Trump Jr. later met with the lawyer in a session that included the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, and then-campaign chairman Paul Manafort. Trump Jr. said he did not tell his father about the meeting . Donald Trump failed to follow through on his campaign promise to reveal dirt on Clinton.<e5><ca>He instead focused a June 13 event in New Hampshire on national security issues. The Post noted he pledged to reveal damning information on Clinton at a later date. A hacker, which U.S. intelligence agencies have linked to Russia , began releasing emails stolen from the Democratic National Committee on June 15, 2016. The intelligence agencies say the Kremlin actively worked to influence the presidential election in favor of Trump under the direction of President Vladimir Putin.
Title.x: Trump Teased Major News On Clinton Hours After Don Jr. Set Meeting On Russian Dirt
Title.y: Trump Teased Major News On Clinton Hours After Don Jr. Set Meeting On Russian Dirt

text: Alabama state officials on Thursday officially declared Democrat Doug Jones the winner of its special Senate election, after Republican opponent Roy Moore tried to launch a last-minute effort to contest the outcome. Less than an hour before, an Alabama judge rejected Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawsuit attempting to delay certification of the results, saying that the court did not have the jurisdiction to rule in the case . According to The Associated Press , the suit was filed in Montgomery Circuit Court on Wednesday night, with Moore requesting that the state delay the certification of the election results, launch a fraud investigation and hold a new election. Jones later filed a motion to dismiss Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawsuit. Alabama Secretary of State John Merrill (R) said Thursday morning that he had no plans to delay declaring Jones the winner that afternoon. <U+0089><db><cf>The short answer to that is no,<U+0089><U+06DD> Merrill told CNN . <U+0089><db><cf>Doug Jones will be certified today.<U+0089><U+06DD> After state officials certified the election results, Jones said in a statement that he is <U+0089><db><cf>looking forward to going to work for the people of Alabama in the new year.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore later issued a defiant statement, again blaming <U+0089><db><cf>Democrats<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>the Washington establishment<U+0089><U+06DD> for his loss, and claiming without evidence that <U+0089><db><cf>election fraud experts across the country have agreed that this was a fraudulent election.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I have stood for the truth about God and the Constitution for the people of Alabama,<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore said. <U+0089><db><cf>I have no regrets. To God be the glory.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore lost the Dec. 12 contest to fill Attorney General Jeff Sessions <U+0089><U+06EA> vacated Senate seat to Democratic candidate Jones. During the contentious campaign, the former judge faced accusations of sexual harassment and misconduct from multiple women who claimed he preyed on them when they were teenagers and he was in his 30s. Moore, who was twice removed from the Alabama Supreme Court for failure to follow judicial orders, largely disappeared from the campaign trail in the days leading up to the election. Although the Republican National Committee originally withdrew its formal support of Moore, the party decided to once again fund his campaign after President Donald Trump officially endorsed him . Still, Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s critics urged voters to choose someone else. Just before the election, Sen. Richard Shelby (R-Ala.) announced that he did not vote for Moore . <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>d rather see the Republican win, but I<U+0089><U+06EA>d rather see a Republican write-in,<U+0089><U+06DD> Shelby told CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s Jake Tapper about the vote he cast two days before the special election. Jones,<e5><ca>a civil rights advocate and former prosecutor , ultimately won the race by about 20,000 votes. Following the stunning victory , Jones became Alabama<U+0089><U+06EA>s first Democratic senator in 25 years. In the complaint filed Wednesday, Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyers said they are certain voter fraud occurred, and that the only question is whether there was enough to sway the election. Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyers did not elaborate on exactly how they believe fraud occurred. The complaint repeatedly accuses Merrill of not doing enough to investigate voter fraud, but Merrill said Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign had not informed his office of specific allegations to investigate. Merrill said the first he heard about the allegations was late Wednesday evening, shortly before midnight . <U+0089><db><cf>I did read them. We take all allegations very seriously and we investigate all allegations that are introduced to us,<U+0089><U+06DD> Merrill said in a text message. <U+0089><db><cf>There<U+0089><U+06EA>s also a process for introducing them to us which requires that the complainant complete the form on www.stopvoterfraudnow.com .<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s complaint cites a viral interview with a man the night of the election who indicated in an off-the-cuff comment that people from all over the country had come to vote and canvass for Jones in Alabama. After tracking down the man in the video and determining he was a registered voter in the state, Merrill declared the case was <U+0089><db><cf>nailed shut.<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore, however, says Merrill should have done more to investigate the claim. The suit also alleges that large numbers of out-of-state voters came to Alabama and illegally voted in the election. It includes a sworn affidavit from a poll worker saying she had never seen so many people vote with out-of-state driver<U+0089><U+06EA>s licenses. Alabama law permits people to vote with a state-issued ID from any state . As a supposed example of voter fraud, the complaint also cited an incident where sample ballots filled out for Jones were on display in a probate judge<U+0089><U+06EA>s office prior to the election. The ballots were removed after a complaint from Moore, and Merrill said he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe the incident was a case of voter fraud . Moore also claimed there was Democratic <U+0089><db><cf>voter intimidation<U+0089><U+06DD> in the race, pointing to a super PAC ad that incorrectly told Alabamians their votes would be a matter of public record. Google removed the ad from the internet before the election after Merrill complained. Moore also took aim at the higher-than-expected turnout in Jefferson County, the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s most populous, saying it was <U+0089><db><cf>inexplicably substantially higher<U+0089><U+06DD> than places in other parts of the state. Moore implied it was suspicious that turnout in the race far exceeded what was projected. He also pointed to 20 precincts in Jefferson County where he received substantially less of the vote share than the Republican Party. Read the complaint below: This article has been updated throughout. Sam Levine contributed reporting.
Title.x: Doug Jones Officially Declared Winner Of Alabama Senate Election After Judge Rejects Roy Moore Lawsuit
Title.y: Doug Jones Officially Declared Winner Of Alabama Senate Election After Judge Rejects Roy Moore Lawsuit

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><db><d3> Lawyers for Donald Trump , spurred by the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s own inquiries,<e5><ca>are exploring his power to grant pardons <U+0089><db><d3> to aides, family and himself <U+0089><db><d3> as a means of undermining special counsel Robert Mueller <U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election, The Washington Post reports . The Post, citing an unnamed source familiar with the queries, said the president himself had asked advisers about the constitutional power, although another source noted that Trump sought only to further his understanding of the privilege.<e5><ca>Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyer John Dowd called the claims <U+0089><db><cf> nonsense .<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyers are also looking into Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s potential conflicts of interests, perhaps as a way of removing him from the Justice Department<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation, according to a Post article that cited several of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s legal advisers. Also on Thursday, various outlets reported Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s longtime personal attorney and lead counsel on the Russia investigation, Marc Kasowitz, would be stepping into a smaller role . Kasowitz made headlines last week after he threatened a stranger in a string of profane emails, saying things like <U+0089><db><cf>watch your back, bitch,<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m on you.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump has reportedly been unhappy with some members of his legal team following a series of revelations involving his son Donald Trump Jr. HuffPost has reached out to Kasowitz for comment. Mark Corallo, the spokesman for Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s team of personal lawyers, resigned Thursday, the Post and Times reported. The New York Times also reported on the Trump team<U+0089><U+06EA>s inquiries, which it described as <U+0089><db><cf>wide-ranging,<U+0089><U+06DD> including <U+0089><db><cf>scrutinizing donations to Democratic candidates<U+0089><U+06DD> and looking into investigators<U+0089><U+06EA> former clients and Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s relationship with former FBI Director James Comey. Trump fired Comey in May while he was leading an investigation into whether Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign colluded with Russia. Trump later admitted he was thinking about the Russia investigation when he decided to dismiss the FBI director. Among the potential conflicts of interest that Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyers are looking at is an alleged dispute over membership fees between Mueller and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Virginia golf club, according to the Post. Earlier Thursday , Bloomberg reported that Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team is examining transactions involving the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s businesses and those of his associates, including <U+0089><db><cf>Russian purchases of apartments in Trump buildings , Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s involvement in a controversial SoHo development with Russian associates, the 2013 Miss Universe pageant in Moscow and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s sale of a Florida mansion to a Russian oligarch in 2008.<U+0089><U+06DD> CBS News later confirmed the report, and the Wall Street Journal said the investigation includes potential money laundering by Paul Manafort , who was Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign manager during part of the 2016 presidential campaign. Manafort is scheduled to testify before Congress on July 26 , as will the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s eldest son, Donald Trump Jr. In a lengthy interview Wednesday in The New York Times, Trump said Mueller would be crossing a <U+0089><db><cf> red line <U+0089><U+06DD> if he looked into the Trump family<U+0089><U+06EA>s finances beyond any ties with Russia. Eric Holder, who was an attorney general in the Obama administration, tweeted Thursday night that there was no valid reason to question Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation:
Title.x: Trump Asks About Pardons As Lawyers Look At Ways to Derail Mueller Probe
Title.y: Trump Asks About Pardons As Lawyers Look At Ways to Derail Mueller Probe

text: President Donald Trump appeared to claim credit for booming house sales on Thursday, but folks online weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t having it. With sales of existing homes in the U.S. hitting their highest level in more than a decade, Trump shared this message on Twitter: Trump didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t explicitly suggest he was responsible for the boost, but fellow tweeters believed he was giving off that impression by using his MAGA slogan. Many responded by thanking former President Barack Obama , whose policies would have led to the jump. Others questioned why booming house sales were a good thing given how previous soaring numbers ultimately led to the 2008 global financial crisis:
Title.x: Tweeters Refuse To Let Donald Trump Take Credit For Booming House Sales

text: Former President George H.W. Bush said he was sorry after actress Heather Lind accused him of sexually assaulting her during a TV show promotion in 2014. <U+0089><db><cf>President Bush would never <U+0089><db><d3> under any circumstance <U+0089><db><d3> intentionally cause anyone distress, and he most sincerely apologizes if his attempt at humor offended Ms. Lind,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Jim McGrath, a Bush spokesman, told HuffPost Wednesday in a statement. Later Wednesday, Bush<U+0089><U+06EA>s office issued a second statement saying that the former president<e5><U+0289><db><cf>has patted women<U+0089><U+06EA>s rears in what he intended to be a good-natured manner<U+0089><U+06DD> and that because he is confined to a wheelchair, <U+0089><db><cf>his arm falls on the lower waist of people with whom he takes pictures.<U+0089><U+06DD> See the full statement below: In a now-deleted Instagram post on Tuesday, Lind said she posed with Bush, who was in a wheelchair, for a photo-op during a private screening in Houston of her AMC television series, <U+0089><db><cf>Turn: Washington<U+0089><U+06EA>s Spies.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf> He sexually assaulted me ,<U+0089><U+06DD> she wrote in the post,<e5><ca>according to reports. <U+0089><db><cf>He didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t shake my hand,<U+0089><U+06DD> Lind wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>He touched me from behind from his wheelchair with his wife Barbara Bush by his side. He told me a dirty joke. And then, all the while being photographed, touched me again. Barbara rolled her eyes as if to say <U+0089><db><f7>not again.<U+0089><U+06EA> His security guard told me I shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have stood next to him for the photo.<U+0089><U+06DD> A second woman , actress Jordana Grolnick, recounted a similar story to Deadspin. <U+0089><db><cf>We all circled around him and Barbara for a photo, and I was right next to him,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>He reached his right hand around to my behind, and as we smiled for the photo he asked the group, <U+0089><db><f7>Do you want to know who my favorite magician is?<U+0089><U+06EA> As I felt his hand dig into my flesh, he said, <U+0089><db><f7>David Cop-a-Feel!<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Lind said she has learned to use her own personal power against those who wield theirs inappropriately. <U+0089><db><cf> It seems to me a President<U+0089><U+06EA>s power is in his or her capacity to enact positive change, actually help people, and serve as a symbol of our democracy. He relinquished that power when he used it against me and, judging from the comments of those around him, countless other women before me. What comforts me is that I too can use my power, which isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t so different from a President really.<U+0089><U+06DD> Lind said she was moved to recount the experience after seeing a photo of the 93-year-old Bush with former President Barack Obama at the One America Appeal hurricane relief concert. She said she was disturbed that Bush was afforded such reverence. Lind<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusation follows a slew of recent public sexual harassment and assault allegations against film executive Harvey Weinstein, director James Toback and others. Several women have accused President Donald Trump of sexual assault. Trump has denied the allegations. Need help? Visit RAINN<U+0089><U+06EA>s National Sexual Assault Online Hotline or the National Sexual Violence Resource Center<U+0089><U+06EA>s website . This article was updated to include a second statement from George H.W. Bush<U+0089><U+06EA>s office.
Title.x: George H.W. Bush Apologizes After Actress Says He Sexually Assaulted Her
Title.y: George H.W. Bush Apologizes After Actress Says He Sexually Assaulted Her

text: Senators killed the GOP<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>skinny<U+0089><U+06DD> Obamacare repeal bill, called the Health Care Freedom Act of 2017 , in a 49-51 vote early Friday morning. The bill would have eliminated the penalty on people who decline to get insurance, thereby removing a piece of Obamacare that has long drawn conservative ire. It also would have suspended the medical device tax for three years while allowing greater contributions into Health Savings Accounts. And the bill would have made it easier for states to get waivers from the federal government, giving them a little more leeway to redirect money that<U+0089><U+06EA>s supposed to help people buy health insurance. The precise effect of that particular provision is a little unclear . GOP leaders tried to assure caucus members the point of the bill was merely to push the process along <U+0089><U+06E5> to get the debate to the next stage, so that House and Senate leaders can negotiate and come up with a bill that<U+0089><U+06EA>s acceptable to both chambers. But that promise wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t enough for three Republican senators, including Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), who cast one of the crucial no votes that doomed the bill. Read more updates below:
Title.x: Read The Latest Updates On The Senate's Health Care Voting Frenzy
Title.y: Read The Latest Updates On The Senate's Health Care Voting Frenzy

text: CNN ended its relationship with political commentator Jeffrey Lord after he tweeted <U+0089><db><cf>Sieg Heil<U+0089><U+06DD> on Thursday. <U+0089><db><cf>Nazi salutes are indefensible,<U+0089><U+06DD> a CNN spokesperson said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>Jeffrey Lord is no longer with the network.<U+0089><U+06DD> The tweet was directed at Angelo Carusone , the president of Media Matters for America. Lord wrote an op-ed calling Media Matters a <U+0089><db><cf>fascist<U+0089><U+06DD> group for launching a campaign to get advertisers to pull their support for Fox News<U+0089><U+06EA> Sean Hannity. Lord reportedly told The New York Times that he was in a CNN car when he learned he was fired. He also spoke with CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s Brian Stelter after his firing Thursday. <U+0089><db><cf>I love CNN,<U+0089><U+06DD> Lord said. <U+0089><db><cf>I feel like they are caving to bullies here.<U+0089><U+06DD> Lord also appeared to make light of the situation late Thursday, in his first tweet since the announcement that he<U+0089><U+06EA>d been fired. Yashar Ali, a journalist who has written for HuffPost, tweeted that representatives from MSNBC, NBC and Fox News had confirmed they weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t hiring Lord. Lord joined CNN as a political commentator in 2015 and was known for his provocative and unabashed support of President Donald Trump . He once called Trump the <U+0089><db><cf>Martin Luther King of health care,<U+0089><U+06DD> later arguing he did it <U+0089><db><cf> deliberately and with reason .<U+0089><U+06DD> But his inflammatory statements weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t limited to his defenses of Trump. Among other things, Lord once claimed <U+0089><db><cf> there are no people of color <U+0089><U+06DD> in America, called the Ku Klux Klan a <U+0089><db><cf>leftist<U+0089><U+06DD> organization and argued singer Ariana Grande was partly to blame for the terrorist attack at her concert in the United Kingdom. CNN host Anderson Cooper infamously criticized Lord in May when he argued Lord would defend Trump <U+0089><db><cf>if he took a dump on his desk.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cooper later apologized for the comment. This story has been updated. Matt Ferner contributed to this report.
Title.x: CNN Cuts Ties With Jeffrey Lord After Nazi Salute Tweet
Title.y: CNN Cuts Ties With Jeffrey Lord After Nazi Salute Tweet

text: As the official start of the <U+0089><db><cf> Unite the Right <U+0089><U+06DD> rally kicked off in Charlottesville, Virginia, former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke said the gathering of white supremacists, neo-Nazis and far-right individuals pointed to a future fulfillment of President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>promises.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This represents a turning point for the people of this country,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Duke in video uploaded to Twitter by Indianapolis Star photojournalist Mykal McEldowney. <U+0089><db><cf>We are determined to take our country back. We are going to fulfill the promises of Donald Trump. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s what we believed in, that<U+0089><U+06EA>s why we voted for Donald Trump. Because he said he<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to take our country back. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s what we gotta do.<U+0089><U+06DD> In a tweet, Trump condemned <U+0089><db><cf>hate<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>violence<U+0089><U+06DD> in response to clashes at the rally on Saturday, though he did not call out white supremacists in particular. Duke responded to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweet by stating that Trump should <U+0089><db><cf>remember<U+0089><U+06DD> that <U+0089><db><cf>White Americans<U+0089><U+06EA> were the ones to put him in office. Duke, a former KKK Grand Wizard, has long connected his message of white supremacy to ideas espoused by the president. During the presidential campaign, Duke stated that he and Trump had similar messages,<e5><ca>pointing to Trump proposing policies like a border wall or Muslim ban. <U+0089><db><cf>Donald Trump is talking implicitly. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m talking explicitly,<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke said last year, according to Time. Duke supported Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign and publicly celebrated his lead on election night. Trump disavowed Duke and the KKK , but only after initially declining to do so , claiming he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t <U+0089><db><cf>know anything about<U+0089><U+06DD> him. This weekend<U+0089><U+06EA>s rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, called <U+0089><db><cf>Unite the Right,<U+0089><U+06DD> was nominally billed as a protest against the removal of a monument to Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee. The rally drew out hundreds of demonstrators bearing Nazi symbols and Confederate flags and chanting racist slogans. Violence has erupted between the far-right rally attendees and counter-protestors, leading Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe (D) to declare a state of emergency. Correction: A previous version of this story incorrectly referred to far-right rally participants as <U+0089><db><cf>far-left.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Ex-KKK Leader David Duke Says White Supremacists Will 'Fulfill' Trump's Promises
Title.y: Ex-KKK Leader David Duke Says White Supremacists Will 'Fulfill' Trump's Promises

text: Rep. Trent Franks (R-Ariz.)<e5><ca>announced Thursday he is resigning from Congress next year. Several news outlets reported Franks<U+0089><U+06EA> impending departure from the House earlier Thursday. In a statement , Franks said the House Ethics Committee is investigating his <U+0089><db><cf>discussion of surrogacy with two previous female subordinates, making each feel uncomfortable.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I deeply regret that my discussion of this option and process in the workplace caused distress,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>In the midst of this current cultural and media climate, I am deeply convinced I would be unable to complete a fair House Ethics investigation before distorted and sensationalized versions of this story would put me, my family, my staff, and my noble colleagues in the House of Representatives through hyperbolized public excoriation.<U+0089><U+06DD> Franks said he has informed House leadership he will resign effective Jan. 31. In a separate statement,<e5><ca>the House Ethics Committee announced it will investigate Franks to determine whether he <U+0089><db><cf>engaged in conduct that constitutes sexual harassment and/or retaliation for opposing sexual harassment.<U+0089><U+06DD> House Speaker Paul Ryan <U+0089><U+06EA>s (R-Wis.) office said in a statement Thursday that the speaker was briefed on <U+0089><db><cf>credible claims of misconduct<U+0089><U+06DD> last week and then discussed the allegations with Franks, who did not deny them. <U+0089><db><cf>Subsequent conversations took place this week between the speaker and Rep. Franks leading to the congressman<U+0089><U+06EA>s decision to offer his letter of resignation,<U+0089><U+06DD> the statement said . Franks huddled with colleagues on the House floor late Thursday afternoon. Rep. Andy Biggs (R-Ariz.) had his arm wrapped around Franks, appearing to be consoling him. According to Roll Call, rumors of inappropriate behavior circulated before Franks<U+0089><U+06EA> announcement. The eight-term congressman is a social conservative and one of the most aggressive anti-abortion legislators in Congress. He has led the charge, year after year, to ban abortion after 20 weeks of pregnancy nationwide and to limit abortion in the District of Columbia. Residents of D.C. protested his efforts in 2012 by lining up outside the Arizona congressman<U+0089><U+06EA>s office with plastic rats and photos of pot holes, suggesting that he try to fix more pressing problems in the city than women having abortions. Franks also caused an uproar in 2013 when he claimed during an abortion debate that the <U+0089><db><cf>incidence of rape resulting in pregnancy are very low,<U+0089><U+06DD> defending his bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s lack of an exception for rape and incest victims. The congressman is notorious for comparing abortion to slavery and the Holocaust .<e5><U+0289><db><cf>What changed peoples mind over slavery?<U+0089><U+06DD> he asked during a 2013 debate on the D.C. anti-abortion bill. <U+0089><db><cf>What changed their minds over the tragedy in Eastern Europe, the horror in Eastern Europe?<U+0089><U+06DD> Franks further incensed minority rights groups last year when he introduced legislation to impose criminal penalties on doctors who are suspected of performing abortions based on the race or sex of the fetus, which they warned would codify dangerous stereotypes against women of color. Read Franks<U+0089><U+06EA> full statement here. Laura Bassett contributed reporting. This is a developing story. Check back for updates.
Title.x: Trent Franks To Resign From Congress
Title.y: Trent Franks To Resign From Congress

text: Tiffany and Ivanka Trump posed together in swimsuits to wish their followers a Merry Christmas from Mar-a-Lago. In a video clip Tiffany posted to her social media accounts on Tuesday, the sisters smile and blow kisses at the camera while <U+0089><db><cf>O Holy Night<U+0089><U+06DD> plays in the background. Social media users mercilessly mocked the sisters for their post. <U+0089><db><cf>I sure hope your fellow Americans in Puerto Rico who have been without power for 3 months enjoy this as much as you are,<U+0089><U+06DD> one commenter wrote on Instagram. Others tweeted out their feelings. Tiffany seemed undeterred by the criticism and later posted a solo shot of herself on Instagram and Twitter wishing her followers a <U+0089><db><cf>happy and peaceful<U+0089><U+06DD> new year. President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump shared photos on their respective social media accounts to mark the Christmas holiday. Ivanka, who celebrates Hanukkah, shared photos of her son and husband fishing while they were down in Florida:
Title.x: Ivanka And Tiffany Trump Mercilessly Mocked For Mar-A-Lago Christmas Video
Title.y: Ivanka And Tiffany Trump Mercilessly Mocked For Mar-A-Lago Christmas Video

text: One of President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s nominees to a lifetime seat on a U.S. district court struggled to answer basic questions about law during his Senate confirmation hearing on Thursday. Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) asked a panel of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s judicial nominees to indicate if they had never tried a case to verdict in a courtroom. Matthew Spencer Petersen, a nominee for the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, raised his hand. Kennedy proceeded to press him on legal matters. KENNEDY: Have you ever tried a jury trial? PETERSEN: I have not. KENNEDY: Civil? PETERSEN: No. KENNEDY: Criminal? PETERSEN: No. KENNEDY: Bench? PETERSEN: No. KENNEDY: State or federal court? PETERSEN: I have not. It only got worse from there. Petersen, who is currently the chairman of the U.S. Federal Election Commission, struggled to answer more questions as it became clear he did not have the experience typically expected of a federal judge. KENNEDY: As a trial judge, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re obviously going to have witnesses. Can you tell me what the Daubert standard is? PETERSEN: Sen. Kennedy, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have that readily at my disposal but I would be happy to take a closer look at that. That is not something I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve had to contend with. KENNEDY: Do you know what a motion in limine is? PETERSEN: Yes.. I haven<U+0089><U+06EA>t, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m, again, my background is not in litigation as when I was replying to Chairman (Chuck) Grassley (R-Iowa), I haven<U+0089><U+06EA>t had to um, again, do a deep dive. Petersen then began ticking off his experience <U+0089><db><cf>in a decision-making role<U+0089><U+06DD> at the FEC. Kennedy interrupted him: KENNEDY: Yes, I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve read your resume. Just for the record, do you know what a motion in limine is? PETERSEN: I would probably not be able to give you a good definition right here at the table. KENNEDY: Do you know what the Younger abstention doctrine is? PETERSEN: Um, I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve heard of it...<e5><ca>but I, again. KENNEDY: How about the Pullman abstention doctrine ? PETERSEN: I... I heard... KENNEDY: Y<U+0089><U+06EA>all see that a lot in federal court. A number of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s judicial nominees have come under fire for not being fit to serve on the federal bench. Four of his court picks have been rated <U+0089><db><cf>not qualified<U+0089><U+06DD> by the American Bar Association <U+0089><U+06E5> an embarrassingly high number to receive the abysmal rating in a president<U+0089><U+06EA>s first year. One of them, district court court nominee Brett Talley, withdrew his nomination this week. Part of the reason this keeps happening is that Trump is nominating judges at a breakneck pace without taking the time to thoroughly vet their backgrounds. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s leading to problems later in their confirmation process, as senators discover more details about their background. Many of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s court picks are being funneled to him by the The Federalist Society, a right-wing legal organization focused on filling up courts with conservative judges. Kennedy is one of few Republicans critical of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s judicial nominees, saying at one point the president is <U+0089><db><cf> getting some very, very bad advice .<U+0089><U+06DD> See Kennedy<U+0089><U+06EA>s full exchange with Petersen above. Jennifer Bendery contributed reporting.
Title.x: Trump Judicial Nominee Can't Answer Basic Questions About The Law In Disastrous Hearing
Title.y: Trump Judicial Nominee Can't Answer Basic Questions About The Law In Disastrous Hearing

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> You may have seen this photo of President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s motorcade winding down a wooded road last week as a woman on a bicycle pedaled by <U+0089><U+06E5> giving the middle finger to Trump. The picture, snapped by a White House photographer traveling with the president as he left his golf course in Sterling, Va., went viral almost immediately. News outlets picked up the story when it appeared in a White House pool report.<e5><ca>Late-night talk show hosts told jokes about the encounter and people on social media began hailing the unidentified woman as a <U+0089><db><cf>she-ro,<U+0089><U+06DD> using the hashtag #Her2020 . The woman<U+0089><U+06EA>s name is Juli Briskman. Her employer, government contractor Akima LLC, wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t so happy about the photo.<e5><ca>They fired her over it. In a Saturday interview with HuffPost, Briskman, a 50-year-old mother of two,<e5><ca>said she was stunned that someone had taken a picture of her giving Trump the middle finger. As the photo circulated online,<e5><ca>Briskman decided to tell Akima<U+0089><U+06EA>s HR department what was happening when she went to work on Monday.<e5><ca>By Tuesday,<e5><ca>her bosses called her into a meeting and said she had violated the company<U+0089><U+06EA>s social media policy by using the photo as her profile picture on Twitter and Facebook. <U+0089><db><cf>They said, <U+0089><db><f7>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re separating from you,<U+0089><db><f7><U+0089><U+06DD> said Briskman. <U+0089><db><cf>Basically, you cannot have <U+0089><db><f7>lewd<U+0089><U+06EA> or <U+0089><db><f7>obscene<U+0089><U+06EA> things in your social media. So they were calling flipping him off <U+0089><db><f7>obscene.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Briskman, who worked in marketing and communications at Akima for just over six months,<e5><ca>said she emphasized to the executives that she wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t on the job when the incident happened and that her social media pages don<U+0089><U+06EA>t mention her employer. They told her that because Akima was a government contractor, the photo could hurt their business, she said. Virginia is an employment-at-will state, meaning employers can fire people anytime and for any reason. But Briskman said what<U+0089><U+06EA>s been particularly infuriating is that a male colleague kept his job after recently posting lewd comments on his Facebook page that featured Akima LLC as his cover photo. She said this colleague was reprimanded for calling someone <U+0089><db><cf>a fucking Libtard asshole<U+0089><U+06DD> on Facebook, but was allowed to delete the post and keep his job. <U+0089><db><cf>How is that any less <U+0089><db><f7>obscene<U+0089><U+06EA> than me flipping off the president?<U+0089><U+06DD> she asked. <U+0089><db><cf>How is that fair?<U+0089><U+06DD> Akima did not respond to requests for comment via email and phone. Asked what she was thinking when she saw Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s motorcade roll up next to her, Briskman said it was a gut reaction to flip him off. <U+0089><db><cf>He was passing by and my blood just started to boil,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>she said. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m thinking, DACA recipients are getting kicked out. He pulled ads for open enrollment in Obamacare. Only one-third of Puerto Rico has power. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m thinking, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s at the damn golf course again.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I flipped off the motorcade a number of times,<U+0089><U+06DD> she added. Briskman, a Democrat, said she plans to look for a new job with an advocacy group that she believes in, like Planned Parenthood or PETA. Despite getting fired,<e5><ca>she said she has no regrets about the attention her public show of displeasure with Trump received. In fact, she said she<U+0089><U+06EA>s happy to be an image of protest that resonates with many Americans. <U+0089><db><cf>In some ways, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m doing better than ever,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>she said. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m angry about where our country is right now. I am appalled. This was an opportunity for me to say something.<U+0089><U+06DD> UPDATE: 11:54 a.m. Monday <U+0089><U+06E5> Akima<U+0089><U+06EA>s website went down later Monday . Here<U+0089><U+06EA>s a screenshot . UPDATE: 11:41 a.m. Tuesday <U+0089><U+06E5> Briskman<U+0089><U+06EA>s friends have started a GoFundMe campaign to help her raise money while she looks for a new job.
Title.x: Woman Fired For Flipping Off Donald Trump's Motorcade
Title.y: Woman Fired For Flipping Off Donald Trump's Motorcade

text: The 82nd Airborne Division fought several campaigns against Nazi Germany during World War II . So after a man in a hat bearing the elite Army paratrooper unit<U+0089><U+06EA>s insignia was pictured throwing a Ku Klux Klan salute (which resembles and is sometimes mistaken for a Nazi salute) during the weekend<U+0089><U+06EA>s Charlottesville protests ,<e5><ca>the division delivered a pointed message. <U+0089><db><cf>Anyone can purchase that hat,<U+0089><U+06DD> 82nd Airborne wrote on its official Twitter page. <U+0089><db><cf>Valor is earned.<U+0089><U+06DD> The infantry unit, nicknamed the All American Division, was reacting to a photograph that Brandon Friedman, a former Obama administration official, shared of the demonstrator on Twitter. The image was retweeted more than 20,000 times Monday. The 82nd Airborne, which played a critical role in the Allied win at Normandy, northern France, on D-Day in 1944, was swift and scathing in its response to the image. In response to one Twitter user who asked for the identity of the man in the hat, the division replied that it did not know. Instead, it shared an image showing what a real <U+0089><db><cf>All American Paratrooper<U+0089><U+06DD> looks like: It seems the 82nd Airborne continues to battle fascists. Only this time, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s on American soil. CLARIFICATION: This article has been updated to note that the men in the photograph appear to be giving a KKK salute, which is similar to the Nazi salute but is performed with the left hand, with fingers spread and the thumb folded against the palm. <U+0089><U+06E5> America does not do a good job of tracking incidents of hate and bias. We need your help to create a database of such incidents across the country, so we all know what<U+0089><U+06EA>s going on. Tell us your story .
Title.x: White Supremacist In Charlottesville Wearing 82nd Airborne Hat Gets Called Out... By 82nd Airborne
Title.y: White Supremacist In Charlottesville Wearing 82nd Airborne Hat Gets Called Out... By 82nd Airborne

text: Republicans in Congress, as well as people surrounding Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s inner circle in the White House, clearly know something. They<U+0089><U+06EA>re trying to get everything they can, looting the store, taking everything off the shelves like it<U+0089><U+06EA>s the end times. The walls are closing in as the special counsel investigation continues unabated <U+0089><U+06E5> causing some in the GOP to to try to damage it <U+0089><U+06E5> and as the Resistance becomes supercharged, expanding the Democrats<U+0089><U+06EA> chances of making big wins in 2018. The GOP has even lost its last fig leaf of moderation<U+0089><U+06E5>Maine senator Susan Collins<U+0089><U+06E5>who<U+0089><U+06EA>s been having a meltdown in the past few days after being exposed in much of the media, having voted for the Trump tax scam and not received in return promised votes on shoring up Obamacare markets. (Now GOP leaders are telling her they will come in 2018 ...sure.) Collins, who voted for Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s most misogynistic judicial nominees, hostile to a woman<U+0089><U+06EA>s right to choose, has devolved into claiming she<U+0089><U+06EA>s now a victim of an <U+0089><db><cf>unbelievably sexist<U+0089><U+06DD> media, sounding every bit like what the alt-right would call a whiny snowflake. There<U+0089><U+06EA>s been much speculation about why Republicans would pass an enormously unpopular tax bill knowing that the narrative of a tax bill at the time of its passage usually doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t change later, no matter what the reality turns out to be. Many have pointed to the White House and GOP leaders wanting a win of any kind, and needing to placate donors <U+0089><U+06E5> and even being honest about it <U+0089><U+06E5> taking a risk with voters. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s certainly true for some. Others have pointed to GOP senators, some of whom are leaving Congress, benefiting personally from the bill , the most notable example being Sen. Bob Corker of Tennessee flipping his vote after additions to the bill benefited real estate investors like himself (He has adamantly denied this). I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve been saying for a while that much of the motivation, however, also seems to be desperation among many Republicans who see the handwriting on the wall. Between the Russia investigation and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s plummeting approval, they know Trump will fall, or that they will soon lose control of the House and possibly the Senate <U+0089><U+06E5> or both. This would explain why even White House officials like Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and White House economic advisor Gary Cohn backed a plan that will hurt Trump with his base and will further his downfall: These Goldman Sachs alums, too, stand to benefit greatly from the tax bill , and they likely see that this might be the last thing they get before the Trump administration collapses. Cohn has certainly both criticized and mocked Trump enough behind his back (in addition to faking bad reception to hang up on Trump) for us to imagine he is not acting in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s best political interests. Trump, too, is clearly freaking out about the Russia investigation and is desperately trying to cling to his base, no matter what the costs. The reckless announcement to r ecognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel , while it played well to several factions in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s shrinking base, has caused reverberations around the world, forcing Mike Pence to cancel his trip to the Middle East , bringing a rebuke from the United Nations General Assembly and seriously raising tensions in a way that will come back to haunt Trump and the U.S. Banning transgender people from the military (though courts have put this on hold ) and the news reported last week that the Centers for Disease Control has been told by the Trump administration to ban in budget documents words and terms like <U+0089><db><cf>transgender,<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>fetus<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>science-based,<U+0089><U+06DD> plays to evangelicals <U+0089><U+06E5> whose support for Trump has dropped by 17 percent in a recent Pew poll <U+0089><U+06E5> but horrifies most Americans who can see signs of a turn toward fascism. But while Trump may believe these desperate moves will help him, the GOP in Congress knows that Trump can<U+0089><U+06EA>t win again by only playing to his decimated base. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s 2016 win <U+0089><U+06E5> without the popular vote and with Russian interference and James Comey<U+0089><U+06EA>s recklessness <U+0089><U+06E5> was a fluke in which he won the Electoral College by less than 85,000 votes in three states ; his base has shrunk (and slowly keeps eroding) and nothing is bringing it back. By placating some aspects of the base <U+0089><U+06E5> like evangelicals <U+0089><U+06E5> with the aforementioned actions, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s actually scaring away others in the base, and GOP leaders see this. From Virginia to Alabama, they know the blue wave is building into a possible tsunami next fall. They will use every sleazy tactic at their disposal, from voter suppression and ID laws to looking the other way of more possible Russian interference , but it may not be enough to overcome the wave. That will be compounded by the corruption and misjudgments of some of the candidates that the GOP<U+0089><U+06EA>s base, often with the help of Steve Bannon and other extremists, will back in primaries <U+0089><U+06E5> as we saw in Virginia and Alabama. All of this means that, as horrifying and demoralizing as the current climate is, and as damaging as this tax scam will be for years to come, progressives and Democrats must stay committed and determined because of a very real shot at beating the crap out of the GOP at the ballot box in 2018. And Trump may be taken down, either before finishing his term or in 2020 (if he<U+0089><U+06EA>s not taken down by the GOP first in GOP presidential primaries). Undoing the catastrophic damage that Trump and the GOP have created since the start of the Trump presidency will take years. Some of it may be impossible to undo, something the GOP is banking on. But it seems pretty clear that if progressives stay energized and don<U+0089><U+06EA>t let up, Democrats will take back power. And it seems even more clear the GOP knows that. Follow Michelangelo Signorile on Twitter: www.twitter.com/msignorile
Title.x: The GOP Knows The End Is Near
Title.y: The GOP Knows The End Is Near

text: President Donald Trump is getting lots of attention for his national security speech on Monday <U+0089><U+06E5> and as much for the way he drank water, as for what he said. Trump reached for a glass of water during his address, and carefully held onto the small cup using both hands. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s water-sipping is especially ironic considering that he lambasted Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) for the awkward way Rubio grabbed a water glass during his 2013 rebuttal speech to President Barack Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s State of the Union address. Twitter really poured it on in response to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s careful sip:
Title.x: Trump Drinks Water Like Small Child During Big Speech
Title.y: Trump Drinks Water Like Small Child During Big Speech

text: Two more women have told HuffPost that Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.) touched their butts in separate incidents. These are the third and fourth such allegations against Franken in the past week. Leeann Tweeden, a radio host, wrote last week that Franken had kissed and groped her without her consent during a 2006 USO tour. On Monday, Lindsay Menz accused Franken of groping her at the Minnesota State Fair in 2010. The two additional women, who said they were not familiar with each others<U+0089><U+06EA> stories, both spoke on condition of anonymity. But their stories, which describe events during Franken<U+0089><U+06EA>s first campaign for the Senate, are remarkably similar <U+0089><db><d3> and both women have been telling them privately for years. In a statement to HuffPost, Franken said, <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s difficult to respond to anonymous accusers, and I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t remember those campaign events.<U+0089><U+06DD> The first woman, who spoke to HuffPost on condition of anonymity because she<U+0089><U+06EA>s worried she<U+0089><U+06EA>ll be harassed online for making the allegation, said Franken groped her when they posed for a photo after a June 25, 2007, event hosted by the Minnesota Women<U+0089><U+06EA>s Political Caucus in Minneapolis. <U+0089><db><cf>My story is eerily similar to Lindsay Menz<U+0089><U+06EA>s story ,<U+0089><U+06DD> the first woman said. <U+0089><db><cf>He grabbed my buttocks during a photo op.<U+0089><U+06DD> The second woman told HuffPost that Franken cupped her butt with his hand at a 2008 Democratic fundraiser in Minneapolis, then suggested the two visit the bathroom together. She spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear that the allegation could affect her position at work. <U+0089><db><cf>My immediate reaction was disgust,<U+0089><U+06DD> the second woman said. <U+0089><db><cf>But my secondary reaction was disappointment. I was excited to be there and to meet him. And so to have that happen really deflated me. It felt like: <U+0089><db><f7>Is this really the person who is going to be in a position of power to represent our community?<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I can categorically say that I did not proposition anyone to join me in any bathroom,<U+0089><U+06DD> Franken told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><f7>We Stood Next To Each Other ... And Down His Hand Went<U+0089><U+06EA> The first woman, a 38-year-old book editor who was living in Minneapolis at the time, told HuffPost that she had just finished performing with a feminist choir at the Women<U+0089><U+06EA>s Political Caucus event, which Franken and his wife, Franni Bryson, attended. After the ceremony, she and other members of the choir approached him for photos. <U+0089><db><cf>My mother loves Al Franken. She listened to Air America [on which Franken had a radio show] every day,<U+0089><U+06DD> the first woman said. <U+0089><U+06DD>I saw him and asked if we could take a photo together for my mother, and we stood next to each other ... and down his hand went.<U+0089><U+06DD> HuffPost spoke to two sources close to the first woman who corroborated her account. One fellow choir member, Sarah, remembers not only being there for the groping incident but hearing another choir member say that Franken wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t stop looking at her chest. Ten years ago, it was easier to shrug off predatory behavior as <U+0089><db><cf>boys being boys,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sarah said, especially when that predatory behavior came from a political ally. <U+0089><db><cf>At the time ... people weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t as willing to speak against people they felt like were on their side,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sarah said. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s really disappointing. And it<U+0089><U+06EA>s crappy. Ten years ago we were also at an age where there was still a feeling of powerlessness, or that boys will be boys.<U+0089><U+06DD> The first woman<U+0089><U+06EA>s best friend, who likewise wished to remain anonymous, remembers hearing about the groping incident the day after it happened. <U+0089><db><cf>She was in this all-women<U+0089><U+06EA>s choir and he was at an event where she performed, and she told me that he basically grabbed her ass,<U+0089><U+06DD> the best friend said. <U+0089><db><cf>It was a <U+0089><db><f7>Can you believe this happened to me?<U+0089><U+06EA> kind of thing.<U+0089><U+06DD> The first woman wanted to tell her story because Franken is <U+0089><db><cf>a serial groper,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>Only two people have come forward, and people are saying that this is a right-wing conspiracy,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m a liberal person. ... I voted for him after this happened.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><f7>I Was Completely Mortified<U+0089><U+06EA> The second woman, who said she was groped at a fundraiser, told HuffPost it took place in the fall of 2008 at the Loft Literary Center in Minneapolis. She was excited about attending the event and meeting someone she wanted to support. <U+0089><db><cf>I had never attended anything like that,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. She and her friends found Franken and introduced themselves to him. <U+0089><db><cf>I shook his hand, and he put his arm around my waist and held it there,<U+0089><U+06DD> the second woman said. <U+0089><db><cf>Then he moved it lower and cupped my butt.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I was completely mortified,<U+0089><U+06DD> she added. In order to escape the situation, the woman excused herself to go to the bathroom. At that point, she said, Franken leaned in and suggested that he accompany her. She grabbed her friend and fled to the bathroom without him. The second woman told several people <U+0089><U+06E5> including one of the reporters for this story, Zachary Roth <U+0089><U+06E5> about the incident some years ago, but didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t want it reported then. She said she didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t tell anyone at the time of the incident because inappropriate behavior from men was not that unusual to her or her friends. <U+0089><db><cf>Sexual harassment happens so often, you have to learn how to move on,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said, describing her thinking at the time. Several other factors also left her feeling powerless. <U+0089><db><cf>I felt like I didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have a voice,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>This man had all of the power, all of the authority. In addition, he is a white man and I am a woman of color. I was 21 years old. And I was afraid that he would use all of those privileges to discredit me, to make me feel even smaller than I already felt.<U+0089><U+06DD> Today, she said, she feels more confident, in part thanks to the flood of women who have come forward over the last month to share stories of sexual harassment by powerful men. <U+0089><db><cf>I couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t see all these other women come forward and not walk the walk myself,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>I wanted my report to be a way for other women to say, <U+0089><db><f7>Yes, that happened to me and I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have to be afraid.<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Like the second woman, the first woman waited years before deciding to go public with her story. She laughed off the incident at the time, she said, even telling other people about it as a sort of <U+0089><db><cf>party trick.<U+0089><U+06DD> It wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t until recently, she said, that she felt safe talking about how uncomfortable she<U+0089><U+06EA>d felt. On Oct. 12, shortly after The New York Times and The New Yorker published bombshell reports about sexual assault claims against movie mogul Harvey Weinstein that drove the #MeToo social media campaign to new heights, the first woman posted on Facebook about her experience. <U+0089><db><cf>Are we all sharing which famous man has groped us?<U+0089><U+06DD> she wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>Mine<U+0089><U+06EA>s Al Franken.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Men should be held to the same standards regardless of their politics,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>He<U+0089><U+06EA>s an imperfect messenger for a progressive platform. He can<U+0089><U+06EA>t claim to be <U+0089><db><f7>for women<U+0089><U+06EA> and also grope them.<U+0089><U+06DD> Do you have a similar story? Email us at scoops@huffpost.com, or message us securely .
Title.x: Two More Women Accuse Sen. Al Franken Of Inappropriate Touching
Title.y: Two More Women Accuse Sen. Al Franken Of Inappropriate Touching

text: President Donald Trump accused athletes on Friday of disrespecting the American flag when silently protesting by kneeling or sitting while the national anthem is played.
