On June 14, 1923, or Flag Day, a federal code was put in place that would serve as a guideline for how to handle the American flag. A viral Twitter thread brought the almost century-old standards back into the spotlight on Saturday. There are several sections in the code about proper national anthem conduct, how to display the flag, and how to respect the flag in general . The code does state that everyone during the national anthem, <U+0089><db><cf>all present except those in uniform should stand at attention facing the flag with the right hand over the heart,<U+0089><U+06DD> but the guidelines are not legally binding<e5><U+0289><U+06E5> more like official suggestions about how to treat what the code calls <U+0089><db><cf>a living thing.<U+0089><U+06DD> Here are some things that Americans do on a regular basis that are considered disrespectful according to the Flag Code:  American flag clothing <U+0089><db><cf>The flag should never be used as wearing apparel, bedding, or drapery. It should never be festooned, drawn back, nor up, in folds, but always allowed to fall free.<U+0089><U+06DD> That means every American flag swimsuit, button-up shirt, and even those famous Old Navy flag shirts, can be considered disrespectful.  The flag shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be carried flat <U+0089><db><cf>The flag should never be carried flat or horizontally, but always aloft and free.<U+0089><U+06DD> Most people know the flag should never touch the ground, but few know that it has to be displayed vertically.<e5><ca>Maybe it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a nod to the lyric that had the flag <U+0089><db><cf>gallantly streaming<U+0089><U+06DD> in the air. Whatever the case, an unfurled flag that sits flat is a disrespect to the Flag Code.  Drawing on the flag <U+0089><db><cf>The flag should never have placed upon it, nor on any part of it, nor attached to it any mark, insignia, letter, word, figure, design, picture, or drawing of any nature.<U+0089><U+06DD> This one seems pretty self-explanatory. Most people understand that drawing on the symbol of the country will probably be seen as disrespectful. But freedom of expression is a constitutionally protected right, so artists (and the rest of us) are still free to make that choice.  Disposable flag products <U+0089><db><cf>It should not be embroidered on such articles as cushions or handkerchiefs and the like, printed or otherwise impressed on paper napkins or boxes or anything that is designed for temporary use and discard.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sorry to put a damper on probably every Fourth of July cookout ever, but if the paper plate supporting that juicy burger has a flag on it, the Flag Code says that<U+0089><U+06EA>s disrespectful.  Flag advertisements <U+0089><db><cf>The flag should never be used for advertising purposes in any manner whatsoever.<U+0089><U+06DD> If a business or company is using a flag in its advertisements, that<U+0089><U+06EA>s yet another disrespectful gesture. A flag printed on a disposable flier is probably a double offense.  Flag uniforms <U+0089><db><cf>No part of the flag should ever be used as a costume or athletic uniform. However, a flag patch may be affixed to the uniform of military personnel, firemen, policemen, and members of patriotic organizations.<U+0089><U+06DD> It seems like sports teams are running afoul of the guidelines by putting the flag on uniforms.<e5><ca>The only way to respectfully wear the American flag on a costume is with a <U+0089><db><cf>patch<U+0089><U+06DD> on the side of the uniform for service members, firefighters and police officers, according to the code. This article has been updated to include more details about the code<U+0089><U+06EA>s legal standing and its rules about conduct during the national anthem.
Title.x: Here Are Some Ways People Disrespect The Flag Daily Based On Flag Code
Title.y: Here Are Some Ways People Disrespect The Flag Daily Based On Flag Code

text: Sen. John McCain surprised his colleagues early Friday morning when he cast his vote opposing the Health Care Freedom Act ,<e5><ca>joining Republican Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and all of the chamber<U+0089><U+06EA>s Democrats and independents to defeat the bill. Video of the vote, tweeted by entrepreneur and activist Michael Skolnik, shows McCain walking to the front of the Senate floor after his name is called, stretching out his hand, pausing and saying <U+0089><db><cf>No<U+0089><U+06DD> loudly enough for all to hear. His colleagues gasp, and some applaud as he makes his way back to his chair. The Republicans<U+0089><U+06EA> Obamacare replacement lost in the Senate, 49 to 51. Watch the dramatic moment in the video above. CLARIFICATION: Language has been updated to reflect McCain walked to the front of the Senate floor after his name was called.
Title.x: Watch The Senate Gasp Aloud As John McCain Votes No On Health Care Bill
Title.y: Watch The Senate Gasp Aloud As John McCain Votes No On Health Care Bill

text: Former KKK leader David Duke was none too pleased that President Donald Trump on Monday finally got around to condemning extremist groups by name <U+0089><U+06E5> including neo-Nazis and the Ku Klux Klan <U+0089><U+06E5> for the deadly weekend protest in Charlottesville, Virginia. Minutes after Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s speech, Duke lashed out in a series of tweets , claiming the president had been manipulated by the media. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s amazing to see how the media is able to bully the President of the United States into going along with their FAKE NEWS narrative,<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke tweeted. Soon after that, in an anti-Semitic, racist Periscope video rant , Duke spoke directly to Trump, claiming white nationalists abhor violence. He said <U+0089><db><cf>it<U+0089><U+06EA>s just ridiculous<U+0089><U+06DD> that the president felt he had to make Monday<U+0089><U+06EA>s statement. <U+0089><db><cf>President Trump, please, for God<U+0089><U+06EA>s sake, don<U+0089><U+06EA>t feel like you need to say these things,<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke admonished in the video. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not going to do you any good.<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke also stuck up for James Alex Fields, 20, the white nationalist motorist accused of ramming his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, killing Heather Heyer, 32. <U+0089><db><cf>When you<U+0089><U+06EA>re under attack ... you panic and you do things that are stupid and you do things that are wrong,<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke said. Trump made an address to the nation on Monday, after two days of withering criticism for a vague Saturday statement that criticized hatred and bigotry on <U+0089><db><cf>many sides.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, Neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Trump said. Lawmakers from both parties had called Trump out for not specifically denouncing hate groups in the wake of a white nationalist rally that left three people dead, including two state troopers, and at least 19 injured. Some white supremacist organizations, such as the Daily Stormer, praised Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s vague weekend statement. Duke at the time appeared to warn the president against calling out white nationalists, a group that has largely embraced Trump. Duke said on Saturday that the rally would help fulfill Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>promises.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This represents a turning point for the people of this country,<U+0089><U+06DD> Duke said. <U+0089><db><cf>We are determined to take our country back. We are going to fulfill the promises of Donald Trump.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Ex-KKK Leader David Duke Has Meltdown After Trump Condemns White Supremacists In Charlottesville
Title.y: Ex-KKK Leader David Duke Has Meltdown After Trump Condemns White Supremacists In Charlottesville

text: A distinguished U.S. diplomat who was seen as a rising star at the State Department resigned after writing a searing letter to Secretary Of State Rex Tillerson , accusing him of gutting the department and damaging America<U+0089><U+06EA>s standing across the world. Elizabeth Shackelford,<e5><ca>who served as a political officer based in Nairobi for the U.S. mission to Somalia,<e5><ca>lamented in a Nov. 7 letter obtained by Foreign Policy the <U+0089><db><cf>stinging disrespect<U+0089><U+06DD> President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s administration had shown the diplomatic corps and how it was <U+0089><db><cf>driving<U+0089><U+06DD> the department<U+0089><U+06EA>s most experienced staff away in growing numbers. <U+0089><db><cf>The cost of this is visible every day in Mission Somalia, my current post, where State<U+0089><U+06EA>s diplomatic influence, on the country and within our own interagency, is waning,<U+0089><U+06DD> Shackelford wrote. She said she was <U+0089><db><cf>shocked<U+0089><U+06DD> when Tillerson, who stepped down as Exxon Mobil CEO to serve as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s secretary of state, told department employees that advancing human rights across the globe <U+0089><db><cf>creates obstacles to our ability to advance our national security interests.<U+0089><db><cf> If Tillerson is unable to <U+0089><db><cf>stem the bleeding<U+0089><U+06DD> and preserve the department<U+0089><U+06EA>s mission, she added, <U+0089><db><cf>I would humbly recommend you follow me out the door.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s administration has been harshly criticized for downplaying human rights issues in countries like Russia, Turkey, and the Philippines. Democratic lawmakers and former ambassadors have also accused Tillerson of gutting the department<U+0089><U+06EA>s budget and staff at a critical and dangerous time, as difficult foreign policy challenges persist in the Middle East and on the Korean peninsula. Tillerson, who has still has not denied having called Trump a <U+0089><db><cf> moron <U+0089><U+06DD> in private earlier this year, has been the subject of a raft of rumors that his time at the State Department will be short-lived. The White House last month reportedly floated a plan about replacing Tillerson with CIA Director Mike Pompeo in order to help push out the secretary of state. Tillerson has defended the job he has done and said the department has been in need of a <U+0089><db><cf> redesign <U+0089><U+06DD> to simplify its workforce.
Title.x: Star U.S. Diplomat Quits With Fiery Letter To Rex Tillerson
Title.y: Star U.S. Diplomat Quits With Fiery Letter To Rex Tillerson

text: President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s son Eric has echoed his dad<U+0089><U+06EA>s recent attack on Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.). <U+0089><db><cf>I remember Kirsten Gillibrand when she came into his office every three days to ask him for money and ask for major campaign contributions,<U+0089><U+06DD> Eric said in a Wednesday interview on WABC Radio with Rita Cosby.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>There is no one who wanted to get into his office more than Kirsten Gillibrand.<U+0089><U+06DD> On Tuesday, the president tweeted that Gillibrand is a <U+0089><db><cf>lightweight<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>total flunky<U+0089><U+06DD> for Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.).<e5><ca>Trump added that Gillibrand would <U+0089><db><cf>come to my office <U+0089><db><f7>begging<U+0089><U+06EA> for campaign contributions not so long ago,<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>would do anything for them.<U+0089><U+06DD> Many people criticized Trump for the tweet, calling it sexist and sexually suggestive . A scathing USA Today editorial said the tweet showed that Trump <U+0089><db><cf>is not fit for office.<U+0089><U+06DD> Gillibrand, who has called for the president to resign in light of multiple allegations of sexual misconduct against him, termed his attack a <U+0089><db><cf> sexist smear <U+0089><U+06DD> and tweeted defiantly that Trump <U+0089><db><cf>cannot silence me.<U+0089><U+06DD> Eric Trump told Cosby that Gillibrand is nothing but a <U+0089><db><cf>distraction.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s amazing how convenient it is that he<U+0089><U+06EA>s doing incredibly well [as president] ... a minute away from finalizing, maybe the most historic tax cut to our nation and here she is,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>She follows the whole Schumer playbook. Again, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a shame, but it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a distraction. I think we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve gotten pretty good at tuning out distractions, at least I have.<U+0089><U+06DD> He also deemed the recent revival of sexual misconduct allegations against his father the <U+0089><db><cf>distraction of the week,<U+0089><U+06DD> adding that the accusations are <U+0089><db><cf>totally unfounded<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>baseless.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s total nonsense,<U+0089><U+06DD> Eric said, referring to the 21 sexual misconduct allegations that range from harassment to assault and rape . <U+0089><db><cf>That<U+0089><U+06EA>s been the playbook in our government for so long: distract, disrupt,<e5><ca>hurt, bash, defame, do whatever you can for your own political gain.<e5><ca>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s sad that we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have more morals or character or whatever it is.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump and his aides have denied the sexual misconduct allegations, calling them <U+0089><db><cf>false accusations<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>fake news.<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca> White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders suggested in October that all of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusers were lying . A recent poll conducted by Politico and Morning Consult found that half of registered voters believe the allegations against Trump are credible. On Monday, four of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusers held a press conference urging Congress to open an investigation into his alleged inappropriate behavior. Also on Monday, a group of Democratic congresswomen released a letter calling for such a probe. The letter has now been signed by 100 Democratic lawmakers .
Title.x: Eric Trump Joins Attack On Kirsten Gillibrand, Says She Asked For Money 'Every 3 Days'
Title.y: Eric Trump Joins Attack On Kirsten Gillibrand, Says She Asked For Money 'Every 3 Days'

text: It<U+0089><U+06EA>s hard not to like this. Former President Barack Obama <U+0089><U+06EA>s response on Twitter to the violence that unfolded in Charlottesville, Virginia , over the weekend is now the most liked tweet ever . On Saturday night, Obama quoted former South African President Nelson Mandela in a series of tweets: The first of the bunch, in which Obama is smiling at children of different ethnicities, topped 2.8 million likes on Tuesday night. A tweet by Ariana Grande following the deadly bombing in May at the end of her concert in Manchester, England, previously held the top spot with 2.7 million likes. Obama tweeted the quote from Mandela<U+0089><U+06EA>s autobiography Long Walk to Freedom a few hours after James Alex Fields Jr., 20, plowed his car into marchers protesting the <U+0089><db><cf>Unite the Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally attended by various white supremacist groups on Saturday, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer . Also killed that day were two on-duty Virginia state troopers whose helicopter crashed on the outskirts of Charlottesville. President Donald Trump responded to the clashes in Charlottesville in a very different way on Saturday, saying: <U+0089><db><cf>We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides <U+0089><U+06E5> on many sides,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said on national television. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long time in our country, not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long, long time.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also tweeted about the violence numerous times on Saturday. None of his tweets, however, specifically condemned any white supremacy extremist groups. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s most popular tweet addressing the events in Charlottesville on Saturday had not gotten more than 190,000 likes as of Tuesday morning. The others didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t exceed 125,000 likes. Facing bipartisan criticism over his initial responses, Trump on Monday was more explicit in comments he made at the White House. <U+0089><db><cf>Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including the KKK, Neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to what we hold dear as Americans,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. This article was updated on Tuesday night to show that Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweet is the most liked ever. CORRECTION: This article initially misstated how many likes Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Charlottesville tweets from Saturday received.
Title.x: Obamas Beautiful Charlottesville Tweet Is Most Liked Ever
Title.y: Obamas Beautiful Charlottesville Tweet Is Most Liked Ever

text: In his first visit to Puerto Rico following the devastation of Hurricane Maria , President Donald Trump tossed paper towels at suffering survivors Tuesday. A small number of the more than 3 million residents in Puerto Rico still without power were gifted paper towels, which Trump apparently thought was the most pressing need for those in the crowd. Video of the event shows him tossing the paper towels like a child trying to play basketball. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s all very underwhelming. After Puerto Rico<U+0089><U+06EA>s governor told Trump that only 16 people had been reported dead,<e5><ca>Trump said the storm wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t a <U+0089><db><cf> real catastrophe <U+0089><U+06DD> like Hurricane Katrina. <U+0089><db><cf>Everybody watching can really be very proud of what<U+0089><U+06EA>s taken place in Puerto Rico,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added. Later on Tuesday,<e5><ca>the government revised the death count to 34. The number is likely to go up again as more information about the storm<U+0089><U+06EA>s destruction emerges. During Tuesday<U+0089><U+06EA>s visit, Trump also lambasted Puerto Rico for creating a budget strain. <U+0089><db><cf>I hate to tell you, Puerto Rico, but you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve thrown our budget a little out of whack,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. The comments follow a public lashing Trump gave to San Juan Mayor Carmen Yul<cc>_n Cruz after she begged the U.S. government for help. Instead, Trump attacked her on Twitter while at his New Jersey golf resort. Retired Lt. Gen. Russel L. Honor<U+0329> tore down the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets. <U+0089><db><cf>The mayor<U+0089><U+06EA>s living on a cot, and I hope the president has a good day at golf,<U+0089><U+06DD> Honor<U+0329> told CNN. At least now the people of Puerto Rico have some towels to help clean up the mess Trump has exacerbated.
Title.x: Donald Trump Helps Suffering Puerto Ricans By Throwing Paper Towels At Them
Title.y: Donald Trump Helps Suffering Puerto Ricans By Throwing Paper Towels At Them

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> President Donald Trump received applause on Friday when he endorsed police brutality while delivering a speech to law enforcement officers on Long Island, New York. The president suggested that officers should hit suspects<U+0089><U+06EA> heads on the doors of their police cars. <U+0089><db><cf>When you see these towns and when you see these thugs being thrown into the back of a paddy wagon, you just see them thrown in, rough, and I said, <U+0089><db><f7>Please don<U+0089><U+06EA>t be too nice,<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. <U+0089><db><cf>Like when you guys put somebody in the car and you<U+0089><U+06EA>re protecting their head, you know, the way you put their hand over, like, don<U+0089><U+06EA>t hit their head and they<U+0089><U+06EA>ve just killed somebody, don<U+0089><U+06EA>t hit their head, I said, <U+0089><db><f7>You can take the hand away, OK?<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD> he added. His remarks received significant applause. Trump also made the dubious claim that laws were <U+0089><db><cf>horrendously stacked<U+0089><U+06DD> against police officers and said he wants to change those laws. <U+0089><db><cf>For years and years, [laws have]<e5><ca>been made to protect the criminal,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. <U+0089><db><cf>Totally protect the criminal, not the officers. You do something wrong, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re in more jeopardy than they are. These laws are stacked against you. We<U+0089><U+06EA>re changing those laws.<U+0089><U+06DD> In his speech, Trump also said that police officers in many parts of the country couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t do their jobs because they had a <U+0089><db><cf>pathetic mayor<U+0089><U+06DD> or a mayor <U+0089><db><cf>who doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know what<U+0089><U+06EA>s going on.<U+0089><U+06DD> Those comments also received a lengthy applause. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s sad, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s sad. You look at what<U+0089><U+06EA>s happening, and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s sad,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. <U+0089><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to support you like you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve never been supported before.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also spoke about violence in Chicago, which was a consistent theme of his speeches throughout the campaign and is a topic he has continued to reference during his presidency. Trump recalled speaking to an <U+0089><db><cf>impressive<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>rough cookie<U+0089><U+06DD> police officer from Chicago, and said the officer had told him he could straighten out the city<U+0089><U+06EA>s violence problem in a <U+0089><db><cf>couple of days<U+0089><U+06DD> if he was given the authority. Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Trump may not be getting along these days, but the two are on the same page when it comes to policing. Sessions has had the Justice Department pull back from <U+0089><db><cf>pattern or practice<U+0089><U+06DD> investigations that look into widespread constitutional abuses in police departments. Zeke Johnson, senior director of programs at Amnesty International USA, said Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>inflammatory and hateful speech will only escalate tensions between police and communities,<U+0089><U+06DD> putting both officers and civilians at risk. <U+0089><db><cf>Police cannot treat every community like an invading army, and encouraging violence by police is irresponsible and reprehensible,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. Vanita Gupta, who headed the Justice Department<U+0089><U+06EA>s Civil Rights Division under former President Barack Obama, said Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s remarks were <U+0089><db><cf>unconscionable<U+0089><U+06DD> and undermined the positive efforts of local law enforcement to build up community trust. <U+0089><db><cf>The president of the United States, standing before an audience of law enforcement officials, actively encouraged police violence,<U+0089><U+06DD> Gupta said. <U+0089><db><cf>We call on the president to immediately and unequivocally condemn police brutality. We can all respect our law enforcement officers without sanctioning unjust and illegal behavior.<U+0089><U+06DD> Robert Driscoll, a former Justice Department Civil Rights Division official under the President George W. Bush administration, was also critical.
Title.x: Donald Trump Endorses Police Brutality In Speech To Cops
Title.y: Donald Trump Endorses Police Brutality In Speech To Cops

text: Shock and anger were common feelings for most Americans who followed the recent tragic events in Charlottesville, Virginia. To Jack Rosenthal, the hate-filled imagery was something he never thought he<U+0089><U+06EA>d see again, at least not in the United States. Rosenthal is one of 10,000 Romanian refugees who came to America after World War II. At 88 years old, he still mourns the loss of seven family members who died in the Auschwitz death camp. He was the only one to survive. He was born and raised in a farming village in northern Romania. <U+0089><db><cf>Altogether in my village, there were 26 Jewish families,<U+0089><U+06DD> Rosenthal told HuffPost. Most of them didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t survive either. Ultimately, hundreds of thousands of Romanian Jews were massacred in pogroms, slaughtered in death camps or otherwise murdered by Romanian authorities, German forces and others during the war. Rosenthal was 16 when he was taken to Auschwitz, the German Nazi camp in occupied Poland. Later, he was transferred to Buchenwald, another camp near Weimar, Germany, where he was forced to work for the Nazis<e5><U+0289><U+06E5> the only reason he was kept alive until U.S. military forces began to evacuate the camp<U+0089><U+06EA>s 28,000 prisoners in 1945. He came to the U.S. hoping to find a new beginning. <U+0089><db><cf>After I was liberated, I thought to myself the world has learned what terrible traces hate can bring to humanity,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>And now this gives me a depressing feeling because it<U+0089><U+06EA>s happening again, and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s happening now.<U+0089><U+06DD> The successful real estate agent watched the protests from his home in Roslyn, New York, where he lives during the warmer months of the year. In the winter, Rosenthal flies to Florida. Decades later, he remembers how hard it was to get settled in the U.S.<e5><ca>while dealing with the trauma from the war. <U+0089><db><cf>When I came here, I used to get really bad nightmares and I would get up in middle of the night not being able to go back to sleep,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. Those days of lingering fear and uncertainty felt much closer after watching neo-Nazis rage during the violent demonstrations in Charlottesville, he said. But after all the anti-Semitic speeches and the deadly car attack , it was one particular detail that caught Rosenthal<U+0089><U+06EA>s attention. He noticed it while reading about a Aug. 14 court hearing for James Alex Fields Jr., the man accused of plowing his car into a crowd of counterprotesters at the white nationalist rally, leaving a 32-year-old woman dead and injuring at least 19 other people. The article included a photo of Matthew Heimbach, who had helped promote the Unite the Right rally in Charlottesville, voicing his displeasure outside the courtroom after a judge denied bail for Fields. The white supremacist<U+0089><U+06EA>s T-shirt was the first thing Rosenthal saw. On the shirt was a picture of Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, a pre-WWII leader of the Romanian fascist Legion of Saint Michael the Archangel and the Iron Guard political party, which were both linked to the Nazi party. Codreanu urged the destruction of the Jewish community in Romania. Members of his Iron Guard responded with brutality both before and during the war, including a horrifying massacre in Bucharest that killed over 100 Jews. <U+0089><db><cf>I recognized the name right away,<U+0089><U+06DD> Rosenthal said. <U+0089><db><cf>You see something like this, you know, it brings back memories and I<U+0089><U+06EA>m concerned about what could happen in this country,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. The groups behind the Unite the Right rally are not the only ones of their kind. According to a February report from the Southern Poverty Law Center , at least 917 hate groups exist throughout the country. Many Americans were concerned when President Donald Trump failed to immediately condemn white supremacy in responding to the Charlottesville violence. Instead, Trump blamed both sides of the protests <U+0089><U+06E5> a point he repeated on Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>You cannot compare fascism and Nazis to the other people protesting. Maybe there are people on both sides who are misguided, but there is simply no comparison,<U+0089><U+06DD> Rosenthal said. And he reminded us that the consequences of going through horrific violence never really end. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s 70 years after the war and it still has a tremendous impact on me,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s something I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll never forget and that<U+0089><U+06EA>ll always be with me as long as I live.<U+0089><U+06DD> CORRECTION: Due to an editing error, the number of Jews killed by the Iron Guard was significantly overstated in an earlier version of the story. The individual pogroms that killed thousands and tens of thousands of Jews in Romania during World War II were carried out by official Romanian and German forces.
Title.x: This Holocaust Survivor Noticed A Detail In Charlottesville You Might Have Missed
Title.y: This Holocaust Survivor Noticed A Detail In Charlottesville You Might Have Missed

text: President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s terse thanking of Omarosa Manigault Newman for her service via Twitter on Wednesday did not go unnoticed. White House officials claimed Newman resigned as director of communications for the Public Liaison Office the previous day. Multiple news outlets have reported, however, that she was fired by Chief of Staff John Kelly and had to be removed from the grounds. As speculation mounted as to exactly what went down, Trump tweeted this brief message of thanks to the former <U+0089><db><cf>Apprentice<U+0089><U+06DD> star: Fellow Twitter users seized on the post and began to make fun of what appeared to be Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s curt tone with his (soon to be former) controversial aide. Most of the responses were as follows:
Title.x: Donald Trump Tickles Tweeters With His Curt Message To Omarosa
Title.y: Donald Trump Tickles Tweeters With His Curt Message To Omarosa

text: National Football League stars past and present are expressing outrage after President Donald Trump used an address in Huntsville, Alabama, on Friday to attack players who protest during the national anthem. During what was supposed to be a stump speech for Sen.<e5><ca>Luther Strange (R-Ala.), Trump drifted away from campaigning to ask members of the crowd if they<U+0089><U+06EA>d <U+0089><db><cf> love to see one of these NFL owners , when somebody disrespects our flag, to say, <U+0089><db><f7>Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s fired<U+0089><U+06EA>?<U+0089><U+06DD> He also encouraged fans to boycott the league over the protests. Trump did not reference by name San Francisco 49ers former player Colin Kaepernick , who took a knee during the national anthem before games last year to protest police brutality and racial injustice. But his comments were interpreted as a thinly veiled attack on the athlete, who remains a free agent, and other players he has inspired to take similar action. Seattle Seahawks cornerback Richard Sherman, wide receiver Doug Baldwin and former running back Reggie Bush were among those to call out Trump for his remarks: DeMaurice Smith, the executive director of the NFL Players Association, also made his position crystal clear via this statement on Twitter: NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell also released a statement in which it said that <U+0089><db><cf>divisive comments like these demonstrate an unfortunate lack of respect<U+0089><U+06DD> for the league and its players. Stephen Ross, owner of the Miami Dolphins, said that he personally knows some of the NFL players who are protesting and said they were <U+0089><db><cf>smart young men of character who want to make our world a better place.<U+0089><U+06DD> He called for <U+0089><db><cf>unifying leadership<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>and <U+0089><db><cf>civil discourse<U+0089><U+06DD> instead of <U+0089><db><cf>condemnation and sound bites.<U+0089><U+06DD> Hundreds of other tweeters joined in with blasting Trump, with many accusing him of trying to prevent people from exercising their First Amendment rights. The hashtag #takeaknee also began trending globally on Twitter. Check out a sampling of the other responses below: Correction: A previous version of this article misidentified the Brandon Marshall who posted the tweet as being the New York Giants<U+0089><U+06EA> wide receiver.
Title.x: NFL Stars Erupt In Anger Over Donald Trump's 'Son Of A Bitch' Speech
Title.y: NFL Stars Erupt In Anger Over Donald Trump's 'Son Of A Bitch' Speech

text: GOP Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore stunned some listeners when he said he thought America was <U+0089><db><cf>great<U+0089><U+06DD> during the era of slavery.<e5><ca>Though he made the comments at a campaign rally in Florence, Alabama,<e5><ca>more than two months ago, they<U+0089><U+06EA>ve re-emerged in a viral tweet just days before the election. Back in September, one of the few African-Americans in the crowd asked the candidate when he thought was the <U+0089><db><cf>last time<U+0089><U+06DD> America was great. <U+0089><db><cf>I think it was great at the time when families were united . Even though we had slavery, they cared for one another. ... Our families were strong, our country had a direction,<U+0089><U+06DD> Moore responded, according to a Los Angeles Times report in September. At the same rally, he also referred to Native Americans and Asians as <U+0089><db><cf>reds and yellows,<U+0089><U+06DD> the LA Times reported. Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments resurfaced Thursday in a tweet by Eric Columbus, who served in the departments of Justice and Homeland Security during the Obama administration.<e5><ca>Columbus linked to the LA Times story, saying, <U+0089><db><cf>Can<U+0089><U+06EA>t make this up.<U+0089><U+06DD> His message was retweeted thousands of times. People on Twitter went crazy. Actress and rape survivor Gabrielle Union tweeted, <U+0089><db><cf>No. No. No. No. No. No. No.<U+0089><U+06DD> Others pointed out that the years before the Civil War were hardly a time of <U+0089><db><cf>united families<U+0089><U+06DD> as enslaved black families were often broken up and members auctioned off individually to other slave owners. Moore<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments were ricocheting around the nation as the campaign of Democratic opponent Doug Jones was reaching out to black voters in Alabama and blasting the Republican as <U+0089><db><cf>racist.<U+0089><U+06DD> A super PAC backing Jones was targeting Facebook ads at African-American voters in a bid to boost turnout for the Dec. 12 election. <U+0089><db><cf>A racist shouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t represent you,<U+0089><U+06DD> read the text of one ad over an image of Moore. <U+0089><db><cf>If Roy Moore goes to Washington, he<U+0089><U+06EA>ll make decisions that will impact your family for years.<U+0089><U+06DD> Another ad said that Moore<e5><U+0289><db><cf>had ties to the same white supremacist group that inspired the Charleston shooter.<U+0089><U+06DD> (The former judge once addressed the white supremacist Council of Conservative Citizens that Charleston church shooter Dylann Roof would cite in his manifesto.) President Donald Trump threw his full support behind Moore on Monday.
Title.x: Roy Moore Believes America Was Great During Slavery. Twitter Users Detonate.
Title.y: Roy Moore Believes America Was Great During Slavery. Twitter Users Detonate.

text: Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s The Art of the Deal co-author, Tony Schwartz , is predicting that the president is getting ready to call it quits <U+0089><U+06E5> and that the resignation will happen soon. He tweeted Wednesday: In follow-up tweets in response to questions, Schwartz predicted Trump would make a deal for immunity in the Russia investigation in exchange for his resignation. <U+0089><db><cf>The Russia stuff will be huge,<U+0089><U+06DD> he wrote.<e5><U+0289><db><cf> He doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to go to jail .<U+0089><U+06DD> He also urged Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s opponents to keep up the pressure, and he slammed the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s elder children. Schwartz has been predicting resignation as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s endgame, making similar comments in May. <U+0089><db><cf>I surely believe that at some point over the next period of time he<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to have to figure out a way to resign ,<U+0089><U+06DD> Schwartz told CNN at the time. Despite authoring a book with Trump, Schwartz advised the campaign of 2016 Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton for free. <U+0089><db><cf>This is my penance for having created a man who has become a monster ,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said in September. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve spent 30 years feeling bad about it.<U+0089><U+06DD> Schwartz also said he would donate his share of the profits from The Art Of The Deal to the National Immigration Law Center , an organization that helps low-income immigrants.
Title.x: 'Art Of The Deal' Co-Author Tony Schwartz Predicts Trump's About To Resign
Title.y: 'Art Of The Deal' Co-Author Tony Schwartz Predicts Trump's About To Resign

text: President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s personal Twitter account, @realDonaldTrump,<e5><ca>briefly vanished from the internet on Thursday. Social media users noticed that for a short period of time around 7 p.m.<e5><ca> EDT Thursday,<e5><ca>the page was inaccessible. Given the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s frequent use of the platform, confusion began to circulate as to why the account might be deleted. But it was all an employee error, Twitter said about an hour later . It seems that an employee who was leaving the company deleted the account. <U+0089><db><cf>Through our investigation we have learned that this was done by a Twitter customer support employee who did this on the employee<U+0089><U+06EA>s last day,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>the company explained. <U+0089><db><cf>We are conducting a full internal review.<U+0089><U+06DD> Many of the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s critics, and even some of his supporters,<e5><ca>have decried Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s bullying habits on Twitter. And a number of users criticized Twitter for not suspending the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s account after he purportedly violated the platform<U+0089><U+06EA>s user guidelines over what some called a clear threat of violence. In one tweet, the president threatened that North Korea <U+0089><db><cf>won<U+0089><U+06EA>t be around much longer<U+0089><U+06DD> if the country<U+0089><U+06EA>s leadership allowed hostile rhetoric against the United States to continue.<e5><ca>North Korea<U+0089><U+06EA>s government called it a declaration of war . But Twitter refused to suspend or ban Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s account after the incident. <U+0089><db><cf>We hold all accounts to the same Rules, and consider a number of factors when assessing whether Tweets violate our Rules,<U+0089><U+06DD> the company said . <U+0089><db><cf>Among the considerations is <U+0089><db><f7>newsworthiness<U+0089><U+06EA> and whether a Tweet is of public interest.<U+0089><U+06DD> The White House did not respond to HuffPost<U+0089><U+06EA>s request for comment. This story has been updated with more information from Twitter.
Title.x: Rogue Twitter Employee Deletes Donald Trumps Account On Last Day
Title.y: Rogue Twitter Employee Deletes Donald Trumps Account On Last Day

text: Former President Barack Obama tweeted a quote from former South African President Nelson Mandela Saturday in an apparent response to the violence in Charlottesville, Virginia. <U+0089><db><cf>No one is born hating another person because of the color of his skin or his background or his religion.<e5><ca>People must learn to hate, and if they can learn to hate, they can be taught to love.<e5><ca>For love comes more naturally to the human heart than its opposite,<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama tweeted. The quote is from Mandela<U+0089><U+06EA>s autobiography, Long Walk to Freedom . Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s series of tweets also featured a photo of him greeting children at a day care facility in Bethesda, Maryland, in 2011. President Donald Trump mentioned Obama in his response to the Charlottesville protests, during which white supremacists and other fringe groups clashed with counter-protesters. <U+0089><db><cf>We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides <U+0089><U+06E5> on many sides,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Trump said Saturday. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long time in our country, not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long, long time.<U+0089><U+06DD> At least three people died in the Charlottesville area Saturday. A 32-year-old woman was killed after a car plowed into a group of anti-racist protesters. Two more people were killed in a helicopter crash near Charlottesville. The Associated Press has reported that the crash was linked in some way to the violence in Charlottesville, but the details were not immediately clear.
Title.x: Obama Responds To Charlottesville Violence With A Quote From Nelson Mandela
Title.y: Obama Responds To Charlottesville Violence With A Quote From Nelson Mandela

text: The mayor of San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Saturday defended her request for federal aid in the wake of Hurricane Maria, hours after President Donald Trump lashed out at her for asking for assistance and accused her of unnecessarily criticizing him. During an appearance on MSNBC,<e5><ca>Carmen Yulin Cruz reiterated that Puerto Rico needed more help and said her previous critiques of the administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s response had not been intended as a personal slight. <U+0089><db><cf>Actually, I was asking for help,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>I wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t saying anything nasty about the president.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>I will continue to do whatever I need to do, say whatever I need to say, compliment the people I need to compliment, and call out the people that I need to call out,<U+0089><U+06DD> she added.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>This isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t about me. This isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t about anyone. This is about lives that are being lost if things do not get done properly real quickly.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump had tweeted criticisms of Cruz earlier in the day, saying she demonstrated<e5><U+0289><db><cf>poor leadership ability.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>The Mayor of San Juan, who was very complimentary only a few days ago, has now been told by the Democrats that you must be nasty to Trump,<U+0089><U+06DD> he wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>They want everything to be done for them when it should be a community effort,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump added, noting how there were now 10,000 federal workers on the <U+0089><db><cf>totally destroyed<U+0089><U+06DD> island who were <U+0089><db><cf>doing a fantastic job.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also criticized CNN and NBC for their coverage of the relief effort. He tweeted again on Saturday afternoon, claiming the media was misrepresenting aid work taking place in Puerto Rico. The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s posts were an apparent reaction to the criticism that Cruz has leveled at his administration in recent days over its handling of the fallout from the natural disaster, which has claimed at least 16 lives since ripping through the island more than a week ago. Elaine Duke, the acting secretary of homeland security, on Thursday enthusiastically praised how federal authorities had reacted to the aftermath of the storm. <U+0089><db><cf> I know it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a hard storm to recover from ,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>But I know it is really a good news story in terms of our ability to reach people and the limited number of deaths that have taken place in such a devastating hurricane.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz, however, called that statement <U+0089><db><cf>irresponsible.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf> This is a people are dying story . This is a life or death story,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said on Friday<U+0089><U+06EA>s broadcast of CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>New Day.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This is a story of a devastation that continues to worsen because people are not getting food and water.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz also used a news conference at a distribution center on Friday to blast the response and ask Trump to step up efforts to get aid delivered to islanders in need. <U+0089><db><cf> We are dying here, and I cannot fathom the thought that the greatest nation in the world cannot figure out logistics for a small island of 100 miles by 35 miles,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. <U+0089><db><cf>Mayday! We are in trouble.<U+0089><U+06DD> She has responded to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets by saying that the one goal was <U+0089><db><cf>saving lives.<U+0089><U+06DD> Critics have also called out Trump for devoting so much time to attacking NFL players who take a knee during the national anthem as the relief effort was struggling to get under way. Trump said Saturday that he would visit Puerto Rico with first lady Melania Trump on Tuesday. This article has been updated with comments Cruz made Saturday morning.
Title.x: San Juan Mayor Responds To Trump's Attacks: 'I Was Asking For Help'
Title.y: San Juan Mayor Responds To Trump's Attacks: 'I Was Asking For Help'

text: Actress Louise Linton, who married Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in June, posted and then deleted a photo of herself and her husband as they walked off an Air Force jet Monday that was akin to a fashion shoot tagging the designers she was wearing. After facing criticism from an Instagram user, Linton, who is married to the man who is fifth in the presidential line of succession, responded to the user with a long comment filled with classist attacks. Linton has now taken her Instagram account private, not allowing Instagram users who don<U+0089><U+06EA>t already follow her to see her account. In the now-deleted post, Linton and Mnuchin are photographed deplaning the military jet (according to Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s Instagram post, they were landing in Kentucky), which Mnuchin is required to use for official government travel. The caption on her Instagram post read: <U+0089><db><cf>Great #daytrip to #Kentucky! #nicest #people #beautiful #countryside #rolandmouret pants #tomford sunnies, #hermesscarf #valentinorockstudheels #valentino #usa<U+0089><U+06DD> Linton has tagged designers she appears to be wearing in previous Instagram posts, but it<U+0089><U+06EA>s unusual, if not unprecedented, for the spouse of a Cabinet secretary to promote the designers she is wearing in any social media post, much less one that includes a photograph of herself with her husband while on government travel. An Instagram user, called <U+0089><db><cf>Jenni M,<U+0089><U+06DD> responded to Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s post and said, <U+0089><db><cf>Glad we could pay for your little getaway. #deplorable<U+0089><U+06DD> Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to Jenni M came after she appeared to examine Jenni M<U+0089><U+06EA>s Instagram feed, making note of Jenni M<U+0089><U+06EA>s family and children. <U+0089><db><cf>@Jennimiller29 cute!....Aw!! Did you think this was a personal trip?! Adorable! Do you think the US govt paid for our honeymoon or personal travel?! Lololol. Have you given more to the economy than me and my husband? Either as an individual earner in taxes OR in self sacrifice to your country? I<U+0089><U+06EA>m pretty sure we paid more taxes toward our day <U+0089><db><cf>trip<U+0089><U+06DD> than you did. Pretty sure the amount we sacrifice per year is a lot more than you<U+0089><U+06EA>d be willing to sacrifice if the choice was yours. You<U+0089><U+06EA>re adorably out of touch. Thanks for the passive aggressive nasty comment. Your kids look very cute. Your life looks cute. I know you<U+0089><U+06EA>re mad but deep down you<U+0089><U+06EA>re really nice and so am I. Sending me passive aggressive Instagram comments isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t going to make life feel better. Maybe a nice message, one filled with wisdom and hunanity [SIC] would get more traction. Have a pleasant evening. Go chill out and watch the new game of thrones. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s fab!<U+0089><U+06DD> Linton on Tuesday released a statement apologizing for her <U+0089><db><cf>inappropriate and highly insensitive<U+0089><U+06DD> Instagram post and her response to Jenni M, according to CNN reporter Jeremy Diamond. Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s Instagram post comes at a time when her husband is under attack by some of President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s loyalists for his lack of populist credentials. Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s out-of-touch post isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t likely to help Mnuchin, the former Goldman Sachs executive who served as the finance chair of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s presidential campaign. A spokesman for Mnuchin did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The Instagram user that Linton attacked also did not respond to a message asking for comment. This is not Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s first encounter with controversy. In 2016, Linton came under fire for her self-published memoir, In Congo<U+0089><U+06EA>s Shadow , which detailed her time as a student in Zambia. In July of 2016, Zambians, and their advocates, criticized Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s portrayal of Zambia as a war-torn, poverty-stricken nation with wild animals running through the streets. Linton was also criticized for portraying herself as a white savior. Under pressure, Linton withdrew the book from sale and pledged to give any proceeds to charity. The actress actually dressed as Marie Antoinette in a 2007 episode of <U+0089><db><cf>CSI: NY.<U+0089><U+06DD> Mnuchin and Linton were in Kentucky on Monday to tour Fort Knox , which holds the federal government<U+0089><U+06EA>s $200 billion gold reserves. This article has been updated to include Linton<U+0089><U+06EA>s apology. Follow Yashar <U+0089><db><d3> or send him a tip <U+0089><db><d3> on Twitter: @yashar
Title.x: Steve Mnuchins Wife Has A Let Them Eat Cake Moment On Instagram
Title.y: Steve Mnuchins Wife Has A Let Them Eat Cake Moment On Instagram

text: I received a call Monday night from Roger Stone, the infamous political prankster and Donald Trump confidant. He wanted to talk about Anthony Scaramucci , whose 10-day tenure as White House communications director had just ended in ignominy. Stone said that Scaramucci reminded him of <U+0089><db><cf>a suicide bomber,<U+0089><U+06DD> then switched centuries for his next metaphor. <U+0089><db><cf>The administration is like the French Revolution,<U+0089><U+06DD> Stone said. <U+0089><db><cf>You never know who will be beheaded next.<U+0089><U+06DD> But Stone didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe that Scaramucci would stay far from the president for long. <U+0089><db><cf>As you know, none of us are ever really gone. He still has the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s cellphone, the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s private number. Just because he<U+0089><U+06EA>s not in the White House, no one should think his influence has gone.<U+0089><U+06DD> When I spoke to Scaramucci on Tuesday afternoon, the financier was more interested in justifying his recent past. From the beginning of his time in the Trump White House , way back on July 20, critics said that Scaramucci was too similar to Trump, too eager to be on TV, to last. Scaramucci was keenly aware of that particular liability. It explains why his opening news conference was so filled with compliments for the president. He knew there was only one person watching whose opinion of him mattered. <U+0089><db><cf>The president thought I killed it,<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci told me the following day, still clearly hyped up by his experience in the White House briefing room. <U+0089><db><cf>If you were 7 inches taller, I<U+0089><U+06EA>d be worried,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump told Scaramucci, according to someone familiar with the conversation who asked not to be named quoting the president. The euphoria wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t last long. A Politico reporter alerted Scaramucci that Ryan Lizza of The New Yorker tweeted Wednesday night that Scaramucci was at dinner with the president, first lady Melania Trump, Fox News host Sean Hannity and former Fox News co-president Bill Shine.  Scaramucci was livid about the information being passed on to a reporter. For one thing, he said the guest list was incomplete. The tweets didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t mention the presence of Ainsley Earhardt and Brian Kilmeade, co-hosts of <U+0089><db><cf>Fox & Friends,<U+0089><U+06DD> as well as White House counselor Kellyanne Conway and Vice President Mike Pence , who, he said, left before the sit-down dinner. For another, he knew that the full guest list also included Kimberly Guilfoyle, co-host of <U+0089><db><cf>The Five<U+0089><U+06DD> on Fox News. Early the next morning, Olivia Nuzzi of New York Magazine confirmed that Guilfoyle was there. Scaramucci realized that the inclusion of Guilfoyle would raise suspicion. He said he was aware that some associates and members of the media were gossiping about his friendship with the Fox host and feared this particular connection would only make matters worse. He said he took it as <U+0089><db><cf>an attack.<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci strongly denies having a sexual relationship with Guilfoyle. Stone, a friend of Guilfoyle<U+0089><U+06EA>s, explained that Scaramucci and Guilfoyle <U+0089><db><cf>are very close friends but nothing more.<U+0089><U+06DD> He added, <U+0089><db><cf>He is way too short for Kimberly.<U+0089><U+06DD> Through a Fox News spokesperson, Guilfoyle said she<U+0089><U+06EA>s known Scaramucci for years through her work at Fox News and the two are <U+0089><db><cf>good friends.<U+0089><U+06DD> As soon as Scaramucci returned from Wednesday night<U+0089><U+06EA>s dinner, he called Lizza and gave his now-infamous interview , published Thursday, in which he suggested that former White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus was a <U+0089><db><cf>paranoid schizophrenic<U+0089><U+06DD> and that White House chief strategist Steve Bannon practiced auto-fellatio. Scaramucci said he felt burned by the interview. <U+0089><db><cf> The Lizzas and Scaramuccis have been friends for over 50 years. My dad knew his dad from construction, and we were building a personal relationship. Most of what I said was humorous and joking. Legally, it may have been on the record, but the spirit of it was off. And he knew that.<U+0089><U+06DD> Still, Scaramucci told me, he has plans to take Lizza out for a beer. When I asked Lizza for his response, he wrote back: <U+0089><db><cf> I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve only known Anthony in his capacity as a Trump surrogate and then White House communications director. We are not and have never been <U+0089><db><f7>old family friends,<U+0089><U+06EA> though I think our fathers knew each other, so maybe that<U+0089><U+06EA>s what he<U+0089><U+06EA>s talking about. (The Long Island Italian world in that generation is relatively small.) But again, that would not be a reason to suppress an explosive on-the-record interview.<U+0089><U+06DD> According to several sources close to the White House, the president was initially amused by the Lizza exchange but changed his opinion when he saw how much negative attention it was bringing. Scaramucci said he offered to resign before the weekend. The president told him that wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be necessary, but he instructed Scaramucci to <U+0089><db><cf>watch it<U+0089><U+06DD> in the future, according to someone familiar with the conversation. I spoke with Scaramucci on Saturday morning, and he sounded defeated. <U+0089><db><cf>I think I have strep,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. On top of everything else, the night before, The New York Post had broken the news of his impending divorce from his second wife, Deidre Ball. That Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s marriage was in trouble was hardly a secret. Long before Ball filed for divorce on July 6, Scaramucci was open with friends and associates about what he believed to be the sorry state of their union and how they were struggling through regular counseling sessions. He just hated that his relationship was being discussed in public. A follow-up report from the Post said that Scaramucci didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t attend the birth of their son last week. Instead, he sent Ball a short congratulatory text. Scaramucci said this is an unfair characterization of events. He told me that Ball<U+0089><U+06EA>s due date was Aug. 9, so when he boarded Air Force One to West Virginia last Monday to attend the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s address at the National Scout Jamboree, he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t think he<U+0089><U+06EA>d be in danger of missing the birth. As soon as she texted him that she was going into labor, he said, he looked into chartering a plane from West Virginia but discovered that there was a wide no fly-zone around Air Force One. He explained that he decided to wait to fly back to Washington with the president, then travel to New York from there. As of Tuesday afternoon, he still hadn<U+0089><U+06EA>t met his son. Scaramucci claimed that right after the birth Ball texted him her request for some space. When I asked about this text, Ball<U+0089><U+06EA>s lawyer, Jill Stone, responded: <U+0089><db><cf>Any texts of that nature had nothing to do with the baby or seeing the baby.<U+0089><U+06DD> (Jill Stone said she couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t comment on the rest of Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s version of events.) When I spoke to Scaramucci on Saturday, he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have much to say about the collapse of his marriage. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s fine. I mean, what am I going to do?<U+0089><U+06DD> He perked up when he started talking about the fantastic team he was going to bring into the White House<U+0089><U+06EA>s communications shop and the big plans he was going to enact after a tumultuous first week. But on Monday morning, Scaramucci knew he was cooked. Retired Marine Gen. John Kelly , the new chief of staff, who insisted that all White House staff report to him, asked for his resignation. <U+0089><db><cf>It was a very polite conversation,<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci says. Scaramucci then went to see Trump, who was unavailable. He ended up speaking with the president, his daughter Ivanka Trump and his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, separately later in the day by telephone. All were gracious, he said. <U+0089><db><cf>The president told me he knows I have his back, but he has to try to tighten the ship.<U+0089><U+06DD> So what are you going to do next, I asked him. <U+0089><db><cf>I am now going to go dark,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. And then? <U+0089><db><cf>Then I will reemerge.<U+0089><U+06DD> He paused. <U+0089><db><cf>As me.<U+0089><U+06DD> CLARIFICATION:<e5><ca>The section about Ryan Lizza<U+0089><U+06EA>s and Olivia Nuzzi<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets was changed to more accurately reflect the night<U+0089><U+06EA>s sequence of events.
Title.x: Why The Mooch Lost His Cool
Title.y: Why The Mooch Lost His Cool

text: When President Donald Trump went after local officials in Puerto Rico, accusing them of wanting <U+0089><db><cf>everything to be done for them,<U+0089><U+06DD> one TV writer had the perfect response. Using Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s own words and a single photo from 2011, former <U+0089><db><cf>Tonight Show<U+0089><U+06DD> writer Jess Dweck offered Trump some ice cold tea. The photo is from a 2011 shoot the Trump family did at his ultra-lavish Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Florida. The original photo can be found on Getty Images<U+0089><U+06EA> website , titled <U+0089><db><cf>Melania, Donald, And Barron Trump Shoot At Mar-a-Lago Club.<U+0089><U+06DD> The caption of the photo above says the Trumps are posing with the Mar-a-Lago <U+0089><db><cf>household staff.<U+0089><U+06DD> It<U+0089><U+06EA>s part of a series of photos featuring the Trumps literally swimming in luxury and posing in various parts of the famed estate, including one of Melania Trump in a gown playing tennis . Tweeting from his similarly extravagant golf club in Bedminster,<e5><ca>New Jersey, Trump accused local officials in Puerto Rico of wanting <U+0089><db><cf>everything to be done for them,<U+0089><U+06DD> in the aftermath of two devastating hurricanes. <U+0089><db><cf>Such poor leadership ability by the Mayor of San Juan, and others in Puerto Rico, who are not able to get their workers to help,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump wrote in a series of tweets on Saturday. <U+0089><db><cf>They want everything to be done for them when it should be a community effort.<U+0089><U+06DD> The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweets were in response to several emotional pleas from San Juan Mayor Carmen Yul<cc>_n Cruz,<e5><ca>who asked the government to provide more aid and less paperwork to the hurricane-wretched island. Many people were shocked at the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s remark, especially since he suggested Puerto Ricans <U+0089><U+06E5> a majority of whom are still without power and drinking water , according to the Defense Department <U+0089><U+06E5><e5><ca>weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t putting in enough effort to help themselves. The tweet drew angry responses from many who wanted Trump to know what kind of work Puerto Ricans were doing to recover from the storm.
Title.x: One Photo Stands Out After Trump Says Puerto Rico Wants 'Everything Done For Them'
Title.y: One Photo Stands Out After Trump Says Puerto Rico Wants 'Everything Done For Them'

text: Paul Manafort ,<e5><ca>the former Trump campaign chairman who was indicted on federal conspiracy and money laundering charges Monday, has a long history of ties to pro-Putin groups in Ukraine.<e5><ca>He also has a long history of connections to Donald Trump . According to leaked texts sent and received by his daughter, Andrea Manafort Shand, the two pals were <U+0089><db><cf>perfect allies.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Trump administration has been working overtime to downplay Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s role in last year<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign. <U+0089><db><cf>Paul Manafort was brought in to lead the delegate process, which he did, and was dismissed not too long after that,<U+0089><U+06DD> White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said Monday. <U+0089><db><cf>Paul was brought on sometime in June, and by the middle of August he was no longer with the campaign,<U+0089><U+06DD> then-press secretary Sean Spicer said in March. Spicer<U+0089><U+06EA>s statement was untrue, and Sanders<U+0089><U+06EA> claim was misleading. The public record shows that Manafort, who had known Trump for decades ,<e5><ca>joined his campaign toward the end of March 2016. And Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s eventual resignation didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t necessarily indicate he was leaving Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s orbit, according to his daughter<U+0089><U+06EA>s texts. Manafort Shand may have wanted to inflate her father<U+0089><U+06EA>s role to impress her friends. But even after her father stepped down from the campaign last August , Manafort Shand was under the impression that he had continuing influence within the Trump campaign and beyond. The following texts, sent by Manafort Shand to her sister, Jessica Manafort, and to friends and part of a cache discovered by the website Krypt3ia earlier this year, offer a markedly different understanding of the Trump/Manafort relationship than the president and his allies are attempting to sell.<e5><ca>(Manafort previously confirmed the authenticity of several of the other texts to Politico.) The texts have been lightly edited for grammar and clarity. March 17, 2016: The Manafort daughters claim Trump asked their father to run his campaign. Jessica Manafort: Guess who called Dad last night and asked him to run his convention. Andrea Manafort Shand: Mom told me he was going to call dad. She told me to get ready for Trump to be president and pick the position in the White House I want. JM: Dad gave him his list of requirements and so long as he can fulfill the list, Dad accepted. March 29:<e5><ca>Even before he was announced as campaign chairman, her father<U+0089><U+06EA>s role was much larger than the public knew,<e5><ca>Manafort Shand claims. Friend: I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not paying enough attention to really form an opinion. But yea I think economy makes sense, just hate what an asshole<e5><ca>[Trump] is in the process. AMS: Well hopefully my dad will help scale that back. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s part of the reason he was brought on. He is refusing payment. Bc he doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to be viewed as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s employee. Only having his expenses covered. He is involved purely because he wants to help the country and he thinks trump is best, so long as trump gets trained a bit. PS this is all top secret, so please do not repeat. AMS: Dude he is second in command. Perhaps arguably running it. The campaign manager is all for show. [Corey Lewandowski] doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t do shit. Trump has been managing his own campaign April 7: Manafort Shand paints her father as a master manipulator who is a close ally of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s. [ After sending her friend a CNN article hinting at Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s expanded role within the campaign. ] Friend: Is Paul getting a bigger role?! Seems like it ... AMS : You<U+0089><U+06EA>re surprised?? I told you this was the game. You think Paul does anything in moderation? Friend : And like, if Trump gets elected, guess who<U+0089><U+06EA>s gonna be chief of staff ... AMS : Phffff. He would never accept. Friend : Too many skeletons in his closet? AMS : Too constrictive. Paul is a lone wolf. Has to go his own way. Do what he wants when he wants how he wants. He doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have room for other people and their needs/wants. Friend : Yea that sounds about right AMS : He likes the challenge. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s why he<U+0089><U+06EA>s doing this. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a game for him. He isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t being paid. Friend : Man I bet he<U+0089><U+06EA>s loving it. AMS : This is pure sport. He is a power hungry egomaniac. Yes. He is loving it. Conclusively. Him and trump are perfect allies for this agenda. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s so weird he is my dad. [ Later ] AMS : It<U+0089><U+06EA>s just weird. Like<e5><ca>[my dad] doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t seem that smart. Like he is smart. But I know I<U+0089><U+06EA>m smarter than him. Friend : I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t doubt that, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s a master manipulator. Which seems pretty key. AMS : He is very manipulative. I did inherit that ability. But I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t exploit it like he does. I know all his tactics. They aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t that brilliant but they do work. Friend : But yes you<U+0089><U+06EA>re right, you have a moral conscious [sic]. AMS : Like he just tells you the sky is green over and over. And eventually you are like is it? I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t possess the ability to just lie like he does. Friend : Yea he works his charm. AMS : It<U+0089><U+06EA>s confidence. When you say something unwaveringly, people start to believe it. Friend : I mean yea that got Trump where he is today. AMS : Yup. Perfect allies. Trump probably has more morals than my dad. Which is really just saying something about my dad. My dad is a psycho!!! At least trump let his wives leave him. Plus, Trump has been a good father. AMS : Trump waited a little too long in my opinion, but I can attest to the fact that he has now hired one of the world<U+0089><U+06EA>s greatest manipulators. I hope my dad pulls it off. Then I can sell my memoir with all his dirty secrets for a pretty penny. [ Later, Manafort Shand talks to another friend about her feelings regarding the campaign. ] AMS : He was brought on to be convention manager, but really it was always to run shit. And now that<U+0089><U+06EA>s being publicly known. Or acknowledged I guess. [ Later ] JM : Dad and Trump are literally living in the same building and mom says they go up and down all day long hanging and plotting together April 12: Manafort Shand offers campaign-related favors from her father to a friend. AMS : By the way, if you want to exploit my dad to better your career, please let me know. Friend : Are you serious? AMS : Completely. Friend : I wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be opposed to exploiting him. AMS : I am on a business email basis with my dad. [ Later ] AMS : My dad is Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s right-hand man right now and will be through November. But he won<U+0089><U+06EA>t accept any position in the White House, so his leverage will diminish at that point (assuming Trump wins). April 13: Manafort refused payment as a power play, his daughter claims. AMS : Yup. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s a match made in heaven. Egomaniacs galore. AMS : But yea<e5><ca>[my dad is] super tight with the Trumps. All the kids call him all the time. And him and Trump both live in Trump Tower in NYC. So it<U+0089><U+06EA>s like a sitcom. Although <U+0089><db><d3> top top secret. Can<U+0089><U+06EA>t repeat, promise? My dad isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t getting paid for trump. Friend : WHAT, really? AMS : He refused payment. Trump is only covering expenses. Friend : Political favors later? AMS : Eh maybe but the truth of it is, I think there are rules for how much you can pay campaign personnel, so it isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t much to start with <U+0089><db><d3> not to my dad anyway. And my dad wants Trump to listen to him and respect him. View him as an equal, not as staff. So refusing payment makes it so. And makes it clear to Trump why my dad is doing it <U+0089><db><d3> because he wants to. AMS : And my dad won<U+0089><U+06EA>t take an appointment either. Trump knows that, too. So this isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t for personal gain for my dad, and that<U+0089><U+06EA>s true <U+0089><db><d3> not a game. So why is my dad doing it? Sport. AMS : This is his wheelhouse. And he gets off on power too. My dad loves challenges and this is like a chess game. He got a mistress because he was bored. Trump is his new mistress. May 19:<e5><ca>Although her father was never officially co-manager with Lewandowski, Manafort Shand claims that was effectively the case. [ After sending her friend a link to an ABC article about Manafort moving up yet again within the campaign .] AMS : My mom told me they were gonna call them co-managers, and then Corey went to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s son-in-law,<e5><ca>Ivanka<U+0089><U+06EA>s husband, and burst into tears about how that would ruin him. So since my dad doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t care about titles, this was the compromise. May 26: Manafort Shand offers campaign-related favors from her father to Lockheed Martin. Friend : Helleeew! I have an awkward favor/question to ask, so if you<U+0089><U+06EA>re not down, I totally understand. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not sure how you and your dad are these days, and I<U+0089><U+06EA>m gonna guess you<U+0089><U+06EA>re overloaded with requests to get in touch, but if it<U+0089><U+06EA>s do-able, could you help me get in touch with or pass on an email to someone in your dads office? AMS : Sure, what<U+0089><U+06EA>s your end goal? Friend : It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not an effort to help the campaign. My dad works for Lockheed Martin, and they want to essentially let Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s transition team know that they<U+0089><U+06EA>re ready, available, and happy to provide info about defense acquisition and sustainment. So to discuss policy. But they can<U+0089><U+06EA>t reach out to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s team <U+0089><db><d3> the team would have to reach out to them. So I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve got an email with info that would be amazing if passed on to the right people. Again <U+0089><db><d3> if this is not your cup of tea, totally forget I asked. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m only asking bc it<U+0089><U+06EA>s my dad. AMS : I hear ya <U+0089><db><d3> it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not a problem, I just think it<U+0089><U+06EA>s probably a bit early. But I can ask my mom who the right person would be to receive the email. I would imagine Rick Davis or Rick Gates. But I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll find out and let you/them know. Friend : Thank you!! I really appreciate it. I think they want to get in front ahead of time instead of play catch up. I feel weird asking for a favor like this haha. AMS : You<U+0089><U+06EA>re not the first. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s no bother. I am happy to be a conduit. I just can<U+0089><U+06EA>t promise anything other than initial access. Friend : Just being a conduit is amazing! Zero expectations, just doin what I can for my dad so anything at all is fucking great. AMS :<e5><ca>Totally get it. Not every day you know the man behind the man. Gotta exploit it. Which is why I am happy to help. Cuz fuck it, hopefully someone can benefit by my relation to the count of Monte Cristo. June 20: Manafort had enough sway to pick Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s vice president,<e5><ca>his daughter claims. AMS : My dad is picking VP. So there<U+0089><U+06EA>s that. Aug. 17: Trump hires Steve Bannon and promotes Kellyanne Conway . Manafort Shand claims that her father was really the one who hired them and that public perception of his being sidelined is incorrect. AMS : [My dad] hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t been demoted. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s total bullshit. No surprise that the media is wrong. Again. My dad hired those 2 people. Interviewed them in trump towers Aug. 19: Manafort Shand claims that her father<U+0089><U+06EA>s resignation was merely to appease the public, but that he<U+0089><U+06EA>s still very much involved. AMS : So I got to the bottom of it. As I suspected, my dad resigned from being the public face of the campaign but is still very much involved behind the scenes. He felt he was becoming a distraction and that would ultimately take a toll on the campaign. Friend : Wow. Well, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m really glad he<U+0089><U+06EA>s still part of it. Seriously, who knows what would have happened at the convention if he wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t running the show. AMS : Yes for sure. He said that, in the next few weeks, we should hopefully be seeing a new Trump, so to speak. Last night<U+0089><U+06EA>s speech was a speech my dad had been pushing him to make for several weeks, and since it was so well-received, he thinks Trump will be more responsive to doing things a bit differently. [ Later ] Friend : Thoughts go out to your pops <U+0089><db><d3> I can only imagine that he<U+0089><U+06EA>s relieved, angry, hurting, a combination of a lot of emotions. Wishing you and your fam the best AMS : Hahaha, you<U+0089><U+06EA>re so silly. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s all just PR. Paul Manafort, Andrea Manafort Shand and the White House did not respond to requests for comment.
Title.x: Paul Manafort's Daughter Texted Friends About How Tight Her Dad Was With Trump
Title.y: Paul Manafort's Daughter Texted Friends About How Tight Her Dad Was With Trump

text: In the past few days, thousands white supremacists have taken over Charlottesville, Virginia, for a <U+0089><db><cf>Unite The Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally . The rally has also attracted plenty of counter-protesters, namely Antifa <U+0089><U+06E5> a fringe left radical group that stands for <U+0089><db><cf>Anti-fascism.<U+0089><U+06DD> Violence and chaos has since ensued on both sides. The governor declared a state of emergency early Saturday morning. Charlottesville has become a city under siege. In looking at photographs and video of the happenings in Virginia, you would think you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve gone back in time to the Civil Rights era. They are clear indications that racism, anti-Semitism, sexism <U+0089><U+06E5> pure, unfiltered hatred <U+0089><U+06E5> is still thriving in America in 2017. If you<U+0089><U+06EA>re thinking, <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not that bad,<U+0089><U+06DD> then you<U+0089><U+06EA>re not paying attention. Let the photos speak for themselves. This is the world we live in and we must do better:
Title.x: Look At What's Happening In America In 2017
Title.y: Look At What's Happening In America In 2017

text: Eric Bolling, a longtime Fox News host, sent an unsolicited photo of male genitalia via text message to at least two colleagues at Fox Business and one colleague at Fox News , a dozen sources told HuffPost. Recipients of the photo confirmed its contents to HuffPost, which is not revealing their identities. The women, who are Bolling<U+0089><U+06EA>s current and former Fox colleagues, concluded the message was from him because they recognized his number from previous work-related and informal interactions. The messages were sent several years ago, on separate occasions. The women did not solicit the messages, which they told colleagues were deeply upsetting and offensive. One of the recipients said that when she replied to Bolling via text, telling him never to send her such photos again, he did not respond. Four people, outside of the recipients, confirmed to HuffPost they<U+0089><U+06EA>d seen the photo, and eight others said the recipients had spoken to them about it. For this story, HuffPost spoke to 14 sources in and out of Fox News and Fox Business, all of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity either because they currently work at the networks and aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t allowed to speak to members of the press without prior authorization or because they have confidentiality agreements with Fox News and its parent company 21st Century Fox. Over the past year, the network has been rocked by multiple accusations of sexual harassment and assault by Fox News and Fox Business executives and on-air talent. Last year, former Fox News Chairman Roger Ailes resigned after former Fox News host Gretchen Carlson filed a lawsuit accusing him of sexual harassment. Since Ailes was forced out, multiple former and current Fox News hosts have accused him of harassment, including CNN anchor Alisyn Camerota. Last April, after a bombshell New York Times report revealed that Bill O<U+0089><U+06EA>Reilly had quietly settled multiple sexual harassment suits, the network forced him out. Reached Friday by HuffPost about the accusations against Bolling, a Fox spokesperson said,<e5><U+0289><db><cf>We were just informed of this and plan to investigate the matter.<U+0089><U+06DD> When asked whether Bolling at any point had sent unsolicited lewd or inappropriate text messages or emails (including an image of a man<U+0089><U+06EA>s genitalia) to Fox News or Fox Business colleagues, his attorney Michael J. Bowe responded, <U+0089><db><cf>Mr. Bolling recalls no such inappropriate communications, does not believe he sent any such communications, and will vigorously pursue his legal remedies for any false and defamatory accusations that are made.<U+0089><U+06DD> Bolling, a former commodities trader, has worked at the Fox News and Fox Business networks since 2007, when he joined after leaving CNBC. He has had a history of making misogynistic on-air remarks during his tenure at Fox News, the most notable during a September 2014 segment on the panel show <U+0089><db><cf>The Five<U+0089><U+06DD> while discussing the first woman fighter pilot from the United Arab Emirates leading the bombing of the Islamic State. Bolling asked on air if instead of saying <U+0089><db><cf>boots on the ground<U+0089><U+06DD> it would be more appropriate to say <U+0089><db><cf>boobs on the ground.<U+0089><U+06DD> He apologized the next day, citing <U+0089><db><cf>a look<U+0089><U+06DD> he got from his wife when he arrived home. The allegations against Bolling recall statements he made attacking Anthony Weiner in 2014, after the former New York congressman had been embroiled in a scandal for sexting several women. During a Twitter war with Weiner, Bolling concluded with a tweet that said: <U+0089><db><cf>text us if you want a fair & balanced intv **NO SEFIES PLEASE [sic]**<U+0089><U+06DD> In May 2017, when Weiner pleaded guilty to federal charges of exchanging lewd messages with an underage girl, Bolling said , <U+0089><db><cf>He is a sick human being, to continue to do this time and time again, continue to get caught, saying he<U+0089><U+06EA>s not going to do it again, gets caught again.<U+0089><U+06DD> Bolling serves as one of the co-hosts of <U+0089><db><cf>The Specialists,<U+0089><U+06DD> a new program on the Fox News Channel. Previously, he served as one of the hosts of <U+0089><db><cf>The Five<U+0089><U+06DD> and as a fill-in host for O<U+0089><U+06EA>Reilly and Sean Hannity.
