After the network fired O<U+0089><U+06EA>Reilly last April, Fox News announced that Bolling would leave the <U+0089><db><cf>The Five<U+0089><U+06DD> and host another panel program at 5 p.m. with co-hosts Eboni Williams and Katherine Timpf. Bolling<U+0089><U+06EA>s star at the Fox Networks has risen in the past two years, in part because of his close relationship with and strong support of President Donald Trump. Bolling can often be seen aggressively defending Trump on the network, and his loyalty has been repaid. Over the past few years, Trump has tweeted praise and support for Bolling at least a dozen times, including support for his book in 2016. When <U+0089><db><cf>The Specialists<U+0089><U+06DD> premiered earlier this year, Bolling was granted an exclusive interview with Trump. Fox News recently renewed Bolling<U+0089><U+06EA>s contract. In a statement in June, Fox News co-president Suzanne Scott said that Bolling<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf> insight is valued, and we are pleased to have him at the network for many more years to come.<U+0089><U+06DD> The multiyear extension ended speculation that he was going to accept a position in the Trump administration. In an interview with NJ.Com, Bolling said the Trump transition had floated the position of commerce secretary, but he said he would only consider joining as a senior adviser. In the interview, Bolling said he believed he had a future in politics : <U+0089><db><cf> When the lights go down on my TV career, the next step is running for Senate.<U+0089><U+06DD> Follow Yashar <U+0089><db><d3> or send him a tip <U+0089><db><d3> on Twitter: @yashar
Title.x: Fox News Host Sent Unsolicited Lewd Text Messages To Colleagues, Sources Say
Title.y: Fox News Host Sent Unsolicited Lewd Text Messages To Colleagues, Sources Say

text: Anthony Scaramucci has resigned from his role as White House communications director. Scaramucci was named communications director on July 21, a mere 10 days ago. Axios reports he resigned at the request of Gen. John Kelly, the new White House chief of staff. <U+0089><db><cf>Mr. Scaramucci felt it was best to give Chief of Staff John Kelly a clean slate and the ability to build his own team,<U+0089><U+06DD> a statement from the White House press secretary said Monday. <U+0089><db><cf>We wish him all the best.<U+0089><U+06DD> According to CBS and CNN, Scaramucci was escorted from White House grounds Monday. The resignation comes after a controversy-laden week for Scaramucci that included a profanity-laced tirade against other members of President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s White House staff. His rant, published in The New Yorker, was mostly aimed at then-White House chief of staff Reince Priebus. ( Priebus resigned from his post last week and was replaced Monday morning by Kelly.) Scaramucci referred to Priebus as <U+0089><db><cf>a fucking paranoid schizophrenic, a paranoiac.<U+0089><U+06DD> Scaramucci also gave one of the more memorable quotes so far of the Trump administration during that interview, while arguing that he doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t care for media attention. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not Steve Bannon, I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not trying to suck my own cock,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. But that rant wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t the only eyebrow-raising moment during his 10 days in the White House. Scaramucci brought on criticism after directing comments about hair and makeup at White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders. He also reportedly received divorce papers from his wife, who gave birth to the couple<U+0089><U+06EA>s son while Scaramucci was with Trump last week. Michael Short, an aide in the White House press office, resigned last week because of pressure from Scaramucci, who had threatened to <U+0089><db><cf>fire everybody<U+0089><U+06DD> in order to stop leaks. Even his hire was laden with controversy. Former White House press secretary Sean Spicer reportedly submitted his resignation after learning Trump was giving Scaramucci a prominent role on the White House communications team. Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s short tenure followed that of Mike Dubke, who resigned in May after just three months as White House communications director. Just this morning, Trump assured his Twitter followers there is <U+0089><db><cf>No WH chaos!<U+0089><U+06DD> When asked about Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure during a White House press briefing Monday afternoon, Sanders confirmed that Scaramucci <U+0089><db><cf>does not have a role at this time in the Trump administration,<U+0089><U+06DD> saying Scaramucci and Kelly came to <U+0089><db><cf>a mutual agreement<U+0089><U+06DD> about Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure. She would not say if Scaramucci resigned or was fired. Of Kelly, Sanders said, <U+0089><db><cf>all staff will report to him.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sanders also commented on Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s interview with The New Yorker, saying Trump found the remarks <U+0089><db><cf>inappropriate.<U+0089><U+06DD> This was a breaking story that has been updated throughout.
Title.x: Anthony Scaramucci Out At White House After A Whirlwind 10 Days
Title.y: Anthony Scaramucci Out At White House After A Whirlwind 10 Days

text: President Donald Trump issued an explosive statement against <U+0089><db><cf>Radical Islamic Terror<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>just hours after an attack in Barcelona, Spain, on Thursday left at least 13 people dead. Earlier this week, Trump said he needed to get all <U+0089><db><cf>the facts<U+0089><U+06DD> before singling out hate groups for condemnation after violent protests sparked by a white supremacist rally left one woman dead in Charlottesville, Virginia, on Saturday. Trump initially posted a measured response to the incident in Barcelona: Less than an hour after his initial tweet, Trump followed up, implying the Barcelona attack was linked to <U+0089><db><cf>Radical Islamic Terror<U+0089><U+06DD>: During the Republican presidential primary race, Trump told crowds a story <U+0089><U+06E5> a false one , according to historians <U+0089><U+06E5> about John <U+0089><db><cf>Black Jack<U+0089><U+06DD> Pershing, the Army general who commanded U.S. forces in World War I. According to Mother Jones ,<e5><ca>Trump spoke of Pershing executing Muslim insurgents in the Philippines in the early 1900s with bullets dipped in pig<U+0089><U+06EA>s blood and eliminating <U+0089><db><cf>a problem<U+0089><U+06DD> for 25 years (unlike the 35 years mentioned in his tweet): He caught 50 terrorists who did tremendous damage<U+0089><db>_and he took the 50 terrorists and he took 50 men and dipped 50 bullets in pig<U+0089><U+06EA>s blood. You heard about that? He took 50 bullets and dipped them in pig<U+0089><U+06EA>s blood [which is considered haram]. And he has his men load up their rifles and he lined up the 50 people and they shot 49 of those people. And the 50th person, he said, you go back to your people and you tell them what happened. And for 25 years there wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t a problem. After telling that story, Trump claimed<e5><U+0289><db><cf>we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve got to start getting tough and we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve got to start being vigilant and we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve got to start using our heads or we<U+0089><U+06EA>re not gonna have a country, folks.<U+0089><U+06DD> As Time reported in 2016 , historians know of no evidence to support Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s claim. The magazine quoted one saying it would have been <U+0089><db><cf>out of character<U+0089><U+06DD> for Pershing. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments on Barcelona came just hours after news broke of the carnage there, which police confirmed they were treating as a terrorist attack. The so-called Islamic State claimed responsibility for the assault via its Amaq news agency, but it<U+0089><U+06EA>s unclear to what degree the group<U+0089><U+06EA>s leadership was involved in planning it. White House chief of staff John Kelly briefed Trump on the matter Thursday afternoon. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s quick response sharply contrasts with his reactions to the violence in Charlottesville. Trump argued in his initial response on Saturday that<e5><U+0289><db><cf>many sides<U+0089><U+06DD> were to blame for the tumult, which erupted amid a white supremacist protest against efforts to remove a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee. The president didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t explicitly condemn hate groups until Monday,<e5><ca>two days after a car allegedly driven by a white supremacist plowed into a group of counterprotesters, killing a 32-year-old woman . In a rambling press conference Tuesday, Trump defended his initial statement, arguing he needed to get <U+0089><db><cf>the facts<U+0089><U+06DD> before making more definitive remarks against racist groups. <U+0089><db><cf>I wanted to make sure, unlike most politicians, that what I said was correct, not make a quick statement. The statement I made on Saturday, the first statement, was a fine statement, but you don<U+0089><U+06EA>t make statements that direct unless you know the facts,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>It takes a little while to get the facts. You still don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know the facts. It is a very, very important process to me. It is a very important statement. So I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to go quickly and just make a statement for the sake of making a political statement. I want to know the facts.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump on Tuesday also again blamed <U+0089><db><cf>both sides<U+0089><U+06DD> for the clashes in Charlottesville. <U+0089><db><cf>You had a group on one side that was bad. You had a group on the other side that was also very violent,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. <U+0089><db><cf>Nobody wants to say that. I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll say it right now.<U+0089><U+06DD> But Trump has been quick to cite <U+0089><db><cf>radical Islamic terrorism<U+0089><U+06DD> for attacks in the past. It took him less than a day to respond to terrorist attacks in Paris, Manchester, England, and London, the last of which he used as a reason to plug his proposal for a travel ban from several Muslim-majority countries. His rhetoric toward <U+0089><db><cf>radical Islam<U+0089><U+06DD> is often violent and sweeping, unlike his comments on the white supremacist and racist groups who gathered for the rally in Charlottesville,<e5><ca>which Trump claimed had some <U+0089><db><cf> fine people .<U+0089><U+06DD> As Vox has pointed out, Trump has been generally slow to respond to violent incidents where Muslims are the victims. Trump also has claimed he can <U+0089><db><cf>predict<U+0089><U+06DD> terrorism , saying he <U+0089><db><cf>can feel it.<U+0089><U+06DD> After a gunman who claimed allegiance to the Islamic State attacked a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, in June 2016, killing 49 and wounding scores more, Trump bragged about <U+0089><db><cf> being right on radical Islamic terrorism .<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Trump's Quick Response To Barcelona Attack Makes His Charlottesville Reactions Look Even Worse
Title.y: Trump's Quick Response To Barcelona Attack Makes His Charlottesville Reactions Look Even Worse

text: Steve Bannon , a senior adviser to the president who was largely credited with shaping the strategy that got Donald Trump to the White House, is out from his role as the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s chief strategist. Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, said Bannon and Chief of Staff John Kelly agreed Friday would be his last day. <U+0089><db><cf>We are grateful for his service and wish him the best,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sanders said in a statement. The details of Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure remain unclear. The New York Times reported Trump had decided to remove Bannon, but also that a source close to Bannon said the adviser had submitted his resignation on Aug. 7 to be effective Aug. 14. MSNBC <U+0089><U+06EA>s Stephanie Ruhle also tweeted Bannon is <U+0089><db><cf>out.<U+0089><U+06DD> CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s Jim Acosta and Axios<U+0089><U+06EA> Jonathan Swan both tweeted Bannon had been fired. Vanity Fair<U+0089><U+06EA>s Gabriel Sherman tweeted that Bannon was expected to return to Breitbart News , the site espousing white nationalist views that he led before joining Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s president campaign. Charlie Spiering, Breitbart<U+0089><U+06EA>s White House correspondent, said Bannon had returned immediately and chaired an editorial meeting on Friday. Bannon told Bloomberg Businessweek that he is going to fight for Trump <U+0089><db><cf>against his opponents <U+0089><U+06E5> on Capitol Hill, in the media, and in corporate America.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>If there<U+0089><U+06EA>s any confusion out there, let me clear it up: I<U+0089><U+06EA>m leaving the White House and going to war,<U+0089><U+06DD> he told the outlet. A source close to Bannon told The Atlantic<U+0089><U+06EA>s Rosie Gray that Bannon is now <U+0089><db><cf>fully unchained.<U+0089><U+06DD> Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure comes amid a recent wave of White House staffing shakeups and turmoil. According to Axios , Trump believed that Bannon was behind recent leaks to the press. The president has made stopping leaks a top priority. Backlash over Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to white supremacist violence in Charlottesville, Virginia ,<e5><ca>may have also led to the departure.<e5><ca>Former White House communications director Anthony Scaramucci on Sunday blamed Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s failure to directly call out far-right groups on Bannon. Scaramucci himself was fired after just 10 days on the job , after he forced out then-chief of staff Reince Priebus . Both Bannon and Priebus had strongly objected to Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s hiring, and former press secretary Sean Spicer resigned over it . In a statement, the Democratic National Committee said Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure would mean <U+0089><db><cf>there is one less white supremacist in the White House, but that doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t change the man sitting behind the Resolute desk.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Donald Trump has spent decades fueling hate in communities, including his recent attempts to divide our country and give a voice to white supremacists,<U+0089><U+06DD> the group said in a statement. Bannon, who left Breitbart to run Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign in August 2016, pushed Trump to be loyal to the populist base that got him elected. He was a conservative force in the West Wing who helped draft Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s controversial ban on travel and immigration from several Muslim-majority countries. Bannon was once considered one of the most influential members of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s inner circle, but he has receded from public view in recent months. After his feud with Jared Kushner, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s son-in-law, became public earlier this year, Trump urged the two to work it out. Politico also reported Trump was upset over a new book highlighting the importance of Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s role in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s presidential campaign. Bannon also gave a bizarre interview this week to The American Prospect, a progressive publication, calling white supremacists a <U+0089><db><cf>collection of clowns<U+0089><U+06DD> and contradicted Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s military threats to North Korea. In April, when Bannon and Kushner feuded, Trump downplayed Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s role during his presidential campaign, portraying him as someone who took over in the homestretch and whom he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know well . Bannon once pledged to fight for the <U+0089><db><cf> deconstruction of the administrative state .<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>He long assailed establishment Republicans and reportedly called House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) a <U+0089><db><cf>limp-dick motherfucker<U+0089><U+06DD> when there was talk of pushing Ryan to challenge Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s claim to the Republican nomination. Progressives long protested Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s elevation to his role as Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s chief strategist, citing his offensive views . Following Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s apparent refusal to denounce the white nationalist protesters in Charlottesville, they renewed their calls to <U+0089><db><cf>fire Bannon.<U+0089><U+06DD> Leaders of the congressional black, Asian, Hispanic and progressive caucuses also had sent a letter to the White House demanding the dismissal of Bannon along with aides Stephen Miller and Sebastian Gorka, saying their presence in the White House emboldened white supremacists across the country. The letter came after Trump faced criticism for initially condemning <U+0089><db><cf>all sides<U+0089><U+06DD> after the violent protests in Charlottesville. <U+0089><db><cf>Americans deserve to know that white nationalists, white supremacists, and neo-Nazis are not in a position to influence U.S. policy,<U+0089><U+06DD> the letter said. <U+0089><db><cf>That is why we continue to find Steve Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s presence in your administration incredibly alarming and dangerous to our nation and the world, and once again, we urge you to immediately remove Steve Bannon from the White House altogether. As you know, Mr. Bannon is the co-founder of the white nationalist, <U+0089><db><f7>alt-right<U+0089><U+06EA> website, Breitbart News. Under his direction and approval, this site published blatantly bigoted rhetoric about women, Muslims, and other minorities. It is no wonder that white nationalist groups, such as the KKK, have praised Mr. Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s extreme political statements.<U+0089><U+06DD> This article has been updated with more details about Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure from the White House and return to Breitbart.
Title.x: Top Trump Adviser Steve Bannon Out From White House
Title.y: Top Trump Adviser Steve Bannon Out From White House

text: Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) is firing back at former presidential candidate Hillary Clinton . In her new book, What Happened , Clinton blames Sanders for doing<e5><U+0289><db><cf> lasting damage <U+0089><U+06DD> to her campaign. Sanders, speaking to Stephen Colbert on the CBS <U+0089><db><cf>Late Show<U+0089><U+06DD> on Thursday night,<e5><ca>wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t taking the blame. <U+0089><db><cf>Look, Secretary Clinton ran against the most unpopular candidate in the history of this country and she lost and she was upset about it and I understand that,<U+0089><U+06DD> the senator said. <U+0089><db><cf>But our job is really not to go backwards. It is to go forwards.<U+0089><U+06DD> He said the country is facing <U+0089><db><cf>enormous problems<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>I think it<U+0089><U+06EA>s a little bit silly to keep talking about 2016.<U+0089><U+06DD> And he was just getting warmed up. text: Monica Lewinsky didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t need 140 characters to tweet how she felt about Anthony Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s comparing himself to her . She needed just one emoji. On Wednesday evening, Scaramucci griped about Ryan Lizza, the New Yorker reporter to whom he made a series of crass comments last month, setting the stage for his own swift exit as White House communications director. Linda Tripp is the woman who befriended White House intern Monica Lewinsky and secretly recorded some of their conversations in an attempt to get dirt on Lewinsky<U+0089><U+06EA>s affair with then-President Bill Clinton . Scaramucci made the comparison between Lizza and Tripp because he claimed the reporter taped their call without telling him. (Quick reminder: Unlike Tripp<U+0089><U+06EA>s recording, Lizza<U+0089><U+06EA>s actions were clearly legal.) The bizarre tweets led many people to infer that if Lizza = Tripp, then Scaramucci = Lewinsky. Lewinsky waited until Thursday morning to offer her opinion on Twitter. It was worth the wait. For those not up on emoji arcana, the flushed face emoji is usually a comment on mistakes or other embarrassing situations . Yep. And yep.

text: In the public feud between Anthony Scaramucci and Reince Priebus , what hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t been fully explained is why Scaramucci so dislikes the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s now-former chief of staff <U+0089><db><d3> a man he alternates between calling <U+0089><db><cf>Reince Penis<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>Rancid Penis,<U+0089><U+06DD> according to an adviser to the White House. The acrimony first surfaced during the presidential transition. The two men had been cordial before then. They met six years ago, when Scaramucci was a fundraiser for presidential candidate Mitt Romney and Priebus was chair of the Republican National Committee. They interacted peaceably during Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign as Scaramucci made the rounds on television and at donor events. After Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s victory, Priebus was named chief of staff, and Scaramucci, according to someone close to the transition, was assured that he was also in line for a big position within the administration. (Sources for this story requested anonymity to discuss the details of sensitive conversations.) While preparing for his move into government, Scaramucci struck a deal <U+0089><db><d3> which is still under regulatory scrutiny <U+0089><db><d3> to sell his stake in his hedge fund, SkyBridge Capital, to Chinese conglomerate HNA Group and another company. He assumed that he<U+0089><U+06EA>d be put in charge of the public liaison office, a job that Valerie Jarrett held in the Obama administration. He had it all mapped out, according to the White House adviser. He identified 2,500 influential business leaders across the United States and had come up with a clever name for them: Trump Team 2,500. He believed these people would help pressure Congress into supporting the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s agenda. But Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s plans were foiled in early January. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s when Priebus, according to a confidant of both Scaramucci and the president, told Trump, <U+0089><db><cf>He played you.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>How<U+0089><U+06EA>s that?<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump asked Priebus, according to the same source, who has spoken to several people within the White House about the conversation. Priebus then told Trump that he felt Scaramucci had been offered too much for SkyBridge by HNA Group. The deal, he implied, smelled bad <U+0089><db><d3> as if the Chinese might expect favors from within the administration for that inflated price. The source also said that Priebus mentioned there was email traffic between Scaramucci and the Chinese proving this. The White House rejected this version of events and declined to make Priebus available for comment. Ultimately, Scaramucci was not offered the job. But he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t give up. He asked Trump son-in-law Jared Kushner to get him in the door. According to two people familiar with the conversation, Kushner assured him that he didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t think Scaramucci was <U+0089><db><cf>shady,<U+0089><U+06DD> adding, <U+0089><db><cf>But it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not what I think that matters.<U+0089><U+06DD> Priebus had already planted the seed of doubt in Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s mind . Scaramucci then tried presidential adviser Steve Bannon, who, according to those same two people, explained that he was too busy attempting to save the job of another adviser, Stephen Miller, to spend time or capital trying to help Scaramucci. A friend of Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s said he complained that some in the White House assumed his finances were suspect because he<U+0089><U+06EA>s of Italian descent. Scaramucci also took Priebus<U+0089><U+06EA> behavior as a sign that Priebus was feeling insecure about his own job. <U+0089><db><cf>I will try things the Washington way first,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump had told his inner circle when he first named Priebus chief of staff, according to the confidant of Scaramucci and Trump. The implication was clear: If the Washington way did not work, then the New York real estate way would take over. Finally, Scaramucci went to Keith Schiller, the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s longtime bodyguard. He asked Schiller to put him on the phone with Trump so that he could lodge his complaints directly. The president listened, according to their mutual friend, and said he would find a position for Scaramucci as soon as he could. In June, Scaramucci was appointed to be senior vice president and chief strategy officer of the Export-Import Bank. But the Priebus incident lingered in his mind. So, on July 11, when Donald Trump Jr. found himself in trouble for holding a meeting with several people close to the Russian government the previous summer, Scaramucci sensed an opportunity. According to the mutual friend, Scaramucci told everyone he spoke to that day, including the president, that he was sure the person who divulged details of the meeting was Priebus. Scaramucci made the case <U+0089><db><d3> not necessarily backed by evidence <U+0089><db><d3> that with all the leaks targeting the administration, it was odd that only a few had hit Priebus directly. Ten days later, Scaramucci was named the new White House communications director. The announcement noted that he would be reporting directly to the president <U+0089><db><d3> an unusual move that leapfrogged over the chief of staff. Priebus balked, insisting that Scaramucci report to him. But Trump overrode his chief of staff. Not only was the hedge fund manager who had known Trump for 21 years officially in charge of the press shop, but he was also set to oversee the reorganization of the White House. Scaramucci seemed to have his revenge. At least until Thursday evening. In an interview with The New Yorker , Scaramucci called Priebus <U+0089><db><cf>a fucking paranoid schizophrenic<U+0089><U+06DD> and explained how he, unlike Bannon, is <U+0089><db><cf>not trying to suck my own cock.<U+0089><U+06DD> Now, Scaramucci<U+0089><U+06EA>s future at the White House is less clear, even if Trump reportedly <U+0089><db><cf> loved <U+0089><U+06DD> the outburst. Two sources close to the president said the very traits that have so endeared Scaramucci to Trump <U+0089><db><d3> tenacity, frankness, limitless swagger <U+0089><db><d3> could end up endangering his new job if he continues to steal news cycles from the president. But those same sources said he<U+0089><U+06EA>s safe for now. <U+0089><db><cf>Mark my words: Anthony will ultimately be an exceptionally good communications director,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Sam Nunberg, a former Trump aide who still talks to the president. <U+0089><db><cf>His career proves he<U+0089><U+06EA>s a master communicator. I hope he keeps his perfect chin up.<U+0089><U+06DD> On Friday, the news broke that Priebus had been ousted as chief of staff. The story has been updated to remove a reference to a lawyer whom Scaramucci and Kushner share, as Scaramucci hired that attorney before he was first turned down for a job in the administration.
Title.x: Here's The Real Reason Anthony Scaramucci Hates Reince Priebus
Title.y: Here's The Real Reason Anthony Scaramucci Hates Reince Priebus

text: King James has spoken. After President Donald Trump tweeted Saturday morning he would be <U+0089><db><cf>withdrawing<U+0089><U+06DD> Golden State Warriors player Stephen Curry<U+0089><U+06EA>s invitation to visit the White House to celebrate his team<U+0089><U+06EA>s NBA title, LeBron James took to Twitter to give the president a piece of his mind. <U+0089><db><cf>U bum @ StephenCurry30 already said he ain<U+0089><U+06EA>t going!<U+0089><U+06DD> James wrote. <U+0089><db><cf>So therefore ain<U+0089><U+06EA>t no invite. Going to White House was a great honor until you showed up!<U+0089><U+06DD> Curry recently made it clear that he would not be visiting the White House, even though his team, the Golden State Warriors, won the 2017 NBA championship. <U+0089><db><cf>I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to go. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s the nucleus of my belief. If it was just me, it would be a pretty short conversation,<U+0089><U+06DD> Curry told reporters during Golden State<U+0089><U+06EA>s media day. James has also said he would not have visited the White House if his team, the Cleveland Cavaliers, had won. <U+0089><db><cf>Going to the White House is considered a great honor for a championship team,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump tweeted. <U+0089><db><cf>Stephen Curry is hesitating, therefore invitation is withdrawn!<U+0089><U+06DD> Curry played James three years in a row during the NBA finals, winning this past year. Even though the two have a rivalry for the ages, it looks like LBJ still has Curry<U+0089><U+06EA>s back when it counts.  CORRECTION : A previous version of this article stated that Curry had played James two years during the NBA finals. The Warriors have played the Cavaliers three years in a row during the NBA finals.
Title.x: LeBron James Tweets Brutal Response To Trump's Steph Curry Tweet

text: While President Donald Trump was inside the Pensacola Bay Center auditorium in Florida on Friday night, urging people to vote for Senate candidate Roy Moore , Ivanka Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s pointed comment on accusations against the Alabama Republican was plastered on a political ad outside. (She also said in that interview that she had <U+0089><db><cf>no reason to doubt the victims<U+0089><U+06EA> accounts.<U+0089><U+06DD>) She criticized Moore just days after The Washington Post reported he had had inappropriate relationships with teens when he was in his 30s. One woman said he removed her clothing and groped her when she was just 14. The ads were arranged for Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Pensacola rally by American Bridge , a liberal group and PAC. <U+0089><db><cf>Try as Trump and the Republican Party might, there<U+0089><U+06EA>s no way to escape the truth about Roy Moore or Ivanka Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s own words,<U+0089><U+06DD> American Bridge spokeswoman Allison Teixeira Sulier said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a disgusting new low that the President, the RNC, and the rest of the Republican Party are trying to help send a pedophile to the US Senate, and the American people won<U+0089><U+06EA>t soon forget it.<U+0089><U+06DD> The New York Times reported last month that Trump was angry with his daughter for speaking out against Moore. The president strongly supports the former judge despite multiple accusations of sexual misconduct.
