text: On Christmas Eve, President Donald Trump retweeted an altered image of himself that appeared to show a bloody splatter covering the CNN logo on the bottom of his shoe. The photo is captioned: <U+0089><db><cf>Winning.<U+0089><U+06DD> Journalists and commentators swiftly responded on Twitter, blasting the president for once again stoking violent aggression toward the media <U+0089><U+06E5> something that has become one of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s favorite pastimes. The image was originally shared Saturday afternoon by a Twitter account named <U+0089><db><cf>oregon4TRUMP<U+0089><U+06DD> in response to a tweet from the president bragging about the accomplishments of his first year in office. <U+0089><db><cf>The Stock Market is setting record after record and unemployment is at a 17 year low,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump tweeted on Saturday. <U+0089><db><cf>So many things accomplished by the Trump Administration, perhaps more than any other President in first year. Sadly, will never be reported correctly by the Fake News Media!<U+0089><U+06DD> After lashing out in a tweet against the second highest-ranking FBI official on Sunday, the president then retweeted the doctored image of himself with the blood-splattered CNN logo. He subsequently tweeted his rage against <U+0089><db><cf>fake news,<U+0089><U+06DD> as he has on many occasions before. <U+0089><db><cf>CNN-labeled blood on the sole of his shoe. Retweeted by the President of the United States on Christmas Eve,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>CNN anchor Jake Tapper said on Twitter about the retweet. Jason Osborne, a former adviser for the Trump campaign, responded to Tapper by claiming the blood splatter looked like a squashed bug, while accusing the journalist of stirring controversy. But Tapper wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t the only journalist who saw the bloody CNN logo, nor the implications of the retweet. Walter Shaub, former director of the United States Office of Government Ethics, denounced the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s post, calling Trump a <U+0089><db><cf>wannabe autocrat.<U+0089><U+06DD>  National security lawyer Bradley Moss noted that many journalists risk their lives reporting from war-torn regions of the globe.<e5><ca>One report by the Committee to Protect Journalists estimates that at least 42 journalists from different countries around the world were killed while reporting in 2017. Another group, Reporters Without Borders, says as many as 65 journalists have been killed this year. Trump has promoted attacks against journalists in the past. His raucous presidential campaign rallies frequently featured calls inciting violence against reporters and others . In July, the president tweeted a video that showed him beating up a man with a CNN logo as his head. The video appeared to be a repurposed clip of Trump , then a reality TV star, beating up WWE owner Vince McMahon in 2007 <U+0089><U+06E5> whose head was replaced with the outlet<U+0089><U+06EA>s logo. In August, the president shared <U+0089><U+06E5> and later deleted <U+0089><U+06E5> a tweet that featured a cartoon <U+0089><db><cf>Trump train<U+0089><U+06DD> running over a man with a CNN logo superimposed over his face.
Title.x: Twitter Reacts After Trump Retweets Photo Of Himself With Bloody CNN Logo
Title.y: Twitter Reacts After Trump Retweets Photo Of Himself With Bloody CNN Logo

text: President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s administration parted ways with yet another staffer this week. Politico reported Thursday that Andy Hemming resigned from his position as the White House communications team<U+0089><U+06EA>s director of rapid response on Monday. The 31-year-old former Republican National Committee staffer, who was profiled by Politico<U+0089><U+06EA>s Annie Karni this month, was responsible for finding positive mainstream media news stories about the Trump administration and recirculating those reports to key reporters and talking heads. Hemming<U+0089><U+06EA>s goal was to ultimately create more mainstream coverage about positive moments for the Trump administration on the very networks the president routinely bashes and refers to as <U+0089><db><cf>fake news,<U+0089><U+06DD> according to Karni<U+0089><U+06EA>s piece. Every presidential administration has staffers dedicated to monitoring the press and pushing out stories related to favorable moments.<e5><ca>But Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s relationship with the press and responses to news coverage is unprecedented. For instance, Vice News reported this month that the president receives a folder filled with positive news about himself twice a day <U+0089><U+06E5> a report previous presidents apparently did not receive. Hemming<U+0089><U+06EA>s role in the administration was a bizarre one, considering his boss regularly picks public feuds with journalists and mainstream news outlets he was required to target with positive stories. Just this week, Trump spent a considerable amount of time trashing the media during his campaign rally in Phoenix a rant that resulted in the crowd chanting<e5><U+0289><db><cf>CNN sucks.<U+0089><U+06DD> Hemming has not publicly commented on his exit, but a White House source told CNN that the decision to part ways was mutual. The departure is the latest in a summer filled with staff shake-ups. In July, press secretary Sean Spicer resigned just before communications director Anthony Scaramucci was hired . Then Reince Priebus left his position as White House chief of staff, days before Scaramucci was shown to the door . Last week, Steve Bannon stepped down as White House chief strategist. Meanwhile, several Trump administration advisers have parted ways with the president over his controversial response to a violent white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, this month.
Title.x: Trump Staffer Responsible For Finding Positive News Stories Resigns
Title.y: Trump Staffer Responsible For Finding Positive News Stories Resigns

text: Sen. Cory Booker (D-N.J.)<e5><ca>is calling on President Donald Trump to resign over the more than a dozen sexual misconduct allegations against him. Booker made the comments Saturday during a campaign event in Alabama to support Doug Jones, the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s Democratic candidate for Senate.<e5><ca>Jones is engaged in a tight race against embattled Republican candidate Roy Moore, whose campaign has been dogged by sexual misconduct accusations. Booker told VICE News that the sexual harassment allegations against Trump are <U+0089><db><cf>far more damning<U+0089><U+06DD> than the claims against Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.), who on Thursday announced his resignation from office after multiple women accused him of groping them. <U+0089><db><cf>I just watched Al Franken do the honorable thing and resign,<U+0089><U+06DD> Booker said. <U+0089><db><cf>My question is <U+0089><db><d3> why isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t Donald Trump doing the same thing? Who has more serious allegations against him, with more women who have come forward.<U+0089><U+06DD> While Trump has been quick to call out other high-profile men accused of sexual misconduct in recent weeks,<e5><ca>including Franken and Matt Lauer,<e5><ca>who was fired from NBC<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>Today<U+0089><U+06DD> show over sexual assault allegations, he<U+0089><U+06EA>s refrained from applying the same level of scrutiny to his own behavior. At least 19 women have accused Trump of sexual misconduct, including forcible kissing and groping, since the 1980s. He even bragged about grabbing women <U+0089><db><cf>by the pussy<U+0089><U+06DD> on the now-infamous 2005 <U+0089><db><cf>Access Hollywood<U+0089><U+06DD> tape. Trump denied the allegations throughout his 2016 presidential campaign and dismissed the <U+0089><db><cf>Access Hollywood<U+0089><U+06DD> recording as merely <U+0089><db><cf>locker room talk.<U+0089><U+06DD> In October, White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders suggested all the women accusing Trump of sexual harassment were lying. Booker<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments follow a call by Sen. Jeff Merkley (D-Ore.) that Trump should resign. <U+0089><db><cf>The president should resign because he certainly has a track record with more than 17 women of horrific conduct,<U+0089><U+06DD> Merkley said on Thursday . Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) tweeted on Thursday that Trump should <U+0089><db><cf>think about resigning,<U+0089><U+06DD> a point he reiterated on Sunday during NBC<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>Meet The Press.<U+0089><U+06DD> As lawmakers push for Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s record of alleged sexual misconduct to be re-examined, the president is working to get Moore elected in the Alabama Senate race.<e5><ca>Despite his swift condemnation of Franken, Trump has endorsed Moore,<e5><ca>a man accused of making sexual advances toward teenagers when he was in his 30s decades ago. <U+0089><db><cf>We cannot afford, this country, the future of this country, cannot afford to lose a seat in the very, very close United States Senate,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump told a crowd Friday at a rally in Florida near the Alabama border. <U+0089><db><cf>Get out and vote for Roy Moore!<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Cory Booker Calls On Donald Trump To Resign Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations
Title.y: Cory Booker Calls On Donald Trump To Resign Over Sexual Misconduct Allegations

text: HBO<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>Vice News Tonight<U+0089><U+06DD> was on the ground amid the chaos and violence that hit Charlottesville, Virginia last weekend and the resulting documentary is an education. Correspondent Elle Reeve primarily follows white nationalist leader Christopher Cantwell throughout the 22-minute piece. Interspersed throughout are interviews with ex-KKK leader David Duke prominent white nationalists Robert Ray and Matthew Heimbach, and counter-protesters like Charlottesville locals and members of Black Lives Matter. The documentary follows everything that happened from Friday night<U+0089><U+06EA>s protest to Sunday<U+0089><U+06EA>s vigils . Most heart-wrenchingly, there is footage of the driver who killed Heather Heyer while she was crossing the street and the horrifying aftermath <U+0089><U+06E5> the wailing in the streets, the passersby covered in blood that is not theirs, the shocked faces. Reeve also takes us into Cantwell<U+0089><U+06EA>s hotel room, his bed covered in weaponry, where he tells us he anticipates even more violent protests. This account of Charlottesville, from the inside, is a raw and unfiltered look at America today. And it is truly terrifying.
Title.x: This Charlottesville Documentary Is Required Watching For Americans in 2017
Title.y: This Charlottesville Documentary Is Required Watching For Americans in 2017

text: Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Tex.) on Thursday tried to mock supporters of net neutrality , the rule repealed by the FCC that had required Internet service providers to treat all traffic equally. It didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t go well. Critics warn the repeal could lead to ISPs charging extra for access to certain websites or even block them completely. Cruz had an imaginary argument in which the concerns of a <U+0089><db><cf>snowflake<U+0089><U+06DD> are shut down by an <U+0089><db><cf>informed observer<U+0089><U+06DD> such as himself: Journalist and historian Eoin Higgins fired back with a tweet that used just 10 words and a photo illustrating the kinds of traffic that could be slowed or stopped by ISPs: The photo is a scene showing porn star Cory Chase in the hardcore flick<e5><U+0289><db><cf>Moms Bang Teens 20,<U+0089><U+06DD> which infamously earned a <U+0089><db><cf>like<U+0089><U+06DD> from Cruz<U+0089><U+06EA>s Twitter account earlier this year. Cruz insisted the <U+0089><db><cf>like<U+0089><U+06DD> was caused by a staffer with access to his account. <U+0089><db><cf> It was an honest mistake , it wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t malicious, it wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t deliberate,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz told CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s Dana Bash. <U+0089><db><cf>It was a screwup.<U+0089><U+06DD> CORRECTION: A previous version of this story misstated the last name of Eoin Higgins, who has reported for HuffPost.
Title.x: 1 Embarrassing Photo Shuts Down Ted Cruz's Argument Against Net Neutrality
Title.y: 1 Embarrassing Photo Shuts Down Ted Cruz's Argument Against Net Neutrality

text: People online tore into President Donald Trump after he appeared to offer his condolences on Twitter about the wrong mass shooting. On Tuesday night, Trump posted this message: The deadly incident at the First Baptist Church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, took place on Nov. 5. So it appears Trump <U+0089><U+06E5> or a staffer <U+0089><U+06E5> mistakenly resent a tweet his account shared in the aftermath of that attack: ...Or, Trump meant to comment on Tuesday<U+0089><U+06EA>s shooting at the Rancho Tehama Elementary School in northern California which left at least four people dead and several injured ,<e5><ca>but he included the wrong town in his post. The tweet was timestamped at 11:34 p.m. and remained live as of early Wednesday morning. It was deleted around eight hours later. People online were quick to express their anger over the blunder: This article has been updated with details of the tweet being deleted.
Title.x: Twitter Slams Donald Trump For Tweeting Condolences About The Wrong Mass Shooting
Title.y: Twitter Slams Donald Trump For Tweeting Condolences About The Wrong Mass Shooting

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><db><d2> President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s falsehood-rich style appears to have come back to bite him as he brags about his only major legislative accomplishment. Having passed tax cuts that provide modest help to most Americans, Trump and GOP leaders are finding that most Americans just don<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe it. A CNN poll earlier this month found that only 21 percent of respondents believed they would be better off under the tax plan, while 37 percent believed they would be worse off. Another 36 percent thought they would not be affected much either way. In reality <U+0089><db><d2> at least until the individual tax cuts expire at the end of 2025 <U+0089><db><d2> the vast majority of families will benefit from the cuts, although not necessarily that much for the typical middle-income family. While the overall benefits skew toward the wealthy because of the dramatic 40-percent reduction in the corporate income tax rate, some 80 percent of taxpayers will see a tax reduction next year, according to the non-partisan Tax Policy Center, while 5 percent will get a tax increase and the remainder will see little difference. That disconnect is not surprising to Neil Newhouse, a prominent Republican pollster. <U+0089><db><cf>The data you<U+0089><U+06EA>re seeing is measuring voter reaction to the Trump-GOP tax plan, and neither of those brands is scoring particularly well right now,<U+0089><U+06DD> Newhouse said. <U+0089><db><cf>Voters are responding less to what<U+0089><U+06EA>s actually in the tax plan and more to who<U+0089><U+06EA>s taking credit for it.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump <U+0089><U+06E5> as he has done regularly whenever confronted with news he does not like <U+0089><U+06E5> blamed the media for the plan<U+0089><U+06EA>s unpopularity. <U+0089><db><cf>The Massive Tax Cuts, which the Fake News Media is desperate to write badly about so as to please their Democrat bosses, will soon be kicking in and will speak for themselves,<U+0089><U+06DD> the president tweeted on Thursday. <U+0089><db><cf>Companies are already making big payments to workers. Dems want to raise taxes, hate these big Cuts!<U+0089><U+06DD> Many Republicans agree with Trump that the news media have emphasized how much the tax plan will benefit the wealthy <U+0089><db><d2> including Trump himself <U+0089><db><d2> but failed to point out that the typical middle-class family would also benefit by about $78 per month. <U+0089><db><cf>Republicans are correct to assume that the bill will become more popular when people see it in their paychecks,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Rory Cooper, once a top aide to former Republican House Majority Leader Eric Cantor. But Cooper and others acknowledge that some of the public<U+0089><U+06EA>s skepticism is based on Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s apparent inability or unwillingness to communicate truthfully <U+0089><db><d2> a trait that has extended to the tax cut bill as well. On Wednesday, for instance, on a day that Trump might have simply stated the facts about the bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s final passage and the benefits it contained, he instead decided to embellish, so that the first three statements he made about the bill were all untrue. Trump claimed that tax legislation <U+0089><db><cf>really hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t been done<U+0089><U+06DD> before <U+0089><db><d2> which was false. He then claimed that the bill was <U+0089><db><cf>the largest tax cut in the history of our country<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><d2> which was also false. And then he claimed that the tax cuts for individuals totaled $3.2 trillion <U+0089><db><d2> which is not remotely close to true. The bill cuts taxes in all by about $1.8 trillion over 10 years, of which $1.2 trillion goes to individuals and households. <U+0089><db><cf>Completely unnecessary,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Republican political consultant Rick Tyler about Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s string of falsehoods. <U+0089><db><cf>He thinks that just because he says something, people will believe it. He probably believes it. Because he exhibits all the symptoms of a pathological liar.<U+0089><U+06DD> Tyler, like most Republicans, supports the tax cuts. He argues that the wealthy pay most of the federal taxes that are collected, so it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not unreasonable to see them benefit the most from a tax cut. <U+0089><db><cf>I think the administration and the Republicans made a communications error by saying it<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to be a huge break for the middle class,<U+0089><U+06DD> Tyler said, adding that families will be able to make their own decision about the law once they start seeing changes in their paychecks. But Republicans counting on the tax cuts to give them a big political boost come next Election Day may be in for a disappointment. President George W. Bush<U+0089><U+06EA>s 2001 tax cuts were larger than the ones just passed, and even included $600 <U+0089><db><cf>rebate<U+0089><U+06DD> checks mailed to taxpayers. Yet just two years later, only 19 percent of Americans believed their taxes had gone down, while 32 percent believed their taxes had risen. President Barack Obama and a Democratic Congress passed a payroll tax cut in 2010 that saved the typical family $1,000 through reduced payroll deductions. Voters again did not seem to notice it, and believed their taxes had gone up. Whether Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tax cuts are viewed the same way remains to be seen, said Peter Brown, assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Poll. <U+0089><db><cf>Does this help him or not? We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to find out,<U+0089><U+06DD> Brown said. <U+0089><db><cf>If people start seeing their paychecks start getting bigger, and they make the connection between their paychecks and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s policies, that would be good for Trump.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: Trump's Credibility Is So Low That Americans Dont Believe Theyre Getting A Tax Cut
Title.y: Trump's Credibility Is So Low That Americans Dont Believe Theyre Getting A Tax Cut

text: One of actor Danny Masterson <U+0089><U+06EA>s alleged sexual assault victims says a Netflix executive told her this weekend that higher-ups at the company don<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe the four women who have accused Masterson of rape. Netflix confirmed in a statement that Andy Yeatman, its director of global kids content, made those <U+0089><db><cf>careless<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>uninformed<U+0089><U+06DD> comments, but noted that he was not initially aware that the woman he was speaking to had accused Masterson of rape. Masterson stars in the Netflix program <U+0089><db><cf>The Ranch,<U+0089><U+06DD> alongside his former <U+0089><db><cf>That <U+0089><U+06EA>70s Show<U+0089><U+06DD> co-star Ashton Kutcher (<U+0089><db><cf>That <U+0089><U+06EA>70s Show<U+0089><U+06DD> is also streaming on Netflix). Although four women have accused Masterson of raping them and the Los Angeles County District Attorney and Los Angeles Police Department are investigating the allegations, Netflix has not taken any action against the actor, not even a suspension pending investigation. The lack of action on Netflix<U+0089><U+06EA>s part <U+0089><U+06E5> even though the company moved quickly to suspend and then fire Kevin Spacey after BuzzFeed published a report detailing an allegation of sexual misconduct against the actor <U+0089><U+06E5> has led to outrage on Twitter, an online petition that had gained over 36,000 signatures by Monday morning, and a Daily Beast story titled <U+0089><db><cf> Netflix<U+0089><U+06EA>s Disturbing Sexual-Assault Hypocrisy .<U+0089><U+06DD> Yeatman spoke with the woman, whom HuffPost is referring to as Victim B, on the sidelines of a kids<U+0089><U+06EA> soccer game in Los Angeles. Yeatman is the head coach of a soccer team for 8- and 9-year-old girls. Victim B<U+0089><U+06EA>s husband is the head coach of the team that played against Yeatman<U+0089><U+06EA>s on Sunday. Their respective daughters play on the teams that their fathers coach. When Victim B approached Yeatman and asked him if he worked at Netflix, she says he answered in the affirmative. Victim B said she asked Yeatman why Netflix was not taking action against Masterson in light of the district attorney<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation and the multiple accusations of rape. According to Victim B and another witness, Yeatman said Netflix takes sexual misconduct allegations seriously but that <U+0089><db><cf>we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe them,<U+0089><U+06DD> referring to Masterson<U+0089><U+06EA>s four accusers. Victim B told HuffPost she never expected Yeatman to say such a thing and was left stunned. She said she then told him, <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m one of them,<U+0089><U+06DD> indicating she was one of Masterson<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusers. The conversation ended quickly. Victim B said Yeatman approached her at the game about an hour later, ostensibly to clear the air, and told her that he<U+0089><U+06EA>d had no idea she was one of Masterson<U+0089><U+06EA>s alleged victims. Victim B told HuffPost that she began to cry and told Yeatman, <U+0089><db><cf>I hope no one ever says that to your daughter.<U+0089><U+06DD> Yeatman then told her that he can<U+0089><U+06EA>t decide whether Netflix takes action against Masterson. Victim B told Yeatman that she and the other women accusing Masterson of rape were telling the truth and that <U+0089><db><cf> Netflix is going to regret this, this is a mistake, they<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to see.<U+0089><U+06DD> Victim B said, and the witness confirmed, that Yeatman said, in what they described as a condescending tone, <U+0089><db><cf>we<U+0089><U+06EA>ll see.<U+0089><U+06DD> A Netflix spokesman denied that Yeatman said <U+0089><db><cf>we<U+0089><U+06EA>ll see.<U+0089><U+06DD> But the company confirmed in a statement that Yeatman told Victim B that Netflix executives didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe the four women accusing Masterson of rape. <U+0089><db><cf>While he was coaching a youth soccer match today, Mr. Yeatman <U+0089><U+06E5> a Netflix kids<U+0089><U+06EA> programming executive <U+0089><U+06E5> was approached by a stranger who did not identify herself or explain her connection to Danny Masterson,<U+0089><U+06DD> the statement read. <U+0089><db><cf>Mr. Yeatman<U+0089><U+06EA>s comments were careless, uninformed and do not represent the views of the company. Further, he would have no insights into decision making on The Ranch . We are aware of the allegations against Danny Masterson and we are following the current investigation, and will respond if developments occur.<U+0089><U+06DD> Victim B said she initially approached Yeatman when she found out from her husband that he was a Netflix executive. Frustrated by the silence from Netflix on the Masterson issue, she said she hoped he could provide some direction. She said she didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t intend to identify herself as an alleged victim until Yeatman said higher-ups at Netflix didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t believe Masterson<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusers. Victim B noted that she had seen Yeatman in the past at other soccer games and that her husband knew him from previous games. Lilly Yeatman, the wife of Andy Yeatman, sent an email to the husband of Victim B after this piece was initially published, saying Victim B <U+0089><db><cf>has really done a terrible thing to a great guy<U+0089><U+06DD> and that her husband <U+0089><db><cf>is terribly sad and heartbroken for any woman who has been hurt or mistreated.<U+0089><U+06DD> The email, which Victim B provided to HuffPost, was sent from Lilly Yeatman<U+0089><U+06EA>s professional email address at Disney. Neither Disney nor Lilly Yeatman immediately responded to a request for comment. Masterson has been the subject of an almost year-long investigation conducted by the LAPD and the Los Angeles County District Attorney<U+0089><U+06EA>s Office. Four women have accused Masterson of violently raping them in the early 2000s . They have told law enforcement that they believe Masterson spiked their drinks with something that led them to black out before and during the alleged rapes. Masterson has denied all allegations of rape and said that the encounters in question were consensual. An attorney for the actor denied that Masterson ever placed any drugs in someone else<U+0089><U+06EA>s drink and said that as a Scientologist, Masterson has a strict anti-drug policy for himself and for guests in his home. Netflix has known about the accusations since at least March, when journalist Tony Ortega revealed that the LAPD had an active investigation into multiple allegations of rape against the actor. Three of the women who have accused Masterson were members of the Church of Scientology at the time they say they were raped. Church doctrine says that contacting law enforcement to report another Scientologist is a high crime and will lead to being declared a suppressive person <U+0089><U+06E5> meaning that person will be shunned from the church, and their friends and family members who are church members must stop speaking to them. Despite that edict, Victim B filed a police report against Masterson in 2004. But the case was quickly thwarted when dozens of Scientologists filed affidavits with the LAPD claiming that Victim B wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t telling the truth. The LAPD officially reopened the case against Masterson in January, and referred it to the district attorney in April. Sources in the police department and district attorney<U+0089><U+06EA>s office have described the evidence against Masterson as <U+0089><db><cf>compelling<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>overwhelming.<U+0089><U+06DD> This article has been updated with details from Lilly Yeatman<U+0089><U+06EA>s email to the husband of Victim B. Follow Yashar <U+0089><db><d3> or send him a tip <U+0089><db><d3> on Twitter: @yashar
Title.x: Netflix Exec Tells Woman The Company Doesnt Believe Actors Rape Accusers. Then She Said She Was One.
Title.y: Netflix Exec Tells Woman The Company Doesnt Believe Actors Rape Accusers. Then She Said She Was One.

text: One of Ivanka Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s photos from her family<U+0089><U+06EA>s holiday break in Florida is causing quite the stir. The 36-year-old daughter of President Donald Trump posted pictures on Twitter and Instagram earlier this week of her husband, Jared Kushner, fishing with their son. People pointed out that there<U+0089><U+06EA>s a Confederate flag in the background of one of the shots. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s on another boat, flying next to an American flag: <U+0089><db><cf>Confederate flag over Jared<U+0089><U+06EA>s shoulder,<U+0089><U+06DD> Walter Shaub , the former director of the U.S. Office of Government Ethics under President Barack Obama, tweeted. <U+0089><db><cf>Couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t find four photos without one? Or is this a dog whistle?<U+0089><U+06DD> Other Twitter users also called out Ivanka over the posting: Others found the whole flag controversy a non-issue: The photo is the second social media flap for the Trump family over the holidays.<e5><ca>Ivanka and her sister, Tiffany Trump, were mercilessly mocked after Tiffany posted a video of the two in their swimsuits,<e5><ca>making duck faces at the camera while <U+0089><db><cf>O Holy Night<U+0089><U+06DD> played in the background. Tiffany wished her followers a <U+0089><db><cf>Merry Christmas<U+0089><U+06DD> while a filter with angel wings and a halo floated around the screen:
Title.x: Ivanka Trump's Vacation Picture Has A Confederate Flag In The Background
Title.y: Ivanka Trump's Vacation Picture Has A Confederate Flag In The Background

text: The nearly 500-page overhaul of the tax code that Republicans rammed through the Senate early Saturday morning gave lawmakers and experts little more than a moment<U+0089><U+06EA>s notice to pore over the law<U+0089><U+06EA>s myriad changes. But one thing is clear: The bill is filled with perks for America<U+0089><U+06EA>s wealthiest individuals and largest corporations, many of them paid for by closing loopholes that benefit middle-class people. By 2027, the top one-fifth of earners would receive 90 percent of the tax bill<U+0089><U+06EA>s benefits, according to an analysis by the nonpartisan Tax Policy Center. Here are some of the legislation<U+0089><U+06EA>s most outrageous components <U+0089><U+06E5> from giveaways for the super-rich to carve-outs for private schools. Dramatically reducing the corporate tax rate. The centerpiece of the Republican tax bill is its slashing of the top corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 20 percent. Republicans claim this is necessary to restore American competitiveness, noting that, on paper at least, the United States has one of the highest corporate rates in the developed world. However, many large corporations are able to take advantage of deductions and loopholes that allow them to register profits overseas. This means that in practice, the average effective corporate tax rate on profit from new investments in the U.S. is 24 percent <U+0089><U+06E5> just a shade higher than the G-7 average of 21 percent. There are, of course, proponents of a lower corporate tax rate in both major political parties. Former President Barack Obama , for example, proposed lowering the top corporate rate to 28 percent as part of a revenue-neutral, comprehensive tax reform package. But without major changes in the way corporations do business,<e5><ca>a big corporate tax cut is not actually likely to result in more job creation and higher wages. Instead, it is just a windfall for the corporate executive suite that is bound to exacerbate income inequality. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s because corporate incentives are such that executives and their boards are rewarded for how much they maximize quarterly returns for big investors , not how much they invest in the long-term growth of their companies <U+0089><U+06E5> let alone how they treat their workers. As a result, Fortune 500 CEOs and their fellow decision-makers are just as likely to spend the extra cash they get from this massive tax cut on dividends and stock buybacks, rather than expanding their workforces. They have even said as much . Creating a big new tax deduction for private school tuition. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) succeeded in adding an amendment to the final bill that would expand tax-exempt 529 college savings plans to parents saving for K-12 private school tuition, as well as expenses associated with home schooling. Technically the expanded savings accounts would allow parents to amass tax-free savings for public school education as well, but it is not at all clear what major costs are incurred from a public school education. And there are no exceptions to the types of schooling eligible for the tax break, meaning that the tax code is now almost certain to subsidize private religious education. <U+0089><db><cf>By expanding choice for parents and opportunities for children, we have prioritized the education of the next generation of Americans, allowing families to save and prepare for their children<U+0089><U+06EA>s future educational expenses,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz said in a statement about the amendment<U+0089><U+06EA>s passage. Although the tax benefit is sure to save some families money, the ballooning cost of private elementary and secondary school makes it unlikely that it will increase access to private school for middle- and low-income kids. Average annual tuition at non-sectarian private elementary schools rose from $4,120 in 1979 to $22,611 in 2011, according to a study by the National Bureau of Economic Research released in July. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s no surprise then that in 2013, 26 percent of families in urban area with incomes in the 90th income percentile sent their kids to private school, compared to just 7 percent of families in the 50th percentile, according to NBER. In 1968, by contrast, the study said, there was a gap of just 5 percentage points in the two income groups<U+0089><U+06EA> respective rates of private school enrollment. Encouraging corporations to automate <U+0089><U+06E5> without any help for displaced workers. A provision of the tax bill would allow companies to deduct from their taxable income the entire cost of certain kinds of business investments that were previously only eligible for a 50 percent deduction. Traditionally, manufacturing firms and other infrastructure-heavy companies took advantage of the deduction to buy new factory equipment. But the increase in the deduction comes at a time when corporations are investing in automation of their production facilities through the use of robots and artificial intelligence technology, noted Robert Kovacev, a corporate tax attorney for the Steptoe & Johnson law firm in Washington, D.C. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to accelerate spending, basically, on robots that could displace workers,<U+0089><U+06DD> Kovacev told HuffPost. Kovacev is supportive of the deduction, because automation is likely to increase productivity <U+0089><U+06E5> defined as the amount of economic output generated per work-hour. And many experts maintain that, over the long run, this type of technological disruption is a net job creator. That is likely to serve as cold comfort, however, for the mostly blue-collar workers displaced by automation in the short term. And Congress chose to speed up the automation process without any companion measures to offset the fallout for affected workers. <U+0089><db><cf>It would be a good idea to pair this with a tax incentive to encourage companies either to employ more human workers or retrain them for jobs in the new economy,<U+0089><U+06DD> Kovacev said. Some progressive lawmakers have other ideas about how to address the harm caused by automation. For example, San Francisco County Supervisor Jane Kim has explored the idea of implementing a <U+0089><U+06DD> robot tax <U+0089><U+06DD> on companies for every robot they employ to perform a job previously done by humans. The revenue raised by the tax would fund the retraining of displaced workers. Setting the stage for cuts to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. The Republican tax bill will add $1 trillion to the national debt over a 10-year period, according to the most recent estimate from the Joint Committee on Taxation, a nonpartisan congressional tax analysis body. The lack of measures to pay for the tax cuts is why Sen. Bob Corker (R-Tenn.) decided to vote against the final Senate bill, becoming the only Republican to do so. Many progressive economists believe the national debt is not a major challenge at this juncture. Interest rates on Treasury bonds remain low by historical standards. Still, once Republicans pass their budget-busting tax cuts, they frequently stoke debt fears to justify taking an ax to federal spending. They did it when Obama took office despite their overwhelming support for former President George W. Bush<U+0089><U+06EA>s tax cuts, and they have already indicated they plan to do it again. This time, though, they are coming for the three largest social insurance programs <U+0089><U+06E5> Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. Sen. Marco Rubio (R-Fla.) was one of several Republican lawmakers to explicitly say that following the changes to the tax code, the next priority would be scaling back so-called <U+0089><db><cf>entitlement<U+0089><U+06DD> spending. <U+0089><db><cf>You also have to bring spending under control. And not discretionary spending. That isn<U+0089><U+06EA>t the driver of our debt,<U+0089><U+06DD> Rubio said last week . <U+0089><db><cf>The driver of our debt is the structure of Social Security and Medicare for future beneficiaries.<U+0089><U+06DD> Rejecting a proposal to expand a tax credit for families with children in order to reduce the corporate tax rate even more. Rubio and Sen. Mike Lee (R-Utah) wanted to add an amendment to the tax bill that would have modestly expanded the Child Tax Credit, which is effectively a cash benefit for low-income working families with children. The latest version of the change would have provided some 10 million families with about $75 more per year , according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal think tank. To pay for the roughly $87 billion price of expanding the tax credit, Rubio and Lee proposed reducing the top corporate tax rate to just under 21 percent, rather than the 20 percent threshold that President Donald Trump and GOP leaders were seeking. The amendment collapsed in a 71-29 vote with just 20 Republicans and nine Democrats voting for it. Most Republicans objected to the amendment on the grounds that the corporate rate needed to drop to 20 percent. Democrats declined to rally behind it, because they argued that the tax credit was far too small to provide meaningful help to vulnerable people and that GOP leaders would ultimately strip it out in conference committee regardless. All but eliminating the estate tax for the country<U+0089><U+06EA>s wealthiest households. Under the Senate bill, an even tinier sliver of households in the country would be subject to the estate tax levied on the assets that ultra-rich individuals leave to their heirs when they die. Currently, $11 million in assets are exempt from the estate tax, ensuring that it falls on just 0.2 percent of American households with taxable assets. While the top statutory estate tax rate is 40 percent, the average effective rate paid by families subject to the tax is about 17 percent, according to the Tax Policy Center . The tax nonetheless serves as a major source of revenue for the federal government and achieves the additional goal of modestly limiting intergenerational wealth transfers, which some experts believe undermine meritocracy and social mobility. The Senate bill would double the estate tax exemption to $22 million for couples, eliminating the tax entirely for half the estates that currently pay it, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities . Those households still subject to the tax would get a $4.4 million tax cut, which CBPP points out would be enough to provide Pell grants to fund college tuition for 1,100 low- and moderate-income students. The bill Republicans passed in the House gets rid of the estate tax entirely over time.
Title.x: Here Are 6 Of The Most Radical Aspects Of The GOP Tax Bill
Title.y: Here Are 6 Of The Most Radical Aspects Of The GOP Tax Bill

text: President Donald Trump said Thursday he would donate $1 million of his own money to the Hurricane Harvey relief effort, a gesture that his son Eric Trump used to attack CNN. When retweeting a Fox News story about the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s pledge Thursday night, Eric added a message asking if CNN or the mainstream media would <U+0089><db><cf>acknowledge this incredible generosity.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>My guess: they wont,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added. Unfortunately for the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s second-oldest son, he guessed wrong. In addition to the announcement being widely covered following White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders<U+0089><U+06EA> briefing, CNN covered the news on air and online three hours before Eric Trump sent his tweet. A few hours after his tweet, CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s public relations team responded on Twitter with screenshots of the network<U+0089><U+06EA>s coverage of the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s pledge.
Title.x: Eric Trump Fails Miserably Trying To Call Out CNN
Title.y: Eric Trump Fails Miserably Trying To Call Out CNN

text: Former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon has attacked President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner as the <U+0089><db><cf>railhead of all bad decisions<U+0089><U+06DD> in the White House. Bannon picked apart the problems of the White House and derided the couple as <U+0089><db><cf>Javanka<U+0089><U+06DD> in a wide-ranging interview with Vanity Fair published Thursday.<e5><ca>He said Ivanka was a <U+0089><db><cf>fount of bad advice during the campaign,<U+0089><U+06DD> and claimed he once called her to her face <U+0089><db><cf>the queen of leaks.<U+0089><U+06DD> Vanity Fair also reported Bannon considers Kushner an elitist with no political experience who is in over his head and is out of touch with Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s constituency. <U+0089><db><cf>He doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t know anything about the hobbits or the deplorables,<U+0089><U+06DD> Bannon said. <U+0089><db><cf>The railhead of all bad decisions is the same railhead: Javanka.<U+0089><U+06DD> He said it was Kushner who encouraged Trump to fire FBI director James Comey.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s the dumbest political decision in modern political history, bar none,<U+0089><U+06DD> Bannon insisted, calling it a<e5><U+0289><db><cf>self-inflicted wound of massive proportions.<U+0089><U+06DD> Bannon didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t exactly gush about his old boss, either. <U+0089><db><cf>The Trump presidency that we fought for, and won, is over,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>he told writer Gabriel Sherman, and reportedly told a friend last month that he believes the president has <U+0089><db><cf>lost a step.<U+0089><U+06DD> He joked to Vanity Fair that Trump is <U+0089><db><cf>like an 11-year-old child.<U+0089><U+06DD> Bannon has reportedly said in private conversations that he believes Trump only has a 30 percent chance of finishing his term because he may be impeached or removed from office under the 25th Amendment. Bannon doesn<U+0089><U+06EA>t let himself off easy, either.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>I realize in hindsight I was just a staffer, and I<U+0089><U+06EA>m not a good staffer,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>I had influence, I had a lot of influence, but just influence.<U+0089><U+06DD> Now, outside of the White House and back at Breitbart, Bannon said, he feels more powerful. <U+0089><db><cf>I have power. I can actually drive things in a certain direction,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said.
Title.x: Steve Bannon Blasts 'Javanka' As Everything Wrong With The White House
Title.y: Steve Bannon Blasts 'Javanka' As Everything Wrong With The White House

text: While McKinley Tech students in Washington, D.C., were still settling into a new year of classes Friday, in walked the former president of the United States. Barack Obama strolled in, casually asked if the high schoolers minded him crashing their class and then waited for the shock waves to subside. The former president then spoke to the students about why he strived to engage with people their age during his eight years in office. <U+0089><db><cf>One of the things I did throughout my presidency was I<U+0089><U+06EA>d meet with groups of young people everywhere I went, whether it was here in the United States or when I was traveling overseas,<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama told the teenagers. <U+0089><db><cf>Just to kind of hear from them, find out what they<U+0089><U+06EA>re interested in, because I do believe that most of the problems we have are going to be solved by you.<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama posted video and photos of his day out on Instagram and Twitter . Students at McKinley Tech are why he is <U+0089><db><cf>hopeful about the future,<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama said. <U+0089><db><cf>Make us proud,<U+0089><U+06DD> his Instagram caption reads. <U+0089><db><cf>You<U+0089><U+06EA>re the next generation of leaders, and we need you.<U+0089><U+06DD> Obama and his wife, Michelle, made frequent visits to schools around the world during their time in the White House. The first lady brought their daughters on a trip to promote girls<U+0089><U+06EA> education in West Africa .<e5><ca>Friday<U+0089><U+06EA>s visit was part of the former president<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf> ongoing conversation with young people ,<U+0089><U+06DD> according to a statement obtained by The Hill.
Title.x: When School Starts And Your Sub Teacher Is Barack Obama
Title.y: When School Starts And Your Sub Teacher Is Barack Obama

text: As severe flooding threatened Texas residents in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, President Donald Trump on Sunday focused on the <U+0089><db><cf>wonderful<U+0089><U+06DD> response by government officials to the storm while marveling at the disaster<U+0089><U+06EA>s scope. Trump spent much of the weekend assuring Americans that he was following the storm, posting self-congratulatory tweets and boasting about the <U+0089><db><cf>great talent on the ground.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>So far, so good!<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump tweeted at Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) on Saturday, after the lawmaker warned that the storm presented a critical moment for the president, citing the poor response to Hurricane Katrina in 2005 by then-President George W. Bush<U+0089><U+06EA>s administration. Later on Sunday evening, Trump issued another, similar tweet thanking no one in particular. Although Hurricane Harvey has been downgraded to a tropical storm, heavy rainfall from it is expected to last for days and the Houston area braced for the prospect of catastrophic flooding . The National Weather Service reported at least five fatalities in the region. According to Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s weekend schedule, he has been monitoring the storm from his Camp David retreat, receiving regular updates from authorities.<e5><ca>But it was clear from his tweets that Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s priorities were not entirely on the disaster. On Sunday, Trump announced via Twitter that he would visit Texas <U+0089><db><cf>as soon as that trip can be made without causing disruption.<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Yet he immediately tweeted that he would also visit Missouri. He bragged that Missouri is <U+0089><db><cf>a wonderful state...that I won by a lot<U+0089><U+06DD> in the 2016 election, and he politicized the visit by predicting that a Republican would defeat its Democratic U.S. senator, Claire McCaskill, who is up for re-election next year. Among Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s other missives on Sunday morning: reiterating that Mexico would provide reimbursements for his long-promised border wall and charging that Mexico and Canada are <U+0089><db><cf>being very difficult<U+0089><U+06DD> in negotiations to revamp the North American Free Trade Agreement. He also asserted that NAFTA was the <U+0089><db><cf>worst trade deal ever made<U+0089><U+06DD>. He even found time to plug a book by ardent supporter David Clarke, the sheriff of Milwaukee County who runs a jail where the deaths last year of four persons <U+0089><U+06E5> including a newborn <U+0089><U+06E5> have raised concerns about its operations. On Friday evening, while Hurricane Harvey was about to make landfall, Trump used the opportunity to unleash a storm of other news , spurring questions about whether he deliberately timed the actions to keep the spotlight off them. He quietly issued a memo outlining guidance on enforcing his decision to ban transgender people from serving in the military. He also pardoned Joe Arpaio, the former Arizona sheriff who had been found in contempt of court for violating a judge<U+0089><U+06EA>s order stemming from a racial profiling case. Notwithstanding Hurricane Harvey, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s pardon of Arpaio spurred fierce criticism, including from Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.). Despite Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s emphasis of how well various government entities had responded to Hurricane Harvey,<e5><ca>FEMA administrator Brock Long on Sunday warned that recovery efforts had only just begun, characterizing the disaster as <U+0089><db><cf>a storm that the United States has not seen yet.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>FEMA is going to be [in Texas] for years,<U+0089><U+06DD> Long told CNN<U+0089><U+06EA>s Jake Tapper. <U+0089><db><cf>This disaster is going to be a landmark event.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: As Hurricane Harvey's Aftermath Slams Texas, Trump Tweets A Storm Of Self-Congratulations And Grievances
Title.y: As Hurricane Harvey's Aftermath Slams Texas, Trump Tweets A Storm Of Self-Congratulations And Grievances

text: A man attending the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville , Virginia, earlier this month fired his gun in the direction of a black counterprotester who was holding a torch, and police in their vicinity did not seem to respond. Those events appear in a video filmed two weeks ago by a volunteer with the American Civil Liberties Union of Virginia and published by the civil rights group on Saturday. As seen in the footage below, a man in a blue sleeveless shirt, a green vest and a bandana on his head pulls out a gun and aims it at a counterprotester, who is off camera and appears to be holding a makeshift lit torch. The first man appears to yell a racial slur at the black man, then fires the gun toward the ground in the direction of the counterprotesters. The shooter then leaves the scene by joining a line of white supremacist protesters and walking past law enforcement officers, who were standing behind metal barricades about 10 feet away . Police arrested Richard Wilson Preston, 52, in connection with the incident in the video above,<e5><ca>the Daily Progress reported on Saturday. Wilson was charged with discharging a firearm within 1,000 feet of a school during the so-called <U+0089><db><cf>Unite The Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally on Aug. 12. He is in custody in Towson, Maryland. Rosia Parker, a Charlottesville activist who was there when the man fired his gun, told the New York Times that police did nothing when the shooting occurred. <U+0089><db><cf>We all heard it and ran <U+0089><U+06E5> I know damn well they heard it,<U+0089><U+06DD> Parker told the Times, referencing the police who were standing behind the barricades. <U+0089><db><cf>They never moved.<U+0089><U+06DD> Corinne Geller, a spokeswoman for the Virginia State Police, told the newspaper that troopers did not react to the shooting because they couldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t hear the gun being fired over <U+0089><db><cf>the loud volume of the crowd yelling and chanting, drums and music.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Had any one of our troopers witnessed that incident they would have immediately acted just as they did for the other four arrests made during the weekend,<U+0089><U+06DD> Geller told the Times. In the aftermath of the violence in Charlottesville, the ACLU of Virginia has called on Charlottesville police to release body camera footage from the rally showing any civil rights violations similar to the one in the video. According to the ACLU<U+0089><U+06EA>s official statement, the video of the shooting is <U+0089><db><cf>consistent with our regular calls<U+0089><U+06DD> for law enforcement agencies to release footage from the protests<e5><U+0289><db><cf>that depicts any incident of public concern.<U+0089><U+06DD> The video was discovered while ACLU staffers were reviewing footage that staff and volunteers documented at the Charlottesville rally.<e5><ca>The group turned in the video to the FBI on Aug. 17 and sent copies to the Virginia State Police and Charlottesville Police Department on Aug. 20. A person familiar with the video told HuffPost the ACLU refrained from making the video public until an arrest was made. The Charlottesville Police Department and the Charlottesville communications director did not return HuffPost<U+0089><U+06EA>s request for comment. Only eight people were arrested on the day that violence broke out between white supremacists, fringe groups and anti-racism protesters in Charlottesville, according to the Times. Among those arrested was James Fields , a 20-year-old white supremacist who killed 32-year-old Heather Heyer and injured dozens of others when he rammed his car into a group of counterprotesters. Two other arrests were made in connection with another violent crime caught on video that took place during the rally. Police arrested Daniel Patrick Borden, 18, and Alex Michael Ramos, 33, in connection with the beating of Deandre Harris , a black 20-year-old who was protesting the white supremacy rally. A mob of white supremacists beat Harris with metal poles in a parking lot near police headquarters during the rally, leaving Harris bloodied, with a broken wrist, deep gashes to the head and a chipped tooth. The assault on Harris was filmed and shared widely on social media.
Title.x: Video Shows Man Shooting At Crowd During Charlottesville Rally, With No Police Response
Title.y: Video Shows Man Shooting At Crowd During Charlottesville Rally, With No Police Response

text: Steve Bannon reportedly called House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) <U+0089><db><cf>a limp-dick motherfucker who was born in a petri dish at the Heritage Foundation,<U+0089><U+06DD> referring to the think tank whose fiscal conservative policies the representative espouses. The detail is one of many bizarre nuggets in Devil<U+0089><U+06EA>s Bargain , a new book on White House chief strategist Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s role in President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s political rise, by Bloomberg Businessweek reporter Joshua Green, who has extensively covered the former Breitbart chairman. Green wrote that Bannon<U+0089><U+06EA>s comment on Ryan came during the spring of 2016, when it became increasingly possible that Trump would become the GOP presidential nominee, to the surprise and concern of establishment Republicans. Some of them had floated Ryan as a possible alternative if the party<U+0089><U+06EA>s convention were to become contested. <U+0089><db><cf>One fleetingly popular scenario to stop Trump from becoming the nominee was for GOP delegates to coalesce around a white-knight alternative at the party convention in July,<U+0089><U+06DD> Green wrote, noting that Ryan had <U+0089><db><cf>emerged as the chattering-class favorite.<U+0089><U+06DD> This development,<e5><ca>according to Green, <U+0089><db><cf>sent Bannon into a panic of his own<U+0089><U+06DD> and the Breitbart chairman who later that summer would lead Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign, began <U+0089><db><cf>plotting an all-out war to stop Ryan, of whom he was both fearful and dismissive <U+0089><db><d3> sometimes within the same sentence.<U+0089><U+06DD> While heading Breitbart, the conservative news site that frequently espouses white nationalist views, Bannon had long considered establishment Republicans enemies. One of the site<U+0089><U+06EA>s reporters, Julia Hahn <U+0089><db><d3> now a White House staffer <U+0089><db><d3><e5><ca>often wrote pieces critical of Ryan. Ryan<U+0089><U+06EA>s office did not return a request for comment. CORRECTION: Due to an editorial error, an earlier version of this article referred to Paul Ryan as a senator. He is in the House of Representatives.
Title.x: Steve Bannon Reportedly Attacked Paul Ryan As 'A Limp-D**k Motherf**ker'
Title.y: Steve Bannon Reportedly Attacked Paul Ryan As 'A Limp-D**k Motherf**ker'

text: Ivanka Trump sparked accusations of nepotism after she stepped into her father Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s shoes for a brief period at the G-20 summit in Hamburg, Germany, on Saturday. In a move that has rankled many of the Trump administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s critics, the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s daughter sat between British Prime Minister Theresa May and Chinese President Xi Jinping during her father<U+0089><U+06EA>s temporary absence from a working session of world leaders titled<e5><U+0289><db><cf>Partnership with Africa, Migration and Health.<U+0089><U+06DD> A Russian official tweeted a photograph of Ivanka Trump sitting in between the duo and it immediately went viral. The image has since been deleted, but not before it could be shared and criticized by people online: Many critics questioned just why Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s daughter, who is an official but unpaid adviser to her father, should represent the U.S. on such an important world stage <U+0089><U+06E5> albeit for a short period of time. According to Agence France-Presse, a White House official has confirmed that Ivanka Trump <U+0089><db><cf> briefly joined the main table when the president had to step out.<U+0089><U+06DD> The official said other world leaders<U+0089><U+06EA> seats were <U+0089><db><cf>also briefly filled by others<U+0089><U+06DD> when they left the table. The BBC points out <U+0089><db><cf>high-ranking officials<U+0089><U+06DD> usually cover for leaders when they are absent. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not clear exactly why Trump left the meeting, nor how long he was away. The original tweet suggested it was so he could attend <U+0089><db><cf>bilateral talks.<U+0089><U+06DD> A BBC correspondent noted that Ivanka Trump <U+0089><db><cf> did not seem to make any major contribution to the session<U+0089><U+06DD> during the time she was filling in. Donald Trump had earlier used a World Bank session on women<U+0089><U+06EA>s entrepreneurship to sing his daughter<U+0089><U+06EA>s praises. Watch the video here: <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m very proud of my daughter, Ivanka, always have been, from day one, I had to tell you that, from day one,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>She<U+0089><U+06EA>s always been great. A champion. She<U+0089><U+06EA>s a champion.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump then speculated as to whether life would be <U+0089><db><cf>easier for her<U+0089><U+06DD> if she <U+0089><db><cf>weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t my daughter.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf> That might be the only bad thing she has going, if you want to know the truth,<U+0089><U+06DD> he added.
Title.x: Ivanka Trump Stepped In For Her Dad At The G-20 Summit, And Folks Weren't Happy
Title.y: Ivanka Trump Stepped In For Her Dad At The G-20 Summit, And Folks Weren't Happy

text: Outgoing Sen. Al Franken (D-Minn.), who resigned from office earlier this month amid sexual misconduct allegations, used his final speech from the Senate floor on Thursday to list President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s many lies. He urged his congressional colleagues on both sides of the aisle to <U+0089><db><cf>stand up for truth.<U+0089><U+06DD> The Democratic senator said Trump did not invent many of the lies he spread <U+0089><U+06E5> including false claims about widespread voter fraud, climate change science and the effectiveness of the Affordable Care Act , but the president was now leading the charge. <U+0089><db><cf>As I leave the Senate, I have to admit that it feels like we are losing the war for truth,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>Maybe it<U+0089><U+06EA>s already lost.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>So what is to be done?<U+0089><U+06DD> Franken said. <U+0089><db><cf>Who will stand up and fight for a more honest debate <U+0089><db><d3> to insist that, even though we have a different set of opinions, we cannot honorably advance our competing agendas unless we use the same set of facts?<U+0089><U+06DD> Franken<U+0089><U+06EA>s last day in office will be Jan. 2.<e5><ca>Minnesota Lt. Gov. Tina Smith is expected to be sworn in as Franken<U+0089><U+06EA>s successor the following day. The state will then be represented by two women senators. Franken chose to resign after eight women publicly accused the senator of sexual misconduct, including unwanted groping, kissing and sexual advances. Dozens of Franken<U+0089><U+06EA>s Democratic colleagues called on him to resign amid the allegations.
Title.x: Al Franken Uses Final Senate Speech To List Trump's Lies To The American People
Title.y: Al Franken Uses Final Senate Speech To List Trump's Lies To The American People

text: President Donald Trump tried to use Jamaican athlete Usain Bolt to criticize National Football League players who protest during the national anthem on Tuesday night. But it didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t go down well. Trump tweeted this five-year-old video of the now retired track star cutting away from a live television interview during the London 2012 Summer Olympics so that he could stand for the U.S. national anthem. <U+0089><db><cf>Even Usain Bolt from Jamaica, one of the greatest runners and athletes of all time, showed RESPECT for our National Anthem,<U+0089><U+06DD> wrote Trump. The president outraged many at a rally in Huntsville, Alabama, on Friday with his thinly veiled attack on former San Francisco 49er Colin Kaepernick and other NFL players who have taken a knee in protest against police brutality and racial injustice during the national anthem before games. Bolt himself has yet to comment on Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s tweet. But Team Jamaica , a forum for the Caribbean island<U+0089><U+06EA>s Olympic sports<U+0089><U+06EA> enthusiasts, immediately came to the runner<U+0089><U+06EA>s defense and admonished the president to leave him<e5><U+0289><db><cf>out of your politricks.<U+0089><U+06DD> The sentiment was echoed by hundreds of other tweeters, whose comments are sampled below:

text: President Donald Trump briefly met with children of the White House press corps on Friday as part of a Halloween celebration, and things got weird pretty quickly. The costumed kids were invited to the Oval Office before trick-or-treating in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building. Trump, ever eager to criticize the press , seized the opportunity to make fun of their parents. <U+0089><db><cf>I cannot believe the media produced such beautiful children,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said, according to a pool report of the event. <U+0089><db><cf>How the media did this, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know.<U+0089><U+06DD> More from the pool report: Trump pointed at the pool and asked the kids, <U+0089><db><cf>Do you know who they are? They are the friendly media.<U+0089><U+06DD> He comforted one young girl, who was clearly a little nervous and crying. And he maintained a playful banter with the kids and the media. <U+0089><db><cf>These are beautiful, wonderful children,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said, turning to the kids. <U+0089><db><cf>Are you going to grow up and be like your parents? Mmm, don<U+0089><U+06EA>t answer that. It can only get me in trouble. You have wonderful parents, right?<U+0089><U+06DD> .... <U+0089><db><cf>You get treated better by the press than anybody in the world, right?<U+0089><U+06DD> he said, again eliciting laughter. <U+0089><db><cf>Well, congratulations, folks. You did a good job,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said to the reporters. Trump motioned toward the kids. <U+0089><db><cf>Here, you did,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. Trump then pointed at himself. <U+0089><db><cf>I wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t say you did very well here,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>But really beautiful children.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump also handed out candy to the children, and commended them for not having <U+0089><db><cf>weight problems.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Who likes this?<U+0089><U+06DD> he asked. <U+0089><db><cf>Well, you have no weight problems. That<U+0089><U+06EA>s the good news, right?<U+0089><U+06DD> Watch the moment below:
Title.x: Donald Trump Met Reporters' Kids, And It Was More Trick Than Treat
Title.y: Donald Trump Met Reporters' Kids, And It Was More Trick Than Treat

text: Days after issuing a bland statement supporting women<U+0089><U+06EA>s equality , the Trump administration halted a key equal pay initiative on Tuesday put in place by the Obama administration. The scrapped provision would have required employers to report aggregate information on how much they pay workers <U+0089><U+06E5> broken down by gender, race and ethnicity <U+0089><U+06E5> and would have been a critical first step in figuring out the scope of the pay gap at different companies. Instead, the Office of Management and Budget said in a memo this week that it was halting implementation so it could review the provision, citing concerns about paperwork and privacy. Ivanka Trump , who speaks frequently about the importance of equal pay for women and who promised last summer that her father feels similarly, issued a statement supporting the move. <U+0089><db><cf>Ultimately, while I believe the intention was good and agree that pay transparency is important, the proposed policy would not yield the intended results,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said on Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>We look forward to continuing to work with [Equal Employment Opportunity Commission], [the Office of Management and Budget], Congress and all relevant stakeholders on robust policies aimed at eliminating the gender wage gap.<U+0089><U+06DD> She offered no further explanation for the administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s action or her endorsement of it. Women<U+0089><U+06EA>s groups universally decried the move. <U+0089><db><cf>This is not a technical tweak as they would have you believe. Make no mistake<U+0089><db><d3> it<U+0089><U+06EA>s an all-out attack on equal pay,<U+0089><U+06DD> Fatima Goss Graves, president and CEO of the National Women<U+0089><U+06EA>s Law Center, said in a statement on Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>Today<U+0089><U+06EA>s action sends a clear message to employers,<U+0089><U+06DD> Graves added. <U+0089><db><cf>If you want to ignore pay inequities and sweep them under the rug, this Administration has your back.<U+0089><U+06DD> They also took aim at the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s eldest daughter for betraying her purported commitment to working women. <U+0089><db><cf>For somebody who has long held herself out as a champion for women and for gender equality, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s really disappointing,<U+0089><U+06DD> Vicki Shabo, vice president for workplace policy and strategy at the National Partnership for Women and Families, told HuffPost on Wednesday. <U+0089><db><cf>[This] spits in the eye of gender equality and in the eyes of women and people of color who are so often paid less and do not know.<U+0089><U+06DD> On average, women in the U.S. are paid 80 cents for every dollar men earn, according to federal data. The pay gap for women of color is even worse. Hispanic women earn 54 cents on the dollar, while black women make 63 cents.<e5><ca>Even when researchers analyze the data and account for differences in education and time spent in the labor force, the wage gap persists. Interestingly, Ivanka Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s book, a bland treatise called Women Who Work , mentions the term <U+0089><db><cf>equal pay<U+0089><U+06DD> only once, focusing more on individual moves women can make to achieve success in the workplace. <U+0089><db><cf>When you<U+0089><U+06EA>re passionate and work hard you can achieve great things,<U+0089><U+06DD> she writes. But even when a woman is going full-steam ahead at work, she may not realize that her male peers are out-earning her. After 19 years as a manager at a Goodyear plant in Alabama, Lilly Ledbetter famously found out she had been making less than her male colleagues after someone sent her an anonymous note. Her lawsuit led to the passage of equal pay legislation in 2009. Employers are now required to report information about the race, ethnicity and gender of their employees. Starting a few years ago, tech companies have made their Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reports public, which has led to a painful <U+0089><U+06E5> but fruitful <U+0089><U+06E5> discussion about the lack of women in the tech industry. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s easy to imagine how pay data would<U+0089><U+06EA>ve advanced the conversation even further and made it easier for federal regulators to spot patterns of discrimination. <U+0089><db><cf>Having pay data in summary form will help us identify patterns that may warrant further investigation,<U+0089><U+06DD> the former chairwoman of the EEOC said last year at a conference in New York. In the past, she said, <U+0089><db><cf>we<U+0089><U+06EA>d learn about a pay-discrimination problem because someone saw a piece of paper left on a copy machine or someone was complaining about their salary to co-workers.<U+0089><U+06DD> Companies with more than 100 workers were set to receive a new form to report the data in September and start providing more detailed information to the EEOC in 2018. Most employers were already preparing to file this data, according to Shabo. Indeed, in recent years, activist shareholders have been pressuring public companies to report data <U+0089><U+06E5> a few companies, including Apple and Amazon, have started opening up about gender and pay. Stopping the Obama administration provision from going into effect was the result of an orchestrated effort by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the federal contractors business lobby and anti-worker and anti-regulatory senators on the Hill, Shabo said. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s even more disappointing because the provision already represented a compromised effort, she added. <U+0089><db><cf>It wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t as comprehensive or as detailed as we would<U+0089><U+06EA>ve liked. This was something that was put together with the ease and efficiency of the employer community in mind.<U+0089><U+06DD> Still, there had been rumors since January that this would happen, and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s hard to be surprised that the White House, which has been openly hostile to women<U+0089><U+06EA>s rights <U+0089><U+06E5> by rolling back provisions on contraception and reinstating harsh restrictions on women<U+0089><U+06EA>s health around the world <U+0089><U+06E5> would make such a move. <U+0089><db><cf>This is not a woman- or family-friendly administration,<U+0089><U+06DD> Shabo said.
Title.x: With Ivanka Trump's Blessing, White House Ditches Equal Pay Rule
Title.y: With Ivanka Trump's Blessing, White House Ditches Equal Pay Rule

text: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - An organization established for U.S. President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s transition to the White House a year ago said on Saturday that the special counsel investigating allegations of Russian meddling in the 2016 election had obtained tens of thousands of emails unlawfully. Kory Langhofer, counsel to the transition team known as Trump for America, Inc., wrote a letter to congressional committees to say Special Counsel Robert Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team had improperly received the emails from the General Services Administration, a government agency. Career staff members at the agency <U+0089><db><cf>unlawfully produced TFA<U+0089><U+06EA>s private materials, including privileged communications, to the Special Counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s Office,<U+0089><U+06DD> according to the letter, a copy of which was seen by Reuters. It said the materials included <U+0089><db><cf>tens of thousands of emails.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s transition team used facilities of the GSA, which helps manage the U.S. government bureaucracy, in the period between the Republican<U+0089><U+06EA>s November presidential election victory and his inauguration in January. The Trump team<U+0089><U+06EA>s accusation adds to the growing friction between the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s supporters and Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s office as it investigates whether Russia interfered in the election and if Trump or anyone on his team colluded with Moscow. Asked for comment, White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders said: <U+0089><db><cf>We continue to cooperate fully with the special counsel and expect this process to wrap up soon.<U+0089><U+06DD> The GSA and officials at the special counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s office did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Norm Eisen, who served on former President Barack Obama<U+0089><U+06EA>s transition team,<e5><ca>responded on Twitter to the letter, saying<e5><U+0289><db><cf>there is NO expectation of privacy in your transition emails.<U+0089><U+06DD> Democrats say there is a wide-ranging effort by the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s allies on Capitol Hill and in some media outlets to discredit Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation. Trump himself has loudly declared Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s effort a waste of time. <U+0089><db><cf>There is absolutely no collusion. That has been proven,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump told reporters on Friday. Russia denies interfering in the election. On Friday, Representative Adam Schiff, the top Democrat on the House of Representatives Intelligence Committee, said he fears the committee<U+0089><U+06EA>s Republican majority intends to close its investigation of the topic prematurely. Some Republicans have argued that Mueller is biased against Trump and should be fired. The letter was sent to the U.S. Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Government Affairs, and the U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform. It asked for Congress to act immediately <U+0089><db><cf>to protect future presidential transitions from having their private records misappropriated by government agencies, particularly in the context of sensitive investigations intersecting with political motives.<U+0089><U+06DD> The letter said Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s office obtained the emails despite the fact that it was aware the GSA did not own or control the records. It said the special counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s office has <U+0089><db><cf>extensively used the materials in question, including portions that are susceptible to claims of privilege<U+0089><U+06DD> without notifying the Trump for America team. On the transition team were a number of aides who were later caught up in Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation, such as former national security adviser Michael Flynn who pleaded guilty this month to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Russia. Langhofer, the Trump transition team lawyer, wrote in his letter that the GSA<U+0089><U+06EA>s transfer of materials was discovered on Dec. 12 and 13. The FBI had requested the materials from GSA staff last Aug. 23, asking for copies of the emails, laptops, cell phones and other materials associated with nine members of the Trump transition team response for national security and policy matters, the letter said. On Aug. 30, the FBI requested the materials of four additional senior members of the Trump transition team, it said. Langhofer argued that while such transition teams are involved in executive functions, they are considered private, nonprofit organizations whose records are private and not subject to presidential records laws. (Reporting By Steve Holland and John Walcott; Editing by Alistair Bell)
Title.x: Trump Allies Flip Out After Mueller Lands Tens Of Thousands Of Emails
Title.y: Trump Allies Flip Out After Mueller Lands Tens Of Thousands Of Emails

text: The mayor of San Juan, Puerto Rico blasted President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s meeting with local leaders on the island Tuesday as a public relations stunt. <U+0089><db><cf> There was no exchange with anybody , with none of the mayors,<U+0089><U+06DD> Mayor Carmen Yul<cc>_n Cruz said on MSNBC. She called out Trump for the bizarre moment when he tossed paper towels to storm survivors in need of supplies after Hurricane Maria left many on the island without basic necessities. <U+0089><db><cf>This terrible and abominable view of him throwing paper towels and throwing provisions at people, it does not embody the spirit of the American nation,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz said. <U+0089><db><cf>That is not the land of the free and the home of the brave, that beacon of democracy that people have learned to look up to across the world.<U+0089><U+06DD> She also said the president had a communications problem and called him the <U+0089><db><cf>miscommunicator-in-chief.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz made headlines last week when she slammed the federal government for its slow response to the storm and pleaded for help from anyone able to provide it. <U+0089><db><cf>I am going to do what I never thought I would do. I am begging, begging anyone who can hear us to save us from dying,<U+0089><U+06DD> Cruz said in a tearful news conference last Friday.<e5><U+0289><db><cf> We are dying, and you are killing us with inefficiency and bureaucracy .<U+0089><U+06DD> On Twitter, Trump claimed the mayor had been told by Democrats that she must be <U+0089><db><cf>nasty<U+0089><U+06DD> to him. <U+0089><db><cf> Actually, I was asking for help ,<U+0089><U+06DD> she later said. <U+0089><db><cf>I wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t saying anything nasty about the president.<U+0089><U+06DD>
Title.x: San Juan Mayor Slams Donald Trump For 'Terrible And Abominable' Puerto Rico Stunt
Title.y: San Juan Mayor Slams Donald Trump For 'Terrible And Abominable' Puerto Rico Stunt

text: Three people are dead and at least 35 have been treated for injuries following a white supremacist rally and a helicopter crash in the Charlottesville, Virginia, area. At one point a car plowed into an anti-racist group amid clashes between white supremacist activists, some armed, and anti-fascist protesters. Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe (D) declared a state of emergency on Saturday afternoon. President Donald Trump blamed <U+0089><db><cf>many sides<U+0089><U+06DD> for the unrest. Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced a federal investigation into the violence at the rally. The FBI and the U.S. Attorney<U+0089><U+06EA>s Office for the Western District of Virginia have also launched a civil rights investigation into the fatal car crash. CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. <U+0089><U+06E5> Thousands of white supremacists and armed militia groups faced off with counter-protesters during a violent and chaotic rally that raged for hours in this Virginia city on Saturday, resulting in the deaths of at least three people. Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe (D), who declared a state of emergency Saturday afternoon, condemned the violence during a press conference that evening, sending a message to the white supremacists. <U+0089><db><cf>Our message is plain and simple: Go home. You are not wanted in this great commonwealth,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>Shame on you.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Please go home and never come back. Take your hatred, and take your bigotry,<U+0089><U+06DD> McAuliffe added. Charlottesville Police Chief Al Thomas said 35 people were treated for injuries by city personnel on Saturday, with injuries ranging from minor to life-threatening. Three people died Saturday, including a 32-year-old woman who was hit by a car that plowed into a group of counter-demonstrators and two others who perished in a helicopter crash near the protests. James Alex Fields Jr., 20, was arrested in connection with the car incident. He was charged with one count of second-degree murder, three counts of malicious wounding and one count of failing to stop at an accident resulting in a death, police Col.
