Martin Kumer told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>It was just terrifying,<U+0089><U+06DD> said 23-year-old Thomas Pilnik, a Charlottesville resident who witnessed the crash.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>I remember people flying into me, telling me to run and get out of the way and watching people fly like they were just bowling pins.<U+0089><U+06DD> As of 10 p.m. Eastern on Saturday , police had made three other arrests related to the rally: <U+0089><db><cf>You came here today to hurt people and you did hurt people,<U+0089><U+06DD> McAuliffe said at Saturday<U+0089><U+06EA>s press conference. Groups in Charlottesville beat each other with flagpoles and bats, threw punches, chanted slogans and used chemical sprays on each other at a downtown park. Some reporters covering the event were doused in raw sewage. <U+0089><db><cf>There was a cloud,<U+0089><U+06DD> said a witness, who asked not to be named. <U+0089><db><cf>Things were flying. Most people managed to get out of the way.<U+0089><U+06DD> Attorney General Jeff Sessions said Saturday night that U.S. Attorney Rick Mountcastle has opened a federal investigation into the violence at the rally, with the full support of the Justice Department. The U.S.<e5><ca>attorney<U+0089><U+06EA>s office and regional FBI office also announced a civil rights investigation into the circumstances surrounding the deadly car crash. <U+0089><db><cf>The violence and deaths in Charlottesville strike at the heart of American law and justice,<U+0089><U+06DD> Sessions said in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>When such actions arise from racial bigotry and hatred, they betray our core values and cannot be tolerated.<U+0089><U+06DD> The <U+0089><db><cf>Unite the Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally was promoted by white nationalist Richard Spencer and drew several different groups, including activists from the so-called <U+0089><db><cf>alt-right,<U+0089><U+06DD> Nazis, Ku Klux Klan members and other white supremacists, some of whom dressed in militia uniforms and were openly carrying long guns. Counter-demonstrators and anti-fascist groups also attended. After demonstrations got heated Friday night, tensions were running high even before the rally officially began at noon, with members of the <U+0089><db><cf>alt-right<U+0089><U+06DD> chanting the Nazi phrase <U+0089><db><cf>Blood and soil!<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>White lives matter!<U+0089><U+06DD> as they marched toward Emancipation Park. With Confederate flags and Nazi memorabilia on full display, they also chanted <U+0089><db><cf>Fuck you faggots!<U+0089><U+06DD> James Allsup, who was in Charlottesville for the <U+0089><db><cf>Unite the Right<U+0089><U+06DD> rally, told Mediaite that <U+0089><db><cf>white people are tired of being told by the cosmopolitan elites that we are the problem.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>This is the biggest racist rally in recent memory,<U+0089><U+06DD> a 23-year-old anti-fascist from Michigan, who wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t give his name, told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>And we are all out here opposing these motherfuckers and trying to get a temperature check where the right is <U+0089><U+06E5> where the far right is at <U+0089><U+06E5> and how they<U+0089><U+06EA>re organizing, and where we can apply radical strategies to defeat fascism.<U+0089><U+06DD> Early Saturday, McAuliffe asked on Twitter for a stop to the violence. As violence among the groups grew on Saturday morning, some fled the scene, while others coughed and cried from the chemical sprays. Two fences and a line of cops helped separate the opposing groups, though police did not immediately intervene in the violence. Police donned riot gear as fights escalated. Meanwhile, hundreds more white supremacists joined in the fray through the afternoon, making their way under a banner hung by the city that read <U+0089><db><cf>Diversity makes us stronger.<U+0089><U+06DD> Those standing on the sidelines were baffled as to why police weren<U+0089><U+06EA>t immediately stopping the skirmishes. <U+0089><db><cf>If this were Ferguson, riot gear, tear gas, everything would have been used,<U+0089><U+06DD> said Anthony Bennett, a pastor from Connecticut, referring to the Missouri town where protests broke out in August 2014 after Darren Wilson, at the time a police officer, shot and killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager. <U+0089><db><cf>There<U+0089><U+06EA>s a different standard here in Charlottesville.<U+0089><U+06DD> Unidentified militia members brandishing guns also showed up at the scene. Just minutes before the planned noon rally was set to begin, police threatened arrest for <U+0089><db><cf> unlawful assembly .<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Thousands of people began to disperse, but it wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t immediately clear where they were going. Eventually, arrests began. Late Friday night, a white nationalist march at the University of Virginia campus painted a sobering picture of what was to come. A torch-bearing procession of hundreds that included Spencer, at least one man wearing a Nazi SS T-shirt and another carrying a bat,<e5><ca>ended with a clash at the campus rotunda where a Thomas Jefferson statue stands. Spencer admitted on Twitter that a group surrounded counter-protesters at the statue. Counter-protesters told HuffPost that some among their ranks were then hit with some type of irritant Friday night <U+0089><U+06E5> they claim it was Mace, unleashed by the white supremacists.<e5><ca>Protesters on the fringe left, who come to these events to battle the fringe right, often try to hide their identities for fear of retaliation. Some counter-protesters threatened a HuffPost reporter with a gun when he attempted to photograph, from a distance, those recovering from the irritant. <U+0089><db><cf>Don<U+0089><U+06EA>t make me use my gun on you,<U+0089><U+06DD> a woman said, grabbing a holster on her hip. Punches and torches were thrown during the fracas, but local police eventually dispersed the crowds. President Donald Trump did little to denounce the white supremacists, instead saying Saturday that <U+0089><db><cf>many sides<U+0089><U+06DD> were responsible for the violence. <U+0089><db><cf>We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides <U+0089><U+06E5> on many sides,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said at a ceremony for the signing of a bill to reform the Veterans Affairs health care system. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long time in our country, not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long, long time.<U+0089><U+06DD> Comments from state and local officials addressed the racism more directly. Charlottesville Mayor Michael Signer spoke out against the white supremacists who gathered in his city. <U+0089><db><cf>They do not agree with the rules of democracy and they are on the losing side of history,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said during a press conference Saturday evening. McAuliffe spoke directly to white supremacists during the press conference, reminding them that <U+0089><db><cf>we are a nation of immigrants.<U+0089><U+06DD> McAuliffe said he spoke to Trump on Saturday and told the president he<U+0089><U+06EA>d be willing to work together, despite their differences, to help prevent this kind of violence in the future. <U+0089><db><cf>There has got to be a movement in this country to bring people together,<U+0089><U+06DD> McAuliffe said. The rally Saturday was thinly disguised on Facebook as an event in support of the statue of Gen. Robert E. Lee downtown, which is slated for removal as the city works to respect diverse voices in its telling of American history. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s part of a nationwide effort to remove Confederate monuments from public property. According to the Southern Poverty Law Center, more than 60 Confederate symbols have been removed from city- and state-owned land across the U.S. since avowed white supremacist Dylann Roof massacred nine parishioners at a black church in Charleston, South Carolina, in 2015. Most recently, the city of New Orleans toppled four statues honoring the Confederacy. <U+0089><db><cf>These efforts have made us a target for folks around the country who oppose telling the full story of race,<U+0089><U+06DD> Signer told HuffPost on Friday. <U+0089><db><cf>They don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want the narrative changed or to tell the full story of race. I think this will have the effect of redoubling our progress.<e5><ca>To become an honest society, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t think we have any choice but to tell the full story.<U+0089><U+06DD> The rally<U+0089><U+06EA>s real purpose, however, shines through in the event<U+0089><U+06EA>s advertising, which looks a lot like Nazi propaganda and reads like a poorly billed concert: Spencer<U+0089><U+06EA>s followers claimed that that violence was coming to Charlottesville in the form of <U+0089><db><cf>roving mobs<U+0089><U+06DD> of Antifa <U+0089><U+06E5> groups of black-clad, masked anti-fascists, anarchists and socialists. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a scare tactic that white nationalists use regularly to pull crowds of people to a city in defense of it. They were able to draw hundreds to Gettysburg over the Fourth of July weekend after claiming members of Antifa were coming to desecrate graves. Antifa never came, but the Ku Klux Klan did, and the only bloodshed came when a lone patriot shot himself in the leg . The weeks and days leading up to the rally in Charlottesville had the city gearing up for war. The city had seen this type of menacing before: White supremacists showed up with torches at the Lee monument in May, an act that evoked Ku Klux Klan symbolism. Some businesses closed down Saturday to keep employees safe. Others reportedly opened their doors solely as a safe space in case of an emergency. Some locals were prepared to take drastic measures to protect their city. <U+0089><db><cf>As a lifelong resident of Charlottesville and a mother of two, this is about making the world more equitable for my children,<U+0089><U+06DD> Leslie Scott-Jones of Solidarity C<U+0089><U+06EA>Ville wrote in a news release. <U+0089><db><cf>I am not naive about the urgent threat of August 12 , nor do I believe the threat ends there... My family has been here since the 1700<U+0089><db>_s, this is my home, and I have no other choice than to protect it.<U+0089><U+06DD> This article has been updated with new details, including comments from Trump and anti-fascist demonstrators, information about Fields and information about the various investigations into Saturday<U+0089><U+06EA>s events. Sebastian Murdock, Paige Lavender and Carla Herreria contributed to this report.
Title.x: White Supremacist Rally Triggers Violence In Charlottesville
Title.y: White Supremacist Rally Triggers Violence In Charlottesville

text: Special counsel Robert Mueller has taken his Russia investigation closer to the heart of Donald Trump , looking into the finances of the president and his family. Mueller has asked Deutsche Bank to share information on accounts held by the Trump family as part of his investigation into Russia<U+0089><U+06EA>s alleged attempts to influence the 2016 election,<e5><ca>Reuters reported Tuesday. The bank has loaned the Trump Organization millions of dollars over the years. Trump does not like revealing details of his finances. He still hasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t released his tax returns, unlike other presidents in recent history. And in July, Trump implied that he would consider firing Mueller if he started looking into his finances. From his interview with New York Times reporters Peter Baker, Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman: SCHMIDT: Last thing, if Mueller was looking at your finances and your family finances, unrelated to Russia <U+0089><db><d3> is that a red line? HABERMAN: Would that be a breach of what his actual charge is? TRUMP: I would say yeah. I would say yes. By the way, I would say, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t <U+0089><db><d3> I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t <U+0089><db><d3> I mean, it<U+0089><U+06EA>s possible there<U+0089><U+06EA>s a condo or something, so, you know, I sell a lot of condo units, and somebody from Russia buys a condo, who knows? I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t make money from Russia.<e5><ca>... SCHMIDT: But if he was outside that lane, would that mean he<U+0089><U+06EA>d have to go? [crosstalk] HABERMAN: Would you consider <U+0089><U+06E5> TRUMP: No, I think that<U+0089><U+06EA>s a violation. Look, this is about Russia. So I think if he wants to go, my finances are extremely good, my company is an unbelievably successful company. And actually, when I do my filings, peoples say, <U+0089><db><cf>Man.<U+0089><U+06DD> People have no idea how successful this is. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a great company. But I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t even think about the company anymore. I think about this. <U+0089><U+06EA>Cause one thing, when you do this, companies seem very trivial. O.K.? I really mean that. They seem very trivial. But I have no income from Russia. I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t do business with Russia. ... HABERMAN: Would you fire Mueller if he went outside of certain parameters of what his charge is? [crosstalk] SCHMIDT: What would you do? [crosstalk] TRUMP: I can<U+0089><U+06EA>t, I can<U+0089><U+06EA>t answer that question because I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t think it<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to happen. The White House did not immediately return a request for comment. Trump has reportedly considered firing Mueller in the past. Last week, after Mueller charged Michael Flynn, Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s former national security adviser, with lying to the FBI, speculation picked up again that the president may take the drastic step. <U+0089><db><cf>I would worry in a real way that Donald Trump may preemptively pardon some people, and I still worry in a real way that Donald Trump may decide to cause the firing of Robert Mueller ,<U+0089><U+06DD> Preet Bharara, the former U.S. attorney who was ousted by Trump, said on Monday. With Flynn now cooperating with Mueller, the investigation is moving closer and closer to Trump and his inner circle <U+0089><U+06E5> including his son-in-law and trusted adviser, Jared Kushner . Trump, of course, is in this situation because he initially fired James Comey.<e5><ca>The FBI director said Trump approached him and tried to get him to ease up on the Russia investigation and to specifically be lenient toward Flynn <U+0089><U+06E5> who lied about his interactions with Russian officials before the inauguration. After the disclosure of the pressure Trump had placed on Comey, Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Mueller as special counsel . UPDATE: 3:32 p.m. <U+0089><U+06E5> Trump ignored a reporter<U+0089><U+06EA>s shouted question about the <U+0089><db><cf>red line<U+0089><U+06DD> Tuesday during an Oval Office event. White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders punted on a similar question Tuesday afternoon, referring to the statement of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s personal lawyer, Jay Sekulow, who denied that there were any subpoenas for financial information.
Title.x: Trump Said Probing His Finances Would Be A 'Red Line.' That's Exactly What Robert Mueller Is Now Doing.
Title.y: Trump Said Probing His Finances Would Be A 'Red Line.' That's Exactly What Robert Mueller Is Now Doing.

text: A federal grand jury in Washington, D.C., reportedly has filed the first charges in the investigation led by special counsel Robert Mueller into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, CNN said Friday evening. According to the network, the charges are sealed under a federal judge<U+0089><U+06EA>s order. It remains unclear who has been indicted and on what charges. The person or persons indicted could be taken into custody as soon as Monday, CNN said. Federal officials have not yet validated the CNN report, and a spokesman for Mueller declined to comment to Reuters. However, if confirmed,<e5><ca>it would mark a major development in the special counsel<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe. <U+0089><db><cf>If anybody thinks the Mueller investigation is going to be wrapping up, this decision guarantees it will go well into 2018,<U+0089><U+06DD> CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin said. Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Mueller in May,<e5><ca>following President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s controversial decision to fire FBI Director James Comey amid the agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into possible Russian meddling during the 2016 presidential election.<e5><ca>Mueller is a former prosecutor and served as FBI director from 2001 to 2013. Mueller was tasked with overseeing the investigation into possible coordination between the Trump campaign and Russian officials during the election,<e5><ca>along with any matters that directly arise from the investigation. Since then, reports have emerged that Mueller was investigating whether Trump attempted to obstruct justice. Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team is reportedly also looking into a dossier containing explosive, unverified allegations regarding Trump and his associates, compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele for the research firm Fusion GPS. Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s team is also investigating Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s associates. The team is reportedly looking into possible tax and financial crimes by Paul Manafort.<e5><ca>Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s former campaign manager was forced out in August 2016 over his past business dealings with pro-Russian figures in Ukraine. Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s lobbying firm disclosed in June it was paid<e5><ca>$17.1 million for work on behalf of a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine from 2012 to 2014, without Manafort being registered with the Department of Justice as a foreign agent at the time.<e5><ca>FBI agents raided Manafort<U+0089><U+06EA>s home in July, seizing documents and other items. Roger Stone, a longtime adviser to Trump, said that he had spoken to Manafort at 5 p.m. Friday and, as of that time, Manafort <U+0089><db><cf>knew nothing of this,<U+0089><U+06DD> referring to the report of the indictments. Stone<U+0089><U+06EA>s statement didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t clarify matters <U+0089><U+06E5> a suspect wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be informed of an indictment <U+0089><U+06E5> but it indirectly indicated that Stone and his friend of 40 years (and former business partner) were checking in with each other about where things stood at the close of business this week. A suspect would never be informed of an indictment. Later Friday night, Stone told HuffPost that he had spoken to Manafort at 8:30 p.m. and that the former campaign chairman had <U+0089><db><cf>said nothing.<U+0089><U+06DD> Stone added that he thought Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s primary investigative focus was an obstruction case rather than the more central issue of collusion, which presumably would be the greater risk to Manafort. Another close mutual friend of Trump and Manafort, speaking on background to be candid, said that he expected the former campaign manager to be indicted, though he had heard nothing specific as of late Friday . <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s a shame what<U+0089><U+06EA>s going to happen to Paul,<U+0089><U+06DD> the friend said. <U+0089><db><cf>He wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t even a Trump guy.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump has fiercely denied allegations that his campaign colluded with the Russians and has referred to the reports about Mueller investigating questions of possible obstruction of justice as <U+0089><db><cf>the single greatest witch hunt in American political history.<U+0089><U+06DD> Friday<U+0089><U+06EA>s news of the reported indictments emerged just hours after Dana Boente, the top federal prosecutor in the Eastern District of Virginia, submitted his resignation . Boente was simultaneously serving as the head of the Department if Justice<U+0089><U+06EA>s National Security Division and had been acting attorney general earlier this year following Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s firing of former acting Attorney General Sally Yates. One of Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s grand juries was reportedly impaneled in Boente<U+0089><U+06EA>s Eastern District of Virginia, which is commonly referred to as a <U+0089><db><cf>rocket docket<U+0089><U+06DD> because of the fast pace of cases in the federal judicial district. Boente had served at the Justice Department for 33 years and is planning to stay on until his successor is confirmed. The reason for his departure is unclear. This article has been updated with later comments from Roger Stone. Howard Fineman and Ryan Reilly contributed reporting. CORRECTION : An earlier version of this article said Sally Yates resigned. She was fired by Trump.
Title.x: Report: First Charges Filed In Mueller's Russia Probe
Title.y: Report: First Charges Filed In Mueller's Russia Probe

text: It was a stunning moment. On Sunday, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson suggested that the president of the United States does not speak for American values. After deflecting questions from Fox News<U+0089><U+06EA> Chris Wallace about President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s failure to condemn white supremacist groups who incited deadly violence in Charlottesville, Virginia, by saying that he and the State Department <U+0089><db><cf>represent America<U+0089><U+06EA>s values,<U+0089><U+06DD> Tillerson said that <U+0089><db><cf> the president speaks for himself .<U+0089><U+06DD> Tillerson<U+0089><U+06EA>s statement caps a tumultuous two weeks in which Trump demonstrated that he has abandoned essential duties of the office, failing to provide basic, measured responses to violence and natural disasters. Throughout last week, he continued to defend his widely condemned response to the violence in Charlottesville <U+0089><db><d3> in which he delayed and then backtracked on a denunciation of white nationalist, KKK and neo-Nazi groups <U+0089><db><d3> including during a campaign-style rally in Phoenix. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s failure to provide the most elementary leadership earned criticism from lawmakers and leaders around the world <U+0089><db><d3> even from a United Nations panel on combating racial discrimination , which expressed deep concern about <U+0089><db><cf>the example this failure could set for the rest of the world.<U+0089><U+06DD> The night Hurricane Harvey slammed into Texas, unleashing potentially historic rainfall, Trump announced he was pardoning former Arizona sheriff Joe Arpaio, who illegally targeted Latinos and was convicted of criminal contempt for violating a court order. In doing so, he bypassed the Department of Justice<U+0089><U+06EA>s normal pardon procedures. (Trump reportedly asked his attorney general about closing the criminal case against Arpaio months earlier.) On Sunday, as residents of Texas began evaluating the flooding and damage from the storm, Trump issued a stream of tweets congratulating authorities and himself for the recovery effort, which he bragged was<e5><U+0289><db><cf>going well!<U+0089><U+06DD> The tweets about Hurricane Harvey were sandwiched between posts on unrelated topics, including the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s personal grievances . For example, Trump immediately followed the announcement that he would visit Texas with a tweet boasting about his election victory in a different state, while suggesting that he would help unseat the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s Democratic senator. Tillerson is not the only administration official attempting to distance himself from the president in recent days. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis can be heard telling U.S. troops in Jordan to <U+0089><db><cf>hold the line until our country gets back to understanding and respecting each other,<U+0089><U+06DD> in a video posted Thursday on Facebook. Mattis also said the U.S. will <U+0089><db><cf>get the power of inspiration back,<U+0089><U+06DD> which many interpreted as criticism of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s leadership. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s unclear exactly when Mattis made the impromptu remarks, though he stopped in Jordan during his overseas trip last week. <U+0089><db><cf>You<U+0089><U+06EA>re a great example for our country right now, and it has got problems,<U+0089><U+06DD> Mattis said in the video . <U+0089><db><cf>You know it and I know it. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s got problems we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t have in the military. And you just hold the line, my fine soldiers and sailors and airmen and Marines.<U+0089><U+06DD> The president<U+0089><U+06EA>s economic adviser, Gary Cohn, told the Financial Times that he contemplated resigning after Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s Charlottesville remarks , saying the administration<e5><U+0289><db><cf>can and must do better in consistently and unequivocally condemning these groups.<U+0089><U+06DD> Of course, many in the Trump administration still unambiguously defend the president. After Trump delivered a scripted but conspicuously vague speech on his Afghanistan war strategy, Vice President Mike Pence insisted Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s primetime address signaled<e5><U+0289><db><cf>American resolve.<U+0089><U+06DD> Nikki Haley, U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said the speech demonstrated <U+0089><db><cf>the signs of a president.<U+0089><U+06DD> The next day, Trump reverted to form at his no-holds-barred Arizona rally, making it next to impossible to believe that he will treat the presidency with the gravity the office is meant to hold.
Title.x: Trump Has Essentially Abdicated The Basic Responsibilities Of A President
Title.y: Trump Has Essentially Abdicated The Basic Responsibilities Of A President

text: Former Democratic Congressman Harold Ford Jr. has been fired for misconduct by Morgan Stanley after facing a human resources investigation into allegations of misconduct, a company spokeswoman confirmed. <U+0089><db><cf>He has been terminated for conduct inconsistent with our values and in violation of our policies,<U+0089><U+06DD> a spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley told HuffPost in an email. At least one woman, who is not a Morgan Stanley employee but interacted with Ford in a professional capacity, was interviewed by Morgan Stanley<U+0089><U+06EA>s HR department as part of the investigation. In two interviews with HuffPost, the woman alleged that Ford engaged in harassment, intimidation, and forcibly grabbed her one evening in Manhattan, leading her to seek aid from a building security guard. The incident took place several years ago when Ford and the woman were supposed to be meeting for professional reasons. Ford continued to contact her after the encounter until she wrote an email asking him to cease contact. The email, which was reviewed by HuffPost, shows that the woman emailed Ford after he repeatedly asked her to drinks. She asked him not to contact her anymore, citing his inappropriate conduct the evening where he forcibly grabbed and harassed her. Ford replied to the email by apologizing and agreeing not to contact her. <U+0089><db><cf>Hey very sorry. Meant no harm,<U+0089><U+06DD> the email reads. <U+0089><db><cf>And I apologize for whatever I may have said or what was said. And my overtures are strictly professional. Again I apologize didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t mean to be inappropriate at all. Sorry that impression was left.<U+0089><U+06DD> HuffPost is not identifying the woman at her request but has reviewed emails that confirm her interactions with Ford and spoke to two people whom the woman confided in about the incident. One woman heard from Ford<U+0089><U+06EA>s accuser the night of the incident and described her as <U+0089><db><cf>distraught, shocked, and frightened,<U+0089><U+06DD> and said that she was concerned about any career ramifications should she report the incident. In a statement provided to HuffPost, Ford denied the allegations: <U+0089><db><cf>This simply did not happen. I have never forcibly grabbed any woman or man in my life. Having drinks and dinner for work is part of my job,<e5><ca>and all of my outreach to the news reporter making these false allegations was professional and at the direction of my firm for business purposes. I support and have tremendous respect for the brave women now speaking out in this important national dialogue. False claims like this undermine the real silence breakers. I will now be bringing legal action against the reporter who has made these false claims about me as well as Morgan Stanley for improper termination.<U+0089><U+06DD> John Singer, Ford<U+0089><U+06EA>s employment counsel with the firm Singer Deutsch LLP, said <U+0089><db><cf>Morgan Stanley has still not told Harold directly of his termination, and unlike every other circumstance I<U+0089><U+06EA>ve been in the company has refused provide me with a reason.<U+0089><U+06DD> He added: <U+0089><db><cf>This all demonstrates how this was a matter of convenience during a hyper-sensitive time and not based on real facts.<U+0089><U+06DD> Ford comes from a prominent political family in Tennessee. His father, Harold Ford Sr., held a congressional seat for 12 terms before retiring, leaving his son to run for the seat, a race which he won handily. Ford served in the House for nearly 10 years before deciding to run for the U.S. Senate seat vacated by Republican Bill Frist. Ford lost that hotly contested 2006 race by fewer than three points to current Republican Sen. Bob Corker. Since leaving Congress in 2007, Ford has worked for two financial services companies, first for Merrill Lynch and then Morgan Stanley, which he joined in 2011 as a managing director. At the time Morgan Stanley announced the hire, The New York Times described Ford<U+0089><U+06EA>s role as a rainmaker of sorts: <U+0089><db><cf> Mr. Ford will be responsible for <U+0089><db><f7>building business opportunities<U+0089><U+06EA> for clients, Morgan Stanley said. He will manage relationships with corporate directors, senior executives and institutional investors, as well as private clients.<U+0089><U+06DD> Ford also serves as a paid on-air political analyst for NBC/MSNBC and regularly appears on the MSNBC program <U+0089><db><cf>Morning Joe.<U+0089><U+06DD> This story has been updated to include statements from Ford and Singer.
Title.x: Exclusive: Former Congressman Harold Ford Jr. Fired For Misconduct By Morgan Stanley
Title.y: Exclusive: Former Congressman Harold Ford Jr. Fired For Misconduct By Morgan Stanley

text: First Lady Melania Trump has made the call to remove a significant part of a historic magnolia tree that has graced the White House<U+0089><U+06EA>s south facade since the 1800s. President Andrew Jackson added the southern magnolia tree to the White House grounds in honor of his late wife. But the tree has decayed to a point where it can no longer be safely preserved, CNN reports. Stephanie Grisham,<e5><ca>Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s spokeswoman,<e5><ca>told The Associated Press on Tuesday that the first lady discussed options with White House staff and reviewed an analysis by the United States National Arboretum before deeming that the tree was a safety risk. <U+0089><db><cf>[Melania Trump]<e5><ca>trusted that every effort had been made to preserve the historic tree, and was concerned about the safety of visitors and members of the press who are often standing right in front of the tree during Marine One lifts,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Grisham told the AP. Grisham said that a <U+0089><db><cf>large portion<U+0089><U+06DD> of the tree will be removed later this week.<e5><ca> Wood and seedlings from the tree will reportedly be preserved for the future. The Jackson Magnolia, also known as a magnolia grandiflora tree, was Andrew Jackson<U+0089><U+06EA>s tribute to wife Rachel Jackson. The pair fell in love and attempted to get married while Rachel was still legally married to her former husband , a situation that caused a scandal during the presidential campaign of 1828. Rachel<U+0089><U+06EA>s health began to decline as Jackson<U+0089><U+06EA>s political career progressed,<e5><ca>and her existing medical issues were compounded by personal attacks during the campaign on her marriage and virtue. Rachel died on December 22, 1828, days after her husband was elected as president. Jackson, who blamed his political enemies for his wife<U+0089><U+06EA>s death, moved into the White House as a widower. He reportedly asked for a sprout from Rachel<U+0089><U+06EA>s favorite magnolia tree at the couple<U+0089><U+06EA>s farm in Tennessee to be planted on the White House grounds. It was placed at the west side of the South Portico in 1835, according to the White House Historical Association. A second magnolia tree was later planted on the east side of the Portico, for symmetry. Since its arrival, the tree has been in the backdrop of many events at the White House <U+0089><U+06E5> from Easter Egg Rolls to routine Marine One departures. Seedlings from the tree have also been used as gifts. President Obama gifted a seedling from the tree to the Israeli people during a trip to former Israeli president Shimon Peres<U+0089><U+06EA> presidential residence in 2013. The Jackson Magnolia started to experience problems in the 1970s, when new trunks, or <U+0089><db><cf>leaders,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>began to emerge from its base. Cement was later used to help shore up a cavity in the tree, which ended up causing more harm. The tree is now standing up with the help of a pole and cable system. According to a report obtained by CNN , experts at the Arboretum told Trump that this system can no longer prevent the tree from collapsing <U+0089><U+06E5> and that the tree may actually be a safety hazard. <U+0089><db><cf>If this was any ordinary tree, it would have been removed long ago,<U+0089><U+06DD> the report from the Arboretum reads. <U+0089><db><cf>We understand this is a historic tree, and all measures have been used to save it to this point in time. While we cannot comment on the need to preserve the tree as long as it stands, we believe eventually, the tree will fail.<U+0089><U+06DD> The White House said on Tuesday that seedlings from the original tree will be available in the future, if another tree needs to be planted on the lawn. CORRECTION: In a previous version of this story,<e5><ca>a wire photo caption misidentified a Japanese magnolia tree as a Southern magnolia.
Title.x: Melania Trump Orders Large Portion Of Historic White House Tree Removed Due To Decay
Title.y: Melania Trump Orders Large Portion Of Historic White House Tree Removed Due To Decay

text: Americans aren<U+0089><U+06EA>t holding back when it comes to President Donald Trump . A new poll from Fox News found that many Americans think the 45th president of the United States is an unstable bully . Respondents were asked how well certain words described the president .<e5><ca>For <U+0089><db><cf>bully,<U+0089><U+06DD> 39 percent chose <U+0089><db><cf>extremely,<U+0089><U+06DD> 14 percent chose <U+0089><db><cf>very<U+0089><U+06DD> and 20 percent went with <U+0089><db><cf>somewhat.<U+0089><U+06DD> For the word <U+0089><db><cf>unstable,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>33 percent selected <U+0089><db><cf>extremely,<U+0089><U+06DD> 11 percent chose<e5><U+0289><db><cf>very<U+0089><U+06DD> and 16 percent agreed with <U+0089><db><cf>somewhat.<U+0089><U+06DD> Just 27 percent said he was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD> a bully while 38 percent said he was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>unstable. The same poll showed that 56 percent of respondents said Trump was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD> presidential, 55 percent said he was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD> a moral leader, 53 percent said he was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD> compassionate or steady and 50 percent said he was <U+0089><db><cf>not at all<U+0089><U+06DD> honest. Despite these views, 58 percent of respondents believed Trump would finish his term. The poll of 1,006 registered voters was conducted Aug. 27-29, and had a margin of error of 3 points. Portions of the poll released earlier this week found a disapproval rating of 55 percent while 56 percent said Trump was <U+0089><db><cf>tearing the country apart.<U+0089><U+06DD> The full poll is available here .
Title.x: Fox News Poll: Americans Think Donald Trump Is An Unstable, Dishonest, Immoral Bully
Title.y: Fox News Poll: Americans Think Donald Trump Is An Unstable, Dishonest, Immoral Bully

text: President Donald Trump spoke again Tuesday on the white supremacist conflict in Charlottesville, Virginia, defending his much-criticized initial statement on the protests and offering an even stronger critique of demonstrators and the causes they fought for during the violent weekend gathering. During remarks at Trump Tower, the president blasted protesters <U+0089><db><cf>on both sides<U+0089><U+06DD> of the conflict in Charlottesville, echoing his initial statement that there was hatred <U+0089><db><cf>on many sides.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>You had a group on one side who was bad, and you had a group on the other side that was also very violent, and nobody wants to say that, but I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll say it right now,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said, referring to white supremacists, anti-fascists known as <U+0089><db><cf>antifa<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>and counterprotesters who converged in Charlottesville over the weekend. <U+0089><db><cf>You had a group on the other side that came charging in without a permit, and they were very, very violent.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump explained why he wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t quick to condemn any specific people in his initial statement on the protests . <U+0089><db><cf>You have people who are very fine people on both sides,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. He argued he was waiting on <U+0089><db><cf>the facts<U+0089><U+06DD> Saturday before condemning white supremacists. <U+0089><db><cf>I wanted to make sure, unlike most politicians, that what I said was correct, not make a quick statement. The statement I made on Saturday, the first statement, was a fine statement, but you don<U+0089><U+06EA>t make statements that direct unless you know the facts,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump argued. <U+0089><db><cf>It takes a little while to get the facts. You still don<U+0089><U+06EA>t know the facts. It is a very, very important process to me. It is a very important statement. So I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to go quickly and just make a statement for the sake of making a political statement. I want to know the facts.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump stayed silent until Saturday afternoon on the situation in Charlottesville, which began heating up with white supremacist marches Friday night. His response <U+0089><U+06E5> which followed that of his wife, Melania, the first from the White House to comment on the protests <U+0089><U+06E5> was a rebuke of hatred<e5><U+0289><db><cf> on many sides .<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides <U+0089><U+06E5> on many sides,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said at a ceremony for the signing of a bill to reform the Veterans Affairs health care system. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long time in our country, not Donald Trump, not Barack Obama. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s been going on for a long, long time.<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said Tuesday his initial remarks were described as<e5><U+0289><db><cf>beautiful.<U+0089><U+06DD> However,<e5><ca>he was widely panned for failing to call out hate groups, prompting even some Republican lawmakers to criticize his remarks. On Monday <U+0089><U+06E5> three days after the events in Charlottesville began and two days after a car driven by a white supremacist plowed into a group of counterprotesters and killed a woman <U+0089><U+06E5> Trump finally condemned hate groups in a press conference where he appeared rigid, carefully reading his statement from a teleprompter. But on Tuesday, Trump issued his strongest statement yet, pointing blame at groups who showed up to demonstrate against the white supremacists who organized in Charlottesville to protest the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee, a Confederate general. <U+0089><db><cf>What about the alt-left that came charging at the, as you say, <U+0089><db><f7>alt-right<U+0089><U+06EA>? Do they have any semblance of guilt?<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump asked reporters. <U+0089><db><cf>What about the fact that they came charging with clubs in their hands, swinging clubs? Do they have any problem? I think they do.<U+0089><U+06DD> According to The New York Times<U+0089><U+06EA> Maggie Haberman, reporters at Trump Tower were told Trump wouldn<U+0089><U+06EA>t be taking questions on Tuesday.<e5><ca>A White House official told CNN staffers they had hoped Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s remarks today would focus on infrastructure. During his remarks Tuesday, the president argued taking down Confederate statues, such as the Lee statue , could lead to the removal of statues of other historic figures, such as George Washington or Thomas Jefferson. <U+0089><db><cf>You really do have to ask yourself, where does it stop?<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. He also defended those in his administration who have ties to white nationalism , including senior adviser Steve Bannon. Ever the businessman, Trump also took the opportunity to plug his winery in Virginia before leaving the press conference, saying it<U+0089><U+06EA>s the reason he knows a lot about Charlottesville. This story has been updated with more details about the presser and events in Charlottesville.
Title.x: Donald Trump Defends People Who Attended White Supremacist Rally In Charlottesville (Plus A Whole Lot More)
Title.y: Donald Trump Defends People Who Attended White Supremacist Rally In Charlottesville (Plus A Whole Lot More)

text: Special counsel Robert Mueller has impaneled a grand jury as part of his investigation into possible collusion between President Donald Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign and Russia in last year<U+0089><U+06EA>s election, sources tell the Wall Street Journal . The report follows Mueller stepping up the probe by hiring several high-powered lawyers. Reuters reported earlier this week that Greg Andres , a former Justice Department attorney who specialized in corruption and bribery cases, joined the investigation. Grand jury subpoenas related to a meeting attended by Trump Jr., the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s eldest son, and a Russian lawyer have been issued, sources told Reuters . Trump Jr. agreed to the meeting after being promised information that would <U+0089><db><cf>incriminate<U+0089><U+06DD> his father<U+0089><U+06EA>s opponent, Hillary Clinton, and was part of the Russian government<U+0089><U+06EA>s effort to benefit Trump. A source familiar with the matter told Reuters that Mueller was investigating whether anyone at the meeting or affiliated with the Trump campaign encouraged Russia to release damaging material it had collected on Clinton. Another told the outlet that Mueller was trying to determine if Trump had been informed of the meeting ahead of time, or if he was briefed after it took place. The president has strongly denied having had any knowledge of the meeting, but has not faulted his son for attending it. Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s probe is one of several government investigations into possible collusion. He is also investigating whether Trump obstructed justice. Read the full Wall Street Journal story here . Assembling a grand jury marks a major step, as it suggests an aggressive and prolonged investigation. Grand juries can be used as legal tools in cases when there is the possibility of criminal conduct , legal experts say. The grand jury, which will be based in Washington, D.C., does not necessarily signify that criminal charges will be brought. But it means it can hear testimony from witnesses under oath, and that the investigation can issue subpoenas to obtain documents. Trump has criticized the investigation as <U+0089><db><cf>a witch hunt,<U+0089><U+06DD> and hinted at removing Mueller. Meanwhile, there has been bipartisan support for legislation to protect Mueller from being fired by Trump . Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein appointed Mueller in May, after Trump fired then-FBI Director James Comey amid the agency<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s campaign. According to Comey, Trump had told Comey to pledge his loyalty to him, undermining the independence of the FBI. He also asked Comey to lay off the FBI<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation into former national security adviser Mike Flynn, who lied about his contacts with Russian officials. Last month, in an interview with The New York Times, Trump warned Mueller to not investigate his finances. Soon after, several sources reported that Mueller had begun including Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s finances as part of the probe . White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said Thursday in a statement that Trump himself was not under investigation. She referred to Ty Cobb, a member of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s outside legal team representing him in the Russia investigations. Ty Cobb, special counsel to the president, said he wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t aware that Mr. Mueller had started using a new grand jury. <U+0089><db><cf>Grand jury matters are typically secret,<U+0089><U+06DD> Mr. Cobb said. <U+0089><db><cf>The White House favors anything that accelerates the conclusion of his work fairly....The White House is committed to fully cooperating with Mr. Mueller.<U+0089><U+06DD> Former FBI Director Jim Comey said three times the President is not under investigation and we have no reason to believe that has changed. Jay Sekulow, another member of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s legal team, similarly told Fox News that<e5><U+0289><db><cf>we have no reason to believe that the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s under investigation here.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sekulow downplayed the news of a grand jury as <U+0089><db><cf>not an unusual move,<U+0089><U+06DD> calling it <U+0089><db><cf>standard prosecutorial approach.<U+0089><U+06DD> He also suggested that the investigation will be resolved quickly, saying he thinks Mueller <U+0089><db><cf>will move expeditiously through the process<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>with the grand jury in place. He also affirmed that Trump does not plan to remove Mueller. <U+0089><db><cf>The president is not thinking about firing Bob Mueller,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. <U+0089><db><cf>This speculation that<U+0089><U+06EA>s out there is just incorrect.<U+0089><U+06DD> This article has been updated throughout with more context about grand juries and Mueller<U+0089><U+06EA>s investigation and response from the White House and Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s outside legal team.
Title.x: Special Counsel Robert Mueller Reportedly Assembles Grand Jury, Ramping Up Russia Probe
Title.y: Special Counsel Robert Mueller Reportedly Assembles Grand Jury, Ramping Up Russia Probe

text: The Democratic Party won a number of races across the country in Tuesday<U+0089><U+06EA>s elections,<e5><ca>securing key state legislative seats and governorships . Many of those victories also made history. Danica Roem Virginia elected its first openly transgender state lawmaker on Tuesday, voting Democrat Danica Roem into the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s House of Delegates. She unseated Virginia Del. Bob Marshall, the Republican who introduced the <U+0089><db><cf> bathroom bill <U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>that would have prohibited transgender students from using the bathroom of their choice. <U+0089><db><cf>No matter what you look like, where you come from, how you worship, who you love, how you identify or any other inherent identifier that you have, you should be celebrated because of who you are, not despite it,<U+0089><U+06DD> Roem said on MSNBC<U+0089><U+06EA>s <U+0089><db><cf>The Last Word.<U+0089><U+06DD> Andrea Jenkins Transgender activist Andrea Jenkins was elected to the Minneapolis City Council, becoming the first openly transgender African-American woman elected to the city council of a major U.S. city. Jenkins was endorsed by the Star Tribune , citing her years of experience working as a policy aide alongside city council members and her commitment to helping underrepresented communities. Justin Fairfax Democrat Justin Fairfax was elected to become Virginia<U+0089><U+06EA>s next lieutenant governor. With his victory, the former federal prosecutor will be the second African-American to win statewide in Virginia. <U+0089><db><cf>I am so grateful for this opportunity,<U+0089><U+06DD> Fairfax said during a statewide victory party, according to WJLA-TV . <U+0089><db><cf>We are changing the course of history in this commonwealth.<U+0089><U+06DD> Sheila Oliver New Jersey elected Sheila Oliver as its first female African-American lieutenant governor. Oliver is no stranger to breaking records: She became the first African-American woman to be elected as Assembly speaker in New Jersey and only the second black female speaker in U.S. history. <U+0089><db><cf>This may not be the first glass ceiling I have broken, but it is certainly the highest,<U+0089><U+06DD> Oliver said during Democrat Phil Murphy <U+0089><U+06EA>s victory party. <U+0089><db><cf>And I hope somewhere in this great state of New Jersey, a young girl of color is watching tonight and realizing that she does not have a limit to how high she can go.<U+0089><U+06DD> Vi Lyles Vi Lyles was elected as Charlotte, North Carolina<U+0089><U+06EA>s first female African-American mayor,<e5><ca>defeating Republican candidate Kenny Smith. <U+0089><db><cf>With this opportunity you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve given me, you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve proven that we are a city of opportunity and inclusiveness,<U+0089><U+06DD> Lyles told a crowd of supporters, according to the Charlotte Observer . <U+0089><db><cf>You<U+0089><U+06EA>ve proven that a woman whose father didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t graduate from high school can become this city<U+0089><U+06EA>s first female African-American mayor.<U+0089><U+06DD> Yvonne Spicer Yvonne Spicer was elected the first mayor of the city of Framingham, Massachusetts. Framingham residents recently voted to become a city, relinquishing its status as <U+0089><db><cf>the largest town in America.<U+0089><U+06DD> This vote altered the way the government will be run: with a mayor and a city council. <U+0089><db><cf>This is a new beginning for Framingham. ... I promise you as your mayor, I will make sure that everyone at Framingham has a seat at the table,<U+0089><U+06DD> Spicer told a group of supporters Tuesday night . Joyce Craig The largest city in New Hampshire just elected its first woman as mayor. Joyce Craig will be the first woman in the Manchester<U+0089><U+06EA>s 266-year history to serve as mayor, unseating the Republican incumbent, Ted Gatsas. <U+0089><db><cf>As the first woman to ever serve as mayor of Manchester, Joyce will lead the city she loves with the same vision and energy that she<U+0089><U+06EA>s brought to her previous decade of public service,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Democratic National Committee Chair Tom Perez told the New Hampshire Union Leader in a statement . Tyler Titus Tyler Titus won a seat on the Erie School Board, becoming the first openly transgender person to ever be elected in the state of Pennsylvania. <U+0089><db><cf>Tyler Titus shattered a lavender ceiling in Pennsylvania today <U+0089><U+06E5> and his victory will resonate well beyond state boundaries,<U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>Victory Fund President & CEO Aisha C. Moodie-Mills told HuffPost in a statement. <U+0089><db><cf>Trans people remain severely underrepresented in our politics and government, and now more than ever we need trans voices like Tyler<U+0089><U+06EA>s in the halls of power.<U+0089><U+06DD> Ravinder Bhalla<U+0089><U+06CF> Hoboken, New Jersey, elected Ravinder Bhalla as its mayor Tuesday night, which will make Bhalla the first Sikh American to be elected mayor of the city. Last week, Bhalla was the target of racist flyers that showed a picture of him along with the words <U+0089><db><cf>Don<U+0089><U+06EA>t let terrorism take over our town!<U+0089><U+06DD> plastered above him. <U+0089><db><cf>Thank you, Hoboken,<U+0089><U+06DD> Bhalla, who served as a city councilman for eight years, posted on Twitter. <U+0089><db><cf>I look forward to being your Mayor!<U+0089><U+06DD> Elizabeth Guzman and Hala Ayala Elizabeth Guzman and Hala Ayala defeated Republican incumbents to become the first two Latinas elected to the Virginia House of Delegates. <U+0089><db><cf>I am so honored for the privilege to represent House District 51,<U+0089><U+06DD> Ayala wrote in a statement . <U+0089><db><cf>I am humbled by the faith that my future constituents have placed in my candidacy and our message.<U+0089><U+06DD> Wilmot Collins Wilmot Collins arrived in Helena, Montana, 23 years ago as a refugee from Liberia. Collins, a 54-year-old Naval reservist and child protection specialist with the Montana Department of Health and Human Services, will become the second black mayor in both Montana and Helena<U+0089><U+06EA>s history. (The city elected its first black mayor, Edward Johnson, in 1873, the Montana Historical Society told the New York Times .) Although Helena<U+0089><U+06EA>s elections are nonpartisan, Collins leans Democratic and is pleased to have sent a message of defiance to President Donald Trump. <U+0089><db><cf>The country is still not what Mr. Trump wants it to be,<U+0089><U+06DD> Collins told HuffPost. <U+0089><db><cf>The citizens of this state and this city where I have lived for the past 23 years have spoken and they are saying we want the best candidate. They<U+0089><U+06EA>re not looking at color, at background and creed.<U+0089><U+06DD> Jenny Durkan Jenny Durkan will become Seattle<U+0089><U+06EA>s first lesbian mayor. She will also be the Emerald City<U+0089><U+06EA>s first woman mayor since 1928. Bertha Knight Landes was the first female mayor of Seattle, and of a major U.S. city, in 1926. <U+0089><db><cf>Ninety-two years later, Seattle<U+0089><U+06EA>s about to have another woman mayor. How about that?<U+0089><U+06DD> Durkan told supporters during her victory speech. Melvin Carter Voters in St. Paul, Minnesota, made history by electing Melvin Carter as the city<U+0089><U+06EA>s first African-American mayor. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m thrilled. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m elated. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m humbled,<U+0089><U+06DD> Carter, a former St. Paul city council member, told a group of supporters at a victory party.<e5><U+0289><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>ve built what I<U+0089><U+06EA>m excited to say is a big, bold, bad vision for the future of St. Paul.<U+0089><U+06DD> Kathy Tran Kathy Tran, a former Vietnamese refugee, became the first Asian-American woman to join Virginia<U+0089><U+06EA>s House of Delegates, representing the state<U+0089><U+06EA>s 42nd District . She will replace David Albo, a Republican who served for 24 years but didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t run for re-election. Janet Diaz Janet Diaz will become the first Latina member of city council in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. <U+0089><db><cf>We need a government that looks like the people it serves ... that looks like its constituents,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said when she announced her candidacy in January. Jonathan McCollar Jonathan McCollar will become the first African-American mayor of Statesboro, Georgia, defeating incumbent Jan Moore. <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s that the city was ready for change , he said Tuesday. <U+0089><db><cf>This is just evidence of the work from the people that were part of this movement.<U+0089><U+06DD> Brendon Barber Brendon Barber, a Georgetown,<e5><ca>South Carolina, city councilman since 1998, will become the city<U+0089><U+06EA>s first ever African-American mayor. The Georgetown native said his knowledge of the city and its municipal employees makes him well-positioned for the job. Mary Parham Copelan Mary Parham Copelan will become Milledgeville, Georgia<U+0089><U+06EA>s, first female African-American mayor, beating incumbent Gary Thrower by just six votes . <U+0089><db><cf>I along with each one of you know that we needed real change and real progress for our city,<U+0089><U+06DD> she wrote on Facebook following her victory. Booker Gainor Booker Gainor, 27, will become Cairo, Georgia<U+0089><U+06EA>s, first African-American mayor. <U+0089><db><cf>It feels amazing ,<U+0089><U+06DD> Gainor said. <U+0089><db><cf>I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t even know how to describe it.<U+0089><U+06DD> Cathy Murillo Cathy Murillo<U+0089><U+06EA>s victory on Tuesday makes her the first Latina mayor of Santa Barbara,<e5><ca>California. She has been a city councilwoman since 2011. <U+0089><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to do such good work ,<U+0089><U+06DD> she said. Laura Curran Democrat Laura Curran will be the first female county executive for New York<U+0089><U+06EA>s Nassau County. She said she aims to fight corruption. Lisa Middleton Lisa Middleton is the first openly transgender person to be elected to a non-judicial office in California. She<U+0089><U+06EA>s joining Palm Springs<U+0089><U+06EA> city council. Mazahir Salih Mazahir Salih will be the first Sudanese-American to join the Iowa City Council following her win on Tuesday. Medicaid expansion in Maine Maine residents approved a ballot initiative Tuesday to expand Medicaid coverage under Obamacare to about 70,000 more people across the state. It<U+0089><U+06EA>s the first time Americans voted on the issue through a referendum. It also represents a setback to Republican Gov. Paul LePage, who vetoed several previous legislative attempts at an expansion. The Maine Democratic Party called the referendum <U+0089><db><cf>a tremendous victory.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>The people of Maine have once again sent a clear message of support for affordable, accessible health care,<U+0089><U+06DD> MDP Chair Phil Barlett said in a statement. Maine joins 31 states , plus the District of Columbia,<e5><ca>in passing Medicaid expansions. Efforts are also underway in Idaho and Utah to put similar measures on 2018 ballots. Daniel Marans contributed reporting
Title.x: Here's A List Of Historic Victories Democrats Had On Election Day
Title.y: Here's A List Of Historic Victories Democrats Had On Election Day

text: Rep. Diane Black (R-Tenn.) proposed on Friday that hospital emergency rooms should be able to turn patients away to help keep health care costs down. <U+0089><db><cf>I<U+0089><U+06EA>m an emergency room nurse,<U+0089><U+06DD> Black told MSNBC host Chuck Todd on Friday. <U+0089><db><cf>There are people that came into my emergency room that I, the nurse, was the first one to see them. I could have sent them to a walk-in clinic or their doctor the next day, but because of a law that Congress put into place to say, no, I have to treat everybody that walks into that emergency room.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>You took away our ability to say, <U+0089><db><f7>No, an emergency room is not the proper place.<U+0089><U+06EA> And then, you put a burden on top of that to say, <U+0089><db><f7>You must do that,<U+0089><U+06EA><U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>added the congresswoman, who is also running for governor of Tennessee. At issue is the Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act, which was signed into law by former President Ronald Reagan in 1986. It was a congressional response to stories of<e5><U+0289><db><cf>patient dumping<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><U+06E5> hospitals would deny treatment to patients or send them elsewhere , usually because the individuals didn<U+0089><U+06EA>t have insurance. Many of these patients were unemployed or were people of color. Those transferred individuals were more likely to die, and the delayed care often jeopardized the patients<U+0089><U+06EA> health. The law put a particular focus on pregnant women (hence <U+0089><db><cf>active labor<U+0089><U+06DD> in the law<U+0089><U+06EA>s name), to ensure that they would be able to deliver their babies and receive full care. Changing the law, as Black advocates, would send America back to a time when hospitals can use their discretion to turn people away. <U+0089><db><cf>We must treat everybody that walks in whether you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve had a sore throat for a week, we must see them. And that crowds the emergency room. It drives the cost of emergencies up,<U+0089><U+06DD> Black added on MSNBC. <U+0089><db><cf>And so, yes, if someone comes in from an auto accident, I don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to ask whether they have insurance or not. I<U+0089><U+06EA>m going to take care of them.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>But what it did is crowd my emergency room, where I work,<U+0089><U+06DD> she added. <U+0089><db><cf>And disallowed me from using my good judgment skills, of which I was trained to do and doctors are as well. And the federal government said, you must <U+0089><U+06E5> and you can<U+0089><U+06EA>t make those decisions. And I think that was a poor thing for us to do.<U+0089><U+06DD> This free-for-all system would not be unlike what happened before Obamacare, when there were fewer requirements for insurance companies to accept people for coverage. It was a time when insurance providers were free to turn people away because they had more expensive pre-existing conditions <U+0089><U+06E5> or were labeled as potentially having an expensive condition down the line. And since these companies were free to do so, they did. Nobody thinks EMTALA is perfect and non-partisan organizations, including the Institute of Medicine , have long called for revising some of the law<U+0089><U+06EA>s regulations as part of a broader strategy to ease emergency room overcrowding. And although conservatives have been among the most critical of the law, even the Heritage Foundation admits that <U+0089><db><cf>the outright repeal of EMTALA is highly unlikely ,<U+0089><U+06DD> and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s not something you hear talked about much in health care debates. When Todd asked Black whether she would get rid of the law, she replied, <U+0089><db><cf>I would get rid of a law that says that you <U+0089><U+06E5> you are not allowed, as a health care professional, to make that decision about whether someone can be appropriately treated the next day, or at a walk-in clinic, or at their doctor.<U+0089><U+06DD> Also, technically, no doctor or hospital is required to see anybody. But treating all patients is a requirement for hospitals using Medicare funds.<e5><ca>So already, a doctor or hospital can turn people away <U+0089><U+06E5> as Black suggests they should be able to do <U+0089><U+06E5> they just won<U+0089><U+06EA>t get to bill Medicare. Jonathan Cohn contributed reporting. Want more updates from Amanda Terkel? Sign up for her newsletter, Piping Hot Truth, here .
Title.x: GOP Lawmaker Says Emergency Rooms Should Be Able To Turn People Away
Title.y: GOP Lawmaker Says Emergency Rooms Should Be Able To Turn People Away

text: Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) harshly criticized President Donald Trump for pardoning Joe Arpaio , the former Maricopa County, Arizona, sheriff who was found guilty of criminal contempt after illegally targeting Latinos. Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s pardon Friday of Arpaio, who was found to have <U+0089><db><cf>willfully violated<U+0089><U+06DD> a 2011 court order barring him from detaining individuals based solely on suspicion about their legal status, was the first of his presidency. McCain issued a statement after Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s announcement, saying it undermined the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s professed respect for the rule of law. <U+0089><db><cf>No one is above the law and the individuals entrusted with the privilege of being sworn law officers should always seek to be beyond reproach in their commitment to fairly enforcing the laws they swore to uphold,<U+0089><U+06DD> McCain said in the statement . <U+0089><db><cf>Mr. Arpaio was found guilty of criminal contempt for continuing to illegally profile Latinos living in Arizona based on their perceived immigration status in violation of a judge<U+0089><U+06EA>s orders. The President has the authority to make this pardon, but doing so at this time undermines his claim for the respect of rule of law as Mr. Arpaio has shown no remorse for his actions.<U+0089><U+06DD> Arpaio supported Trump during the presidential campaign last year and both men have promoted the lie that former President Barack Obama was not born in the United States. The White House defended the pardon by saying the 85-year-old Arpaio had history working in law enforcement. McCain cast the decisive vote last month to block a Republican effort in the Senate to try and repeal the Affordable Care Act, dealing a devastating defeat to Trump and his own party. In 2015, Trump suggested McCain, who was a prisoner of war during the Vietnam War, wasn<U+0089><U+06EA>t really a war hero .
Title.x: John McCain Rips Donald Trump For Pardoning Joe Arpaio
Title.y: John McCain Rips Donald Trump For Pardoning Joe Arpaio

text: WASHINGTON <U+0089><U+06E5> A CEO serving on President Donald Trump <U+0089><U+06EA>s council on manufacturing announced his resignation early Monday from the White House panel, in protest of Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s initial silence on the white nationalist groups who incited Saturday<U+0089><U+06EA>s deadly violence in Charlottesville, Virginia. Ken Frazier, the head of Merck pharmaceuticals,<e5><ca>said in a statement he was stepping down <U+0089><db><cf>as a matter of personal conscience<U+0089><U+06DD> and <U+0089><db><cf>to take a stand against intolerance and extremism.<U+0089><U+06DD> By Monday night, several CEOs joined Frazier in resigning from the council, over Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to Saturday<U+0089><U+06EA>s violence. But other CEOs affirmed that they would remain on the council , their representatives told HuffPost. In response to Frazier<U+0089><U+06EA>s departure, Trump <U+0089><U+06E5> who did not personally denounce the far-right groups that sparked Saturday<U+0089><U+06EA>s deadly carnage in Charlottesville until Monday afternoon <U+0089><U+06E5> directly attacked Frazier on Twitter. His tweet was one of several posted on Monday morning, ranging from attacking <U+0089><db><cf> obstructionist Democrats <U+0089><U+06DD> to pledging he would work on <U+0089><db><cf>trade and military<U+0089><U+06DD> and reiterating his support for Sen. Luther Strange (R-Ala.), who is squaring off against several opponents in a GOP primary on Tuesday. None of his tweets addressed the weekend<U+0089><U+06EA>s violence. After Trump on Saturday had blamed <U+0089><db><cf>many sides<U+0089><U+06DD> for the hatred that led to the violence in Charlottesville, the White House on Sunday said in a statement that <U+0089><db><cf>of course<U+0089><U+06DD> that included <U+0089><db><cf>white supremacists, KKK Neo-Nazi and all extremist groups.<U+0089><U+06DD> Still, the statement was attributed to an unnamed spokesperson, not to Trump himself. This article has been updated to note other CEOs also resigned and that Trump finally denounced the far-right groups Monday afternoon.
Title.x: CEO Quits White House Council Over Trump's Charlottesville Response  And Trump Attacks Him
Title.y: CEO Quits White House Council Over Trump's Charlottesville Response  And Trump Attacks Him

text: President Donald Trump visited local officials and residents in Puerto Rico on Tuesday, congratulating them and boasting almost two weeks after Hurricane Maria left many of the island<U+0089><U+06EA>s 3.4 million people without power, water or food. At his first stop, a briefing with federal and local officials, Trump lavishly praised them. He then repeatedly turned to individuals around the table and invited them to offer their own praise <U+0089><db><d3> while insisting, <U+0089><db><cf>It<U+0089><U+06EA>s not about me.<U+0089><U+06DD> When Puerto Rico<U+0089><U+06EA>s governor told Trump that 16 people so far had been reported dead,<e5><ca>the president lauded officials and minimized the hurricane<U+0089><U+06EA>s damage, suggesting it was not <U+0089><db><cf>a real catastrophe like Katrina.<U+0089><U+06DD> <U+0089><db><cf>Sixteen people versus in the thousands,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. <U+0089><db><cf>You can be very proud of all of your people and all of our people working together.<e5><ca>Sixteen versus literally thousands of people. You can be very proud. Everyone around this table, and everyone watching, can be very proud of what<U+0089><U+06EA>s taking place in Puerto Rico.<U+0089><U+06DD> While Trump bragged about the official number of dead, the final death toll will likely turn out to be higher . Poor communication services have hindered reporting, and current living conditions on the island could jeopardize more lives,<e5><ca>especially those of the sick and the elderly. Trump also appeared to joke about the cost of the storm damage. <U+0089><db><cf>I hate to tell you, Puerto Rico, but you<U+0089><U+06EA>ve thrown our budget a little out of whack,<U+0089><U+06DD> he said. The group of officials around the table applauded several times. San Juan Mayor Carmen Yul<cc>_n Cruz, whom Trump has repeatedly attacked online, did not join in, <U+0089><db><cf>keeping her hands clasped in front of her,<U+0089><U+06DD> according to a White House pool report. The trip comes after Trump repeatedly bragged about his administration<U+0089><U+06EA>s response to the hurricane<U+0089><U+06EA>s devastation,<e5><ca>blamed the U.S. territory of Puerto Rico for its debt crisis and called Cruz <U+0089><db><cf>nasty<U+0089><U+06DD> for criticizing the federal government<U+0089><U+06EA>s sluggish relief efforts. Trump, who visited Texas twice in the days following Hurricane Harvey and headed to Florida four days after Hurricane Irma, said last week that he was delaying a visit to Puerto Rico <U+0089><db><cf>because of the first responders, and we don<U+0089><U+06EA>t want to disrupt the relief efforts.<U+0089><U+06DD> Tensions were high ahead of the president<U+0089><U+06EA>s visit. Trump had attacked the island<U+0089><U+06EA>s residents and leaders, saying they wanted <U+0089><db><cf> everything to be done for them <U+0089><U+06DD><e5><ca>after Cruz begged for additional aid. <U+0089><db><cf>The Mayor of San Juan, who was very complimentary only a few days ago, has now been told by the Democrats that you must be nasty to Trump ,<U+0089><U+06DD> he wrote on Twitter. Trump contends his administration has done a <U+0089><db><cf>great job with the almost impossible situation.<U+0089><U+06DD> Puerto Rico, he noted, was already facing crippling debt before the storm. He said Texas and Florida were <U+0089><db><cf>doing great<U+0089><U+06DD> in the aftermath of hurricanes that hit those states last month. As he departed the White House on Tuesday morning,<e5><ca>the president again lauded the federal response, despite the continued suffering of residents and criticism from officials like Cruz. <U+0089><db><cf>I think she<U+0089><U+06EA>s come back a long way,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said of Cruz. <U+0089><db><cf>I think it<U+0089><U+06EA>s now acknowledged what a great job we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve done. In Texas and Florida, we get an A-plus. And I<U+0089><U+06EA>ll tell you what, I think we<U+0089><U+06EA>ve done just as good in Puerto Rico, and it<U+0089><U+06EA>s actually a much tougher situation.<U+0089><U+06DD> Again he said that <U+0089><db><cf>at a local level, they have to give us more help,<U+0089><U+06DD> while praising the <U+0089><db><cf>incredible job<U+0089><U+06DD> of federal officials. <U+0089><db><cf>Whether it<U+0089><U+06EA>s her or anybody else, they<U+0089><U+06EA>re all starting to say it,<U+0089><U+06DD> Trump said. Following the briefing with federal and local officials on Tuesday, Trump visited with storm victims. He again praised officials for doing <U+0089><db><cf>a fantastic job,<U+0089><U+06DD> as people showed him the storm<U+0089><U+06EA>s damage to their homes, pointing out broken windows and noting power outages. <U+0089><db><cf>We<U+0089><U+06EA>re going to help you out,<U+0089><U+06DD> he told them. <U+0089><db><cf>Have a good time.<U+0089><U+06DD> During a stop at a church, he threw rolls of paper towels into a crowd. In truth, conditions in Puerto Rico remain dire. The Federal Emergency Management Agency has shipped millions of gallons of water and meals to Puerto Rico, but the island no longer has the infrastructure to widely deliver those supplies. Puerto Rican officials said last week that they were unable to move aid across the island without electricity and fuel. Until last week, shipments to the island were also restricted by the Jones Act , a law that increases shipping costs for goods going to Puerto Rico. Trump allowed a temporary waiver of the law last Thursday. As of Monday, all 10 of Puerto Rico<U+0089><U+06EA>s airports were open, and about 37 percent of people had cellphone service, according to the Department of Defense. Two Navy ships are due to arrive Tuesday with more supplies. Still, almost all of Puerto Rico is without electricity ,<e5><ca>and about half the population lacks drinking water. This article has been updated with details from Trump<U+0089><U+06EA>s visit. CORRECTION: A previous version of this article stated incorrectly that <U+0089><db><cf>all 10 of Puerto Rico<U+0089><U+06EA>s hospitals<U+0089><U+06DD> had been reopened. All 10 of the airports have been reopened.
Title.x: Trump Downplays Puerto Rico's Suffering, Says It's Not A 'Real Catastrophe Like Katrina'
Title.y: Trump Downplays Puerto Rico's Suffering, Says It's Not A 'Real Catastrophe Like Katrina'

text: If she was looking for a quiet night on the town, she must have been wildly disappointed. Hillary Clinton received a standing ovation as she and former President Bill Clinton made their way to their seats for a performance of the Tony Award-winning play Osloin New York City on Sunday night. The former secretary of state and presidential candidate was quietly walking down the aisle when audience members caught sight of her and broke out into applause and cheers. We love you, Hillary! several people were heard shouting as others began chanting her first name. With what appeared to be the entire house on its feet, Clinton turned to wave at her supporters as her husband reached her side. It was far from the first such welcome received by the former first lady and New York senator since she conceded the presidential election to Donald Trump. She has been met with similar receptions while attending other Broadway productions, including  Sunset Boulevard ,  In Transit  and  The Color Purple . In contrast, Vice President Mike Pence was booed by audience members at a performance of Hamilton, shortly after Trumps election win.
Title.x: Theater Goes Nuts As Hillary Clinton Appears In The Audience
Title.y: Theater Goes Nuts As Hillary Clinton Appears In The Audience

text: President Donald Trump claimed on Tuesday that Sen. Luther Strange was shooting up in the Alabama polls thanks to his endorsement. But when Strange lost by nearly 10 points to Roy Moore in Tuesday nights Republican primary, the president deleted that and two other messages in support of his candidate. ProPublicas Politwoops, which tracks deleted tweets from politicians, preserved the messages: Trumps deleted tweets and other messages are part of an ongoing lawsuit by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington (CREW), which argues that the erasures violate the Presidential Records Act . The American people not only deserve to know how their government is making important decisions, its the law, CREW Executive Director Noah Bookbinder said in a news release in June. By deleting these records, the White House is destroying essential historical records .
Title.x: Donald Trump Deleted Some Embarrassing Tweets After Alabama Loss
Title.y: Donald Trump Deleted Some Embarrassing Tweets After Alabama Loss

text: President Donald Trump was notably silent about his eldest son on Twitter Tuesday following a string of shocking reports that revealed how Donald Trump Jr. had met with a Russian lawyer in hopes of gaining damning information about 2016 presidential election rival Hillary Clinton. Trump tweeted about Senate Democrats, but failed to comment on The New York Times latest report, which said Don Jr. was informed in advance that the intel he would receive at the meeting with Russian lawyer Natalia Veselnitskaya was actually gathered by the Russian government to help elect his father. Mark Corallo, the spokesman for the presidents personal lawyer, told The New York Times on Sunday that the president  was not aware of and did not attend the meeting with Veselnitskaya, a move some saw as an early effort to distance the White House from Don Jr., who does not serve in any official capacity in his fathers administration. He and his brother Eric run the Trump organization . The president has not personally responded to the growing controversy surrounding his sons meeting last year with Veselnitskaya and has no public events on his schedule for the second day in a row.Last weekend, the Times reported that the younger Trump met with Veselnitskaya alongside the presidents son-in-law Jared Kushner and then-campaign chairman Paul Manafort to obtain information that would help the campaign against Clinton. Don Jr. hit back at the latest Times report on Tuesday, calling the meeting nonsense. On Monday, the Times revealed that Don Jr. was informed via email ahead of the meeting that the promised intel was linked to the Russian government and its attempts to sway the election in his fathers favor. U.S. intelligence agencies have all agreed that Russia, under the direction of President Vladimir Putin, actively worked on an influence campaign to help Trump get elected. At the G-20 summit last weekend, Putin denied any involvement in such machinations. Trump has rushed to defend almost any member of his inner circle, at least initially, who was subject to less than stellar media coverage, including former national security adviser Michael Flynn , his daughter Ivanka , his ultra-rich Cabinet officials and his attorney general, Jeff Sessions . Trumps decision to let Don Jr. defend himself was a notable departure in his efforts to protect his squadron of trusted confidants. In a statement provided to HuffPost, Don Jr.s lawyer, Alan Futerfas, also said the president knew nothing about the meeting, calling it much ado about nothing. Don Jr.s takeaway from this communication was that someone had information potentially helpful to the campaign and it was coming from someone he knew, Futerfas said in the statement, which was first provided to The Times. Don Jr. had no knowledge as to what specific information, if any, would be discussed. Further, at no time was there ever any understanding or commitment that he, or anyone else, would find the information, whatever it turned out to be, to be reliable, credible or of interest, or would even survive due diligence. The meeting lasted about 20-30 minutes, and nothing came of it. His father knew nothing about it. The bottom line is that Don, Jr. did nothing wrong. Don Jr. has admitted that he met with Veselnitskaya (in two separate, but differing statements ), but said she was vague, ambiguous and made no sense. He claimed the conversation quickly turned to an obscure American law called the Magnitsky Act <U+2015> It became clear to me that this was the true agenda all along, he said <U+2015> before he ended the meeting. The 2012 act allowed the U.S. to withhold visas and freeze Russian assets. In retaliation, the Kremlin halted U.S. adoptions of Russian babies. Legal experts said Mondays revelations about Don Jr. knowing that the intel he received from Veselnitskaya actually came from the Russian government were notable. Taking the meeting itself may have been illegal as the U.S. has very specific campaign finance provisions which prohibit contributions from foreign nationals to aid an election.
